CCU NURSING 1645
SEE CAREVUE FLOWSHEET FOR COMPLETE VS, OBJECTIVE DATA

65 YO CARDIAC ARREST AT HOME AT 0200 - ADMITTED AT 0600 TO CCU PUPILS FIXED AND DILATED, ABSENT CORNEALS, GAG, COUGH, NO SPONTANEOUS MOVEMENT, COMPLE6TELY UNRESPONSIVE TO PAIN, HEAD CT - CHANGES CONSISITENT W/ANOXIA, + MYOCLONUS NOTED IN EXTREMITIES, FAMILY INCLUDING WIFE, 2 SONS MET W/[**Name (NI) **] - PT MADE DNR, NO PRESSORS
1500 BP DRPPOING ON .4 MCGS NEO - NEO OFF, BP CONTINUED TO DECREASE, HR FROM 100ST TO 140'S THEN DROPPED TO 60'S, 1630 BEGIN SEVERELY BRADY/APNEIC/ASYSTOLIC - FAMILY NOTIFIED - AWAITING DECISION WHETHER THEY WILL COME TO HOSPITAL.

CCU NSG ADMISSION NOTE: V-F ARREST
HPA: This healthy appearing 47y old male was exercising in bike in gym when he passed out, slumping on person next to him who then lowered him to the floor and started CPR. When EMTs arrived he was in VF and he was defibrillated into sinus tach with high blood pressure. He was taken to outside hospital, very aggitated and hypertensive, intubated started on IV nitro and IV lidocaine. Echo showed gretly decreased LV function. Head CT was negative for bleed. He was transfered to [**Hospital1 2**] EW. Here was continued hypertensive and aggitated and received vesed and fentanyl and became hypotensive and was started on dopamine and sent to cath lab. In cath lab he was found to have 90% OM1 and 99% prox LAD which was thought to be culprit lesion and he had angioplasty and stent to LAD only. He had elevated filling pressures. He continued on dopmine at 8mic/kilo and lido at 2mg min. He was not started on 2B 3A [**Doctor Last Name **] as it was not clear if he had hit his head or not. He was transfered to CCU for further care.

PMH: Elevated cholesterol. On zocor and wellbutrin. Pt is adopted so family history unclear.

ALLERGIES: NKDA.

CCU NSG NOTE: RESP FAILURE/CARDIAC ARREST
O: For complete VS see CCU flow sheet.
THis 68 year old male with long history of COPD that has worsened significantly over the past year, was transfered to CCU with worsening resp failure associated with decreased mental status and sats in the 70s. He was initally admitted to [**Hospital1 2**] [**1-/2092**] for and OSH for continued workup of multiple ulcerous lesions on both lower extremities and possible lung reduction surgery. He was to go to rehab but refused as he felt he was too ill.
Events: 1.He was tried on bi-pap on arrival, but continued to deteriorate and was intubated at 1230 without difficulty. Gas prior to intubation was 7.19/ 87/ 52/35.
2. For full details see arrest record. He had been hemodynamically stable post intubation until ~1500 when BP began to drop. He received 500NS bolus with no effect and at 1530 when levophed was started in new #18 iv in R antecub. BP came up on .06mic/kilo, but dropped again as line blew. Line was being attempted in R IJ when BP was dropping to the 50s. By 1730 HR was dropping to 40s and [**12-26**] amp of atropine was given with hr coming up only transiently. Complex widdened and BP was lost alltogether. He received CPR with a variety of rhythms and non-rhythms. He was defilbrillated X 3 at 300J, 360J, 360j. He received a total of 3 amps epi, 1 amp atropine, 3 amp of bicarb. He went back in to NSR with rate in low 100s. BP slowly came up and levophed was increased and neo added. Xray showed pneumothorax, and he had visible increasing crepetis. A needle was inserted with air being expelled and he BP coming up to the 130s. Neo was weaned off. An amiodarone bolus was given and drip has begun. Pt has remained on levo. CT [**Doctor First Name **] is now inserting chest tube.
ID: Pt has been afebrile. BC X 2, a sputum and urine C & S were sent. Pt on PO ABX.
RESP: Pt now stable on 50% AC 400 X 16 5 PEEP with gas pend. He has very decreased breath sounds bilaterally.
CV: HR 115 ST most of the day until arrest. He is now 90s NSR with BP in low 100s on increasing doses of levo. He had a R radial a-line inserted shortly after arrival.
GI: OG tube inserted and position verified by X-ray.NO stool. Miniamal gastric asp.
RENAL: Foley inserted. Urine output very poor. Urine appears consentrated.
MS/SEDATION: Pt had garbled speach, seemed confused and not cooperative upon arrival. He received etomidate and succynlcholine for intubation and received vesed and fentanyl for sedation. He was started on drips, but fentanyl was shut off at 1500 with BP drop. Versed continues going at 1mg/hr. Pt has been unresponsive since intubation.
SKIN: Dsg changed on lower legs per HO. Needs skin consult to ensure adsgs are appropriate. Area on spine reddened and entire coccyx area red. Pt clearly at risk for breakdown.
FAMILY: His wife called during code and was told to come in as pt was very ill and she should come in. She has not yet arrived.
A: Intubation, arrest, pnuemothorax
P: Monitor for hemodynamic instability. Check results of gas. Increase sedation as tolerated. [**Doctor First Name **]

CCU Nursing PRogress Note (MICU boarder)
S-Unresponsive
O-Neuro-unresponsive on fentanyl 100mcg/hr and versed at 2mg/hr both weaned and d/c'd by 1700. Remains unresponsive throughout day despite weaning of sedation. Family states pt becomes delirious/hallucenates with any narcotic ie percocett or MSO4. +pupils react but negative corneals, no movement of any extremiites.
CV-VSS on levo .45mcg/kg/min, attempted to wean but very sensitive and SBP dropped to 78 transiently. Presently levophed at .33mcg/kg/min with good MAPs 70-80. HR 78-88 NSR, no PAF or VEA on amioderone at .5mg/min, therapy d/c'd at 1800. K 3.5 repleated with 40meq KCL.
Resp-orally intubated on vent 50% 500x22 AC PEEP 5, no spont rr, O2 sats 100%. Attempted to wean FIO2 to .35 and ABG 7.38/42/56. CXR rechecked for CT placement and FIO2 increased back to 50%. Minimal to no secretions during ETT sx. Right posterior chest tube draining small amts serosang drainage. +fluc/-leak with +crepitus right chest down to right hip and across right back.
ID WBC 17 (22) hypothermic 94-99 on cipro/linezoid/flagyl for +MRSA wound with entercoc. (vanco sensitive)
GI-OGT started tube feeds Nutrition consult. Started Probalance 20cc/hr increased by 20cc until reached goal of 50cc/hr. Minimal residuals. No stool. Recent loose stool cdiff negative x2. HCT 26 received 2units PRBC-awaiting post transfusion results.
Endo-started SSRI for slightly elevated blood sugars >200.
GU- foley draining minimal urine output ~10cc/hr. BUN/CR 45/.6
Skin-Bilateral leg dressing done. Skin nurses have been following pt since floor admit 2 weeks ago. Have seen an impressive improvement with the present therapy. Using silvadene cream to BLE open burn-like areas followed by aquafor then kerlix. All extremites were cold and cyanotic this am with temp 95po. Using bare hugger all day with improvement in circulation. +RLE [**1-27**]+edema. Right leg ultrasound negative for arterial blockages.
Social-daughter in from [**Name (NI) 485**] and ex wife in most of the day. Pt also has a son who lives on [**Location (un) 1251**], no word from him yet today. Wife is staying in waiting area until pt stablilizes, very informative regarding pt well being prior to this illness. Mentioned that they do not like it  when different nurses take care of pt. Rarely did they have the same nurse take care of pt on the floor. To have social services follow family for support. Pt does not have a proxy even though it was discussed with him. "He always wanted to be in control, and did not trust anyone making decisions for him."-per ex wife and daughter.
A/P-Antibiotic reaction/BLE vasculitis c/b malnourishment/diarrhea, COPD exacerbation s/p cardiac arrest from rupture pulmonary bleb from positive pressure now with pneumonthorax and persistant hypotension.
Closely monitor VS and maintain MAP>65 with Levo
Keep O2 sats >95%, and in am change mode over to pressure support.
Wean IV sedation gtts and use prn haldol-avoiding all narcotics.
Keep family involved and up to date with POC.
Call social services in am for consult.
Increa

pport family.

[**2167-3-9**] 6:00 PM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 9166**]
 Reason: s/p code blue
 Admitting Diagnosis: RESPIRATORY INSUFFICIENCY; COPD
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
       68 year old man with increased O2 requirement       S;P ETT

 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  s/p code blue
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: Cardiac arrest.

 Portable supine frontal radiograph. Comparison is made to study of three hours
 prior.

 There is a large new right sided pneumothorax. There is probable slight shift
 of the heart as well as an NG tube towards the left consistent with tension.
 There has also been interval placement of a right sided IJ central venous
 catheter with its tip appearing to terminate in the mid SVC. An endotracheal
 tube is unchanged in position. There has also been interval development of
 marked subcutaneous emphysema overlying the right chest wall and entire neck.
 The osseous structures are unremarkable.

 IMPRESSION:
 New right sided probqble tension pneumothorax and marked subcutaneous
 emphysema. Interval placement of right IJ central venous catheter. These
 findings were communicated immediately to the ordering physician, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 9167**]
 [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 9168**].

CCU NSG TRANSFER [**Hospital Ward Name 57**] 2-CHF/HYPOTENSION/RAPID AFIB
S.  "I THINK MY BREATHING FEELS A LITTLE BETTER."

O.  BRIEFLY, PT IS A 76YO MAN ADMITTED TO [**Hospital1 2**] ON [**3-3**] W/SOB - RECENT D/C FROM OSH IN FLA WHERE TREATED FOR CHF/PNEUMONIA; TRANSFERRED TO CCU TODAY W/PROGRESSSIVE SOB DESPITE DIURESIS, W/RAPID AFIB, HYPOTENSION AND RISING CR/INR 3.9 FOR CARDIOVERSION, FURTHER MANAGEMENT.

PLEASE SEE ICU ADMISSION NOTE FOR PMHX/HPI
SEE CAREVUE FLOWSHEET FOR COMPLETE VS, OBJECTIVE DATA

CV: PT ARRIVED TO CCU AT 1545 IN AFI RATE 110-120, BP 85-100/SYST
RR ~ 30-40 VERY LABORED AND ABDOMINAL BREATHING, UNABLE TO LIE FLATTER THAN 45 DEGREES; SATS 95% ON 5L NC; 2ND PIV STARTED - 1645 PT [**Name (NI) 2831**] X2 - 200J - [**Street Address(2) 2832**]/MAT W/FREQ PAC'S RATE 105-110; BP 90-100/
1800 PT RECEIVED LOPRESSOR 50 MG PO PER CCU TEAM - HR SLOWED TO 68-80'S SR W/OCCAS APC'S, BP DRIFTED TO 70'S-80'S/ - PITRESSIN ADDED TO 0.08U/MIN W/BP TO 90-100/50-60; AMIO 400MG GIVEN AT 2100 (2ND DOSE)
2200 LASIX 40 MG IV GIVEN W/FAIR RESPONSE THUS FAR; K+ 5.1 AT 2200
ON COUMADIN - INR 3.9 TODAY

RESP:  RR 28-40'S, O2 SATS 94-97% ON 5L NC, WEARING 100% NRB DURING/POST [**Street Address(2) 2831**], VBG DRAWN W/PH 7.33, LACTIC ACID 1.3; LUNGS RALES 3/4 UP, WEARS CPAP AT NOC FOR OSA - PLACED 10 CPAP/5L ON PATIENT AT 2300

ID:  LOW GRADE FEVER - 99.2 WBC 11.2

NEURO/MS:  ALERT AND ORIENTED X3, PLEASANT AND COOPERATVIE

GU/RENAL: #16 FOLEY PLACED W/O DIFFICULTY - 150CC CLEAR YELLOW URINE
CR AT 2200 REMAINS 2.2

GI:  NPO FOR PROCEDURE - NOW TAKING WATER W/MEDS W/O DIFFICULTY, NO STOOL, ABDOMEN OBESE

ALT COMFORT: PT W/ SEVERE R ARM PAIN AND NUBNESS IN R HAND FINGERS - STATES BEGAN AFTER IV PLACED IN R ARM 2 DAYS AGO - IV NOW OUT, TODAY PAIN WORSENING - US DONE TO R/O THROMBOSIS - NO CLOT SEEN, R RADIAL PULSE 3+ - HAND WARM ? SM AMT SWELLING - PERCOCET 2 TABS GIVEN W/SOME IMPROVEMENT

SOCIAL:  LIVES W/WIFE, WIFE IS PARALYZED FROM WAIST DOWN, USES WHEELCHAIR; SON-IN-LAW CALLED X2 - UPDATED REGARDING CARDIOVERSION

A:  AFIB - SUCCESSFUL CARDIOVERSION; BP W/FAIR RESPONSE TO VASOPRESSIN
   CHF - RESPONDING TO LASIX
   R ARM PAIN - ? ETIOLOGY

P:  MONITOR BP ON VASOPRESSIN, FOLLOW HR/RHYTHM - CONTINUE AMIO LOAD AS ORDERED, ASSESS RESPONSE TO LASIX, CPAP OVERNIGHT, MONITOR R ARM PAIN, ASSESS PULSES, CSM, MEDS FOR PAIN - CONT W/U SOURCE, MONIOTR BUN/CR, LYTES, EMOTIONAL SUPPORT FOR PT/FAMILY.

[**2182-2-18**] 9:39 PM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 61022**]
 Reason: Assess placement of lines.
 Admitting Diagnosis: [**Last Name (un) 59427**] CARDIAC ARREST
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 3**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
     72 year old woman s/p line placement--PA catheter, pacer wire, NGT

 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Assess placement of lines.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Status post pulmonary artery catheter and pacer wire.

 VIEWS:  Supine AP view compared with supine AP view from approximately five
 hours earlier.

 FINDINGS:  The pulmonary artery catheter is located in satisfactory position
 within the proximal right interlobar artery.  The endotracheal tube and venous
 pacing wire remain in stable and satisfactory positions. A nasogastric tube
 has been placed with tip below the diaphragm, extending off the inferior
 borders of the film.  Cardiac and mediastinal contours remain stable.  There
 has been interval progression of bilateral diffuse interstitial opacities
 consistent with interval worsening of interstitial pulmonary edema.  There is
 persistent left lower lobe atelectasis.  No definite pleural effusions are
 identified.  No pneumothorax is present.

 IMPRESSION:

 1. Satisfactory placement of all lines and tubes.
 2. Interval worsening of interstitial pulmonary edema.
 3. Persistent left lower lobe atelectasis.

CCU NPN 3-11PM
CV: pt in rapid a.fib at 140, attempted cardioversion x2 200/300J without success. Given Amioderone bolus and started gtt, pt converted back to NSR shortly after Amio bolus. HR 70's, BP 90's/60. Held captopril and Lopressor this eve. Had received 2.5 IV lopressor at onset of shift when in rapid a.fib. Pulses dop, groin sites D&I, no bleeding, no heatoma. Hep gtt restarted at 8PM at 800u/hr, no bolus.

Resp: remains vented, will attempt to wean and extubate in AM. Sats 98-100% on 40% IMV rate decreased to 10 from 12, for ABG: 85/28/7.46. Suctioned for thick tan sputum x1, copious secretions in oral-pharnyx.

Neuro: sedated on propofol.

GU: CRI, cr 1.5, UO 10-20cc/hr.

GI: abd soft, (+)BS, dressing changed, old dried blood an old dressing. NO stool.

                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Status post fall with cardiac arrest.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial images of the brain were obtained without IV contrast.

 FINDINGS:  There is no evidence of any intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect or
 shift of normally midline structures.  The ventricles, cisterns and sulci are
 unremarkable. The [**Doctor Last Name 181**]-white matter differentiation is within normal limits.
 The visualized osseous structures and paranasal sinuses are unremarkable.

 IMPRESSION:  No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect.

CCU Progress Note:

Please see admission & transfer notes.

This is a 60 yr old S/P CABG [**12-10**] with a complicated post-op course- MRSA pneumonia intubated x4 - trached- drainage of gall bladder- persistent failure treated with natrecor- developed runs of rapid AF- attributed to the natrecor- [**2127-2-11**] went into RAF- dropped B/P 60's- unresponsive- shocked with 200J- brought to CCU for observation.

IDDM- blind, vascular disease,& renal involvement.

O- see flowsheet for all objective data.

cv- Tele: NSR occ PVC- no A-fib this shift- HR 74-82 B/P 107-121/39-59
Hct 30.2- K 3.8 Kcl 20 meq given- Mg 1.9 Mg sulfate 2gms given-

resp- In O2 70% trach mask- lung sounds diminished @ the bases with scattered rhonchi- suctioned thick yell/brn colored secretions- SaO2 95-100%.

gi- abd soft (+) bowel sounds- had 1 soft formed brn colored stool today  quiac (-) taking po well- no n/v- tube used to drain gall bladder clamped.

gu- foley draining yellow colored urine qs- diuresing well from AM bumex- (-) 550cc since 12am- BUN 83 Crea 1.6

neuro- awake, alert, & oriented X 2- very cooperative- moving all extremities- Pt is blind, but communicates without difficulty.

endo- very brittle diabetic- blood sugars up & down- FS done q2hrs- NPH 34 u given this AM- 12n bs 266- 12u humulog given.

id- afebrile- T 97-97.5 PO

A- S/P CABG with multiple complications.

P- monitor vs, lung sounds, I&O, & labs- con't to check BS Q2hrs- offer emotional support to Pt & family- keep them updated on plan of care.

 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
    58 year old man s/p cardiac arrest

  r/o PNA with new RUL opacity
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE AP PORTABLE VIEW OF THE CHEST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  58-year-old man s/p cardiac arrest, rule out pneumonia.

 Comparison is made with prior study performed a day before.

 FINDINGS:  There is opacity of the right upper lobe with air bronchograms,
 unchanged from prior study consistent with aspiration/ aspiration pneumonia.
 Stable opacities in the right infrahilar region.  There is no pneumothorax or
 pleural effusion.  The cardiomediastinal contour is unremarkable.  ET tube in
 adequate position.  NG tube with tip not included on the film passing the
 diaphragm.

 IMPRESSION:  Persistent right upper lobe consolidation, which may be due to
 aspiration or evolving aspiration pneumonia.

 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  58 year old man with cardiac arrest

  ? ICH
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  58-year-old man with cardiac arrest.  Question of intracranial
 hemorrhage.

 No comparison studies.

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast CT of the head.

 FINDINGS:  There is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect, shift
 of normally midline structures.  The ventricles are symmetric and normal in
 size.  The mastoid air cells are clear.  There is ethmoid sinus thickening
 along with air-fluid levels seen within the maxillary sinuses, left greater
 than right, and sphenoid sinuses.  These findings are consistent with post
 endotracheal tube placement.  A retention cyst is also noted within the right
 maxillary sinus.

 IMPRESSION:

 No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage.

[**2174-6-9**] 3:22 PM
 CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 106176**]
 Reason: ? fx
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  58 year old man with cardiac arrest
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? fx
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Cardiac arrest, evaluate for fracture.

 COMPARISON:  None.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial MDCT images were obtained through the cervical spine without
 intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformations are provided.

 CT OF THE CERVICAL SPINE:  The cervical spine is imaged from C1 through the
 upper portion of T4.  No fracture is identified within the cervical spine.

 At C2-3, there is marked facet degenerative change and facet joint space
 narrowing with moderate narrowing of the right neural foramen at C2-3.

 At C5-6, there is loss of intervertebral disc space height and posterior
 spondylosis with mild left neural foraminal narrowing and mild central spinal
 stenosis.

 The prevertebral soft tissues appear within normal limits.  The visualized
 outlines of the thecal sac appear unremarkable.  CT is limited in its ability
 to provide intrathecal detail, compared with MRI.

 The visualized portions of the lung apices demonstrate ground-glass opacity
 and dependent opacities, likely representing a combination of pulmonary edema
 and atelectasis.

 IMPRESSION:  No fracture of the cervical spine.  Multilevel degenerative
 change of the cervical spine, most evident at C2-3 and C5-6.

[**2164-4-26**] 5:54 PM
 CTA CHEST W&W/O C &RECONS; CTA ABD W&W/O C & RECONS             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 97568**]
 CTA PELVIS W&W/O C & RECONS; CT 150CC NONIONIC CONTRAST
 Reason: CARDIAC ARREST, EVAL FOR DISSECTION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  49 year old man with unknown cause of cardiac arrest
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  evaluate for dissection
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) **] [**Doctor First Name 141**] [**2164-4-26**] 6:52 PM
  no aortic aneurysm or dissection. no PE.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  49 year old with cardiac arrest, assess for aortic dissection.

 TECHNIQUE:  CT of the chest with and without IV contrast.  CT of the abdomen
 and pelvis with IV contrast.  The CTA dissection protocol was used.  150 cc of
 Optiray was used for this examination due to need for fast bolus technique.
 Multiplanar reformatted images were obtained.

 No prior studies for comparison.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITH AND WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Soft-tissue windows reveal
 several non-pathologically-enlarged axillary lymph nodes.  There is no
 significant mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.  There are no pleural
 effusions.  Heart and pericardium are normal in appearance.  There is no
 pulmonary embolus, and the pulmonary artery is otherwise normal in appearance.
 Lung window images reveal reexpansion of the left lung after repositioning of
 the endotracheal tube. There is residual basilar atelectasis on the left, and
 to a lesser degree on the right. There is no focal consolidation or nodule
 within the lungs.  The bronchi are patent to the segmental level.  An
 endotracheal tube is seen now terminating approximately 1 to 1.5 cm above the
 carina.

 Bone windows reveal no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions within the
 thorax.  There is an old fracture of the left 8th rib with a persistent
 lucency.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:  The patient is post cholecystectomy.  The
 liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenals, kidneys, intraabdominal large and small
 bowel are all normal in appearance.  There is no free fluid, free air, or
 pathologic lymphadenopathy within the abdomen.  Several tiny hypodense lesions
 are seen in the left kidney, likely representing cysts.  Focal calcification
 is seen with the appendix representing an appendicolith.  There is no evidence
 of appendicitis. Mild fat stranding is seen in the abdomen just anterior to
 Gerota's fascia bilaterally.  This is of uncertain clinical signifigance and
 may relate to recusitation efforts.

 CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The visualized portion of the upper pelvis
 demonstrates normal-appearing bowel loops.  There is no free fluid or

 INDICATION:  The patient found down at home with cardiac arrest of unknown

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images through the chest were obtained without
 contrast.  Subsequently, following the administration of 100 cc of Optiray,
 contiguous axial images through the chest were obtained during opacification
 of the pulmonary artery and aorta.  Coronal and sagittal reconstructions were
 obtained.

 CTA OF THE CHEST:  There are no filling defects within the pulmonary arterial
 vessels to suggest a pulmonary embolus.  The aorta is of normal caliber, and
 there is no evidence of thoracic aortic dissection.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITHOUT AND WITH CONTRAST:  Since the prior CT of earlier
 today, there is increased patchy nodular opacities within the lung bases
 bilaterally.  There is persistent ground-glass opacity in the right middle
 lobe.  The findings are concerning for aspiration or atypical infection. There
 is no pleural or pericardial effusion.  The central airways are patent to the
 level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.  Endotracheal and nasogastric
 tubes are in place.  The endotracheal tube terminates a few cm superior to the
 carina.  A left subclavian central venous catheter is noted, with the tip
 within the superior vena cava.  No pleural or pericardial effusions.  No
 pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes.

 Within the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized portion of the
 liver is of low attenuation, consistent with fatty infiltration.  Imaged
 portion of the spleen is unremarkable.

 BONE WINDOWS:  There are no suspicious osteolytic or sclerotic lesions.

 Multiplanar reformatted images were essential in delineating the anatomy and
 pathology in this case (grade 1).

 and pelvis were then acquired.

 thoracic and abdominal aorta and branches. An occluded infrarenal abdominal

 disease is seen at the aorta and coronary arteries. The lungs are clear. There

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname **] is a 59 yo female with DM1, extensive cardiac hx including CAD,
   systolic and diastolic HF, admitted with acute on chronic HF and
   transferred to the CCU for hypoxia.
   # HYPOXIA: Precipitant not entirely clear. Crackles and CXR consistent
   with flash edema, although no clear trigger such as hypertension or
   tachycardia. Aspiration event also possible given h/o this, as well as
   mild leukocytosis and fever. Other causes include mucus plug (no
   secretions, so unlikely), PE (possible, but patient not currently
   stable for V/Q and would address above issues first). ABG suggests
   profound A-a gradient, given PaO2 of 64 on NRB.
   - Low threshold for BiPAP if hypoxia persists or worsens
   - Furosemide 80mg IV bolus and continue gtt to maintain 100ml/hr UOP
   - Start NTG gtt for acute pulmonary edema
   - Broad-spectrum abx in case of HAP including aspiration: vancomycin,
   cefepime, metronidazole
   - Cycle cardiac markers to evaluate for ischemia
   - Send blood and urine cultures given fevers
   - Repeat CXR in am

 Assessment to rule out fracture requested.

 COMPARISONS:  None.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial noncontrast CT images of the cervical spine were obtained,
 and coronal and sagittal reconstructions were performed. This study was
 initially not identified, or present on the PACS system for viewing,
 resulting in a delay in interpretation.

 FINDINGS:  There is an endotracheal tube passing through the airway, and a
 nasogastric tube passing through the esophagus.  There is a comminuted
 fracture of the C2 vertebral body with loss of height.  The appearance
 suggests an axial loading injury, and the upper fragment is displaced
 inferoposteriorly with some retropulsion into the upper spinal canal.  The
 relationship between the dens and C1 appears preserved, and there is no
 atlanto-occipital subluxation.

 There are multiple fractures through the lateral masses of C2 bilaterally with
 fragmentation of the walls of the transverse foramina. This raises a serious
 conceern of injury to both  vertebral arteries.

 On the right, there is subluxation of the facet joint at C2-3. Also, on the
 left, there is some widening of the facet joint at C2-C3. There is a small
 fracture of the distal spinous process of C3.

 No other evidence of fracture is seen, and the overall alignment of the
 cervical spine is otherwise maintained with some intervertebral disc narrowing
 at C6-C7.

 The soft tissues of the spinal canal are difficult to assess on this study.
 However, given the retropulsion of C2 bone fragments, there is a high risk of
 a hematoma compromising the spinal canal. The possibility of a cord contusion
 cannot be evaluated on this study. At the right lung apex, there is a small
 possible contusion or atelectasis with a tiny effusion.

   Assessment and Plan
   73 yo female with PMH significant for ILD on home O2, diastolic CHF,
   cor pulmonale, s/p liver transplant on immunosuppression,
   post-transplant myeloproliferative disorder s/p CHOP and rituximab
   transferred to ICU for respiratory distress.
   .
   # respiratory distress: hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure.
   Most likely worsening natural course of her ILD with worsening
   pulmonary edema secondary to a fib with RVR.  Patient tenuous at
   baseline. Treating for VAP in addition to underlying lung disease, on
   vanco/zosyn day #[**7-4**]
   - NIPPV, alternate CPAP with face mask
   - serial ABGs. Seems to be stable, If worsening respiratory acidosis,
   will intubate
   - treat SVT as below
   - continue nebulizer treatments
   - No indication for steroids. Has not been responsive to steroids in
   the past
   .
   # SVT: appears to be AF vs MAT on tele and ECG.  The patient was loaded
   with amiodarone drip, started on amiodarone 200mg QD today.  Had
   similar episode on last MICU admission which did not tolerate beta
   blockers and required amio gtt. The patient does not tolerate
   betablockers given hypotensive, thus will attempt to rate control with
   amiodarone only.
   - will continue to monitor on telemetry
   - can attempt bolus IV lopressor if BP will tolerate
   - cont po beta blocker as BP will tolerate
   .
   # hypotension: likely due to RVR, and diastolic heart failure. In the
   setting of low grade fever, must also consider sepsis especially given
   immunosupression . Currently on broad spectrum abx of vanc/zosyn
   - will culture if spikes, follow blood cultures
   - treat SVT as above
   - Will give 1L of NS today, will repeat as tolerated
   - Will continue phenylephrine drip as needed, attempt to wean
   .
   # fever: new low grade temp this am. See hypotension above.  On broad
   spectrum Abs.  Follow culture
   .
   # s/p fall: no evidence of fracture. Pain controlled currently.
   - cont lidocaine patch, tylenol
   - avoid narcotics given tenuous respiratory status
   - PT
   .
   # DM: Even though patient is NPO BG have been very elevated.  Will
   continue to monitor QID and adjust sliding scale accordingly.  Will use
   half dose of outpatient insulin while NPO
   .
   # ILD: unclear etiology. Followed by Pulm. Refractory to steroids.
   - continue supplemental O2
   - no steroids for now
   - alb/atrovent nebs
   .
   # PTLD: no known active issues currently.
   - check LFTs as above
   - continue Tacrolimus at regular dose for now
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH normal this admission. Continue Levothyroxine
   .
   # Access: PICC, PIV
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now given tenuous respiratory status
   .

   - Bactrim M/W/F
   .

   HPI:
   For complete details, please refer to initial medicine admission note
   and MICU call out note [**2125-12-17**]. In brief, Ms. [**Known lastname 5141**] is a 73 yo
   female with PMH significant for ILD on [**1-27**].5L home O2, diastolic CHF,
   cor pulmonale, s/p liver transplant on immunosuppression,
   post-transplant myeloproliferative disorder s/p CHOP and rituximab who
   was initially admitted to hospital on [**12-10**] after a mechanical fall for
   pain control. On [**12-11**] patient had an aspiration event and hypoxia. The
   following day, she had evidence of aspiration on CXR and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  At that time, goals of care were discussed with
   her HCP, her husband, as well as her daughter and they felt they would
   want intubation.  She was made DNR as it was felt that CPR would not be
   indicated. She was transferred to the MICU.
   .
   In the MICU, she was intubated on [**12-12**] for worsening hypercarbia. That
   evening she spiked a fever, went into AF vs MAT with HRs into the 160s,
   and hypotension to the 80s. She did not tolerate beta blockers at that
   time and was started on an amiodarone gtt.  She was also started on
   empiric vancomycin and zosyn for possible aspiration pna.  She received
   aggressive volume resuscitation and converted to NSR the following
   morning.  Her amiodarone was discontinued given concern for worsening
   lung and liver disease.  Her beta blocker was uptitrated. Antibiotics
   were briefly discontinued on [**12-14**] and restarted on [**12-15**].  She was
   eventually diuresed and was able to be extubated on [**12-16**]. She was
   called out to the medical floor on [**12-17**].
   .
   While on the medical floor, she was continued on vancomycin and zosyn
   for presumed aspiration pna. She had no microbiology data to help guide
   therapy. She was continued on diuretics but has run I/O even per
   documentation. While on floor, SBPOs 100s, HRs 80s, RR 20s, O2 90s on
   3LNC.
   .
   On the evening of transfer, trigger called for increased work of
   breathing. Upon floor evaluation, patient denied any subjective SOB. O2
   requirement the same at 90s n 3LNC and no significant change in RR.
   However, at ~ MN, patient went into irregular SVT (AF vs MAT) to 150s,
   T100.3,  with SBPs into 90s, RR increased to 30s, and O2 sats low 90s
   on 4-6L. She received lopressor 5 mg IV x 2 without significant change
   in her HR and decrease in SBP to 80s. CXR repeated without significant
   change compared to this am. ABG showed 7.35/73/54.

 There are no intracranial hemorrhages or masses.  The [**Doctor Last Name 181**]/white matter
 differentiation is maintained.  There are scattered periventricular and deep
 white matter hypodensities consistent with small vessel ischemic changes.

 cerebellum which may represent an old lacunar infarct.

 intracranial, vertebrobasilar and internal carotid arteries.

 within the nasal and oropharynx.  Mild mucosal thickening of the right
 maxillary sinus and the sphenoid sinuses bilaterally are noted.  There is a
 0.8-cm osteoma in the left frontal sinus.  No suspicious bony abnormalities
 are seen.

 IMPRESSION:

 Small vessel ischemic changes and lacune of the right inferior cerebellum.  If
 there is strong concern for an acute infarct or hypoxic injury, recommend

 discussed with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1238**] immediately after the completion of the study.

. HPI:
   HPI: 55 yo gentleman with a history of morbid obesity, type II DM, OSA
   on BiPAP, was initially admitted on [**9-13**] due to altered mental status,
   weakness on his right lower extremity. At that time he was found to
   have bilateral thalami infarcts and left peduncle infarct, then
   re-admitted with free intra-peritoneal air and abdominal pain on [**10-14**].
   He was taken to the OR for this and found to have a perforated Cecum
   secondary to Oglivie's, now s/p right colectomy and end ileostomy with
   Hartmann's pouch. He had a CT scan performed on [**2192-11-6**] to evaluate his
   fluid collections which showed an SMV clot.
   On [**11-20**] pt had CT abd w/ PO contrast via Dobhoff tube for re-eval of
   abdominal abscess/leak that was drained by a pigtail. Later in the
   evening/morning pt was seen tachypnea (has been tachypneic for last few
   days on BiPAP but with sats in mid 90s). Sat 70s, switched to FM -->
   sat 80s, then NRB --> low 90s. HR 110-120s, BP 130s/70s, RR 30s. ABG:
   7.51/41/55 on NRB..  On [**11-21**] pt transferred to TSICU from 5-[**Hospital Ward Name 713**]
   for acute hypoxia. Per primary service, at baseline pt cannot swallow
   and need aggressive pulm toilet and suctioning.
   Impaired Skin Integrity
   Assessment:
   Coccyx wound 4cm x 3 cm x 1cm non stageable, yellow slough, nonviable
   tissue, margins slightly detached friable bleeding.
   Abdominal wound from incision 19cm x 3.5cm x 1cm, beefy red granulation
   tissue no signs and symptoms of infection.
   Inferior to coccyx wound on right gluteus, deep tissue injury bluish
   coloration and nonblanchable 5cm x 4.5cm.
   Action:
   Skin care nurse consulted.
   Wet to dry dressings placed into open wounds, covered with dry gauze.
   Criticaid Cream applied to inferior coccyx wound.
   Response:
   Dressings intact.
   Wound care nurse to follow pt.
   Bariairmax 2 with ETS setup.
   Plan:
   Change dressings daily.
   Use antimicrobial kerlix in ABD wound.
   Use Santyl in coccyx wound.
   Monitor for signs and symptoms of infections.
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   Assessment:
   RR 36, O2sats 88% on NRBM 15LO2, ABG 7.5, 41, 45 on NRBM. Labored
   breathing, question aspiration with oral contrast yesterday.
   Action:
   MD intubated pt. placed on 100 FiO2, RR 14 VT 500 PEEP 10 ,
   bronchoscopy performed in afternoon today.
   Response:
   RR 23, O2 sats 100% on vent, ABG 7.45, 40, 245, large amounts of yellow
   white mucus suctioned from lungs.
   Plan:
   Continue to wean vent. Pulmonary toilet. IV ABX, Rotating bed, antiVAP
   care.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   During intubation pulseless Vtach arrest occurred.
   Action:
   CPR, code team called, pt. coded, see cardiac arrest documentation.
   Response:
   Pt regained pulses and Sinus tachycardic rhythm.
   Plan:
   Monitor pt. for refractory VTACH/VFIB.

Chief Complaint:  perforated cecum / intradominal abscess
   HPI:
   The pt. is 55yoM with hx of morbid obesity, type II DM, OSA on BiPAP,
   with a very complicated 2 month hospital course s/p Cardiac Arrest on
   [**11-21**] transferred to the unit for MRSA HAP.
   Pt initially presented on [**9-13**] due with acute change in MS, weakness on
   his RLE weakness extremity found to have bilateral thalamic, and L
   cerebral peduncle infarcts, transferred to the floor for 2 week course
   with continued FUO and discharged to rehab. Pt re-admitted on [**10-14**] and
   found to have with intra-peritoneal air and abdominal pain taken to the
   OR and found to have perforated Cecum secondary thought to be secondary
   to [**Last Name (un) **] syndrome, then s/p right colectomy and end ileostomy with
   Hartmann's patch.
   His post-op course was complicated by abdominal abscess. The pt
   developed purulence at his op site and wound was opened and cultured.
   He was started on Vancomycin on [**10-23**]. Cultures grew MRSA and VRE. CT abd
   showed large fluid collection. He was intubated on [**10-28**] for inability
   to manage airway secretions and was started on zosyn. CT abd on [**10-30**]
   again showed an organizing fluid collection R hepatic flex to pelvis
   and on [**10-31**] the collection was drained. Fluid grew VRE on [**10-31**]. He was
   continued on Vanco/Zosyn until [**11-5**]. He also had sputum cultures on
   [**10-27**] and [**10-28**] with MRSA. In addition CT scan [**2192-11-6**] to evaluate his
   fluid collections showed an SMV clot. Hematology was consulted and
   hypercoag labs were sent and found to have Factor 5 Leiden. Patient was
   started on Coumadin.
   On [**11-20**] pt had CT abd w/ PO contrast via Dobhoff tube for re-eval of
   abdominal abscess/leak that was drained by a pigtail. Overnight pt
   triggered for tachypnia and subsequently transferred from East to [**Hospital Ward Name **] to the TICU. On arrival to the TICU the pt was in respiratory
   distress. He was emergently intubated. Following intubation he suffered
   a cardiac arrest with pulseless VT responding to epi X3. Down time
   estimated at 5 minutes. He underwent a bronchoscopy on [**11-21**] with
   cultures growing coag + staph. He was started on Vancomycin and

TITLE: Nursing Progress Note.
   55yoM with hx of morbid obesity, type II DM, OSA on BiPAP, thalamoic
   stroke with a very complicated 2 month hospital course s/p Cardiac
   Arrest on [**11-21**] transferred to the unit for MRSA HAP.
   In brief, Mr [**Known lastname 3971**] was admitted in [**Month (only) 705**] with acute thalmic CVA and
   transferred to rehab. Decompensated at rehab and was tx back to [**Hospital1 54**]
   with perforated cecum requiring right colectomy. Post op course c/b
   abdominal abscess (MRSA and VRE) s/p drains, acute SMV thrombosis and
   MRSA PNA. [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 570**] pt was taken for contrast CT via Dobhoff to
   reassess abd wound and that evening pt had increased RR and HR. The
   hypoxemic to 100% NRB and tx to TSICU. On arrival was acutely
   hypoxemic, intubated, VFIB arrest, CPR, shocks, epi/atropine (perfusing
   rhythm regained in [**6-21**] minutes by report) Bronch with mucus plugging
   and BAL + MRSA
   Post arrest he is waking up and following commands. Converted to PSV
   and TX to MICU for medical management.
   Update: Pt OOB to chair for approx three hours today with [**Doctor Last Name **] lift
   with good tol.  Pt more confused today, actively hallucinating but
   re-directable and able to follow simple commands consistently.  Pts
   affect was more labile as well, typically he is a very pleasant man,
   however when placing 2LNCO2 he became agitated, thrashing at myself
   violently & angrily.  Soft wrist restraint in place to protect NGT.
   The pt remains a Full Code.
   Urinary tract infection (UTI)
   Assessment:
   Pt had diminished urine output today when transferred to chair.
   Action:
   Foley flushed with 200ml clear yellow urine output return.  Pt
   maintained on IV Linezolid dosing.
   Response:
   Adequate hourly urine output now in place.
   Plan:
   Cont to follow urine output closely.
   Alteration in Nutrition
   Assessment:
   Pt received on full strength Replete with Fiber tube feeds infusing @
   40ml/hr via R nare Dobhoff NGT.
   Action:
   Tube feeds adv to 50ml/hr today.
   Response:
   Pt appears to be tol tube feeds @ current rate.
   Plan:
   Cont to adv tube feeds as tol to target rate of 90ml/hr.
   .H/O altered mental status (not Delirium)
   Assessment:
   Pt more confused with more labile emotive states today.
   Action:
   Pt freq re-oriented to person/place/time/care rationale.  Pt moved OOB
   to chair during the afternoon.  Pt benefits from excellent family
   support with supportive family members @ BS most of shift.  No
   potent/active psychoactive agents admin today.  L wrist restraint
   remains in place with history of removal of these devices.  In addition
   the pt was asked who he was coping with this long/[**Name (NI) 1442**] hosp,
   verbal and non-verbal support provided.
   Response:
   Pt currently is calm and cooperative.
   Plan:
   Pt will need to be monitored very closely for agitation/aggression.

   extubation.  He will need to be followed closely for pulmonary hygiene,
   encouraged to cough, and given mucolytics. His prior stroke may be
   contributing to his less than optimal ability to clear his secretions.
   He is on Linezolid  for a MRSA pneumonia, VRE UTI, and VRE abdominal
   wall abscess.

Chief Complaint:  respiratory failure
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   55yoM with hx of morbid obesity, type II DM, OSA on BiPAP, thalamoic
   stroke with a very complicated 2 month hospital course s/p Cardiac
   Arrest on [**11-21**] transferred to the unit for MRSA HAP.
   In brief, Mr [**Known lastname **] was admitted in [**Month (only) 705**] with acute thalmic CVA, FUO,
   and transferred to rehab. He decompensated at rehab and was tx back to
   [**Hospital1 54**] with perforated cecum (? secondary to Olgilvie's) requiring right
   colectomy. Post op course complicated by abdominal abscess (MRSA and
   VRE) s/p drains, acute SMV thrombosis (found to be Factor V Leiden
   deficit now on coumadin) and MRSA PNA.

   I spoke to Mr. [**Last Name (Titles) 8038**] son regarding his goals of care. We discussed
   his urosepsis on pressors, chronic poor nutrition status, and chronic
   pain. I relayed his very poor prognosis, and son seemed to have good
   understanding of this and reasonable expectations for survival. The son
   was concerned that DNR/DNI meant withdrawal of care, and that was why
   family had always been reluctant to do this. I explained that he could
   continue to have treatment (pressors, abx, etc) but that CPR/intubation
   would not improve his chronic medical issues and would likely diminish
   his quality of life. Once the son was aware of this, he felt that pt
   would most likely choose to be DNR/DNI; however, son wanted to talk to
   the rest of his family before formally making this decision. In
   addition, I mentioned his poor nutrition status and discussed tube
   feeding/PEG, the benefits and drawbacks to peg. We will rediscuss these
   issues tomorrow with family.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 4992**] is an 88 year-old male with a history of CAD s/p PCI to LCx
   [**2128**], CHF, moderate to severe aortic stenosis who was transferred from
   [**Hospital3 519**] for catheterization with NSTEMI.  According to [**Hospital1 **]
   records the patient presented from home complaining of "not feeling
   well" since last night.  He had +cough productive of white sputum.  He
   denied chest pain, abdominal pain and fever.  He later complained of
   shortness of breath He was initially treated with IV diuresis and
   biomarkers were cycled.  Labs were significant for BNP 600, troponin
   0.08>1.43>1.65>0.38, CK 225>195, CKMB 12.7>8.9.  He also had a positive
   stress test.  Of note, he also had 7 beat run of VT at OSH and atenolol
   was increased.
   .
   Today during catheterization patient was noted to have tight 95-99%
   stenotic lesion just after the LCx stent.  The pressure wire was placed
   in the LAD and became totally occluded.  Patient had chest discomfort
   with ST depressions on ECG and decrease in BP.  At that time the
   patient became hypotensive and bradycardic.  He received 2mg Atropine
   and subsequently developed VF.  CPR was initiated.  He received
   multiple shocks ([**5-5**]), amiodarone 300mg x 1 followed by 150mg x 1,
   epinephrine 2mg and lidocaine 100mg x1.  He was also started on an
   amiodarone gtt at 2mg/min decreased to 1mg/min and a lidocaine gtt at
   2mg/min.  He was also intubated for airway protection.  An IABP was
   inserted.  The LAD was reopened successfully and stented with a bare
   metal stent.  An echocardiogram was also done in the cath lab which
   showed normal LV, ? small segment of anterior hypokinesis.  A Swan
   showed PCWP of 35 after the case (initially was 15).
   .
   On transfer to the CCU, the patient is intubated.  He is off of the
   lidocaine gtt, continues on amiodarone at 1mg/min and is on dopamine
   10mcg/min to maintain his MAPs.  An intra-aortic balloon pump is in
   place in the right groin.
   .
   Of note, at [**Hospital1 **] the patient was seen by GU for gross hematuria.
   This was felt attributable to traumatic catheter insertion.  They
   recommended sending urine cytology and outpatient cystoscopy to rule
   out mass or obstruction.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is an 88 year old male with history of CAD s/p stent to LCx
   (06), moderate to severe AS and diastolic dysfunction who was
   transferred from [**Hospital3 519**] for cath.  Catheterization was
   complicated by acute LAD occlusion during attempt to pass pressure wire
   and resultant VF arrest.  Spontaneous circulation returned after
   multiple shocks, epinephrine, lidocaine and amiodarone.
   .
   #. CAD: Known history of CAD s/p stent to LCx.  Cath today notable for
   stenosis distal to LCx stent.  During evaluation of anatomy patient
   developed TO of LAD which is known to supply collaterals to occluded
   RCA as well.  This resulted in VF arrest requiring multiple shocks,
   amiodarone, lidocaine.  A BMS was able to be placed to the LAD with
   resultant good flow.  Arrest is due to ischemia as clearly evidenced on
   catheterization TO of LAD so patient should improve now that coronary
   is reopened.
   - Continue IABP and follow MAPs on pump.  Continue dopamine as needed
   to maintain MAPs.
   - Continue amiodarone gtt for now.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes.
   - Heparin gtt once arterial sheath is pulled.
   - Continue ASA, Plavix
   - High dose statin
   - Consider repeat catheterization once acute issues resolved to
   intervene on LCx.
   - Check echocardiogram in the AM.
   .
   # s/p intubation: In setting of VF arrest no acute hypoxic or
   hypercarbic event.
   - Confirm tube placement with CXR.
   - Continue on mechanical ventilation overnight
   - Place Aline to follow ABGs.
   .
   #. Pump: Diastolic heart failure, aortic stenosis.  Initially with PCWP
   of 15, however after arrest PCWP elevated to 35.
   - Follow volume status with swan.  Diurese as able.
   - Once patient is no longer hypotensive consider restarting beta
   blocker and ACE inhibitor.
   - Check echocardiogram in the AM.
   .
   #. Rhythm: Currently in sinus rhythm s/p VF arrest.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Continue on amiodarone gtt
   - Holding beta blocker [**12-31**] bradycardia and hypotension
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Creatinine 1.6 post arrest.
   - Trend creatinine.
   - Renally dose all meds.
   .
   # Hypertension: On pressors.
   - Hold imdur, beta blocker.
   # Hyperlipidemia
   - Continue statin
   .
   #. Diabetes mellitus:
   - Continue insulin as per home regimen
   - FS QID
   - Check A1c
   .
   #. FEN:
   - OG tube in place
   - Follow lytes and replete PRN
   .
   #. Access:
   - Right groin swan ganz
   - Left groin with arterial sheath
   - Will attempt Aline
   .
   #. PPx: Heparin gtt, PPI, bowel regimen
   .
   #. Code: Full
   .
   #. Dispo: CCU for now

Chief Complaint:  s/p VF arrest
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 4992**] is an 88 year-old male with a history of CAD s/p PCI to LCx
   [**2128**], CHF, moderate to severe aortic stenosis who was transferred from
   [**Hospital3 519**] for catheterization with NSTEMI.  According to [**Hospital1 **]
   records the patient presented from home complaining of "not feeling
   well" since last night.  He had +cough productive of white sputum.  He
   denied chest pain, abdominal pain and fever.  He later complained of
   shortness of breath He was initially treated with IV diuresis and
   biomarkers were cycled.  Labs were significant for BNP 600, troponin
   0.08>1.43>1.65>0.38, CK 225>195, CKMB 12.7>8.9.  He also had a positive
   stress test.  Of note, he also had 7 beat run of VT at OSH and atenolol
   was increased.
   .
   Today during catheterization patient was noted to have tight 95-99%
   stenotic lesion just after the LCx stent.  The pressure wire was placed
   in the LAD and became totally occluded.  Patient had chest discomfort
   with ST depressions on ECG and decrease in BP.  At that time the
   patient became hypotensive and bradycardic.  He received 2mg Atropine
   and subsequently developed VF.  CPR was initiated.  He received
   multiple shocks ([**5-5**]), amiodarone 300mg x 1 followed by 150mg x 1,
   epinephrine 2mg and lidocaine 100mg x1.  He was also started on an
   amiodarone gtt at 2mg/min decreased to 1mg/min and a lidocaine gtt at
   2mg/min.  He was also intubated for airway protection.  An IABP was
   inserted.  The LAD was reopened successfully and stented with a bare
   metal stent.  An echocardiogram was also done in the cath lab which
   showed normal LV, ? small segment of anterior hypokinesis.  A Swan
   showed PCWP of 35 after the case (initially was 15).
   .
   On transfer to the CCU, the patient is intubated.  He is off of the
   lidocaine gtt, continues on amiodarone at 1mg/min and is on dopamine
   10mcg/min to maintain his MAPs.  An intra-aortic balloon pump is in
   place in the right groin.
   .
   Of note, at [**Hospital1 **] the patient was seen by GU for gross hematuria.
   This was felt attributable to traumatic catheter insertion.  They
   recommended sending urine cytology and outpatient cystoscopy to rule
   out mass or obstruction.

   Patient is an 88 year old male with history of CAD s/p stent to LCx
   (06), moderate to severe AS and diastolic dysfunction who was
   transferred from [**Hospital3 519**] for cath.  Catheterization was
   complicated by acute LAD occlusion during attempt to pass pressure wire
   and resultant VF arrest.  Spontaneous circulation returned after
   multiple shocks, epinephrine, lidocaine and amiodarone.
   .
   #. CAD: Known history of CAD s/p stent to LCx.  Cath today notable for
   stenosis distal to LCx stent.  During evaluation of anatomy patient
   developed TO of LAD which is known to supply collaterals to occluded
   RCA as well.  This resulted in VF arrest requiring multiple shocks,
   amiodarone, lidocaine.  A BMS was able to be placed to the LAD with
   resultant good flow.  Arrest is due to ischemia as clearly evidenced on
   catheterization TO of LAD so patient should improve now that coronary
   is reopened.
   - Continue IABP and follow MAPs on pump.  Continue dopamine as needed
   to maintain MAPs.
   - Continue amiodarone gtt for now.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes.
   - Heparin gtt once arterial sheath is pulled.
   - Continue ASA, Plavix
   - High dose statin
   - Consider repeat catheterization once acute issues resolved to
   intervene on LCx.
   - Check echocardiogram in the AM.
   .
   # s/p intubation: In setting of VF arrest no acute hypoxic or
   hypercarbic event.
   - Confirm tube placement with CXR.
   - Continue on mechanical ventilation overnight
   - Place Aline to follow ABGs.
   .
   #. Pump: Diastolic heart failure, aortic stenosis.  Initially with PCWP
   of 15, however after arrest PCWP elevated to 35.
   - Follow volume status with swan.  Diurese as able.
   - Once patient is no longer hypotensive consider restarting beta
   blocker and ACE inhibitor.
   - Check echocardiogram in the AM.
   .
   #. Rhythm: Currently in sinus rhythm s/p VF arrest.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Continue on amiodarone gtt
   - Holding beta blocker [**12-31**] bradycardia and hypotension
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Creatinine 1.6 post arrest.
   - Trend creatinine.
   - Renally dose all meds.
   .
   # Hypertension: On pressors.
   - Hold imdur, beta blocker.
   # Hyperlipidemia
   - Continue statin
   .
   #. Diabetes mellitus:
   - Continue insulin as per home regimen
   - FS QID
   - Check A1c
   .
   #. FEN:
   - OG tube in place
   - Follow lytes and replete PRN
   .
   #. Access:
   - Right groin swan ganz
   - Left groin with arterial sheath
   - Will attempt Aline
   .
   #. PPx: Heparin gtt, PPI, bowel regimen
   .
   #. Code: Full
   .
   #. Dispo: CCU for now

   stenotic lesion just after the LCx stent.  The pressure wire was placed
   in the LAD and became totally occluded.  Patient had chest discomfort
   with ST depressions on ECG and decrease in BP.  At that time the
   patient became hypotensive and bradycardic.  He received 2mg Atropine
   and subsequently developed VF.  CPR was initiated.  He received
   multiple shocks ([**5-5**]), amiodarone 300mg x 1 followed by 150mg x 1,
   epinephrine 2mg and lidocaine 100mg x1. Lopressor 5mg IVP. He was also
   started on an amiodarone gtt at 2mg/min decreased to 1mg/min and a
   lidocaine gtt at 2mg/min.  He was also intubated for airway protection.
    An IABP was inserted.  The LAD was reopened successfully and stented
   with a bare metal stent.  An echocardiogram was also done in the cath
   lab which showed normal LV, ? small segment of anterior hypokinesis.  A
   Swan showed PCWP of 35 after the case (initially was 15).

   Assessment and Plan
   76-year-old woman with history of T2DM, hypertension, hyperlipidemia,
   and CVA on warfarin was admitted to the CCU with torsade de pointes
   after disopyramide initiation and now s/p cardiac arrest in the setting
   of sustained VT.
   s/p Code Blue and Intubation
   Patient had episode of torsades that degenerated into VT last night and
   now stable on levophed and isoproterenol.
   - continue isoproterenol to target HR > 80 and carvedilol to increase
   membrane stability and decrease PVCs
   - wean levophed
   - obtain repeat ECG
   - will need to pull femoral line and place right IJ or subclavian line
   - wean sedation and extubate as soon as possible after right IJ line
   placement
   Torsades
   Patient started on disopyramide on saturday, and torsades is a known
   complication of this medication. Last dose of disopyramide was on [**2-6**]
   AM. Half life of disopyramide is 4-8 hours; so would expect
   disopyramide to be metabolized and at minimal concentrations within 24
   hours of last dose. Patient now back in sinus.
   - daily ECGs
   - continue magnesium q4h
   - continue to hold disopyramide
   - if torsades continues, recommend magnesium push, consideration of
   lidocaine
   - monitor on telemetry
   - appreciate EP recs
   Atrial fibrillation:
   New onset, with rapid ventricular rate, and patient now in sinus. Has
   been asymptomatic.
   - telemetry
   - continue carvedilol
   - heparin gtt pending breast biopsy and plan for cath and MVR
   - hold coumadin until all procedures are organized or done.
   - IV metoprolol or diltiazem as needed for rapid rates
   [**Last Name (un) 2406**]
   Cr 1.5 from baseline of 1.1. Likely to poor forward secondary to afib
   with RVR.
   - hold losartan and triamterene-HCTZ
   - control RVR as above
   - trend renal labs
   - renally dose meds as appropriate
   .
   Rheumatic Heart disease:
   This was diagnosed on this admission via ECHO. patient needs MV
   replacement and tricuspid repair per CT surgery. They will do this
   pending preop work up, including breast biopsy and cardiac
   catherization
   - Cardiac Surgery is following
   - heparin for now
   - will clarify if surgery will be inpatient this admission or as
   outpatient.
   Breast Mass: as seen on recent mammogram
   - patient on heparin gtt here, will try to get breast biopsy as
   inpatient. This was planned for [**2-7**] but will be delayed in the acute
   setting.
   - will call breast imaging to rearrange this after clarifyig that that
   is should be delayed.
   H/o CVA: holding home warfarin, on heparin gtt for now
   - will restart warfarin on discharge for both CVA and afib
   Diabetes Mellitus Type 2:
   - hold oral hypoglycemics
   - insulin s.s.
   HTN: Patient has a history of hypertension, although currently on
   levophed after the cardiac arrest.
   - holding anti-hypertensives
   - will restart anti-hypertensives as needed
   - wean levophed
   Fluid overload: Likely secondary to MVR. got lasix earlier this
   admission. No history of CHF, EF >55% on ECHO
   - lasix as needed
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:  Right femoral line
   - will pull femoral line and place right subclavian line
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: (Systemic anticoagulation: Heparin gtt)
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Chief Complaint:  PEA ARREST
   HPI:
   This is a 80y.o F with a PMH of ESRD on HD, CVA, diastolic CHF now
   admitted after PEA arrest. The patient presented to the ER with
   complaints of nausea/emesis and diarrhea for three days. Reported she
   was unable to tolerate po intake and felt weak and lethargic. She
   denied abd pain. Reported fever intermittently. Last HD on
   friday.
   .
   In the ED, initial vitals were T: 98.2 HR: 77 BP: 136/56 RR: 20 O2Sat:
   100% RA. Vancomycin 1gm and zosyn given. The patient then became
   unresponsive and was found to be pulseless. CPR was begun. Pt  was
   intubated. She received epi 1mg IV, atropine 1mg IV, Bicarb 1 amp IV,
   Calcium chloride 1amp IV, followed by second round of epi/atropine with
   return of spontaneous circulation after approx 8 minutes. She was them
   given versed 2mg IV for sedation and a R femoral line and NGT were
   placed. The artic sun was placed. She was plavix loaded with 300mg,
   given ASA 600mg PR. 30g kayexelate given. Head CT showed no acute
   process but evidence of chronic microvascular ischemic disease. CT A/P
   with no acute intaabdominal process but bilateral pulmonary infiltrates
   concerning for PNA or aspiration. CE returned elevated with CK 452 MB
   44 MBI 9.7 and Troponin 3.74. ABG 7.21/54/203/23. She was taken
   urgently to the cath lab.
   .
   Cardiac catheterization revealed LAD with 80% mid stenosis, RCA with
   70% proximal, 90% distal - both stented with 0% residual. Severe
   bilateral iliac stenosis. She was given 200mg IV lasix and NTG to
   reduce PCWP from 45mmg Hg to 40mg Hg and mean PA from 46 to 40mm Hg.
   CO 5.4, CI 3.1. The artic sun protocol was not continued given duration
   of patient's arrest and her return of spontaneous movement post cath.
   .
   The patient is now transferred to the CCU for further managment. On
   arrival to the CCU, dialysis was instituted.

   Assessment and Plan
   The pt. is an 80y.o F with a PMH of ESRD on HD, CVA, diastolic CHF now
   admitted after PEA arrest.
   .
   # PEA arrest - the patient presented with complaints of N/V, diarrhea
   and became bradycardic followed by PEA arrest. Pt regained rhythm with
   epi/atropine X2. Unclear precipitant for arrest. She had K recorded at
   7.6 (hemolyzed) repeat 5.9. Hyperkalemia was treated with kayexelate.
   No clear acidosis prior to arrest on labs, glucose 129. Pt with few
   risk factor for PE, makes less likely than acute cardiac ischemic
   event. The patient was found to have CK elevated to 452 with MBI 9.7
   and troponin 3.74. In cath lab the patient was found to have markedly
   elevated PCWP to 45mmg Hg and mean PA to 46 mm Hg. Hemodynamics
   improved with RCA stenting. Pt now s/p RCA PCI.
   - Continue ASA, Plavix
   - Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation
   - Given short duration of arrest approx 8 min with return of spont
   movement in cath lab, aortic sun protocol was deferred
   - Repeat TTE in am
   - Trend CK to peak
   - Wean sedation for neurological assessment
   - Monitor lytes, HD tonight for hyperkalemia and volume overload
   .
   # Multifocal Pulmonary infiltrate - CT demonstrated a diffuse
   consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration.
   - given unclear precipitant of PEA arrest, pt not clearly hypoxic on
   presentation but with initial elevated O2 requirement (FIO2 70%), CT
   with evidence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates - will cover with
   Vanc/Zosyn
   - obtain sputum cultures
   - consider dedicated chest CT when patient stable
   .
   #. ESRD on HD - Given markedly elevated PCWP and hyperkalemia, the
   patient was urgently dialyzed post-cath, continue to monitor lytes and
   fluid status
   .
   #. Chronic Diastolic CHF: Will repeat TTE in am to further evaluate
   systolic function and evidence of diastolic dysfunction. Hold
   metoprolol and losartan for now given unstable BP.
   .
   #. Hypertension - holding outpatient regimen of losartan, metoprolol,
   nifedipine while hypotensive
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism - continue synthroid
   .
   #. Orthostatic hypotension - on midodrine as outpatient after HD, will
   hold for now
   .
   #. FEN - NPO for now, monitor K
   .
   #. Access: R PA catheter
   .
   #. PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, heparin SC
   .
   #. Code:  FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  Pending clinical improvement
   .
   .

   Assessment and Plan
   The pt. is an 80y.o F with a PMH of ESRD on HD, CVA, diastolic CHF now
   admitted after PEA arrest.
   .
   # PEA arrest - the patient presented with complaints of N/V, diarrhea
   and became bradycardic followed by PEA arrest. Pt regained rhythm with
   epi/atropine X2. Unclear precipitant for arrest. She had K recorded at
   7.6 (hemolyzed) repeat 5.9. Hyperkalemia was treated with kayexelate.
   No clear acidosis prior to arrest on labs, glucose 129. Pt with few
   risk factor for PE, makes less likely than acute cardiac ischemic
   event. The patient was found to have CK elevated to 452 with MBI 9.7
   and troponin 3.74. In cath lab the patient was found to have markedly
   elevated PCWP to 45mmg Hg and mean PA to 46 mm Hg. Hemodynamics
   improved with RCA stenting. Pt now s/p RCA PCI.
   - Continue ASA, Plavix
   - Continue supportive management with mechanical ventilation
   - Given short duration of arrest approx 8 min with return of spont
   movement in cath lab, aortic sun protocol was deferred
   - Repeat TTE in am
   - Trend CK to peak
   - Wean sedation for neurological assessment
   - Monitor lytes, HD tonight for hyperkalemia and volume overload
   .
   # Multifocal Pulmonary infiltrate - CT demonstrated a diffuse
   consolidation of the lung bases with bronchial infiltration.
   - given unclear precipitant of PEA arrest, pt not clearly hypoxic on
   presentation but with initial elevated O2 requirement (FIO2 70%), CT
   with evidence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates - will cover with
   Vanc/Zosyn
   - obtain sputum cultures
   - consider dedicated chest CT when patient stable
   .
   #. ESRD on HD - Given markedly elevated PCWP and hyperkalemia, the
   patient was urgently dialyzed post-cath, continue to monitor lytes and
   fluid status
   .
   #. Chronic Diastolic CHF: Will repeat TTE in am to further evaluate
   systolic function and evidence of diastolic dysfunction. Hold
   metoprolol and losartan for now given unstable BP.
   .
   #. Hypertension - holding outpatient regimen of losartan, metoprolol,
   nifedipine while hypotensive
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism - continue synthroid
   .
   #. Orthostatic hypotension - on midodrine as outpatient after HD, will
   hold for now
   .
   #. FEN - NPO for now, monitor K
   .
   #. Access: R PA catheter
   .
   #. PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, heparin SC
   .
   #. Code:  FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  Pending clinical improvement
   .
   .

Chief Complaint:  PEA ARREST
   HPI:
   This is a 80y.o F with a PMH of ESRD on HD, CVA, diastolic CHF now
   admitted after PEA arrest. The patient presented to the ER with
   complaints of nausea/emesis and diarrhea for three days. Reported she
   was unable to tolerate po intake and felt weak and lethargic. She
   denied abd pain. Reported fever intermittently. Last HD on
   friday.
   .
   In the ED, initial vitals were T: 98.2 HR: 77 BP: 136/56 RR: 20 O2Sat:
   100% RA. Vancomycin 1gm and zosyn given. The patient then became
   unresponsive and was found to be pulseless. CPR was begun. Pt  was
   intubated. She received epi 1mg IV, atropine 1mg IV, Bicarb 1 amp IV,
   Calcium chloride 1amp IV, followed by second round of epi/atropine with
   return of spontaneous circulation after approx 8 minutes. She was them
   given versed 2mg IV for sedation and a R femoral line and NGT were
   placed. The artic sun was placed. She was plavix loaded with 300mg,
   given ASA 600mg PR. 30g kayexelate given. Head CT showed no acute
   process but evidence of chronic microvascular ischemic disease. CT A/P
   with no acute intaabdominal process but bilateral pulmonary infiltrates
   concerning for PNA or aspiration. CE returned elevated with CK 452 MB
   44 MBI 9.7 and Troponin 3.74. ABG 7.21/54/203/23. She was taken
   urgently to the cath lab.
   .
   Cardiac catheterization revealed LAD with 80% mid stenosis, RCA with
   70% proximal, 90% distal - both stented with 0% residual. Severe
   bilateral iliac stenosis. She was given 200mg IV lasix and NTG to
   reduce PCWP from 45mmg Hg to 40mg Hg and mean PA from 46 to 40mm Hg.
   CO 5.4, CI 3.1. The artic sun protocol was not continued given duration
   of patient's arrest and her return of spontaneous movement post cath.
   .
   The patient is now transferred to the CCU for further managment. On
   arrival to the CCU, dialysis was instituted.

   risk factor for PE, makes less likely than acute cardiac ischemic
   event. The patient was found to have CK elevated to 452 with MBI 9.7
   and troponin 3.74. In cath lab the patient was found to have markedly
   elevated PCWP to 45mmg Hg and mean PA to 46 mm Hg. Hemodynamics

   35% ([**8-2**]) s/p BiV pacemaker, AF on amiodarone, failed endovascular
   repair of AAA, R->L fem-fem bypass graft ([**2169**]) following resulting in
   R iliac dissection, AAA repair [**2172**]. He presents to CCU for
   milrinone/lasix/neosynephrine infusion for tx of CHF. Just prior to
   transfer, he had 1 minute of monomorphic VT at rate 110bpm that
   terminated spontaneously. He was unresponsive during the episode but
   did not require CPR or shocks. He is now stable, with SBP 100, HR 90.
   His exam is consistent with pulmonary edema, with bibasal crackles and
   wheezing. He has a Cr of 3.4, with baseline of 2. His electrolytes are

   to stop milrinone, give amio and call EP to consider VT ablation.

   A/P: 87 yoF w/ R heart failure, severe TR, severe pulmonary htn, PAF
   admitted with presyncope and nausea in the setting of uptitration of
   nodal agents and poor po intake now with unexplained hypoxia,
   hypotension, bradycardia, ARF, and supratherapeutic INR.
   Regarding her hypoxia, the cause is unclear. Worsened since admission.
   Main intervention has been IVF expansion but little evidence to suggest
   pulmonary edema. Suspect some contribution of severe pulmonary
   hypertension although would not explain acute worsening. Possibly
   related to R->L shunting from increased R sided filling pressures with
   volume expansion.
   Regarding her hypotension, bradycardia, and ARF, all presumed due to
   decreased po intake and increase in nodal agents 2 weeks ago. BPs
   improved after 4L IVF. HRs remains slow but presyncopal symptoms have
   improved. Unclear why Cr so variable during admission. Rare urine eos
   seen and urine Na 62 so may not be entirely prerenal in etiology.
   Patient does not want escalation of care. Wishes made clear that she is
   DNR/DNI. Good insight into her situation. Could consider trial of BiPAP
   but might worsen left sided filling given RV failure, TR, and pulm htn
   and unclear if will improve oxygenation dramatically w/o e/o pulm edema
   or underlying COPD.
   - cont high flow O2
   - consider trial of vasopressors to increase left sided afterload to
   see if improves oxygenation which would support diagnosis of R->L
   shunting
   - cont to hold BP meds and nodal agents
   - hold coumadin until INR<3
   - repeat TTE with bubbles in am

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 77 yo F w/ DMII, HTN, HLD, and dementia
   transferred from OSH s/p cardiac arrest, complicated by upper GI bleed
   and generalized seizure activity.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient with multiple risk factors for CAD including
   DMII, HTN, HLD. She is s/p cardiac arrest, likely VF in setting of AED
   shocks x2. Concern for antero-lateral NSTEMI given ST depressions in
   V2-V6 and TWI in I and aVL. She is s/p cardiac catherization at OSH
   which shows severe 3VD including critical left main disease. Patient
   with negative troponins at OSH, but positive troponins noted in setting
   of ACS vs. troponin leak from AED shocks. Patient would benefit from
   Arctic Sun protocol given recent VF arrest, stable hemodynamics, and
   current GCS scale of 9 (< 10). Relative contra-indications include
   active GIB, but per discussion with post arrest team, pt can be
   re-warmed if bleeding worsened. Head CT negative for acute ICH.
   Patient received full dose ASA yesterday.  Arctic sun was initiated
   after 9h, and was stopped after 2.5h due to bradycardia and torsade de
   pointes.
   - Continue aspirin, at 81mg daily given GIB
   - high dose statin
   - low dose beta-blocker (metoprolol 6.25 [**Hospital1 **])
   - continue heparin gtt without bolus
   - no plavix for now given GIB
   - rewarm patient
   .
   # Rhythm / Torsade de pointes / Bradycardia:  Patient was initiated on
   Arctic sun cooling protocol 9h after the second episode of cardiac
   arrest at OSH.  Patient developed bradycardia, QTc prolongation and
   torsade de pointes which deteriorated to VF, s/p cardioversion x3.  Pt
   loaded with lidocaine, on lidocaine gtt.  She also received 4gm
   magnesium.
   - continue lidocaine gtt
   - Mg bolus if pt goes back to torsade de pointes
   - cardioversion if pt goes back to torsade de pointes and if she
   continues to be full code
   - replete K > 4, Mg > 2
   - telemetry
   .
   # GI bleed: Likely UGIB in setting of anticoagulation received
   (heparin, ASA, plavix, integrillin). Patient on ASA at home, but no
   history of GI bleeds in the past. Patient is currently hemodynamically
   stable and receiving 2 U PRBCs. Guiac positive. Received 2u pRBC
   overnight.  Hct bumped appropriately from 31.8 to 37.2.  GI decided not
   to perform upper endoscopy given torsade de pointes.
   - active T&S
   - continue IV protonix gtt
   - has 2 PIVs and central line access
   - Hct checks [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue heparin gtt and aspirin given stable hct
   - f/u GI recs
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was initially hypertensive after being admitted
   to CCU.  After initiation of Arctic Sun, patient has been bradycardic
   and hypotensive.  Arctic sun stopped after 2.5h, and patient is being
   rewarmed.  Medication effects are also playing a role, including nitro
   gtt which was discontinued, lidocaine gtt also leads to hypotension.
   GIB likely also plays a role.  NS bolus did not help significantly.
   - start dopamine gtt if BP non-responsive to NS boluses
   - continue lidocaine gtt with the understanding that it would drop BP
   - maintain goal MAP>60, UOP >30cc/hr, goal CVP 10cm
   - GIB management as above
   .
   # PUMP:  unknown EF. Patient appears likely hypovolemic on exam in
   setting of recent UGIB.
   - TTE to assess for EF.
   .
   # Seizure: Patient noted to have generalized seizure activity upon
   arrival to CCU. No acute bleed on Head CT. [**Month (only) 8**] be in setting of hypoxia
   s/p VF arrest.  Patient was loaded with dilantin.
   - f/u on final CT head read
   - need EEG

   - IV ativan 2 mg PRN: seizure activity
   - seizure precautions
   .

Pt is a 77 yo F who presented from an OSH after a witnessed cardiac
   arrest at her nursing home. Patient lives at [**Location 1801**] x1 year.  Per
   report, she was sitting in a chair before dinner when she was noted to
   become blue, slumped down into her chair, and became unresponsive.
   Approximately 3 minutes elapsed before CPR was started. She was coded
   for 15 minutes, and reportedly had an AED placed with 1 shock prior to
   EMT arrival. A perfusing rhythm was obtained, and she was intubated in
   the field and taken to [**Hospital6 7184**].  At [**Hospital1 **] she
   again went into vfib, she was shocked into a ST, given amiodarone 300mg
   bolus, with no gtt  asa, heparin with bolus and gtt started,
   integrillin bolus with gtt started, plavix 600mg, and taken to the cath
   lab.  Cath revealed  80-90% LM, 50% Prox LAD, 50% mid LCX, 80-90%
   ostial, 95-99% mic distal RCA.  She was transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for CABG
   consult/further management.

   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 77 yo F w/ DMII, HTN, HLD, and dementia
   transferred from OSH s/p cardiac arrest, complicated by upper GI bleed
   and generalized seizure activity.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient with multiple risk factors for CAD including
   DMII, HTN, HLD. She is s/p cardiac arrest, likely VF in setting of AED
   shocks x2. Concern for antero-lateral NSTEMI given ST depressions in
   V2-V6 and TWI in I and aVL. She is s/p cardiac catherization at OSH
   which shows severe 3VD including critical left main disease. Patient
   with negative troponins at OSH, but positive troponins noted in setting
   of ACS vs. troponin leak from AED shocks. Patient would benefit from
   Arctic Sun protocol given recent VF arrest, stable hemodynamics, and
   current GCS scale of 9 (< 10). Relative contra-indications include
   active GIB, but per discussion with post arrest team, pt can be
   re-warmed if bleeding worsened. Head CT negative for acute ICH.
   Patient received full dose ASA yesterday.  Arctic sun was initiated
   after 9h, and was stopped after 2.5h due to bradycardia and torsade de
   pointes.
   - Continue aspirin, at 81mg daily given GIB
   - high dose statin
   - low dose beta-blocker (metoprolol 6.25 [**Hospital1 **])
   - rewarm patient
   - continue heparin gtt without bolus
   .
   # Rhythm / Torsade de pointes / Bradycardia:  Patient was initiated on
   Arctic sun cooling protocol 9h after the second episode of cardiac
   arrest at OSH.  Patient developed bradycardia, QTc prolongation and
   torsade de pointes which deteriorated to VF, s/p cardioversion x3.  Pt
   loaded with lidocaine, on lidocaine gtt.  She also received 4gm
   magnesium.
   - continue lidocaine gtt
   - Mg bolus if pt goes back to torsade de pointes
   - cardioversion if pt goes back to torsade de pointes and if she
   continues to be full code
   - replete K > 4 Mg > 2
   - telemetry
   .
   # GI bleed: Likely UGIB in setting of anticoagulation received
   (heparin, ASA, plavix, integrillin). Patient on ASA at home, but no
   history of GI bleeds in the past. Patient is currently hemodynamically
   stable and receiving 2 U PRBCs. Guiac positive. Received 2u pRBC
   overnight.  Hct bumped appropriately from 31.8 to 37.2.  GI decided not
   to perform upper endoscopy given torsade de pointes.
   - active T&S
   - IV protonix gtt
   - has 2 PIVs and central line access
   - Hct checks [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue heparin gtt and aspirin given stable hct
   - f/u GI recs
   .
   # Hypotension: Patient was initially hypertensive after being admitted
   to CCU.  After initiation of Arctic Sun, patient has been bradycardic
   and hypotensive.  Arctic sun stopped after 2.5h, and patient is being
   rewarmed.  Medication effects are also playing a role, including nitro
   gtt which was discontinued, lidocaine gtt also leads to hypotension.
   GIB likely also plays a role.
   - NS bolus prn
   - start dopamine gtt if BP non-responsive to NS boluses
   - continue lidocaine gtt with the understanding that it would drop BP
   - maintain goal MAP>60, UOP >30cc/hr
   - goal CVP 10cm
   - GIB management as above
   .
   # PUMP:  unknown EF. Patient appears likely hypovolemic on exam in
   setting of recent UGIB.
   - TTE to assess for EF.
   .
   # Seizure: Patient noted to have generalized seizure activity upon
   arrival to CCU. No acute bleed on Head CT. [**Month (only) 8**] be in setting of hypoxia
   s/p VF arrest.  Patient was loaded with dilantin.
   - f/u on final CT head read
   - f/u neuro recs
   - IV ativan 2 mg PRN: seizure activity
   - seizure precautions
   .
   #  HLD:
   - f/u fasting lipid panel
   .
   #  Diabetes Mellitus II:
   - hold metformin, continue ISS
   - f/u  HgA1c
   .
   #  Schizophrenia
   - continue risperdal
   .
   # Dementia:
   - continue Namenda
   .
   # PVD: s/p AAA repair
   - continue statin
