Chief Complaint:  s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   Pt is a 77 yo F with DMII, HTN, dementia, and paranoid schizophrenia
   who presented from an OSH after a witnessed cardiac arrest at her
   nursing home. Patient lives at [**Location 1801**] x1 year.  Per report, she was
   sitting in a chair before dinner when she was noted to become blue,
   slumped down into her chair, and became unresponsive. No report of
   chest pain or shortness of breath. She was carried back to her room,
   and approximately 3 minutes elapsed before CPR was started. She was
   coded for 15 minutes, and reportedly had an AED placed with 1 shock
   prior to EMT arrival. A perfusing rhythm was obtained, and she was
   intubated in the field and taken to [**Hospital6 7184**].
   .
   At OSH, pt's VS were 106/65 HR 100. EKG with ST depressions in V2-V6
   with no prior for comparison. She reportedly had another VF arrest 20
   minutes later, and was shocked at 200 J back in sinus tachycardia. She
   received 300 mg IV amiodarone x1. She then received ASA 325 mg PO x1,
   Plavix 600 mg PO x1, heparin gtt with bolus, integrillin gtt with
   bolus, and benadryl 25 mg IV x1. She underwent a cardiac catherization
   that showed a 90% left main stenosis, 60% proximal left circumflex, 80%
   RCA, 90% lesion followed by a long complex cork screw like 70% lesion
   in the proximal RCA.  Mid to distal RCA has a haze 95-99% lesion.  She
   was transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for evaluation of CABG.
   .
   In the CCU, patient is unable to answer ROS due to intubation and
   sedation. She was noted to have bleeding from groin site. Angiosheath
   was removed and pressure held with good effect. NG tube was noted to be
   draining ~250 ccs of dark, frothy, coffee-ground blood. Gastric lavage
   was + after 750 ccs of irrigation. Also noted to have upward deviated
   gaze and seizure-like activity (first shaking of the upper extremities,
   and then lower extremities, then tongue fasciculations). Neurology
   urgently consulted, recommended IV dilantin load and IV ativan
   (received 6 mg IV total) with good control of seizure activity. A-line,
   R IJ placed, and patient sent for non-contrast CT and CTA to assess for
   acute ICH prior to initiating Arctic Sun protocol.

   [**Year (4 digits) **] AND PLAN: 77 yo F w/ DMII, HTN, HLD, and dementia
   transferred from OSH s/p cardiac arrest, complicated by upper GI bleed
   and generalized seizure activity.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Patient with multiple risk factors for CAD including
   DMII, HTN, HLD. She is s/p cardiac arrest, likely VF in setting of AED
   shocks x2. Concern for antero-lateral NSTEMI given ST depressions in
   V2-V6 and TWI in I and aVL. She is s/p cardiac catherization at OSH
   which shows severe 3VD including critical left main disease. Patient
   with negative troponins at OSH, but positive troponins noted in setting
   of ACS vs. troponin leak from AED shocks. Patient would benefit from
   Arctic Sun protocol given recent VF arrest, stable hemodynamics, and
   current GCS scale of 9 (< 10). Relative contra-indications include
   active GIB, but per discussion with post arrest team, pt can be
   re-warmed if bleeding worsened. Head CT negative for acute ICH.
   Patient received full dose ASA yesterday.  Arctic sun was initiated
   after 9h, and was stopped after 2.5h due to bradycardia and torsade de
   pointes.
   - continue heparin gtt without bolus
   - will give aspirin 81mg, high dose statin, plavix and low dose BB
   (metoprolol 6.25 [**Hospital1 **]) once pt is able to take PO meds from GIB stand
   point.
   - rewarm patient
   .
   # VF Arrest:  It appears that the first episode of VF arrest in the
   nursing home was related to ischemia.  However, the later VF arrest in
   OSH ED and the 4 episodes of VF overnight last night were due to
   re-perfusion given normalization of EKG, and no evidence of troponin
   elevation.  Pt loaded with lidocaine, on lidocaine gtt.  She also
   received 4gm magnesium.
   - continue lidocaine gtt, decrease to 1mg/min
   - cardioversion if pt goes back to VF and if she continues to be full
   code
   - replete K > 4, Mg > 2
   - telemetry
   .
   # Anoxic brain injury: Patient noted to have generalized seizure
   activity upon arrival to CCU. No acute bleed on Head CT. [**Month (only) 8**] be in
   setting of hypoxia after the 1st VF arrest.  Patient was loaded with
   dilantin. Patient was initiated on Arctic sun cooling protocol 9h after
   the second episode of cardiac arrest at OSH.  Patient developed
   bradycardia, QTc prolongation and VF, s/p cardioversion x3, arctic sun
   was therefore stopped.
   - d/c all sedating meds, including versed and phentanyl
   - f/u on final CT head read
   - need EEG to further assess neuro function
   - f/u neuro recs
   - IV ativan 2 mg PRN: seizure activity
   - seizure precautions
   .
   # GI bleed: Likely UGIB in setting of anticoagulation received
   (heparin, ASA, plavix, integrillin). Patient on ASA at home, but no
   history of GI bleeds in the past. Patient is currently hemodynamically
   stable and receiving 2 U PRBCs. Guiac positive. Received 2u pRBC
   overnight.  Hct bumped appropriately from 31.8 to 37.2.  GI decided not
   to perform upper endoscopy given VF episodes.
   - active T&S

   - has 2 PIVs and central line access

   - continue heparin gtt
   - f/u GI recs on when pt can start to take PO meds

   # Hypotension: Patient was initially hypertensive after being admitted
   to CCU.  After initiation of Arctic Sun, patient has been bradycardic
   and hypotensive.  Arctic sun stopped after 2.5h, and patient is being
   rewarmed.  Medication effects are also playing a role, including nitro

normal. The LAD gave rise to a long, high D1 branch which
travelled as
part of a "twin LAD" system, referred to as ramus intermedius on
prior operative note.  The true LAD gave off few true branches
and had
mild disease only. The large D1 had a proximal 30% lesion only
and competitive flow distally.  The dominant LCx system and
non-dominant
RCA had only mild luminal disease as well.
  2. Graft arteriography revealed the LIMA-diagonal (or ramus
intermedius) to be patent.
  3. Resting hemodynamic measurements revealed normal righ sided
filling
pressures, mildly elevated pulmonary artery pressures and
elevated left
heart filling pressures with a mean PCWP of 24 mmHg and LVEDP of
mmHg.  There was a mean pressure gradient of 8.4 mmHg across the
bioprosthetic mitral valve (as measured between the PCWP and LV
pressure
tracngs), for a calculated valve area of 1.6 cmsq.  Cardiac
output and
index were preserved at 6.1 L/min and 3.4 L/min/m2 respectively.
There
was no gradient across the aortic valve upon catheter pullback
from the
left ventricle.
  4. Left ventriculography revealed severe anteroapical
hypokinesis and
milder inferior hypokinesis with an ejection fraction calculated
at 36%.
No mitral regurgitation was observed.

neck or
arm discomforts were reported by the patient during the
procedure. No

rhythm was
atrial fibrillation with occasional isolated VPDs. Possible rare
aberration was noted (?[**Last Name (un) 14338**] beats). The hemodynamic response
to the
Persantine infusion was appropriate. Post-infusion the patient

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
81F PMH coronary artery disease, s/p CABG/MVR, atrial
fibrillation on coumadin, CHF (EF 30%), COPD, and chronic renal
insufficiency, admitted with dyspnea, found to have wide complex
tachycardia s/p DCCV and amiodarone, and who had the development
of a different wide complex tachycardia treated with DCCV. Based
on assessment of her ECGs, she appears to have been in an SVT
with aberrancy on arrival to the ED, which appears to be a short
RP tachycardia possibly AVNRT vs atrial tachycardia.  The wide
QRS in this setting is most likely due to her acidosis at the
time, although it may also have an element of delayed conduction
in the His-Purkinje system.  Upon cardioversion attempt on
amiodarone, she appears to have gone into a wide complex more
consistent with VT, which was subsequently converted with repeat
DCCV (her PVCs have this similar morphology, which localized to
the lateral LV probably around the site of her aneurysm).  At
this point, the most pressing cardiac issues in this patient
concern prevention of future arrhythmias, treatment of her CHF,
which is probably NYHA class III/IV, and management of her
ongoing GI bleed in the setting of chronic anticoagulation.
Based on her goals as stated to her PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] is DNR, and would
thus probably not be a candidate for an ICD.  Continuing
amiodarone is not unreasonable for prevention of VT, although the
most important issue for the likely SVT will be continuing nodal
agents.  EPS may also be useful, as she could potentially be
cured of the AVNRT if this is the etiology, although again this
may not be consistent with her goals.  As far as her CHF, she is
reasonably euvolemic, and in the setting of probable ischemia
colitis, would probably not diurese her too aggressively for now.
Would continue antibiotics and maintain euvolemia, monitor Hct
and further GI symptoms/bleeding, and follow recs as per surgery
or GI.  Once her GI issues are stable and she has less evidence
of end-organ damage, might consider diuresis and initiation of
treatments for her CHF (Imdur/hydral given her history of CRF and
hypovolemia previously). As far as her positive cardiac
biomarkers, these are probably due to demand rather than an acute
coronary syndrome, and should be trended to decrease.  Given her
ongoing GI bleed, would avoid any additional
anticoagulation/antiplatelets, but would try to keep her on
aspirin if possible.  Overall, her goals of care will probably be
the most pressing point.  She could and probably should undergo a
cath on this admission, if that is something she would want.  If
not, then hospice, etc. should be discussed.
The Assessment and Plan will be reviewed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in
multi- disciplinary rounds.  Please see his/her note in the
[**Hospital 7382**] medical record for further comments and
recommendations.  Thank you for allowing us to participate in the
care of this patient. Please feel free to contact us with any
questions or concerns.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo female with history of CHF (EF 30%), Afib on coumadin, s/p CABG
   presents with dyspnea and CP, found to be hypotensive. Cardioverted for
   ?aflutter, developed v-tach, defibrillated, returned to NSR. CTAb
   showed equivocal colitis. Admitted to MICU for hypotension.
   .
   # Shock. Likely secondary to dehydration in setting of anorexia and
   nausea, together with recent rapid ventricular rates, and baseline
   impaired cardiac function (given mild pulmonary vascular congestion on
   CXR, chronic CHF). Baseline bp appears low (syst in 80s at clinic).
   Differential also includes sepsis, especially in setting of mild
   leukocytosis and colitis seen on CT, though afebrile and WBC not
   significantly elevated.
   - Vasodilatory source: colitis
        - treat with vanco/flagyl/ceftriaxone; follow exam
        - appreciate surgery recs
        - trend lactate
        - check C. Diff
        - follow blood, urine cultures
   - Hypovolemic source: dehydration (pt appears generally volume
   depleted)
        - fluid boluses to maintain UOP and MAP goal of >55 then to
   maintenance fluids when 50 cc/hr UOP achieved
   - Cardiogenic (baseline CHF with low EF, together with superimposed
   arrhythmia)
        - check TTE
        - PE unlikely given supratherapeutic INR
   # Tachy-arrhythmia. Pt with possible a-flutter and RVR initially,
   developed VTach after synchronized cardioversion, returned to NSR with
   defib. Cardiology and EP saw pt in ED.
   - Continue amiodarone gtt, move to PO amiodarone if long term control
   needed
   - Consider AICD
   - Maintain K > 4 (watch renal function though), Mg > 2
   - If persistently hypotensive despite fluid resuscitation, will
   discontinue amiodarone and return to lopressor
   - Restart Coumadin for A-fib when INR within therapeutic range
   .
   # Subacute renal failure. Creatinine 3.2, baseline 1.1 but was elevated
   [**4-29**] to 3.3 (pt refused to seek medical attention at time). Likely
   prerenal in setting of dehydration/chronic CHF with intravascular
   depletion. Foley in place. Urine lytes: BUN 506, Cr 94, Na < 10, FeNa
   about 0.2% implies likely prerenal etiology.
   - Continue gentle fluid boluses and monitor UOP; trend creatinine and
   monitor UOP
   - Renally dose medications
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Hold ACE-I and diuretics
   .
   # NSTEMI. Elevated troponins, CK-MB, anterior TWI on EKG. In setting of
   acute illness, tachycardia
   - Cycle enzymes
   - Manage CAD as below
   - Continue atorvastatin, ASA
   - Repeat ECG
   - Anticoagulation if continued enzyme rise
   .
   # Hepatitis. s/p cholecystectomy. Elevated LFTs likely in setting of
   shock liver.
   - Trend LFTs; manage hypotension (see above)
   - NPO for now
   - Hepatitis viral panel if persistent elevation
   # Abdominal pain/colitis on CT (prelim read). Surgery consulted,
   recommend continue resuscitation, enema, trend labs/lactate, empiric
   abx. Pt is s/p cholecystectomy.
   - Appreciate surgery recs, will follow with serial exams
   - Gentle enema given impaction, colace / senna
   - Trend lactate
   - Empiric IV abx for now as above
   - Follow up final read ab/pelvis CT
   .
   # GIB. Guaiac positive stools
   - Follow Hct.
   .
   # CHF
   - Hold lasix while hypotensive
   - Hold Metoprolol, ACE-I, spironolactone while hypotensive
   .
   # Obstructive lung disease/allergic rhinitis
   - Continue albuterol, cromolyn spray
   - Continue fluticasone nasal spray and inhaler
   - Continue benadryl
   .
   # Anxiety
   - Continue fluoxetine; hold trazodone for now
   .
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, NPO for now (regular heart
   healthy diet when taking POs). Folate.
   # Prophylaxis: SCH, pneumoboots
   # Access: 2 peripherals
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  DNR DNI but consider less aggressive interventions such as
   cardiovert/defib if short-term return to baseline status (see OMR note
   [**5-12**] by PCP [**Doctor Last Name **] for full discussion)

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo F with CHF (EF 30%), CAD, Asthma/COPD, presents with dyspnea,
   found to be in ventricular tachycardia and atrial flutter, now s/p
   cardioversion and defibrillation in sinus rhythm with hypotension.
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock: Suspect that the patient is dehydrated (possibly
   due to poor po intake and diarrhea) and that this is the cause of her
   hypotension. Infection and sepsis are also a possibility given lactate
   of 7 and leukocytosis. The patient does not appear to be in cardiogenic
   shock now that her rhythm is no longer tachycardic.
   - Check blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Follow up final read of CT Ab/Pelv
   - Hold off on antihypertensives for now
   - Bolus for low BP's
   - Consider CVL and pressors if BP refractory to IVF boluses
   - Continue flagyl for now given diarrhea
   - Repeat venous lactate
   - Check pulsus
   -Check ECHO in am
   .
   # NSTEMI:  Seen by cardiology in ED, does not have evidence of evolving
   ST changes on EKG. Given guaiac positive stool will hold off on heparin
   since pt has signs of
demand
 ischemia secondary to malignant rhythm
   from earlier in the day.
   - Cardiology consult in am
   - ECHO
   - Trend cardiac enzymes
   .
   # Atrial flutter/Ventricular tachycardia: In the ED the pt was found to
   be in atrial flutter that converted to Vtach with 100J, and then
   converted to sinus with 200J. Suspect that pt's baseline afib was
   aggravated by dehydration/hypovolemia. Of note, on an old EP study they
   were able to induce VT, likely due to old MI scar.
   - Pt is currently bradycardic and hypotensive, hold beta blocker for
   now
   - Cardiology consult in am
   - Replete K and Mg aggressively
   .
   # Colitis: Evidence of stranding and colonic thickening raise concern
   for colitis. Pt reports that she has had intermittent non-bloody
   diarrhea, but did not have tenderness on exam.
   - Continue flagyl for now
   - Send stool cultures
   - Serial abdominal exams
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Pt's creatinine was 3.2 on admission, stable
   from [**2106-4-29**], but significantly elevated compared to prior values in
   the mid 2's. Suspect that this is a combination of prerenal renal
   failure in addition to likely poor forward flow in the setting of heart
   failure. There also may be a component of ATN since the pt was found
   hypotensive in the 60's systolic at home.
   - Check urine lytes, urine culture
   - Hold lisinopril, spironolactone, lasix for now
   .
   # Hepatitis: Suspect that the elevation of the pt's LFTs (transaminases
   and LDH) are a reflection of shock liver in the setting of recent
   hypotension. At a recent clinic visit the pt's BP was noted to be in
   the 80's systolic on [**4-29**]. There also may be a congestive hepatopathy
   component given pt's cogestive heart failure. Of note, the pt does have
   a chronically elevated common bile duct that now measures >20cm in
   diameter. This may represent a retained stone, however alk phos and
   bili are normal so cholangitis, choledocholithiasis seem unlikely.
   - Trend LFT's for now
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: On coumadin, with a supratherapeutic INR here.
   Since the pt was guaiac positive in ED will plan to hold coumadin
   tonight.
   - Currently rate controlled, consider re-starting beta-blocker once pt
   is no longer hypotensive.
   .
   # Guaiac positive maroon stool: Hct is stable, but this may be falsely
   elevated secondary to hypovolemia/dehydration. Pt denies hematemesis,
   melena. There was no evidence of diverticulitis on CT ab.
   - Trend hct q8h
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T+S
   - Two large bore PIVs
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, regular diet

Chief Complaint:
   GI BLeed
   Atrial Fibrillation
   V-tach on cardioversion
   Acute Renal Failure
   HPI:
   81 yo F with a history of CHF (EF 30%), afib on coumadin, s/p CABG
   presents with dyspnea. This morning called EMS, EMS found pt
   hypotensive, with pulse in 170s, gave pt 150mg amiodarone and aspirin
   in the field. The pt reports that she has had worsening SOB for several
   days, but denies PND, DOE or orthopnea. Denies fever, chills, rigors,
   night sweats. Endorses anorexia, weight loss, fatigue. Denies urinary
   symptoms. Endorses diarrhea for approximately a month.
   .
   In ED, initial vital signs were: 98.8 61/39, 168, 23, 100% on NRB. In
   ED appeared uncomfortable, minimally tender in the epigastrium, found
   to have maroon guaiac positive stools, 2+ non-pitting edema
   bilaterally. On EKG appeared to be in aflutter, given midazolam,
   cardioverted with 100J initially, then went into VTACH, defib with
   200J, converted to NSR. Labs significant for hypoperfusion, CXR appears
   to be c/w CHF, pulmonary edema. CTAb showed equivocal colitis. Covered
   with vanco/flagyl, got levoflox then developed a rash so levoflox was
   stopped. Got 150mg IV amiodarone after cardioversion, now on amiodarone
   gtt. Surgery consult for increased lactate. Cardiology, EP looked at
   EKG, rhythm strip, no recommendations.
   Chest pain
   Assessment:
   - complains of [**11-21**] chest pain X 3, describes feeling as crushing
like a [**Doctor Last Name **] on my chest
 at same time pt c/o sob
   Action:
   - morphine 2mg IVP
   - Albuterol inhaler and atrovent neb PRN
   - Albuterol changed to xopenex neb
   Response:
   - good response after morphine and nebs, patient calms down and able to
   catch breath
   - pt continues to have shortness of breath with activity and at times
   during conversation
   - O2sats maintained 96-100%
   Plan:
   - continue to assess/treat chest pain and respiratory status
   - nebs and morphine PRN
   Cholecystitis, acalculous
   Assessment:
   - abdominal pain and tenderness to palpation
   - abdomen soft + BS
   Action:
   - ducolox suppository given
   - diet changed to full liquids
   Response:
   - pt refusing to eat any of tray, will drink tea and water
   - no bm at this time
   Plan:
   - continue to give bowel regimen, encourage PO intake
   .H/O tachycardia, Other
   Assessment:
   - pt in sinus rhythm, HR 50s-80s
   - frequent PVCs and PACs
   Action:
   - K repleted
   - pm lytes sent
   - ecg done
   - echo done, EP consulted
   - amiodarone gtt stopped at 1600
   - pt started on PO Amiodarone 1600
   Response:
   - less frequent PVCs and PACs after electrolyte repletion
   - pm K 3.3
 given 40meq Po divided doses
   - lactate, liver enzymes, Ck, and Creatinine trending down
   - HR/rhythm unchanged
   Plan:
   - continue to monitor HR/rhythm
   - monitor electrolytes
   - follow up with cardiology about echo results

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo F with CHF (EF 30%), CAD, Asthma/COPD, presents with dyspnea,
   found to be in ventricular tachycardia and atrial flutter, now s/p
   cardioversion and defibrillation in sinus rhythm with hypotension.
   .
   # Hypotension: Suspect that the patient is dehydrated (possibly due to
   poor po intake and diarrhea) and that this is the cause of her
   hypotension. Infection and sepsis are also a possibility given lactate
   of 7 and leukocytosis. The patient does not appear to be in cardiogenic
   shock now that her rhythm is no longer tachycardic.
   - Check blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Follow up final read of CT Ab/Pelv
   - Hold off on antihypertensives for now
   - Bolus for low BP's
   - Consider CVL and pressors if BP refractory to IVF boluses
   - Continue flagyl for now given diarrhea
   - Repeat venous lactate
   .
   # Atrial flutter/Ventricular tachycardia: In the ED the pt was found to
   be in atrial flutter that converted to Vtach with 100J, and then
   converted to sinus with 200J. Suspect that pt's baseline afib was
   aggravated by dehydration/hypovolemia. Of note, on an old EP study they
   were able to induce VT, likely due to old MI scar.
   - Pt is currently bradycardic and hypotensive, hold beta blocker for
   now
   - Consider EP consult
   - Replete K and Mg aggressively
   .
   # Colitis: Evidence of stranding and colonic thickening raise concern
   for colitis. Pt reports that she has had intermittent non-bloody
   diarrhea, but did not have tenderness on exam.
   - Continue flagyl for now
   - Send stool cultures
   - Serial abdominal exams
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Pt's creatinine was 3.2 on admission, stable
   from [**2106-4-29**], but significantly elevated compared to prior values in
   the mid 2's. Suspect that this is a combination of prerenal renal
   failure in addition to likely poor forward flow in the setting of heart
   failure. There also may be a component of ATN since the pt was found
   hypotensive in the 60's systolic at home.
   - Check urine lytes, urine culture
   - Hold lisinopril, spironolactone, lasix for now
   .
   # Hepatitis: Suspect that the elevation of the pt's LFTs (transaminases
   and LDH) are a reflection of shock liver in the setting of recent
   hypotension. At a recent clinic visit the pt's BP was noted to be in
   the 80's systolic on [**4-29**]. There also may be a congestive hepatopathy
   component given pt's cogestive heart failure. Of note, the pt does have
   a chronically elevated common bile duct that now measures >20cm in
   diameter. This may represent a retained stone, however alk phos and
   bili are normal so cholangitis, choledocholithiasis seem unlikely.
   - Trend LFT's for now
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation: On coumadin, with a supratherapeutic INR here.
   Since the pt was guaiac positive in ED will plan to hold coumadin
   tonight.
   - Currently rate controlled, consider re-starting beta-blocker once pt
   is no longer hypotensive.
   .
   # Guaiac positive maroon stool: Hct is stable, but this may be falsely
   elevated secondary to hypovolemia/dehydration. Pt denies hematemesis,
   melena. There was no evidence of diverticulitis on CT ab.
   - Trend hct q8h
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Active T+S
   - Two large bore PIVs
   .

81 yo F with a history of CHF (EF 30%), afib on coumadin, s/p CABG
   presents with dyspnea. This morning called EMS, EMS found pt
   hypotensive, with pulse in 170s, gave pt 150mg amiodarone and aspirin
   in the field. The pt reports that she has had worsening SOB for several
   days, but denies PND, DOE or orthopnea. Denies fever, chills, rigors,
   night sweats. Endorses anorexia, weight loss, fatigue. Denies urinary
   symptoms. Endorses diarrhea for approximately a month.
   .
   In ED, initial vital signs were: 98.8 61/39, 168, 23, 100% on NRB. In
   ED appeared uncomfortable, minimally tender in the epigastrium, found
   to have maroon guaiac positive stools, 2+ non-pitting edema
   bilaterally. On EKG appeared to be in aflutter, given midazolam,
   cardioverted with 100J initially, then went into VTACH, defib with
   200J, converted to NSR. Labs significant for hypoperfusion, CXR appears
   to be c/w CHF, pulmonary edema. CTAb showed equivocal colitis. Covered
   with vanco/flagyl, got levoflox then developed a rash so levoflox was
   stopped. Got 150mg IV amiodarone after cardioversion, now on amiodarone
   gtt. Surgery consult for increased lactate. Cardiology, EP looked at
   EKG, rhythm strip, no reccommendations. On transfer, VS were 102/49, P
   60, 19, 100% 3.5L. No has 2 PIVs. Has gotten 1750 cc IVF, 200 cc in
   foley.
   .H/O tachycardia, Other
   Assessment:
   -          pt arrived to SICU approx 1630 sinus bradycardic,  pvcs
   -          hypotensive
   -          low urine output
   -          denies shortness of breath, breathing is regular and not
   labored
   -          alert, oriented X 3
   Action:
   -          received 500cc bolus NS X 2
   -          urine sent
   -          K running
   -          labs drawn
 only able to get covac, needs cbc to be drawn
   -          Amiodarone gtt running at 1mg/min
   Response:
   -          not responding to fluid, pt remains hypotensive sbp low 80s
 team aware
   -          remains bradycardic hr drops to 45 at times
 team aware
   Plan:
   -          continue to monitor respiratory status
   -          monitor bp and urine output
   -          monitor HR/rhythm, continue Amiodarone gtt at 1mg/min

 deformity to the right inferior ribs which may be related to patient's prior
 surgical procedure.

 perforation.  Nasogastric tube in stomach and a femoral line projecting over
 the patient's right pelvis.

 CT CHEST WITHOUT CONTRAST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  39-year-old man with pneumothorax after chest compression,
 unable to place bedside chest tube, mechanical ventilation and ongoing risk
 for tension pneumothorax, please place chest tube.

 TECHNIQUE:  Chest MDCT of the upper two-thirds of the chest was performed
 using 5-mm axial slice thickness.

 FINDINGS:  This study was performed for localization prior to chest tube
 placement.

 In comparison to earlier today, there is no residual pneumothorax.  One tiny
 air bubble is in the anterior mediastinum.  Note that only the upper two-
 thirds of the chest were covered.  There is no pericardial effusion or
 mediastinal hematoma.  Subcutaneous hematoma was not included in the field of
 view.

 There is no other change since earlier today in bilateral dependent opacities,
 right peribronchial consolidation, severe cardiomegaly and rib fractures.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No residual pneumothorax in the upper two-thirds of the chest.  One
 residual air bubble in the mediastinum.  No chest tube was installed.

 2.  No other change since earlier today.

                                                             (Over)

History of present illness: 39M w/ pmh significant for ebstein's
   anomaly s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided
   systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with palpitations which
   awoke him from sleep.  The patient presented to the ED where he
   appeared pale and was found to be in VT to the 230's. He began to
   experience chest pain and was given amiodarone 150mg IV X1, followed by
   amiodarone gtt.  He became diaphoretic and was therefore given
   etomidate and shocked with 200J.  His rhythm then became fine V-fib, he
   became unresponsive and apneic.  CPR was initiated, epinephrine given
   X1, CPR continued, shocked again at 360J, returned to V-Tach @ 240,
   Intubated, returned to sinus rhyhthm, aspirated vomitus.  had right
   bronchus intubation and ETT was pulled back in ED. Blood pressures
   dropped to 48/43, started on levophed, pressure increased to 124/77.
   .
   On presentation to the CCU [**3-7**], the patient is intubated with mottled
   skin, on levophed, neosynephrine and vasopressin, with HR 85 and BP
   125/77. Remains intubated with Aspiration PNA & ?Failure-requiring
   fio2-100% & PEEP up 16.. Pressors weaned to Levophed & Vasopressin.
   Chest Tube insertion for right pneumothorac-unsuccessful-resolved on
   own.
   Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS, Acute Lung Injury, [**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   Assessment:
   Lung sounds diminished throughout. Sx
minimal thick tannish
   secretions. Sat
s low 88-91% with PO2 70-80. CXR-Aspiration PNA,
   resolved pneumothorac, & ?failure. Renal Failure with elevated Creat &
   decreased urinary output.
   Action:
   Adjusted vent settings with goal maintaining sat >90. Pulm toilet.
   Lasix sm doses to gently diurese.
   Response:
   Sats <90% despite Peep-16. Fio2 remain @ 100%. Po2 mid 70
s Without
   response to Lasix 10mg then 20mg ivp.
   Plan:
   ?Pulm Consult. Contin adjust vent to optimized resp status. ?PA Line
   placement to determine volume status. ?Continue diuresis attempt with
   Lasix.
   .H/O heart disease, congenital
   Assessment:
   Tele: SR w/ freq runs VT. Episodes of Sustained Slow VT-130
s with
   stable BP.
   Action:
   EKG with rhythm strip. Rebolus with Amiodarone X2-1^st 300mg  with
   repat 150mg with resolution of rhythm.Amiodarone gtt increased to
   1.0mg/min. with episode received 500ml NS.
   Response:
   Post second bolus & gtt increase without further episodes of Slow VT.
   Plan:
   EP consult. Contin Amiodarone gtt.
   Fever, unknown origin (FUO, Hyperthermia, Pyrexia)
   Assessment:
   Remains febrile. T Max-101.8 po. Cultured previous shift. BCx2 sent
   with Am labs.
   Action:
   500cc fluid bolus given- levophed gtt @ .4mcq/kg/min & vasopressin gtt
   @ 2.4u/hr- Blood cultures X2, U/A C&S obtained & sent to lab- started
   on zosyn.
   Response:
   MAPs > 60
   Plan:
   Maintain MAPs >60- tritrate gtts accordingly.

Date of service: [**2151-3-8**]
   Initial consultation: CCU
   Presenting complaint: Arrhythmia
   History of present illness: 39 yo M with PMH of ebstein's anomaly s/p
   tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided congestive heart
   failure, presenting with palpitations which awoke him from sleep. The
   patient presented to the ED morning of [**2151-3-7**] where he was found to be
   in VT 230bpm. He began to experience chest pain, given amiodarone 150mg
   IV x 1, followed by amio gtt. He became diaphoretic, given etomidate
   and shocked with 200J, followed by vifib, becoming unresponsive and
   apneic. CPR was initiated, epinephrine x 1, CPR continued, shocked at
   360J, returning to vtach @ 240. He was intubated, returning to sinus
   rhythm, aspriating vomit; noted to have right bronchus intubation and
   ETT repositioned. Due to hypotension SBP 40's started on levophed,
   neosynephrine, and vasopressin with BP increasing to 124/77.
   Subsequently developed left pneumothroax with attempted chest tube
   placement failed, had esophageal ballon placed. Early this morning had
   two recurrent runs of a WCT for which he was treated with amiodarone
   300mg IV then with the second run received 100mg IV lidocaine with
   initiation of lidocaine gtt.  EP consultation for management of
   ventricular tachyarrythmias.
   Past medical history: 1. Ebstein anomaly s/p TV reconstruction
     -- moderate to severe TR
     --RHF, RVEF 25% in [**6-/2149**]
   2. ASD s/p primary closure [**3-/2136**]
   3. LHF with evidence of noncompaction of LV, with LVEF 28% in [**6-/2149**]
   4. Hyperlipidemia
   5. HTN
   6. OSA/Obesity
   7. DVT
   8. Superficial phlebitis
   9. Endocarditis w/ septic emboli to brain prior to Cardiac surgery
   CAD Risk Factors
   CAD Risk Factors Present
   Dyslipidemia, Hypertension
   CAD Risk Factors Absent
   Diabetes mellitus, Family Hx of CAD, Family Hx of sudden cardiac death

   and shocked with 200J, followed by vifib, becoming unresponsive and
   apneic. CPR was initiated, epinephrine x 1, CPR continued, shocked at
   360J, returning to vtach @ 240. He was intubated, returning to sinus
   rhythm, aspriating vomit; noted to have right bronchus intubation and
   ETT repositioned. Due to hypotension SBP 40's started on levophed,
   neosynephrine, and vasopressin with BP increasing to 124/77.
   Subsequently developed left pneumothroax with attempted chest tube
   placement failed, had esophageal ballon placed. Early this morning had
   two recurrent runs of a WCT for which he was treated with amiodarone
   300mg IV then with the second run received 100mg IV lidocaine with
   initiation of lidocaine gtt.  EP consultation for management of
   ventricular tachyarrythmias.

   39 yo [**Male First Name (un) 1983**] with PMH of Ebstein's anomaly s/p reconstruction, ASD s/p
   repair ([**2136**]), LV noncompaction, biventricular heart failure, morbid
   obesity, obstructive sleep apnea
   who is in critical condition following presentation with a wide complex
   tachycardia likely originating from sites of his past intracardiac
   surgery repairs, at this time requiring vasopressor

   with cardiopulmonary support with continuation ofamiodarone and

   with repletion as necessary. To discuss with EP attending regarding

   ------ Protected Section ------
   Patient seen, discussed and examined with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3658**]. The etiology of
   his VT remains uncertain, likely secondary to CM, since ASD repair and
   tricuspid ring wouldn not be expected to give an RVOT type VT. Also a
   question of whether his has junctional tachycardia secondary to meds or
   SVT due to a bypass tract, which is common in Ebsteins anomaly. Cause
   of myopathy uncertain, but possibly, tachy related. He will need an EPS
   when Hemodynamically stable. He may do better in NSR so I will give
   adenosine to stop current rhythm.

 fraction was mildly decreased at 42%.  The anteroseptal and inferolateral wall
 thicknesses were normal. There were prominent trabeculations from the mid to
 apical segments of the left ventricle with maximum ratio of non-compacted
 myocardium to compacted myocardium during diastole of 3.5 in the mid
 inferolateral wall. This is consistent with diagnosis of LV non-compaction.
 The left ventricular mass index was normal (excluding volume of non compacted
 ventricle). The inter-ventricular septum was flattened (D-shape) in diastole
 consistent with RV volume overload.
 The functional right ventricular end-diastolic volume index was mildly
 increased.  The calculated right ventricular ejection fraction of the
 functional RV was severely decreased at 29%. The right ventricular end-
 diastolic volume index of the structural RV (including atrialized RV) was
 severely increased.  The calculated right ventricular ejection fraction of the
 structural RV was severely decreased at 35%
 The aortic valve was tri-leaflet with normal valve area. The tricuspid valve
 had abnormalities consistent with Ebstein's anomaly with mobile leaflets, a
 mobile posterior that was markedly displaced apically. A well seated tricuspid
 annuloplasty ring was present. A signal void was seen in the anatomic right
 atrium during systole consistent with tricuspid regurgitation.

 Quantitative Flow
 There was no significant intra-cardiac shunt.  Aortic flow demonstrated mild
 aortic regurgitation.  The calculated mitral valve regurgitant fraction was
 consistent with no mitral regurgitation. The resultant effective forward LVEF
 was mildly decreased at 41%.
 The right ventricular stroke volume and pulmonic flow demonstrated no
 significant pulmonic regurgitation. Using volumetric data from the functional
 RV, there was moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Using volumetric data from the
 structural RV, there was severe tricuspid regurgitation through the tricuspid
 annulus.

 Non-Cardiac Findings
 The patient is s/p sternotomy. Also noted are slight anterior wedge
 compression fractures in the lower thoracic spine, with narrowing of
 intervening disc space, similar to previous CMR findings on [**2149-7-2**].

 Impression:
 1. Normal left ventricular cavity size with mild global left ventricular
 hypokinesis. The LVEF was mildly decreased at 42%. The effective forward LVEF
 was mildly decreased at 41%.  Prominent non-compacted left ventricular
 myocardium that meet CMR criteria for non-compaction.
 2. Mild functional right ventricular enlargement with evidence of RV volume
 overload. Severe structural RV enlargement. Severe right ventricular systolic
 dysfunction with RVEF at 29%. Severely decreased structural RV systolic
 function with RVEF at 35%.

   - raise head of bed
   - f/u am CXR for tube position.

   anomaly/repairs. Suppressed ectopy w Amiodarone. Now on Metoprolol.

History of present illness: 39M w/ pmh significant for ebstein's
   anomaly s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided
   systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with palpitations which
   awoke him from sleep.  The patient presented to the ED where he
   appeared pale and was found to be in VT to the 230's. He began to
   experience chest pain and was given amiodarone 150mg IV X1, followed by
   amiodarone gtt.  He became diaphoretic and was therefore given
   etomidate and shocked with 200J.  His rhythm then became fine V-fib, he
   became unresponsive and apneic.  CPR was initiated, epinephrine given
   X1, CPR continued, shocked again at 360J, returned to V-Tach @ 240,
   Intubated, returned to sinus rhyhthm, aspirated vomitus.  had right
   bronchus intubation and ETT was pulled back in ED. Blood pressures
   dropped to 48/43, started on levophed, pressure increased to 124/77.
   .
   On presentation to the CCU, the patient is intubated with mottled skin,
   on levophed, neosynephrine and vasopressin, with HR 85 and BP 125/77.

   Assessment and Plan
   39M w/ PMhx of Ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with
   unstable ventricular tachycardia,  now intubated, with hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure, persistent fevers.
   # Respiratory Failure: Mixed hypoxemia and hypercarbia.  Pt continues
   to wean slowly, became hypercarbic and hypoxemic during SBT yesterday
   at 0/8, however patient was unable to stay upright and also ETT likely
   too small which is making wean more difficult.  Pulm following and
   recommend extubation today with anesthesia at bedside given was
   difficult intubation.
   - Cont to wean Fi02 and PEEP as tolerated.  Goal Pa02>60
   - Cont. pressure support
   - Extubation this afternoon with pulm and anesthesia at bedside
   - Consider bronch prior to extubation.
   - cont. nebs
   - If fails extubation will discuss trach. F/u pulm recs.
   - raise head of bed
   - f/u am CXR for tube position.
   # Ventricular Tachycardia: Likely result of scarring from ebstein
   anomaly/repairs. Suppressed ectopy w Amiodarone. Now on Metoprolol.
   - amiodarone decreased to 200mg tid [**3-15**] given received 10gm loading
   - titrate up BB for HR control, increased to 50mg [**Hospital1 **].
    -added Lisionpril 2.5mg PO daily
   - likely will need EP study and possible ablation in future.  Will
   likely need ICD.
   # BP: Off pressors, now elevated BP while weaning sedation.  Added back
   on BB.
   - MAP goal >65,
   -  Wean PEEP and sedative as tolerated.
   - added on low dose ACEI
   # Fevers: Fevers to 103-104 since admission, initially considered to be
   due to aspiration PNA.  However has completed course of abx with no
   sputum production and improving pulmonary function.  Chest CT did not
   show evidence for ongoing infection. Ddx at this point includes occult
   infection (abscess, acalculous cholecystitis, sinusitis), gout,
   thermoregulatory dysfunciton after cardiac arrest/non-exposure heat
   stroke, drug fever, thyroid storm, adrenal insufficiency (although less
   likely now that not hypotensive). Not exposed to any culprit meds for
   NMS.  All culture data negative thus far.  Now with increasing
   secretions.
    Continued to spike fevers.  Still on ATC tylenol, aspirin and cooling
   blanket.  Fem line removed and sent for culture with no growth.
   Possible drug fever given persistent fever with no pos. cx data. C.
   diff negative. CT with PO contrast did not show clear source of fevers.
   CT sinus did have partial opacifications of bilaterally mastoids. CVL
   placed [**3-10**].
   - d/c abx per ID.
   - ID following, appreciate their recs
   - Check mycolytic blood cultures, pending
   - blood cultures NGTD, urine small growth GPC, sputum is oral flora.

   - Repeat sputum given inc. secretions
   - Tylenol 650 qid standing for fever, standing ASA 325 PO qid
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test normal
   - follow LFTs, CK, TSH normal

   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes

Date of service: [**2151-3-8**]
   Initial consultation: CCU
   Presenting complaint: Arrhythmia
   History of present illness: 39 yo M with PMH of ebstein's anomaly s/p
   tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided congestive heart
   failure, presenting with palpitations which awoke him from sleep. The
   patient presented to the ED morning of [**2151-3-7**] where he was found to be
   in VT 230bpm. He began to experience chest pain, given amiodarone 150mg
   IV x 1, followed by amio gtt. He became diaphoretic, given etomidate
   and shocked with 200J, followed by vifib, becoming unresponsive and
   apneic. CPR was initiated, epinephrine x 1, CPR continued, shocked at
   360J, returning to vtach @ 240. He was intubated, returning to sinus
   rhythm, aspriating vomit; noted to have right bronchus intubation and
   ETT repositioned. Due to hypotension SBP 40's started on levophed,
   neosynephrine, and vasopressin with BP increasing to 124/77.
   Subsequently developed left pneumothroax with attempted chest tube
   placement failed, had esophageal ballon placed. Early this morning had
   two recurrent runs of a WCT for which he was treated with amiodarone
   300mg IV then with the second run received 100mg IV lidocaine with
   initiation of lidocaine gtt.  EP consultation for management of
   ventricular tachyarrythmias.
   Past medical history: 1. Ebstein anomaly s/p TV reconstruction
     -- moderate to severe TR

 AP CHEST, 7:48 AM, ON [**3-7**].

 HISTORY:  Ventricular tachycardia.  Intubated.  Check ET tube placement.

 COMPARISON:  AP chest compared to [**2-21**] and [**2150-3-6**]:

 Some of the substantial increase in upper mediastinal caliber between [**2-21**] and today could be due to supine positioning, but the change in caliber and
 in the contours of the right side of the mediastinum suggests more is
 involved, including at least substantial increase in caliber of mediastinal
 veins or alternatively the aorta and possibly development of mediastinal
 hematoma.  As such, possibility of hemodynamically significant pericardial
 effusion or aortic dissection that needs to be excluded.

 Endotracheal tube has been withdrawn from the right main bronchus to the
 thoracic inlet, nasogastric tube passes into the stomach and out of view.  No
 radiopaque central venous catheter is seen.  No pneumothorax or pleural
 effusion.  There is no pulmonary edema.  Partial obscuration of the border of
 the left heart could be divided with change in its geometry, due to worsening
 cardiomegaly and/or pericardial effusion or, alternatively new consolidation
 of atelectasis in the lingula.  No pneumothorax.

 Findings and their clinical significance were discussed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3001**] with the
 physician caregiver [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 33400**] 8:15 a.m. this morning.

   Assessment and Plan
   39M w/ PMhx of Ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with
   unstable ventricular tachycardia s/p intubation and extubation, plan
   for EP procedure with ventricular fibrillation ablation as well as ICD
   placement.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure
 now resolved: Initially mixed hypoxemia and
   hypercarbia. Patient with OSA on CPAP at home at night.
   - continue nighttime CPAP
   # Ventricular Tachycardia: Likely result of scarring from ebstein
   anomaly/repairs. Initially Amiodarone loaded and continued outpatient
   metoprolol. Decreased Amiodarone dose to 200 mg PO TID as has received
   10 g loading dose. Beta blocker had to be titrated down in the setting
   of bradycardia. Plan is for EP study with ICD placement at some point,
   however given that recently had fever and that patient has not been out
   of bed, may need repeat intubation will hold on procedure for a few
   days. Spoke with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] concerning this
   -          f/u daily EP recs
   -          .
   # BP: Patient without history of hypertension. On beta blocker as an
   outpatient as well as Lisinopril. Yesterday patient with low blood
   pressures.
   -          lower beta blocker dose
   -          keep ACEi at current dose, would like to uptitrate as
   tolerated when able
   # Fever- now resolved : Patient initially with Fevers to 103-104,
   initially considered to be due to aspiration PNA.  Patient completed
   course of abx with no sputum production and improving pulmonary
   function.  Chest CT did not show evidence for ongoing infection. Ddx
   for previous fever included occult infection (abscess, acalculous
   cholecystitis, sinusitis), gout, thermoregulatory dysfunciton after
   cardiac arrest/non-exposure heat stroke, drug fever, thyroid storm,
   adrenal insufficiency (although less likely now that not hypotensive).
   Not exposed to any culprit meds for NMS.  All culture data negative
   thus far.
   Fem line removed and sent for culture with no growth.  Possible drug
   fever given persistent fever with no pos. cx data. C. diff negative. CT
   with PO contrast did not show clear source of fevers. CT sinus did have
   partial opacifications of bilaterally mastoids. CVL placed [**3-10**].
   Antibioitcs were discontinued as per ID reccomendations. Blood cultures
   NGTD, [**Last Name (un) **] stim test normal, TSH normal. Fungal blood cultures no
   growth to date.
   .
   # Hypernatremia now resolved -  Patient treated with free water flushes
   through NG tube as well as d5W now with normal sodium discontinued free
   water.
   -          cont to monitor Na
   # Chronic Systolic heart failure - Congestive Heart Failure: Echo s/p
   arrest demonstrated right and left sided heart failure, s/p tricuspid
   reconstruction and ASD repair. Repeat echocardiogram on [**2151-3-15**]
   demonstrates marked right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall
   hypokinesis. Normal left ventricular cavity size with low normal
   systolic function. Well seated tricuspid annuloplasty ring with
   increased gradient. Patient is seen at Children
s congenital heart
   center.
   - hold digoxin
   - hold diuresis for now , would restart on discharge
   - continue low dose ACEi
   .
   # Acute renal failure: likely ATN, Creatinine max to 3.2 during this
   admission, creatinine improved now  to 1.1. Likely ATN in the setting
   of VF arrest.
   -          monitor UOP
   -          renally dose medications
   -          avoid nephrotoxins
   # Nutrition
 patient passed speech and swallow evaluation yesterday.
   Taking good PO.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Multifactorial from shock liver, heart failure (acute
   after arrest) and Amiodarone continuing to improve daily.
   - continue to trend LFTs
   #Gout: R knee swollen, concerning for gout flare, joint tapped, no
   crystals visualized.  Attempted to tap knee again however tap was dry.
   Not currently getting treated with any agents, fever has broken and
   swelling improved.
   -          continue to monitor
   FEN:  replete lytes PRN

Date of service: [**2151-3-7**]
   Initial visit, Cardiology service: CCU
   History of present illness: 39M w/ pmh significant for ebstein's
   anomaly s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided
   systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with palpitations which
   awoke him from sleep.  The patient presented to the ED where he
   appeared pale and was found to be in VT to the 230's. He began to
   experience chest pain and was given amiodarone 150mg IV X1, followed by
   amiodarone gtt.  He became diaphoretic and was therefore given
   etomidate and shocked with 200J.  His rhythm then became fine V-fib, he
   became unresponsive and apneic.  CPR was initiated, epinephrine given
   X1, CPR continued, shocked again at 360J, returned to V-Tach @ 240,
   Intubated, returned to sinus rhyhthm, aspirated vomitus.  had right
   bronchus intubation and ETT was pulled back in ED. Blood pressures
   dropped to 48/43, started on levophed, pressure increased to 124/77.
   .
   On presentation to the CCU, the patient is intubated with mottled skin,
   on levophed, neosynephrine and vasopressin, with HR 85 and BP 125/77.
   Past medical history: 1. Ebstein anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve
   reconstruction
      - moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation
      - right heart failure, RVEF 25% in [**6-17**]
   2. ASD, s/p primary closure [**3-/2136**]
   3. Left heart failure with evidence of noncompaction of LV, with
   LVEF 28% in [**6-17**]
   4. Hyperlipidemia
   5. Hypertension
   6. Obstructive sleep apnea
   7. Obesity
   8. DVT
   9. Superficial phlebitis
   10. endocarditis w/ septic emboli to brain prior to Cardiac surgery.

   39M w/ pmh of ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with

   new left sided pneumothorax. will hold on IV heparin given history of
   brain abscesses years ago.  Will ventilate according to ARDS net
   protocol. Contact CT [**Name2 (NI) **] for chest tube placement.

   -IV heparin if PE, and if head CT is negative
   .
   #Hypotension:Initially secondary to ventricular tachycardia, and
   response to sedatives s/p intubation.  Initially on three pressors but
   weaned off for a short period, still requiring intermittently.  Will
   try to minimize PEEP to maximize venous return. may possibly be from
   decompensated heart failure.
   -pressors as needed
   -fluids as neded
   .
   # Chronic Systolic Congestive Heart Failure: Has right and left sided
   heart failure, s/p tricuspid reconstruction and ASD repair. Will hold
   metoprolol, lisinopril, lasix, and digoxin in setting of hypotension.
   -hold metoprolol, lisinopril, lasix, digoxin
   -echo
   .
   #Gout: holding allopurinol and colchicine
   .

History of present illness: 39M w/ pmh significant for ebstein's
   anomaly s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction, right and left sided
   systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with palpitations which
   awoke him from sleep.  The patient presented to the ED where he
   appeared pale and was found to be in VT to the 230's. He began to
   experience chest pain and was given amiodarone 150mg IV X1, followed by
   amiodarone gtt.  He became diaphoretic and was therefore given
   etomidate and shocked with 200J.  His rhythm then became fine V-fib, he
   became unresponsive and apneic.  CPR was initiated, epinephrine given
   X1, CPR continued, shocked again at 360J, returned to V-Tach @ 240,
   Intubated, returned to sinus rhyhthm, aspirated vomitus.  had right
   bronchus intubation and ETT was pulled back in ED. Blood pressures
   dropped to 48/43, started on levophed, pressure increased to 124/77.
   .
   On presentation to the CCU [**3-7**], the patient is intubated with mottled
   skin, on levophed, neosynephrine and vasopressin, with HR 85 and BP
   125/77. [**2068-3-5**] - Remains intubated with Aspiration PNA &
   ?Failure-requiring fio2-100% & PEEP up 16.. Pressors weaned to Levophed
   & Vasopressin. Chest Tube insertion for right
   pneumothorac-unsuccessful-resolved on own.
   Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS, Acute Lung Injury, [**Doctor Last Name 2**])
   Assessment:
   Lung sounds diminished throughout. Sx
minimal thick tannish
   secretions. Vent settings 100%/450/32/20 peep.  Sat
s 85%, not
   correlating w/ abg sat.  CXR-Aspiration PNA, resolved pneumothorac, &
   ?failure.
   Renal Failure with elevated Creat & decreased urinary output.
   Cisatricurium at 0.18mg/kg/hr.
   Action:
   Nitric Oxide initiated at 40.  During day, adjusted Fio2 down to 70%.
   Pulm toilet. Lasix gtt started.  TOF on 0.18 cisatricurium is 4
   twitches.  Slowly increased up to 0.26mg/kg/hr.
   Response:
   Able to slowly [**Month (only) 202**] Fio2.  u/.o up to 100cc/hr, but remains + for the
   day.  Adequate paralyzation w/ tof at 2.

   Cont adjust vent and Nitric Oxide. Continue diuresis attempt with

   Rec
d pt in junctional rhythm in 80

   Assessment and Plan
   39M w/ PMhx of Ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with
   unstable ventricular tachycardia,  now intubated, with hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure, persistent fevers.
   # Respiratory Failure: Mixed hypoxemia and hypercarbia.  Pt continues
   to wean slowly, became hypercarbic and hypoxemic during SBT yesterday
   at 0/8, however patient was unable to stay upright and also ETT likely
   too small which is making wean more difficult.  Pulm following and
   recommend extubation today with anesthesia at bedside given was
   difficult intubation.
   - Cont to wean Fi02 and PEEP as tolerated.  Goal Pa02>60
   - Cont. pressure support
   - Extubation this afternoon with pulm and anesthesia at bedside
   - Consider bronch prior to extubation.
   - cont. nebs
   - If fails extubation will discuss trach. F/u pulm recs.
   - raise head of bed
   - f/u am CXR for tube position.
   # Ventricular Tachycardia: Likely result of scarring from ebstein
   anomaly/repairs. Suppressed ectopy w Amiodarone. Now on Metoprolol.
   - amiodarone decreased to 200mg tid [**3-15**] given received 10gm loading
   - titrate up BB for HR control, increased to 50mg [**Hospital1 **].
    -added Lisionpril 2.5mg PO daily
   - likely will need EP study and possible ablation in future.  Will
   likely need ICD.
   # BP: Off pressors, now elevated BP while weaning sedation.  Added back
   on BB.
   - MAP goal >65,
   -  Wean PEEP and sedative as tolerated.
   - added on low dose ACEI
   # Fevers: Fevers to 103-104 since admission, initially considered to be
   due to aspiration PNA.  However has completed course of abx with no
   sputum production and improving pulmonary function.  Chest CT did not
   show evidence for ongoing infection. Ddx at this point includes occult
   infection (abscess, acalculous cholecystitis, sinusitis), gout,
   thermoregulatory dysfunciton after cardiac arrest/non-exposure heat
   stroke, drug fever, thyroid storm, adrenal insufficiency (although less
   likely now that not hypotensive). Not exposed to any culprit meds for
   NMS.  All culture data negative thus far.  Now with increasing
   secretions.
    Continued to spike fevers.  Still on ATC tylenol, aspirin and cooling
   blanket.  Fem line removed and sent for culture with no growth.
   Possible drug fever given persistent fever with no pos. cx data. C.
   diff negative. CT with PO contrast did not show clear source of fevers.
   CT sinus did have partial opacifications of bilaterally mastoids. CVL
   placed [**3-10**].
   - d/c abx per ID.
   - ID following, appreciate their recs
   - Check mycolytic blood cultures, pending
   - blood cultures NGTD, urine small growth GPC, sputum is oral flora.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
   39M w/ PMhx of Ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with
   unstable ventricular tachycardia,  now intubated, with hypoxic and
   hypercarbic respiratory failure, persistent fevers.
   # Respiratory Failure: Mixed hypoxemia and hypercarbia.  Pt continues
   to wean slowly, became hypercarbic and hypoxemic during SBT yesterday
   at 0/8, however patient was unable to stay upright and also ETT likely
   too small which is making wean more difficult.  Pulm following and
   recommend extubation today with anesthesia at bedside given was
   difficult intubation.
   - Cont to wean Fi02 and PEEP as tolerated.  Goal Pa02>60
   - Cont. pressure support
   - Extubation this afternoon with pulm and anesthesia at bedside
   - Consider bronch prior to extubation.
   - cont. nebs
   - If fails extubation will discuss trach. F/u pulm recs.
   - raise head of bed
   - f/u am CXR for tube position.
   # Ventricular Tachycardia: Likely result of scarring from ebstein
   anomaly/repairs. Suppressed ectopy w Amiodarone. Now on Metoprolol.
   - amiodarone decreased to 200mg tid [**3-15**] given received 10gm loading
   - titrate up BB for HR control, increased to 50mg [**Hospital1 **].
    -added Lisionpril 2.5mg PO daily
   - likely will need EP study and possible ablation in future.  Will
   likely need ICD.
   # BP: Off pressors, now elevated BP while weaning sedation.  Added back
   on BB.
   - MAP goal >65,
   -  Wean PEEP and sedative as tolerated.
   - added on low dose ACEI
   # Fevers: Fevers to 103-104 since admission, initially considered to be
   due to aspiration PNA.  However has completed course of abx with no
   sputum production and improving pulmonary function.  Chest CT did not
   show evidence for ongoing infection. Ddx at this point includes occult
   infection (abscess, acalculous cholecystitis, sinusitis), gout,
   thermoregulatory dysfunciton after cardiac arrest/non-exposure heat
   stroke, drug fever, thyroid storm, adrenal insufficiency (although less
   likely now that not hypotensive). Not exposed to any culprit meds for
   NMS.  All culture data negative thus far.  Now with increasing
   secretions.
    Continued to spike fevers.  Still on ATC tylenol, aspirin and cooling
   blanket.  Fem line removed and sent for culture with no growth.
   Possible drug fever given persistent fever with no pos. cx data. C.
   diff negative. CT with PO contrast did not show clear source of fevers.
   CT sinus did have partial opacifications of bilaterally mastoids. CVL
   placed [**3-10**].
   - d/c abx per ID.
   - ID following, appreciate their recs
   - Check mycolytic blood cultures, pending
   - blood cultures NGTD, urine small growth GPC, sputum is oral flora.
   Continue to monitor.
   - Repeat sputum given inc. secretions
   - Tylenol 650 qid standing for fever, standing ASA 325 PO qid
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test normal
   - follow LFTs, CK, TSH normal
   # Hypernatremia -  likely in setting of diuresis. Free water deficit
   initially 8L, improving with inc. free water flushes and D5.
   -hold lasix gtt
   -D5W continuous + free water flushes for repletion
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   # Chronic Systolic heart failure - Congestive Heart Failure: Has right
   and left sided heart failure, s/p tricuspid reconstruction and ASD
   repair.
   - hold digoxin
   - TEE and TTE
 showed poor systolic function. Done just after arrest.
   Repeat yesterday showed improved systolic function with EF 50%
   - hold diuresis
   - appreciate Children
s congenital specialist input
   - Cr improving, add back on low dose ACEI
   # ARF: ATN, creatinine increased in setting of continued diuresis.  Cr
   much improved after holding diuresis.
   - d/ced lasix gtt
   - monitor UOP
   # Hypernatremia sodium of 155 from 148, free water defict of 7L, likely
   from combination of fevers and diuresis
   - d
ed lasix gtt
   - start D5W at 100ml/hr- then will reevaluate Na this PM
   # Bowel motility/nutrition
 Monitor for improvement after lightening
   fentanyl
   - Bowel regimen on hold given now with diarrhea
   - Continue TF
   - f/u any nutrition recs
   # Transaminitis: Multifactorial from shock liver, CHF and amiodarone.
   Improving
   - monitor LFTs given amio restarted
   #Gout: R knee swollen, concerning for gout flare, joint tapped, no
   crystals visualized.  Rheum following.  Holding allopurinol and
   colchicines given ARF
   -re-tap knee yesterday without fluid.
   - Cont. to monitor.
   FEN:  agressively replete lytes, treat hypernatremia with free water
   ACCESS:  Fem line d/c
d., new IJ placed [**3-10**].  Fever curve decreasing,
   will monitor femoral blood cultures.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  39-year-old male intubated, with persistent fevers.  Evaluate for
 sinusitis.

 COMPARISON:  None available in the [**Hospital1 99**] PACS.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial imaging was performed through the paranasal sinuses without
 IV contrast.  Coronal and standard tissue algorithm reformations were
 provided.

 CT SINUSES WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  There is bilateral extensive opacification of
 the maxillary sinuses, sphenoid sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, and frontal sinuses.
 Although sphenoid sinus opacification can be seen in the setting of
 intubation, involvement of the remainder of the paranasal sinus system
 extensively, especially the frontal sinuses, is suggestive of acute sinusitis.
 Some of the areas of opacification are dense and can be due to inspisatted or
 proteniceous secretions or related to fungal etiology, if appropriate. There
 is demineralization fo the ethmoid septae and cribriform plates of ethmoid.
 There is partial opacification of the mastoid air cells bilaterally.  These
 findings are more extensive than in the head CT 6 days prior.  Soft tissues
 are grossly unremarkable but not completely assessed.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Progression of opacification of maxillary, sphenoid, ethmoid and frontal
 sinuses, with aerosolized secretions suggestive of acute sinusitis along with
 a chronic component. Fungal etiology cannot eb completely excluded, if
 clinically appropriate history is present.

 2.  New partial opacification of mastoid air cells.

                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  39-year-old male with congenital heart disease, history of lower
 extremity DVT and recent leg swelling and intracranial abscess.  Now with VT
 and needs anticoagulation.  Rule out intracranial pathology.

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain without
 contrast material.  Subsequently, rapid axial imaging was performed through
 the brain during infusion of Omnipaque intravenous contrast material.  Images
 were processed on a separate workstation with display of curved reformats,
 volume-rendered images, and maximum intensity projection images.

 COMPARISON:  No prior study available for comparison.

 FINDINGS:

 HEAD CT:  There is no evidence of acute hemorrhage, edema, mass, mass effect,
 or infarction.  Of note, there is a low-attenuation area in the right
 occipital pole, consistent with encephalomalacia with an associated ex vacuo
 enlargement of the right lateral ventricle trigone, most likely related to
 prior insult.

 Air-fluid levels in the paranasal sinuses is noted and likely reflective of
 the patient's intubated status.

 HEAD CTA:  The carotid and vertebral arteries and their major branches are
 patent without evidence of stenosis.  There is no evidence of aneurysm
 formation or other vascular abnormality.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No acute intracranial pathology.

 2.  Encephalomalacia of the right occipital pole with associated ex vacuo
 dilatation of the right lateral ventricular occipital [**Doctor Last Name 218**] suggestive of prior
 cerebral injury.
                                                             (Over)

   hypercarbia.  Pt continues to wean slowly, became hypercarbic and
   hypoxemic during SBT yesterday at 0/8, however patient was unable to
   stay upright and also ETT likely too small which is making wean more
   difficult.  Pulm following and recommend extubation today with
   anesthesia at bedside given was difficult intubation.

   - Cont. pressure support

   - Consider bronch prior to extubation.
   - cont. nebs
   - If fails extubation will discuss trach. F/u pulm recs.
   - raise head of bed
   - f/u am CXR for tube position.

   anomaly/repairs. Suppressed ectopy w Amiodarone. Now on Metoprolol.
   - amiodarone decreased to 200mg tid [**3-15**] given received 10gm loading
   - titrate up BB for HR control, increased to 50mg [**Hospital1 **].

   likely need ICD.

   - MAP goal >65,
   -  Wean PEEP and sedative as tolerated.
   - added on low dose ACEI

   sputum production and improving pulmonary function.  Chest CT did not
   show evidence for ongoing infection. Ddx at this point includes occult

   thermoregulatory dysfunciton after cardiac arrest/non-exposure heat

   History of present illness: 39 y/o male with history of Ebstein anomaly

   Assessment and Plan
   39 yo male with history of Ebstein's anomaly and ASD s/p TV
   reconstruction and primary ASD closure [**2136**], LV noncompaction,
   biventricular heart failure, moderate-severe tricuspid regurgitation,
   morbid obesity, OSA, who presented on [**3-7**] with unstable ventricular
   tachycardia s/p resuscitation, who is now critically ill, intubated, on
   pressors, on broad spectrum antibiotics for aspiration PNA, and in
   ARDS with difficulty oxygenating, increased PEEP requiring iNO.
   1) Biventricular heart failure with tricuspid regurgitation.
   - His fluid status is difficult to assess given his body habitus, he is
   grossly positive by I/O. Nevertheless, would not aggressively diurese
   given his ongoing infection.
   - PA line monitoring would be ideal, although insertion of a neck line
   may be problem[**Name (NI) **] in this morbidly obese patient.
   - He has not been considered a surgical candidate for a re-do TV
   reconstruction in the past given his comorbidities and non-compliance.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated.
   2) Ventricular tachycardia, possibly related to his cardiomyopathy and
   less likely to his prior surgery. There is also a question of SVT due
   to a bypass tract (common in Ebstein's anomaly).
   - Continue amiodarone drip. Stop lidocaine per EP recs.
   - EPS when clinically stable
   - Monitor K and magnesium
   3) ARDS. Pulmonary following and assisting in ventilator management.
   Difficult oxygenation is secondary to PNA with V/Q mismatch and not
   related to a residual intracardiac shunt, as demostrated by today's
   TEE.
   4) Sepsis.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics
   - await culture results
   Will follow with you

   ABG: 7.35 / 40 / 66 /  / -3   Values as of [**2151-3-8**] 03:25 AM
   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   39M w/ pmh of ebstein's anomaly, s/p tricuspid valve reconstruction,
   right and left sided systolic congestive heart failure, presenting with
   unstable ventricular tachycardia, s/p resuscitation with return to
   sinus tachycardia, now intubated, with hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Ventricular Tachycardia: Likely result of natural history of ebstein
   anomaly.  Currently receiving amiodarone IV, remains in sinus
   tachycardia s/p resuscitation.  Cardiac enzymes mildly elevated, likely
   related to CPR and cardioversion. This AM had sevarel episodes of what
   may have been VT with rate in 120s to 130s, improved with amio bolus
   and increased gtt (however, now also increased LFTs). Required addition
   of lidocaine gtt.
   -likely need VT albation
   -continue amiodarone gtt for now, but careful monitoring of LFTs
   -electrophysiology consult
   .
   #Respiratory Failure: Difficulty oxygenating with Fi02 100% and
   increased PEEP. Per report patient had significant aspiration during
   intubation. PE ruled out with CTA.  CT initially showed left
   pneumothorax, but f/u CT showed resolution after chest tube attempt.
   Also CT and CXRs showing right sided possible aspiration PNA. Being
   ventilated according to ARDS net protocol.  [**Month (only) 11**] have reopened ASD
   repair, causing shunt.
   -echo with bubble study to evaluate for ASD
   -swan cath to check oxygen saturation in four [**Doctor Last Name 135**] to evaluate for
   right to left shunt
   -Giving lasix this AM at increased dose, so far little improvement
   -ARDS net protocol
   -nimbex as paralytic [**Doctor Last Name 23**]
   -nebs
   -if still poor saturation, will consider inhaled nitrous oxide
   -pulm following- appreciate recs
   .
   #Hypotension: Initially secondary to ventricular tachycardia, and
   response to sedatives s/p intubation.  Initially on three pressers but
   now only on levo, still requiring dopa intermittently.  Will try to
   minimize PEEP to maximize venous return. may possibly be from
   decompensated heart failure.  Likely has combination of cardiogenic
   shock and septic shock.
   -pressors as needed
   -fluids as neded
   -would benefit from swan ganz catheter to better understand type of
   hypotenision
   .
   # Sepsis- Leukocytosis/fever/right lobe infiltrate- likely aspiration
   PNA, witnessed emesis during intubation
   -MRSA screen and precautions
   - continue vanco and zosyn, day 2
   .
   # Chronic Systolic Congestive Heart Failure: Has right and left sided
   heart failure, s/p tricuspid reconstruction and ASD repair. Will hold
   metoprolol, lisinopril, lasix, and digoxin in setting of hypotension.
   -hold metoprolol, lisinopril, lasix, digoxin
   -echo today
   .
   # ARF: Cr increased to 2.6. Likely [**3-15**] hypotension. Possible ATN. Low
   UO
   - monitor UO
   - send urine lytes
   - consider renal consult
   .
   # Transaminitis: LFTs increased, may be from shock liver, and/or CHF
   - monitor liver function
   - may need to stop amio
   .
   # Family dynamicis: family concerned about care of pt in the hospital,
   mother wants transfer to [**Name (NI) 49**]
   - social work consult
   - patient relations/advocate consults
   - likely benefit from family meeting today
   .
   #Gout: holding allopurinol and colchicine
   .
   FEN:
   ACCESS: right femoral line
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, sub q heparin
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now

   Mr [**Known lastname **] is a 55 year old judge from [**Location (un) 10461**], with a history

   Briefly, Mr [**Known lastname **] initially noted symptoms upon swimming and
   stressful activity. After failing medical therapy alone he underwent
   PVI at our center in [**2158-4-25**] and was started on amiodarone
   maintenance. Patient however began experiencing breakthrough episodes
   of PAF (documented on holter monitor) lasting approximately 3-4 days
   and which severely limited his abilty to perform actitivies of daily
   life. Patient reports that along with palpitations, he feels shortness
   of breath, lightheadedness, and chest pain.
   .
   Patient was evaluated by his primary cardiologist in [**Month (only) 2287**] and given
   the above symptoms and lack of medical response, amiodarone was stopped
   and plan for re-do PVI with pre procedure MRI was put in place.
   .
   Today, patient underwent successful PVI, however with induced left
   atrial tachycardia patient went into persistant atrial fibrillation
   refractory to cardioversion and ibutilide.  He was given a total of
   460mcg of neo and 10mg IV lasix. He was maintained intubated and
   transferred to the PACU off neo, but SBP trended down to the 70-80's
   and 1mcg/mg/kg in the PACU with SBP 90-100. He was also given a total
   of 1450 IVF.  In the PACU he was cardioverted with 200J to sinus brady
   in the 40's. He was transferred to the ICU intubated and sedated.

   Total of 59 ablation lesions performed (for a total of 5516 seconds)

   most regions except the posterior wall, where we limited power to 20W.
   Conclusions
   1. Atrial fibrillation prior to procedure.
   2. Successful pulmonary vein isolation without inducibility of AF after
   isolation.
   3. Sinus rhythm post-procedure.
   .
   CARDIAC MRI ([**4-/2158**])
   Impression:
   1. Normal left ventricular cavity size with normal regional left
   ventricular systolic function. The LVEF was normal at 63%.
   2. Normal right ventricular cavity size and systolic function. The RVEF
   was normal at 55%.
   3. The indexed diameters of the ascending and descending thoracic aorta
   were normal. The main pulmonary artery diameter index was normal.
   4. Biatrial enlargement.
   5. Three right-sided and two-left sided pulmonary veins with normal
   size and orientation. The right-sided pulmonary veins consist of right
   superior and right inferior pulmonary veins with a small accessory
   pulmonary vein originating near the origin of the right inferior
   pulmonary vein. No CMR evidence of anomalous pulmonary venous return or
   pulmonary vein stenosis.
   6. Incidental note is made of a hyperintense lesion as described above
   in the right kidney, likely representing a renal cyst. Renal ultrasound
   is recommended.
   .
   ECHO ([**4-/2158**])
   Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global
   systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) The right ventricular cavity
   is dilated There is no pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space
   which most likely represents a fat pad.
   .
   ECHO [**2160-1-3**]
   The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild symmetric left
   ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and global systolic
   function (LVEF>55%). Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall
   motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. The right ventricular
   cavity is dilated with depressed free wall contractility. The aortic
   valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not
   present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The tricuspid
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The estimated pulmonary artery
   systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. There is
   an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved
   global and regional biventricular systolic function. The RV is not well
   seen but may be mildly dilated/hypokinetic. No significant valvular
   abnormality seen.

This is a 71 yr old pt who was transfered from OSH s/p CV arrest.
   Pt reportedly was admitted to an OSH w c/o rt leg weakness/numbness,
   which was diagnosed as spinal stenosis. It was decided to perform a
   laminectomy but at time of premed/sedation w fentanyl/versed, pt
   developed CP/(+)STEMI.
   She went to cath lab( laminectory was not completed) and received 3 BMS
   to mid/distal L Cx. Pt was monitored post op, surgical treatment of
   disc issue was postponed for (+)6 wks. Pt was sent to rehab [**2168-2-15**].
   [**2168-2-15**]- Upon admission to rehab, per family- pt felt " unwell". She
   developed chills, felt warm and had nausea, some vomiting.  Pt
   proceeded to "collapse" at rehab- although details re:
   rhythym/hemodynamics are unknown. EMS was called and per report, pt
   had  ?PEA/Asystole and received 4 cycles CPR. A perfusing rhythym was
   restored and pt was admitted transiently to [**Hospital **] Hosp ER, then
   medflighted to [**Hospital1 1**]. She arrived to CCU intubated/on Artic Sun- not
   repsonsive but for moving lower extremities, and hemodynamically stable
   at MN [**2168-2-16**] w family accompanying her.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Pt s/p CV arrest admitted to CCU for Therapeutic Hypothermia,
   management of (+)MI.
   Action:
   Pt arrived to CCU nonresponsive, VSS- on no pressors. Started on
   versed/fentanyl gtt for biting ETT w oral care. HR- 60-48 SR/SB and BP-
   110/50-103/40. CCU team inserted Aline left radial after much
   difficulty.
   Adjustments to vent settings per ABG. Minimal secretions, O2 sats/
   WNL/ventilating well. Artic Sun maintained at 34 degrees, pt
   experiencing no significant side effects while hypothermic currently.
   OG tube inserted . CXR revealing good positioning of ETT/OGT. Family
   given information re: CT scan and pt
s current state of progress/plan
   of care. Support/teaching to family.  Close monitoring of neuro signs-
   very gradual and subtle increase in responsiveness over course of
   shift- currently slight grimace/clenching jaw w oral care-suctioning/
   slight movement of arms w Aline/ABG  attempts. Pupils remains NR at 5-6
 not opening eyes to command or spontaneously. No significant change
   this shift overall. Frequent turning, heparin sq, waffle boots provided
   for pt w complete immobility for optimal skin care. Pt arrived to CCU w
   mepiplex to rt gluteal- changed over to new dsg- small clean skin tear
   observed, no drainage.
   Response:
   Pt arrived to CCU s/p arrest, non responsive but hemodynamically
   stable. Adequate ventilation on current vent settings. Family
   appropriately upset over pt
s current condition, but appear to
   understand plan of care and current course of events.
   Plan:
   Await AM labs- adjust vent as needed as well as replete lytes as needed
   per results. SS insulin as needed per BS. Continue to closely monitor
   temps/artic sun/water temp trends and any sign of shivering- add
   paralytic if needed. Continue skin care/ oral care as per protocol.
   Close monitoring of neuro status/ observe for any improvements/ seizure
   activity. Plan for EEG/EKG/CXR this AM.
