TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:  transfer from OSH with cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   71-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type II,
   hypertension, is transfered from outside hospital s/p cardiac arrest.
   .
   The patient was in her ususal state of health until 2 weeks prior to
   presentation. At that time she developed right leg weakness and
   numbness. She presented to [**Hospital6 **] where she was evaluated
   at it was determined that she had compression of her spinal cord and
   needed a laminectomy. The patient was set to get the laminectomy and
   was getting sedated with fentanyl and versed when she developed chest
   pain. She had an EKG which showed inferior STEMI and she was taken to
   the catheterization lab instead. At that time she was found to have
   diffuse disease and had 3 BMS placed in her mid and distal left
   circumflex. Her peak CK was 452, MB 27.1 and Trop T 0.93 (per obtained
   labs). These downtrended and the patient was observed. The decision was
   made to withhold from spinal surgery for 6-weeks. On [**2168-2-15**] the
   patient was sent to rehabilitation. Per the family, she arrived at
   rehab and felt unwell. She initially had chills and then became very
   warm. She had episodes of nausea and some episodes of vomiting. She
   then collapsed at which point it is unclear if she was responsive or
   had a rhythm. An ambulance was called and she was taken to [**Hospital1 536**]. En route the patient has ?PEA arrest which progressed to
   ?asystole. The patient received 4 rounds of CPR and epinephrine,
   atropine, calcium gluconate and apparently resumed a perfusing rhythm.
   The patient arrived at [**Hospital3 474**] and was med-flighted to [**Hospital1 1**].
   .
   Unable to obtain ROS.

 INDICATION:  Insertion of biventricular pacemaker, decline in cognitive
 function, cardiac arrest with subsequent intubation and frank hemoptysis.
 Supratherapeutic INR.

 FINDINGS:  Comparison made with a radiograph dated [**2145-6-8**] at 01.47 hours
 (pre-cardiac arrest).  There is new asymmetric  opacity in the right lung and
 new bilateral alveolar and interstitial opacities in both lungs on a
 background of moderate cardiomegaly.  No rib fractures or pneumothorax. An
 endotracheal tube and nasogastric tube have been inserted since the previous
 radiograph and are in satisfactory positions.  The positions of the right
 atrial, right ventricular and epicardial pacing wire are satisfactory and
 unchanged.  Moderately severe bilateral glenohumeral subluxation is
 incidentally noted.
 IMPRESSION:  Alveolar and interstitial pulmonary edema, worse on the right.
 The diffuse ground-glass opacity in the right lung may be attributable in part
 to pulmonary hemorrhage, which would fit with the given clinical history.

   63 yr old woman with Stage IV lung Ca presents with resp arrest,
   cardiac arrest, and hypotension.
   Possible evolution of events was that hemoptysis evolved, clotted off
   left mainstem leading to resp distress and ultimately arrest from
   hypoxemia.
   Problems
   [**Name (NI) 1531**]
   Respiratory Failure
   Anemia
   1.       Hypoxemic Resp Distress: due to left lung collapse with
   possible post obstructive blood and or pus. Currently on AC 400 x 10,
   PIP 24, and last gas with quite hypercarbia- since she has COPFD and is
   one lung vented ? autoPEEP and created Zone 1 lung. We will try smaller
   volume and slightly faster rate. Place A line for frequent ABGs and
   hemodynamics. If she bleeds needs left lung down, advance ETT into
   right mainstem and alert IP for urgent intervention. Could also try
   endobronchial blocker. We will cover with Vanco Zosyn for possible post
   obstruictuive PNA esp with plans for intervention in AM.
   2.       Cardiac Arrest: seems that she was hypoxemic then bradycardic
   then PEA
 resolved with brief epi/atrop/CPR
 currently on Neo but
   weaning off
 goal MAP 60-65, maintain UOP 30cc/hr. Formal Echo to be
   done. Cycyle CKs.
   3.       Anemia: source of blood loss unclear, not GI source, Abd CT
   neg for RP or abd bleed, may be blood in chest as source of loss though
   not overt hemoptysis now.
   4.       [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) 1532**]- likely murantic- we have to hold anti coagulation
   acutely but will need to re evaluate once rigid bronch done and risks
   benefits can be assessed.
   5.       Neuro: post arrest- short down time by report. Will check stat
   head CT to look for blled (known mets). Serail Neuro exams throughout
   eveing

   ATTENDING PROGRESS NOTE
   I have reviewed the Comprehensive Progress Note by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] today and
   I concur with the history, physical examination, assessment and
   treatment plan.   I was present during the entire portion of the
   physical examination.
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9204**] is a 77 year old man who suffered an inferior wall STEMI
   complicated by cardiogenic shock earlier this AM.  He was treated with
   PCI using a BMS in the distal RCA following thrombectomy with the
   support of a pacemaker and IABP.
   He was cooled for 24 hours for neuro protection and is now warm.  There
   has been no return in her neurologic function.  His IABP was removed
   for leg leg ischemia and he is currently on reduced pressor
   requirements.  This resulted in a doppler left popliteal and faint PT
   pulse. He is urinating > 100 cc clear urine per hour.
   We have continued all aggressive supportive care until his prognosis in
   better defined tomorrow.
   His prognosis for long-term recovery remains uncertain and this has
   been discussed with his wife and family.

d 80mg IV lasix w/ no response, then 160mg w/ no response

   Upon arrival in CCU Arctic sun was initiated. He arrived on dopamine at
   15mic/kilo, vasopressin at 2.4 units/hr, Norepinephrine at .5mic/kilo,
   Epinephrine at 1.25mic/kilo, amiodarone at 1mg/min, versed at 5mg/hr

   Assessment:
   Pt had been unresponsive to any stimuli and versed was dropped to .5
   and fentanyl to 25mic. By 1100 he was noted to have tongue twitching
   and periodic myoclonic jerks that would cause him to flail and for his
   eyes to open slightly. He became dyscordanant with with vent. His
   pupils were unresponsive and no cranial nerve activity was noted.
   Action:

   .05mic/kilo. Not train of 4 was able to be obtained. The jerking
   stopped and he was ventilated without further difficulty. Continuous
   EEG monitoring was initiated and status epilepticus was seen.

TITLE: CCU resident admission note
   Chief Complaint:  found down (PEA)
   HPI:
   Mr [**Known lastname 9204**] is a 77 yo russian speaking gentleman with PMH significant
   for stroke, no known heart disease, who presented to the ED yesterday
   evening after having been found down in PEA by paramedics.  Per the
   patients wife, the patient complained of chest pain starting around 8
   PM, then at 11 PM she found him down. Per ED attending note fire
   department initiated CPR for 2 minutes. Blood pressure was 80/p. The
   parametics were able to restore a wide complex rhythm with
   approximately 10 rounds of epinephrine and atropine.  [**1-24**] amp D50 was
   given for BS of 26. Patient was intubated and started on dopamine in
   the field.
   On arrival to the ED, BP was 100/60, rhythm was wide complex with pulse
   in the 60s-80s, GCS was 4. 12 lead ECG showed inferior STE and
   anterolateral ST depressions. Patient received ASA rectal. Heparin
   therapy was initiated. He was taken for emergent cath and was found to
   have to have totally occluded LAD in the mig-segment with
   collateralization, 80 and 60% occlustion of D1/D2 branches, small
   circumflex with no disease, and distally occluded RCA with a 70%
   stenosis of the PDA bifurcation and a 90% stenosis of the PL branch
   noted after recanalization. Left and right heart pressures were
   markedly elevated with a PCWP of 33 and a RA of 23. Thrombus was
   removed from the RCA and stent was placed. The procedure was
   complicated by difficult to maintain pressures and ventricular
   tachycardia that was poorly responsive to lidocaine and amiodarone.
   Patient required defibrillation multiple times. For pressor support
   patient received dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. For
   anticoagulation patient received bivalirudin, integrillin, and heparin.
   For heart rate patient received atropine 1mg and 2.5 Metoprolol IV. In
   the cath lab, ballon pump and pacemaker were placed. Wedge pressures
   were recorded at 33. Pt was given 80 mg lasix with no appreciable UOP.
   .
   Pt is sedated and intubated, therefore unable to complete ROS. Family
   is not by bedside.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 77 year Russian speaking male with PMH DM,
   reported prior CVA s/p cardiac arrest (PEA). Resuscitated to wide
   complex perfusing rhythm. ED code STEMI was called for inferior STE and
   anterolateral ST depressions - cath demonstrated acute thrombus in RCA
   s/p bare metal stent. Patient unstable in cath lab required multiple
   pressors, ballon pump and temp wire.
   .
   # CORONARIES: STEMI with inferior elevations and anterior lateral
   depressions. Cath demonstrated chronic totally occcluded LAD with
   collaterals, small circ and acute distally ocluded RCA. Patient is s/p
   bare metal stent RCA placement. R heart cath demonstrates RV infarct
   (see below).
   - ASA 325 mg qd and daily plavix 75 mg qd
   - Patient currently with epitaxis, due to coagulopathy affects of
   cooling hold integrillin and plavix load due to risk > benefit
   - Pressor support to maintain MAP >50
   .
   # PUMP: Patient currently in cardiogenic shock secondary to cardiac
   arrest and STEMI. Extremities cool (prior to artic sun), PA sat 53%.
   PCWP 33.
   - ECHO this am
   - Currently on levophed, epinephrine, dopamine and vasopressin. Goal
   MAP 50, attempt to wean dopamine then epinephrine.
   - Continue ballon pump. Will need to add Heparin drip if decrease rate
   from 1:1.

   .

   called and resuscitated pt- by report Epi/Atropine 10 rounds, intubated

   Pt was sent to cath lab: T.O RCA
 BMS placed. In/out VT
 shocked total
   10 times, bolused w/ amio and gtt started.  IABP placed. PCWP 33
 rec
   80mg IV lasix w/ no response, then 160mg w/ no response. Pt admitted
   to  CCU post-cath.
   CCU:  [**10-27**] nites- Arctic sun was initiated on arrival.  He arrived on
   dopamine 15mcg/kg/ vasopressin at 2.4 units/hr/ Levo 0.5mcg/kg/ EPI
   1.25mcg/kg/ Amio at 1mg/min/ Versed 5mg/hr/ Fentanyl 200mcg/min. Pt on
   IABP 1:1 for hypotension/severe CV shock and hemodynamic instability.
   10/5 days-He started on Kepra for seizures seen on EEG and Versed gtt
   was increased. Lasix gtt was started for volume overload and pt started
   to respond w good uo. Also- pressors were weaned slightly but pt
   remained unstable w freq runs VT- repletion of lytes appeared to
   diminish frequency of arrythmias and pt converted from initial AF to
   SR. He continued to have metabolic acidosis. He required vecuronium to
   stay in sink with vent.
   [**10-28**]  More stable hemodynamically with pressures weaned further.Warmed
   to 37 by 1000 and now with low grade fever responding to Tylenol. GI:
   No bowel sounds RENAL: He continues on lasix gtt at 10mg/hr. He
   received 500 diuril at 1100. His urine output improves with higher
   maps. Creatinine is bumping and is 38/2.6.
   Acidosis, Metabolic
   Assessment:
   pH had remained 7.25 and below. Lactate has normalized and he has no
   gap. He is no longer hyperglycemic. Attempts to wean PEEP have failed
   and he has high FI02requirement. Gas at 1400 was more acidotic at
   7.22/48/70
   Action:
   RR increased to 26 with resulting gas improved at 7.27/39/78/-8
   Response:
   Repeat gas later to ensure he does not become more acidotic.
   Plan:
   Monitor gases and treat as ordered.

   Assessment:

   Neuro states he continues to have bursts of electriform seizure
   activity, but nothing  else. His prognosis is very grim.  He shows no
   signs of cranial nerve activity and has had no movement off paralytic.
   He continues on keppra.
   Action:
   He will be weaned off midaz tonight. Neuro will monitor to ensure he
   does not go back into status. Keppra dose renally dosed. Neuro
   attending plans for family meeting tomorrow at 1300.
   Response:
   No change in pt neuro status.
   Plan:

   Translator needs to be arranged for . I  Continue monitoring neuro
   status for change. Wean versed per order.

   Assessment:
   Once pt warmed blood sugar quickly dropped. Drip was shut off at 0930
   at 133 and pt sugar went to 60.
   Action:
   He has had sugars checked Q 30 min and has thus far required 4 amps of
   D50. [**Last Name (un) 72**] consulted and they feel this is a time [**Last Name 9231**] problem as
   he gets rid of all the insulin in his body. The D50 should be given for
   sugars of 80 or below. We could hang D10 but it would be a large fluid
   load.
   Response:
   He will bounce into the 200s after the D50, but in ~1
 hr require

   Continue to monitor blood sugars frequently to prevent hypoglycemia.

   All pedal pulses are now dopplerable. Pt remains hemodynamically stable

   Monitor pedal pulses and groin site for change. Check with team about

   Assessment and Plan
   77 year Russian speaking male with PMH DM, reported prior CVA s/p
   cardiac arrest (PEA). Resuscitated to wide complex perfusing rhythm. ED
   code STEMI was called for inferior STE and anterolateral ST depressions
   - cath demonstrated acute thrombus in RCA s/p bare metal stent. Patient
   unstable in cath lab required multiple pressors, ballon pump and temp
   wire. Patient continues to be intubated, on pressors, with balloon
   pump; being weaned on vent and pressors.
   .
   # CORONARIES: STEMI with inferior elevations and anterior lateral
   depressions. Cath demonstrated chronic totally occcluded LAD with
   collaterals, small circ and acute distally ocluded RCA. Patient is s/p
   bare metal stent RCA placement. R heart cath demonstrates RV infarct
   - ASA 325 mg qd and daily plavix 75 mg qd
   - Patient post-cath with epitaxis; due to coagulopathy affects of
   cooling hold integrillin and plavix load due to risk > benefit
   - Pressor support to maintain MAP >50
   .
   # PUMP: Patient currently in cardiogenic shock secondary to cardiac
   arrest and STEMI. Extremities cool (prior to artic sun), PA sat 53%.
   PCWP 33. EF: 25%.
   - Currently on levophed, epinephrine, dopamine and vasopressin. Goal
   MAP 50, attempt to wean dopamine then epinephrine.
   - Wean epinephrine today, then dopamine as tolerated.
   - Continue ballon pump; on heparin gtt
   - Limit fluid intake
   - Renal to re-eval for CVVH for fluid overload, goal 2-3L off as
   tolerated
   - Continue with lasix drip; additional diuresis as tolerated with loop
   or thiazide diuretic
   .
   # RHYTHM: Hx of PEA and V Tach s/p temp wire. Was in afib, currently
   appears to be in sinus rhythm.
   - D/C amiodorane drip, currently 0.5 mg/min
   - Initiate Amiodarone po 400mg tid
   - Consider cardioversion if loses sinus rhythm
   - Telemetry
   .
   # Cardiac Arrest: Most likely secondary to unstable V Tach and RCA RV
   infarct.
   - Artic sun cooling protocol
 now in warming phase
   - For treatment of underlying causes [**Last Name 435**] problem list.
   .
   # Acid-Base disorder: Anion gap (20) metabolic acidosis with inadequate
   compensation initially. Etiology most likely lactate acidosis. Serum
   tox negative. Patient does not take diabetes medications as outpatient,
   per PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 9217**] was 1.5 suggesting pure AG metabolic acidosis.
   This morning, most recent ABG: 7.25/33/91/-[**12-7**]. Acidemic
 metabolic
   acidosis, respiratory compensation via Winter
s Formula should put the
   pCO2 at between 26 and 30, so see inadequate compensation as some CO2
   still being retained. Serum ketones negative so less concerning picture
   for DKA.
   - Lactic Acidosis: replete bicarb as needed, based upon acid/base
   status as it fluctuates throughout the day
   - Maintain vent settings, increase RR if needed to help with metabolic
   acidosis compensation
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Patchy infiltrate throughout CXR, most likely
   edema secondary to cardiogenic shock demonstrated by high filling
   pressures on right heart cath. Patient is intubated. Patient net
   positive yesterday so concern for worsening pulmonary edema.
   - repeat CXR this AM
   - ARDSnet tidal volumes
   - Paralytics while ventilated for now, decreasing as tolerated
   - Follow-up ABG closely and adjust vent settings as needed
   - Increase peep to improve oxygenation
   - Renal to re-eval for CVVH for fluid overload
   - Lasix drip and extra diuresis as tolerated to increase urine output
   - Sedation versed and fentanyl
   - Increase PEEP to 16 as PO2 on most recent gas 66
   .
   # Neuro: Pt with poor GCS on admission and decorticate posturing.
   Yesterday morning, GCS 3. Neurology unable to assess MS due to sedation
   and cooling. Of note patient too unstable to have head CT scan prior to
   cath and does have prior history of stroke. Neuro feels status
   epilepticus is occurring, based on EEG. Patient treated with keppra and
   midazolam thus far.
   -cooling blanket
   -EEG per cooling protocol
   -f/u neuro recs
   -continue keppra [**Hospital1 **]
   -continue midazolam
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: Insulin resistance picture could be part of
   sympathomimetic treatment plus overall ischemic state. Serum ketones
   negative, so DKA less likely.
   - Insulin drip [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 77**] [**Last Name (un) 72**] rec
s, replete K > 3.3 (but on hold now
   during warming stage of Arctic sun)
   - F/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 72**] rec
s today
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Prior baseline 0.9 creatinine. Acute renal
   failure most likely secondary to hypoperfusion. Pt not responsive to
   160 mg bolus of lasix given in cath lab. Responded to lasix drip and
   thiazide diuretic with urine output yesterday and overnight.
   - renal to re-eval for CVVH for fluid overload
   - Lasix drip continue
   - renal dose all meds
   - follow-up lytes q6hr, replete as needed
   - f/u urine lytes

TITLE: CARDIOLOGY FELLOW CCU ADMISSION NOTE
   77M Russian speaking with report of prior CVA with witnessed arrest,
   found to be in PEA by EMS, resuscitated with approximately 10 rounds of
   epinephrine and atropine to a wide complex perfusing rhythm. In ED, BP
   100/60s without pressors, pulse 60-80s wide complex. Initial rhythm
   strip and subsequent 12 lead ECG showed inferior STE and anterolateral
   ST depressions.
   Taken emergently to cath lab where RCA found to be acutely occluded.
   Thrombus removed and a Vision stent was placed. An intraaortic balloon
   pump was placed for hemodynamic support. A temporary pacemaker was
   placed for bradycardia. He developed recurrent ventricular tachycardia
   that was poorly responsive to lidocaine and amiodarone; he also
   required increasing doses of dopamine, levophed, epinephrine.
   PE:  SBP 80/50s  P 100-150s
   Intubated, not sedated
   RRR, no murmurs
   Distal pulses 1+ bilaterally
   Pupils dilated bilaterally, no blink reflex, mild gag
   GCS 3
   A/P: 77M s/p cardiac arrest with unstable blood pressure requiring
   pressors and recurrent ventricular tachycardia.
   - initiate cooling protocol
   - continue vasopressors and amiodarone
   - ongoing monitoring for return of neurologic function

77 y/o M witnessed cardiac arrest at home (reportedly had been having
   CP since 8pm [**10-27**]). Resuscitated in the. Intubated and sent to [**Hospital1 5**] ED
   on Dopa and IVF w/o. To cath lab: T.O RCA
 BMS placed. In/out VT
   shocked total 10 times, bolused w/ amio and gtt started.  IABP placed.
   PCWP 33
 rec
d 80mg IV lasix w/ no response, then 160mg w/ no response
   (fdifficult foley placement [**2-24**] h/o prostate Ca). To CCU post-cath.
   Upon arrival in CCU Arctic sun was initiated. He arrived on dopamine at
   15mic/kilo, vasopressin at 2.4 units/hr, Norepinephrine at .5mic/kilo,
   Epinephrine at 1.25mic/kilo, amiodarone at 1mg/min, versed at 5mg/hr
   and fentanyl at 200mic/min. He had IABP in place with maps in 50s to
   low 60s. He was intubated and unresponsive. He had minimal urine
   output. He was bleeding from his nose.
   The pt has remained critically ill on multiple pressers. He has been
   weaned to much lower doses of many, but remains acidotic with profound
   metabolic disorder including hypokaelemia for which he is being
   repeatedly repleted, hyperglycemia and hypophosphatemia.
   Seizure, with status epilepticus
   Assessment:
   Pt had been unresponsive to any stimuli and versed was dropped to .5
   and fentanyl to 25mic. By 1100 he was noted to have tongue twitching
   and periodic myoclonic jerks that would cause him to flail and for his
   eyes to open slightly. He became dyscordanant with with vent. His
   pupils were unresponsive and no cranial nerve activity was noted.
   Action:
   At ~1115 he was bolused with 8mg vecuronium and started on drip at
   .05mic/kilo. Not train of 4 was able to be obtained. The jerking
   stopped and he was ventilated without further difficulty. Continuous
   EEG monitoring was initiated and status epilepticus was seen. He was
   boluse with 2000mg keppra IV with minimal improvement in status. He
   then received 8mg bolus of midazalam that improved his EEG tracing. Per
   neuro versed was increased to 3mg/hr.
   Response:
   Neuro states he continues to have improved EEG readings, less seizure
   activity.
   Plan:
   Continue midaz and keppra as ordered. Monitor for signs of seizures.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Pt remains in cardiogenic shock post RCA stent. IABP is in place 1:1
   with good augmentation and improved unloading. He was on max doses of
   all pressers. He was in a-fib, having frequent PVCs, but no runs of VT.
   Cks 3643 with troponin 20. He has Art and venous sheaths in R groin and
   IABP in L groin. Feet are cold, but all pulses now dopplerable. Maps
   have stayed over 60.  He was profoundly hypokaelemic. He was making no
   urine. pH remains in low 7s with periodic bicarb being given.
   Action:
   Pressers have been wean and at present he is on norepi at .1mic/kilo,
   vasopressin at 2.4 units, dopamine at 5mic/kilo, epi at .03 mic/kilo.
   Amiodarone was decreased to .5mg/min. He was bolused with lasix 80mg IV
   at 1100.  Last blood gas on AC 550 X 24, 15 PEEP and 80% was
   7.26/32/73/-11 15. his lactate was 7. He received a total of 140meq KCL
   IV. dHe received 600lmg plavix down NG tube. He has also been mag and
   calcium replaced.
   Response:
   He has remained hemodynamically stable on  lower presser doses. He went
   into NSR at ~1630, but is now having more ectopy, including runs of
   V-tach. Latest K was 3.2 and he is now receiving an addition 60 meq KCL
   IV. He received 150meq biCarb at 1800.
   Plan:
   Get gas ~ 8, Continue cycling enzymes. Monitor lytes closely and
   repleate as needed.

Chief Complaint: STEMI/VFIB ARREST.
   24 Hour Events:
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: 51 yo man no known medical history was
   noticed to be driving erratically earlier this morning in NH and
   ultimately suffered an unrestrained MVA crashing his car into a tree.
   Did not appear to EMS to be traumatic arrest. Found apneic and
   pulseless in VF, with downtime of minutes before CPR initiated with
   EMS. Shocked 3x, epinephrine x2,atropine x1, lidocaine 2g IV then taken
   to [**Hospital3 **] Center in NH, then to [**University/College 2158**]. On arrival to the
   [**Hospital1 5**] ED he had a GCS of 7, unconscious. Initial CE were CK: 1694
   Trop-T: 4.11 and have EKG changes consistent with STEMI. He was loaded
   with [**Last Name (LF) 12105**],[**First Name3 (LF) **], integrillin, and started on heparin drip.  Within 3
   hours of his arrest he hit the cath lab and was found to have total
   occlusion of the LAD proximally with BMS placed to the ostium of the
   LAD. There was also 30% distal RCA lesion, minimal Lcx disease. He
   underwent LHC with L ventriculograpy and coronary angiography which
   noted proximal TO of LAD. A BMS was placed.
   On leaving the cath lab he was found to be hypertensive and was started
   on nitro gtt, and NGT was placed, and transferred to the CCU.
   On arrival to the CCU he was hemodynamically stable. A repeat EKG at
   that time showed improvement in his ST elevation post
   revascularization. He was weaned off nitro GTT, continued on [**First Name3 (LF) 12105**] and
   heparin GTT.
   .
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
   psoriasis
   cholecystectomy
   .
   MEDICATIONS:
   unknown
   .
   ALLERGIES:
   unknown
   .
   SOCIAL HISTORY: works as an accountant, lives in [**Location **]. Occassional EtOH.
   Quit smoking several years ago.
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY: father died of massive MI at age 47. Mother with
   ?mitral valve prolapse died at age 79 (about three months ago).

Chief Complaint:
   He initially lost his DP/PT in his left leg, and warming blankets were
   placed peripherally with recovery of his pulse
    overnight he received 4L IVF with  improvement of his lactate from 5.1
   to 2.7 closing of his anion gap to **** with UOP 30-40cc/hr maintaing
   BPs with MAPs in the 80s. Around 6:30pm his maps dropped to the high
   50
s, his UOP trailed off, amnio off, sedation decreased, fluids wide
   open,  dobutamine was started peripherally and a central line was
   placed.
   He was shivering significantly with subsequent warming, initially got
   vecuronium boluses x 2 then started on vecuronium drip.
   His GFS ranged 300s to 400s with humalog given, and was started on an
   insulin drip this am.
   On Telemetry  he was in sinus with PVCs.

   Weaning sedation and when pt woke up and nodding head placed on PS

Chief Complaint:  Transfer s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   55-year-old male with history of two vessel CAD, ischemic
   cardiomyopathy, EF ~15%, mitral regurgitation, and diabetes on oral
   agents who presents from OSH s/p VT/VF cardiac arrest.  By report,
   patient had been having nausea/vomiting and diarrhea for several days
   prior to admission.  In this setting had decreased PO intake.  On night
   of admission was dry heaving for some time.  Heard by his sister to be
   gurgling and she came up stairs to find patient pulseless, with eyes
   rolled back, rigid and foaming at mouth.  Immediately initiated CPR and
   family called EMS.
   .
   On arrival, EMS found patient to be in VF and was shocked into VT.
   Shocked 3 times in total for VT/VF.  Patient was intubated on arrival
   to OSH ED.  Was given epinephrine/lidocaine/atropine and amiodarone
   with subsequent return of perfusing rhythm.  Reportedly was responsive
   in the ED, and then had a second arrest the details of which are
   unclear but was thought to be respiratory in nature. Was admitted to
   the ICU where impression was for cardiogenic shock with oliguric renal
   failure likely [**3-16**] ATN.
   .
   In ICU, patient on dopamine/levophed for presumed cardiogenic shock.
   CE's reportedly unremarkable and no e/o ischemia by ECG but [**Last Name (un) **]
   baseline LBBB.  Patient inutabed for airway protection and requiring
   versed for sedation.  Course c/b hyperglycemia requiring insulin gtt.
   Now transfered to [**Hospital1 19**] for further management.
   .
   On arrival to [**Hospital1 19**], patient intubated with stable VS on
   dopamine/levophed.

   Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling

   posteriorly directed jet of moderate to severe (3+) mitral
   regurgitation is seen. Due to the eccentric nature of the regurgitant
   jet, its severity may be significantly underestimated (Coanda effect).

 CARDIAC ARREST
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  55 y/o M ischemic cardiomyopathy EF 15%, now s/p
   VT/VF arrest transfered with cardiogenic shock.
   .
   # Shock/Arrest: Initial rhythm appears to be VF with e/o VT throughout
   ACLS treatment.  Could be [**3-16**] to thrombosis of DES in RCA vs. occlusion
   of LAD although both seem unlikely given relatively flat biomarkers
   post-arrest.  Scar mediated VT/VF is a possibility.  Currently, most
   likely in cardiogenic shock s/p arrest with improving hemodynamics on
   arrival.  Nothing by history to suggest another etiology for arrest
   although cannot exclude the possibility.
   - wean dopamine with MAP goal > 60.
   - weaned levophed to off on arrival.
   - If deteriorates clinically would consider cath urgently, otherwise
   plan for cath on Monday if INR allows.
   - Repeat ECG in AM.
   - Consider RHC PRN.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated for airway protection.  High peak
   pressures on the vent, with relatively small tidal volumes.  CXR
   unimpressive, and oxygenating well.
   - Wean as tolerated.
   .
   # CORONARIES: 2 vessel CAD with DES in RCA.  Plan as outlined above.
   - Aspirin
   - Plavix
   - Hold heparin gtt as INR supratherapeutic on coumadin.
   - High dose statin in acute setting until cath and then consider return
   to home dose if no acute plaque rupture detected.
   .
   # PUMP/Valves:  3+MR/2+TR by echo [**2106**].
   - Repeat Echo to evaluate for new wall motion abnormalities and
   progression of valvular disease that might be contributing to shock
   - Diurese as tolerated.
   - Central Venous O2 sat for Fick Cardiac Output
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm.  Monitor on tele.
   - Will need ICD for secondary prevention
   .
   # Neuro Status: With sedation weaned is responsive and follows simple
   commands.  Reportedly CT head negative at OSH.
   - wean sedation
   - follow exam closely
   .
   # Diabetes: Finger sticks have improved to normal range.  Does not
   require insulin at home but poorly controlled on oral agents.
   - hold metformin.
   - humalog insulin sliding scale
   .
   # LV Thrombus:
   - No e/o thrombus on repeat echo's, and ? need to continue coumadin
   long-term
   - Heparin gtt when INR < 2.0
   - hold vitamin K/coumadin and allow INR to reverse on its own.
   - Likely [**3-16**] coumadin at home with superimposed portion from liver
   failure.
   .
   # Liver Injury: Likely shock liver.
   - Trend enzymes
   .
   # Renal Failure: Likely ATN.  Send urinalysis, urine lytes.
   - I/O
   - foley catheter
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Likely [**3-16**] to arrest.
   - CIS

Chief Complaint:  Transfer s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   55-year-old male with history of two vessel CAD, ischemic
   cardiomyopathy, EF ~15%, mitral regurgitation, and diabetes on oral
   agents who presents from OSH s/p VT/VF cardiac arrest.  By report,
   patient had been having nausea/vomiting and diarrhea for several days
   prior to admission.  In this setting had decreased PO intake.  On night
   of admission was dry heaving for some time.  Heard by his sister to be
   gurgling and she came up stairs to find patient pulseless, with eyes
   rolled back, rigid and foaming at mouth.  Immediately initiated CPR and
   family called EMS.
   .
   On arrival, EMS found patient to be in VF and was shocked into VT.
   Shocked 3 times in total for VT/VF.  Patient was intubated on arrival
   to OSH ED.  Was given epinephrine/lidocaine/atropine and amiodarone
   with subsequent return of perfusing rhythm.  Reportedly was responsive
   in the ED, and then had a second arrest the details of which are
   unclear but was thought to be respiratory in nature. Was admitted to
   the ICU where impression was for cardiogenic shock with oliguric renal
   failure likely [**3-16**] ATN.
   .
   In ICU, patient on dopamine/levophed for presumed cardiogenic shock.
   CE's reportedly unremarkable and no e/o ischemia by ECG but [**Last Name (un) **]
   baseline LBBB.  Patient inutabed for airway protection and requiring

 CARDIAC ARREST
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  55 y/o M ischemic cardiomyopathy EF 15%, now s/p
   VT/VF arrest transfered with cardiogenic shock.
   .
   # Shock/Arrest: Initial rhythm appears to be VF with e/o VT throughout
   ACLS treatment.  Could be [**3-16**] to thrombosis of DES in RCA vs. occlusion
   of LAD although both seem unlikely given relatively flat biomarkers
   post-arrest.  Scar mediated VT/VF is a possibility.  Currently, most
   likely in cardiogenic shock s/p arrest with improving hemodynamics on
   arrival.  Nothing by history to suggest another etiology for arrest
   although cannot exclude the possibility.
   - wean dopamine with MAP goal > 60.
   - weaned levophed to off on arrival.
   - If deteriorates clinically would consider cath urgently, otherwise
   plan for cath on Monday if INR allows.
   - Repeat ECG in AM.
   - Consider RHC PRN.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated for airway protection.  High peak
   pressures on the vent, with relatively small tidal volumes.  CXR
   unimpressive, and oxygenating well.
   - Wean as tolerated.
   .
   # CORONARIES: 2 vessel CAD with DES in RCA.  Plan as outlined above.
   - Aspirin
   - Plavix
   - Hold heparin gtt as INR supratherapeutic on coumadin.
   - High dose statin in acute setting until cath and then consider return
   to home dose if no acute plaque rupture detected.
   .
   # PUMP/Valves:  3+MR/2+TR by echo [**2106**].
   - Repeat Echo to evaluate for new wall motion abnormalities and
   progression of valvular disease that might be contributing to shock
   - Diurese as tolerated.
   - Central Venous O2 sat for Fick Cardiac Output
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm.  Monitor on tele.
   - Will need ICD for secondary prevention
   .
   # Neuro Status: With sedation weaned is responsive and follows simple
   commands.  Reportedly CT head negative at OSH.
   - wean sedation
   - follow exam closely
   .
   # Diabetes: Finger sticks have improved to normal range.  Does not
   require insulin at home but poorly controlled on oral agents.
   - hold metformin.
   - humalog insulin sliding scale
   .

   - No e/o thrombus on repeat echo's, and ? need to continue coumadin

   - hold vitamin K/coumadin and allow INR to reverse on its own.

   ASSESSMENT
   This 52-year-old man with few other medical problems, mild hypertension
   and dyslipidemia, presents with his first symptomatic ischemic episdose
   with significant coronary disease involving all major vessels.
   PLAN
   Coronary Artery Disease
     Catheterization reveals significant RCA, LAD (including diagonal)and
   LCx disease with stent placement to the LCx. Given extensive disease,
   the patient is a candidate for CABG. Symptomatic ischemia and EKG
   changed likely derived from occluded LCx. After recovery from this
   procedure, CABG will likely be considered.
   - Stop Plavix given likely surgery
   - Continue integrillin for 18 hours, or until surgery (switching off
   3-4 hours before surgery)
   - Atorvastatin 80 mg QD
   - Morphine 2-4 mg Q4H PRN pain
   - Check A1c - pnd
   - Lipid panel (not checked for ~ 10 months) - pnd
   - ASA 325 QD EC
   - Echo when stable given concern for MR in context of MI
   - CSurg has been contact[**Name (NI) **] re CABG
 they follow
 we appreciate their
   input
   - Trend enzymes until peak and trend down
   [**Name (NI) **] Fibrillation, Ventricular Tachycardia, Torsades du Pointes
     Although atypical, AF appears to be an ischemic rhythm in this case
   (concern for MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 7306**] stretch). It appeared responsible for
   hypotension, but hypotension continues despite resolution of AF
   however, each of the above rhythms is also associated with lowered
   pressure. Cardioversion was desirable and successful in the cath. lab.
   Since that time, ventricular tachycardia and torsades du pointes have
   been more concerning. Given QTc prolongation amiodarone was initially
   avoided for fear, apparently justified of torsades (given frequent
   ectopy). However, desire to avoid beta blocker, based on recent trial
   data with AMI patients, and very frequently falling pressure with
   ventricular tachycardia eventually led to us deciding upon amiodarone
   loading. This has indeed reduced VT and pads are on the patient if
   sustained torsades appears. If his pressure improves today, we may also
   use very small amount of beta-blocker. We will also continue to
   aggressively replete K and Mg and remove the Swan-Ganz line for fear
   that this could also trigger arrhythmias (although, so far, they do not
   appear to have right ventricular origin)
   - Continue amiodarone

   ASSESSMENT
   This 52-year-old man with few other medical problems, mild hypertension
   and dyslipidemia, presents with his first symptomatic ischemic episdose
   with significant coronary disease involving all major vessels.
   PLAN
   Coronary Artery Disease
     Catheterization reveals significant RCA, LAD (including diagonal)and
   LCx disease with stent placement to the LCx. Given extensive disease,
   the patient is a candidate for CABG. Symptomatic ischemia and EKG
   changed likely derived from occluded LCx. After recovery from this
   procedure, CABG will likely be considered.
   - Stop Plavix given likely surgery
   - Continue integrillin for 18 hours, or until surgery (switching off
   3-4 hours before surgery)
   - Atorvastatin 80 mg QD
   - Morphine 2-4 mg Q4H PRN pain
   - Check A1c - pnd
   - Lipid panel (not checked for ~ 10 months) - pnd
   - ASA 325 QD EC
   - Echo when stable given concern for MR in context of MI
   - CSurg has been contact[**Name (NI) **] re CABG
 they follow
 we appreciate their
   input
   - Trend enzymes until peak and trend down
   [**Name (NI) **] Fibrillation, Ventricular Tachycardia, Torsades du Pointes
     Although atypical, AF appears to be an ischemic rhythm in this case
   (concern for MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 7306**] stretch). It appeared responsible for
   hypotension, but hypotension continues despite resolution of AF
   however, each of the above rhythms is also associated with lowered
   pressure. Cardioversion was desirable and successful in the cath. lab.
   Since that time, ventricular tachycardia and torsades du pointes have
   been more concerning. Given QTc prolongation amiodarone was initially
   avoided for fear, apparently justified of torsades (given frequent
   ectopy). However, desire to avoid beta blocker, based on recent trial
   data with AMI patients, and very frequently falling pressure with
   ventricular tachycardia eventually led to us deciding upon amiodarone
   loading. This has indeed reduced VT and pads are on the patient if
   sustained torsades appears. If his pressure improves today, we may also
   use very small amount of beta-blocker. We will also continue to
   aggressively replete K and Mg and remove the Swan-Ganz line for fear
   that this could also trigger arrhythmias (although, so far, they do not
   appear to have right ventricular origin)
   - Continue amiodarone
   - Leave cardioversion pads in place
   - Start small dose of metoprolol if pressure permits
   - Remove Swan
   - Monitor with telemetry
   Hypertension/Hypotension
     Will not need to treat hypertension initially, given hypotension.
   Will reconsider antihypertensive regimen if indicated and depending on
   indications at discharge. Hypotension, Rx initially with dopamine,
   electrical cardioversion and baloon pump.
   - Continue balloon pump for now
 turn off for short periods [**Hospital1 7**] to
   evaluate pressure without
   - Follow Fick CI with mixed sat
   - Avoid pressors if possible, consider dobutamine as first line
   Leukocytosis
     Likely stress demargination in ACS. Cortisol quite elevated at 26 in
   the evening.
   - Follow
   Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia
   - Replete aggressively to ensure K does not even go below 4 and Mg
   stays above 2
   FEN:
   - No IVFs (received 4.5 L overnight)
   ACCESS:
   - PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   - DVT ppx with heparin IV
   - Pain management with morphine
   - Bowel regimen with colace and senna (standing)

   - wean settings as able

   hypoglycemia is a possibility, hypoxia less likely. Trop leak and
   worsening ST depressions on EKG; however, ischemia typically associated
   with VF arrest.  EKG now back at baseline
   - ECHO (eval for per effusion and r hear strain)
   - trend CE
   - no heparin or ASA given GI bleed
   # UGIB: NGT draining BRB with hct drop 36--> 27. Unknown baseline. Now
   s/p 4units pRBCs without adequate bump in hct
   - GI consult again today and likely needs EGD for continued UGIB and

   His initial rhythm was PEA.  He received CPR and then was found to be

   to sinus tach (all per report). In the ED, his BP was 68/41.  He was
   intubated and EKG was done which showed afib, rate 70s, RBBB, ST
   elevation in aVR and V1 with ST depressions in II, III, V3-V6, poor

   lab.  In the cath lab, his 3 grafts were patent.  He had a stenosis of
   his distal LAD which was treated with balloon angioplasty.

   Assessment:
   s/p PEA arrest with conversion to VT after CPR in the field [**4-7**] (as
   reported). Also s/p cardiac cath [**4-7**] w/ distal LAD disease treated w/
   angioplasty. On amiodarone gtt. Now cooled via Arctic Sun Protocol to
   goal temperature 34 degrees celcius- initiated at 1830 pm on [**4-7**].

   right radial aline placed overnight.

   # Cardiac arrest: Reportedly in PEA arrest initially with conversion to
   VT after CPR.  Intubated in the ED.  He was started on amiodarone gtt
   in [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  Differential for PEA arrest includes cardiac ischemia
   although grafts were patent, distal LAD disease treated with POBA vs
   pulmonary embolism vs heart failure vs primary electrical disease vs
   intracranial hemorrhage (reportedly normal mental status prior to
   arrest) vs tamponade.  There is no evidence for hypovolemia/bleeding,
   hyper/hypokalemia (K on arrival to ED was 4.0), medication overdoses,
   or trauma.  Acidosis was evident on arrival to ED, however may have
   been a result of arrest vs cause of.
   - Continue amiodarone gtt for now to prevent further arrhythmias
   - Induce cooling protocol with Arctic Sun - although patient is
   currently hypothermic on his own.  Goal temperature 34 degrees.  Of
   note, hypothermia can cause hypocoagulability so will need to monitor
   bleeding status - patient oozing from NGT currently.
   - Serial ABGs, goal CO2 35-40.
   - Will check CT PE to rule out PE as cause of arrest and will do CT
   head to rule out acute intracerebral hemorrhage.  Given large contrast
   load will give post-cath and post-CT IVF.
   - Continuous EEG monitoring to assess for status epilepticus once
   patient returns from CT scan - high incidence of status epilepticus in
   post arrest patients.  Can try propofol or benzodiazepines.
   - Neuro evaluation given new symptoms of myoclonic jerking, ? status:
   Concern for anoxic brain injury including anoxic myoclonus, no
   brainstem reflexes and no withdrawal to stimuli.  Neuro does not feel
   movements are related to seizure activity.
   - Check echocardiogram in AM to look for structural heart disease.
   - Pressors as needed to keep MAPs>65
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Check full panel of labs to evaluate electrolytes
   - Continue ASA.  Will continue plavix as reportedly had BMS x 2 in
   9/[**2156**].
   - Trend lactate.  5.1 on admission > 1.6.
   - Tight glycemic control.  Discussed with his outpatient
   endocrinologist who says patient does not do well on lantus.
   .
   #. CAD s/p CABG ([**2143**], redo [**2152**]).  Cardiac catheterization today
   revealed distal LAD disease s/p POBA.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes.
   - Continue ASA, plavix
   - High dose statin
   - Continue beta blocker as tolerated by BP
   .
   #. Pump: Hemodynamics on catheterization not assessed on cath.
   - Echocardiogram in the AM.
   .
   # Rhythm: s/p PEA arrest, converted to VT prior to ED arrival.  Now in
   atrial fibrillation on telemetry.
   - Not on coumadin at outpatient given history of frequent falls.
   - Continue to monitor closely on telemetry.
   .
   #. s/p AVR: Bioprosthetic valve
   - Evaluate aortic function with echocardiogram in the AM.
   .

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is an 85 year-old male with a history of CAD s/p CABG [**2143**]
   (SVG-LCx, LIMA-LAD), redo in [**2152**] (SVG>PDA) with AVR, constrictive
   pericarditis who presents from home after PEA arrest, taken emergently
   to cath lab and found to have distal LAD lesion treated with POBA.
   Etiology of PEA arrest remains unclear.
   .
   # Cardiac arrest: Reportedly in PEA arrest initially with conversion to
   VT after CPR.  Intubated in the ED.  He was started on amiodarone gtt
   in [**Hospital1 19**] ED.  Differential for PEA arrest includes cardiac ischemia
   although grafts were patent, distal LAD disease treated with POBA vs
   pulmonary embolism vs heart failure vs primary electrical disease vs
   intracranial hemorrhage (reportedly normal mental status prior to
   arrest) vs tamponade.  There is no evidence for hypovolemia/bleeding,
   hyper/hypokalemia (K on arrival to ED was 4.0), medication overdoses,
   or trauma.  Acidosis was evident on arrival to ED, however may have
   been a result of arrest vs cause of.
   - Continue amiodarone gtt for now to prevent further arrhythmias
   - Induce cooling protocol with Arctic Sun - although patient is
   currently hypothermic on his own.  Goal temperature 34 degrees.  Of
   note, hypothermia can cause hypocoagulability so will need to monitor
   bleeding status - patient oozing from NGT currently.
   - Serial ABGs, goal CO2 35-40.
   - Will check CT PE to rule out PE as cause of arrest and will do CT
   head to rule out acute intracerebral hemorrhage.  Given large contrast
   load will give post-cath and post-CT IVF.
   - Continuous EEG monitoring to assess for status epilepticus once
   patient returns from CT scan - high incidence of status epilepticus in
   post arrest patients.  Can try propofol or benzodiazepines.
   - Neuro evaluation given new symptoms of myoclonic jerking, ? status:
   Concern for anoxic brain injury including anoxic myoclonus, no
   brainstem reflexes and no withdrawal to stimuli.  Neuro does not feel
   movements are related to seizure activity.
   - Check echocardiogram in AM to look for structural heart disease.
   - Pressors as needed to keep MAPs>65
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Check full panel of labs to evaluate electrolytes

   9/[**2156**].

   - Tight glycemic control.  Discussed with his outpatient

 HISTORY:  85-year-old male with PEA arrest at home, status post cath with only

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT of the chest was obtained before and after the administration
 of intravenous contrast.  The images were reformatted in the axial, coronal,
 sagittal, and oblique planes.

 FINDINGS:
 No filling defect in pulmonary artery branches suggestive of pulmonary
 embolism. Evidence of pulmonary hypertension suggested by increased size of
 pulmonary artery (main measures 35 mm, right measures 26 mm and left measures
 22 mm).

 Presence of moderate amount of right effusion associated with adjacent lung
 atelectasis.  Emphysematous changes with presence of scattered bullae

Chief Complaint:  syncope
   HPI:
   [This note is an adaptation and updating of the original CCU admission
   note which was not placed in MetaVision; it reflects history obtained
   by me and by the CCU team. Assessment and plan is for MICU admission.]
   The patient is an 82 year old male with a history of CRI being set up
   for HD, DM, and HTN who presented after a syncopal episode. The patient
   is being transitioned to HD due to continually worsening renal
   function. He is followed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1788**] of nephrology, with daily
   kayexalate and frequent electrolyte monitoring. By report, the patient
   has not had his usual daily bowel movements for 3 days and had missed a
   scheduled lab check on the day of presentation due to the snow.
   .
   On the morning of presentation, the patient awoke nauseous and not
   feeling well, got up to go to the bathroom and felt dizzy. He was
   witnessed by his family to syncopize, and was unresponsive for a few
   minutes. Following the event, he continued to feel light headed and
   nauseous. The patient complained of low back pain throughout the day.
   It was unclear if this was due to trauma. EMS was called, evidently
   after a pre-syncopal event (per second-hand account of patient
   grandson) on the evening of presentation; he had not clearly worsened
   during the day before that according to his grandson. When EMS arrived
   the patient continued to vomit, his HR was 80, BP 90/50, and he was
   taken to [**Hospital3 **].
   .
   At [**Hospital3 **], the patient was found to be in a junctional
   bradycardia as low as 15; he had a BP 105/70, Cr of 3.5, and K was 6.5.
   He got 0.5 of atropine, then 1mg of atropine without effect.
   Transcutaneous pacer pads were used, but due to concern of low blood
   pressure, no sedation was given, and shocks were discontinued when they
   did not capture. The patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] CCU for
   transvenous pacing.
   .
   On transport, Mr [**Known lastname 4518**]
s HR remained 18-20 with SBP of 105-147, with an
   oxygen saturation of 92% on a NRB. On arrival to the floor, the patient
   was found to be minimally responsive with labored breathing. An ABG was
   obtained, with a gas of 7.02/43/102, potassium of 7.3, and lactate of
   7.0. Ten (10) units of insulin and 50ml of dextrose were administered.
   The patient's breathing became increasingly agonal, and bag ventilation
   was intiated. His pulse became thready and systolic blood pressures
   dropped into the 60s. Dopamine was started, and quickly up titrated to
   20. The patient was by this time in PEA arrest and a code blue was
   called. The patient was ultimately intubated. With absent pulse, chest
   compressions were intiated. The patient received a total of 3 amps of
   atropine, 2 pushes of epi, 2g of calcium, and 2 amps of bicarb. The
   patient regained a normal HR at 80 and BP of 120/50.
   Renal was emergently consulted. A temporary HD line was placed and CVVH
   was initiated. He was difficult to ventilate initially until it was
   recognized that he had a right mainstem bronchus intubation; his ETT
   was pulled back and his oxygenation improved. Since then, by report he
   has remained stable on the ventilator. He had a CT scan of his abdomen
   for which a preliminary read suggested colitis and pancreatitis without
   contrast extravasation into the peritoneum. When he was transferred to
   the MICU he remained on dopamine as a pressor but the nursing staff
   were soon able to stop this, after which his pressures remain stable
   and MAPS remained >65.

   placement. Presented to OSH with 1 day history of malaise. On daily
   kayexlate for hyperkalemia, missed a dose and  began to complain of low
   back pain, nausea, had pre-syncope - EMS was called and found him
   vomitting and hypotensive. On arrival to OSH ED was in junctional
   bradycardia with rate to 15. Failed transcutaneous pacing and was

   nauseous. The patient complained of low back pain throughout the day.
   It was unclear if this was due to trauma. EMS was activiated on the
   evening of presentation, but it is unclear what had precipitated the

   The patient is an 82 year old male with a history of CRI being set up
   for HD, DM, and HTN who presented after a syncopal episode. The patient
   is being transitioned to HD due to continually worsening renal
   function. He is followed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1788**] of nephrology, with daily
   kayexalate and frequent electrolyte monitoring. By report, the patient
   has not had his usual daily bowel movements for 3 days and had missed a
   scheduled lab check on the day of presentation due to the snow.
   .
   On the morning of presentation, the patient awoke nauseous and not
   feeling well, got up to go to the bathroom and felt dizzy. He was
   witnessed by his family to syncopize, and was unresponsive for a few
   minutes. Following the event, he continued to feel light headed and
   nauseous. The patient complained of low back pain throughout the day.
   It was unclear if this was due to trauma. EMS was called, evidently
   after a pre-syncopal event (per second-hand account of patient
   grandson) on the evening of presentation; he had not clearly worsened
   during the day before that according to his grandson. When EMS arrived
   the patient continued to vomit, his HR was 80, BP 90/50, and he was
   taken to [**Hospital3 **].
   .
   At [**Hospital3 **], the patient was found to be in a junctional
   bradycardia as low as 15; he had a BP 105/70, Cr of 3.5, and K was 6.5.
   He got 0.5 of atropine, then 1mg of atropine without effect.
   Transcutaneous pacer pads were used, but due to concern of low blood
   pressure, no sedation was given, and shocks were discontinued when they
   did not capture. The patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] CCU for
   transvenous pacing.
   .
   On transport, Mr [**Known lastname 4518**]
s HR remained 18-20 with SBP of 105-147, with an
   oxygen saturation of 92% on a NRB. On arrival to the floor, the patient
   was found to be minimally responsive with labored breathing. An ABG was
   obtained, with a gas of 7.02/43/102, potassium of 7.3, and lactate of
   7.0. Ten (10) units of insulin and 50ml of dextrose were administered.
   The patient's breathing became increasingly agonal, and bag ventilation
   was intiated. His pulse became thready and systolic blood pressures
   dropped into the 60s. Dopamine was started, and quickly up titrated to
   20. The patient was by this time in PEA arrest and a code blue was
   called. The patient was ultimately intubated. With absent pulse, chest
   compressions were intiated. The patient received a total of 3 amps of
   atropine, 2 pushes of epi, 2g of calcium, and 2 amps of bicarb. The
   patient regained a normal HR at 80 and BP of 120/50.
   Renal was emergently consulted. A temporary HD line was placed and CVVH
   was initiated. He was difficult to ventilate initially until it was
   recognized that he had a right mainstem bronchus intubation; his ETT
   was pulled back and his oxygenation improved. Since then, by report he
   has remained stable on the ventilator. He had a CT scan of his abdomen
   for which a preliminary read suggested colitis and pancreatitis without
   contrast extravasation into the peritoneum. When he was transferred to
   the MICU he remained on dopamine as a pressor but the nursing staff
   were soon able to stop this, after which his pressures remain stable
   and MAPS remained >65.

   placement. Presented to OSH with 1 day history of malaise. On daily
   kayexlate for hyperkalemia, missed a dose and  began to complain of low
   back pain, nausea, had pre-syncope - EMS was called and found him
   vomitting and hypotensive. On arrival to OSH ED was in junctional
   bradycardia with rate to 15. Failed transcutaneous pacing and was
   transfered to [**Hospital1 19**]. On arrival ABG 7.02/43/102. K 7.3 and lactate of
   7.0 -> PEA arrest. Epi + atropine as well as hyper K -> ROSC.
   Intubated during the code and transferred to the CCU where he was
   initiatiated on CVVH. Also got chest/ab/pelvis CT which showed possible
   ischemic colitis and pancreatiac edema c/w pancreatitis. Transfered
   from CCU to MICU on dopamine but this was rapidly weaned off.
   Events: daily wake up this morning. RSBI =13. Patient extubated to face
   tent at 0945. Patient received recemic epi neb x1 for possible stridor
   with improvement. Weaned O2 to 2L NC this evening. SAT 98-100%.
   Patient attempting to get OOB, pulling at tubes. Translator to bedside,
   patient trying to get up to go to the bathroom. Foley cath explained to
   patient, asked him not to pull at tubes. Patient has been calm and
   cooperative since. At that time pt also denied pain, and stated he had
   no questions or concerns for staff at this time. Family in to visit
   this evening.

Chief Complaint:  syncope
   HPI:
   [This note is an adaptation and updating of the original CCU admission
   note which was not placed in MetaVision; it reflects history obtained
   by me and by the CCU team. Assessment and plan is for MICU admission.]
   The patient is an 82 year old male with a history of CRI being set up
   for HD, DM, and HTN who presented after a syncopal episode. The patient
   is being transitioned to HD due to continually worsening renal
   function. He is followed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1788**] of nephrology, with daily
   kayexalate and frequent electrolyte monitoring. By report, the patient
   has not had his usual daily bowel movements for 3 days and had missed a
   scheduled lab check on the day of presentation due to the snow.
   .
   On the morning of presentation, the patient awoke nauseous and not
   feeling well, got up to go to the bathroom and felt dizzy. He was
   witnessed by his family to syncopize, and was unresponsive for a few
   minutes. Following the event, he continued to feel light headed and
   nauseous. The patient complained of low back pain throughout the day.
   It was unclear if this was due to trauma. EMS was called, evidently
   after a pre-syncopal event (per second-hand account of patient
   grandson) on the evening of presentation; he had not clearly worsened
   during the day before that according to his grandson. When EMS arrived
   the patient continued to vomit, his HR was 80, BP 90/50, and he was
   taken to [**Hospital3 **].
   .
   At [**Hospital3 **], the patient was found to be in a junctional
   bradycardia as low as 15; he had a BP 105/70, Cr of 3.5, and K was 6.5.
   He got 0.5 of atropine, then 1mg of atropine without effect.
   Transcutaneous pacer pads were used, but due to concern of low blood
   pressure, no sedation was given, and shocks were discontinued when they
   did not capture. The patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] CCU for
   transvenous pacing.
   .
   On transport, Mr [**Known lastname 4518**]
s HR remained 18-20 with SBP of 105-147, with an
   oxygen saturation of 92% on a NRB. On arrival to the floor, the patient
   was found to be minimally responsive with labored breathing. An ABG was
   obtained, with a gas of 7.02/43/102, potassium of 7.3, and lactate of
   7.0. Ten (10) units of insulin and 50ml of dextrose were administered.
   The patient's breathing became increasingly agonal, and bag ventilation
   was intiated. His pulse became thready and systolic blood pressures
   dropped into the 60s. Dopamine was started, and quickly up titrated to
   20. The patient was by this time in PEA arrest and a code blue was
   called. The patient was ultimately intubated. With absent pulse, chest
   compressions were intiated. The patient received a total of 3 amps of
   atropine, 2 pushes of epi, 2g of calcium, and 2 amps of bicarb. The
   patient regained a normal HR at 80 and BP of 120/50.
   Renal was emergently consulted. A temporary HD line was placed and CVVH
   was initiated. He was difficult to ventilate initially until it was
   recognized that he had a right mainstem bronchus intubation; his ETT
   was pulled back and his oxygenation improved. Since then, by report he
   has remained stable on the ventilator. He had a CT scan of his abdomen
   for which a preliminary read suggested colitis and pancreatitis without
   contrast extravasation into the peritoneum. When he was transferred to
   the MICU he remained on dopamine as a pressor but the nursing staff
   were soon able to stop this, after which his pressures remain stable
   and MAPS remained >65.
   Patient admitted from: [**Hospital1 19**] CCU transfer

   hyperkalemia.
   # Hypotension: Mr [**Known lastname 4518**] was hypotensive in the CCU, even after his
   hyperkalemia and bradycardia were corrected. He had a high lactate. His
   CT scan included findings of possible pancreatitis (supported by high
   pancreatic enzymes) and colitis (which might be source of high but now
   lower lactate).  His lactate is declining which is reassuring; however,
   his pancreatic enzymes are rising and fluid balance will need to be
   watched closely. Sepsis may have been an underlying issue; cultures are
   pending.
   -- q6h Hct and chem.7 as measures of hydration status in context of
   pancreatitis
   -- BP stable for now
   -- discuss fluid balance and dialysis vs fluid boluses + diuresis with
   renal fellow as necessary; currently putting out urine and holding
   normal blood pressure
   -- vanc/zosyn as empiric treatment for first 48 hours in setting of
   high lactate; cultures pending; hope to narrow coverage or remove it if
   lactate appears to be result of poor perfusion only; renal failure
poor perfusion without infection remains the most economical
   explanation
   # Bradycardia: Mr [**Known lastname 4518**] was transferred to the [**Hospital1 19**] CCU from [**Hospital1 **] originally because of bradycardia refractory to transcutaneous
   pacing attempts. The bradycardia was in the setting of severe
   hyperkalemia, and although he first had a PEA cardiac arrest requiring
   resuscitation, his arrythmias resolved after correction of potassium in
   the [**Hospital1 19**] CCU. Agree with CCU assessment that potassium level is likely
   source of his original bradycardia and likely his syncopal and
   pre-syncopal events described by his family.
   -- correct potassium, follow K q 6 for first 24 hours, q12 thereafter
   if stable
   -- no need for pacing currently, keeping on telemetry and pacer pads
   are available if necessary
   # Hyperkalemia: Patient had failed to get labs checked and kayexelate
   was not producing usual BM. Presented with K of 7.3, and likely
   etiology of patients arrythmia, which had corrected with short term
   interventions. Patient

Chief Complaint:  s/p cardiac arrest, hypotension
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 4273**] is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2,
   tracheobronchomalacia s/p tracheal Y stenting earlier this year
   presents with witnessed PEA arrest at friend's workplace. Per family,
   friend reported that patient "appeared to be asleep." This did not
   immediately raise concern because the patient falls asleep frequently
   during the day, even in social situations. His wife notes that he was
   more somnolent than usual this morning; he had a hard time getting out
   of bed. He went to breakfast with friends as per his usual routine, and
   he actually fell asleep at the restaurant as well. Once he slumped
   forward EMS was called. He was down for approximately four minutes
   prior to initiation of CPR. Apparently, his initial rhythm on EMS
   arrival was PEA, and he received 1 mg epinephrine and 1 mg atropine. He
   also received 300 mg amiodarone but it is unclear whether this was
   given first or subsequent to other medications. On tracings from EMS,
   appears that patient is intermittently paced which is wide complex and
   this may have been mistaken for VT. Reportedly, he had return of pulses
   after 6 minutes of CPR. Two IVs were placed and the patient was
   intubated in the field. Unfortunately, the actual EMS documentation is
   no longer with his chart. He was initially cooled in the field by
   report. [**Hospital **]hospital EKG also concerning for inferior STEMI, but on my
   review, this appears only on paced beats with ST elevations in II and
   III and ST depressions in I.
   .
   On arrival to the ED, the patient's initial vitals were T 95.1, HR 60
   (paced), BP 80/40, O2 100%. Blood pressures decreased to the 60s;
   cooling was stopped. Right femoral CVL was placed for IV access. He was
   placed on dopamine gtt with persistent hypotension and levophed was
   added. FAST exam was negative. He also required epinephrine gtt to
   maintain blood pressures in the 90s systolic. CT
   head/neck/chest/abdomen/pelvis revealed bilateral lower lobe
   infiltrates concerning for aspiration versus pneumonia. He received IV
   ceftriaxone 1 g X 1 (but not vancomycin which was also ordered in the
   ED). A left radial arterial line as placed. On CT scan, his ETT was
   noted to be anterior to his tracheal stent. IP and anesthesia/critial
   care were called to the bedside where bronchoscopy was used to
   reposition the tube; the ETT is now located within the stent about 2.5
   cm above the carina. Cardiology was consulted from the ED; they did not
   feel that his presentation was consistent with acute STEMI. ECHO
   performed at the bedside showed preserved EF (> 55%) with no regional
   wall motion abnormalities.
   .
   On arrival to the ICU, the patient is not sedated but is intubated and
   unresponsive to voice and painful. On further questioning, the
   patient's wife notes that the patient has had a cough productive of
   sputum for the past few months; he has been treated intermittently with
   antibiotics for this. She reports no recent fevers at home. The patient
   did not have any other particular complaints in the past few days. As
   above, he was more somnolent on the morning of this incident. Overall,
   the patient's family admits that they know little about his medical
   history because the patient did not share his medical problems. The
   most recent medication list that the patient's wife can find is from
   9/[**2175**].

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, AVR X 2, and TBM
   s/p tracheal stent who presents status post PEA arrest.
   .
   # PEA arrest: Unclear circumstances surrounding the arrest. From family
   history, patient will fall asleep frequently during the day. This could
   be secondary to chronic hypercarbia which could be exacerbated by
   patient's multiple narcotic pain medications. Could hypothesize that
   patient took additional narcotics which depressed his already-tenuous
   respiratory drive leading to hypercarbia and hypoxia which led to PEA
   arrest. Other possibility is cardiac event but ekg on admit not
   necessarily concerning for MI. Other etiologies (electrolyte
   abnormalities, PE, hypothermia) less likely given lab and scan results.
   Unclear what type of neurologic deficits, if any, he will have
   following this event. We elected not to cool him per protocol with
   arctic sun due to length of time since arrest (~ 1315 and 1815 on
   arrival to MICU) in addition to instability of blood pressures (on 3
   pressors on arrival to MICU).
   - support respiratory failure as below
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - treat other issues as below
   - continually reassess neurologic status
   .
   # Shock: Patient's hypotension on arrival to [**Hospital1 19**] could be related to
   profound acidosis in setting of resuscitation or hypothermia. Following
   aggressive IVFs in ED, pressors were quickly weaned to off on arrival
   to the ICU. Could also be [**2-8**] to underlying infectious source (did have
   leukocytosis and bandemia on arrival) and most obvious source is
   infiltrates seen on chest CT. UA negative on arrival. Cardiac function
   (per echo performed in the ED) preserved at this time so less suspicion
   for cardiac shock.
   - continue to monitor blood pressure with arterial line
   - treat broadly for HCAP with cefepime / vancomycin
   - send sputum culture
   - repeat lactate
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Again unclear precipitant though patient has
   multiple pulmonary issues including sleep apnea (likely obesity
   hypoventilation syndrome), tracheobronchomalacia with recent tracheal
   stenting, and recurrent pneumonias (antibiotics almost continuously per
   wife due to sputum production). He also apparently takes multiple
   narcotics and other meds (i.e., flexeril, seroquel, valium) which could
   contribute to altered mental status which would exacerbate
   hypoventilation.
   - adjust ventilator settings per ABGs
   - obtain records from [**Location (un) 755**] regarding tracheal stenting
   - send sputum culture
   - add on urine legionella antigen
   .
   # Renal insufficiency: Unclear baseline creatinine. Would be helpful to
   obtain records from PCP or coverage over the weekend. Likely that
   creatinine will be higher in setting of shock and arrest, already
   improving with IVF and resuscitation.
   - trend creatinine
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - obtain records from PCP to establish recent Cr baseline
   .
   # CK elevation: Unlikely cardiac source given low MB and MBI. Troponin
   slightly elevated but in setting of renal insufficiency and stress from
   hypotension.
   - cycle CKs to peak
   - EKG in AM
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus: FSBS in 300s on arrival to the ICU. Will start
   insulin gtt and monitor blood sugars q1h until under better control.
   .
   # Hypertension: Hold antihypertensives for now given pressor
   requirement on arrival. Reconsider initiation of meds when stabilized,
   though home regimen unclear.
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: Reinitiate statin when NG in place or patient
   taking POs.
   .
   # Chronic pain: Will continually reassess. Not currently on any
   sedation and will wait for mental status to improve prior to giving any
   narcotics or benzos, etc.
   .
   # FEN: npo for now as no NG, replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPx: ppi, bowel meds, pneumoboots for now (? heparin allergy)
   .
   # ACcess: R IJ CVL, left radial arterial line
   .
   # CODE: full, discussed with family
   .
   # COMM: with patient and family. Son [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4273**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 4276**], Wife [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4277**].
   .

 (2A:21, 16) measuring 21 x 10 mm and 27 x 9 mm respectively.  There is
 extensive vasogenic edema surrounding these areas of hemorrhage.  There is
 subarachnoid hemorrhage as well as layering in the sylvian fissure and in the
 gyri and sulci of the temporal, parietal, and frontal lobes.  Hypoattenuation
 is seen in the left occipital lobe (2A:19).  There is marked edema of the left
 hemisphere with compression of the lateral ventricle and 7 mm rightward shift
 of normally midline structures.  Basilar cisterns appear patent.  No
 hemorrhage or infarct is identified in the right hemisphere.

 Osseous structures appear intact.  There is partial opacification of the
 posterior nasal passages which may reflect the patient's intubated status.
 The globes and orbits are intact.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  Probable hemorrhagic conversion of MCA territorial infarct.  PCA
 territorial infarct without hemorrhagic conversion.

 2. Extensive left hemispheric edema with rightward shift of midline and mass
 effect upon the lateral ventricle.

   3. Shock management: Possibly [**2-26**] post-arrest state and myocardial

   arrest s/p CPR/ACLS and now on pressors and cooling protocol.

   arrest.  Wife states patient was 'not himself' the day prior.  No

   unlikely to be PE & no e/o EKG. Small R-sided pneumothorax (now s/p
   chest tube) with no e/o tension prior to arrival.  No e/o hypovolemia.
   With profound acidosis.  Thus, unclear but potentially primary cardiac
   vs pulmonary source.  Now s/p  cooling protocol - 18 hours cooling, 6
   hours warming (unclear start time per outside hospital records, given
   EMS records, will presume 0200, so cooled until [**2150**]).  Now rewarmed.

   .

81 year old male with known cad s/p cabg [**10**], ischemic cardiomyopathy ef
   40-45%, afib, HTN, MR, TR, & bifascicular block transferred from [**Hospital1 **]
   [**Location (un) **] s/p vtach/vfib arrest. The patient presented to [**Location (un) **] for
   exercise stress testing with nuclear imaging. EKGs from [**Location (un) **]
   document a narrow complex tachycardia with rate 110-[**Street Address(2) 11434**]
   depressions in V2-V5, then monomorphic VT & finally ventricular
   fibrillation. Successfully  resuscitated after  cpr, intubation,
   receiving 6 shocks at 360 joules, amiodarone 300 mg x 4, atropine 1 mg
   x 2, epinephrine 1 mg x 3, and sodium bicarb x 1. The patient was
   intubated. After return of spontaneous circulation was started on a
   norepinephrine infusion and transported to the cardiac catheterization
   lab at [**Hospital1 1**].
   Cardiac catheterization revealed a right-dominant circulation with
   extensive disease of the native vessels:svg-lad patent, svg-pda 40%
   occluded, svg-om occluded, & lima-lad atretic. Right heart cath
   revealed elevated pad & wedge. Post cardiac cath-admitted to ccu &
   artic sun protocol initiated.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Pt conts on Arctic Sun cooling therapy, Intubated on CMV, IABP on 1:1
   setting.
   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:

81 year old male with known cad s/p cabg [**10**], ischemic cardiomyopathy ef
   40-45%, afib, HTN, MR, TR, & bifascicular block transferred from [**Hospital1 **]
   [**Location (un) **] s/p vtach/vfib arrest. The patient presented to [**Location (un) **] for
   exercise stress testing with nuclear imaging. EKGs from [**Location (un) **]
   document a narrow complex tachycardia with rate 110-[**Street Address(2) 11434**]
   depressions in V2-V5, then monomorphic VT & finally ventricular
   fibrillation. Successfully  resuscitated after  cpr, intubation,
   receiving 6 shocks at 360 joules, amiodarone 300 mg x 4, atropine 1 mg
   x 2, epinephrine 1 mg x 3, and sodium bicarb x 1. The patient was
   intubated. After return of spontaneous circulation was started on a
   norepinephrine infusion and transported to the cardiac catheterization
   lab at [**Hospital1 1**].
   Cardiac catheterization revealed a right-dominant circulation with
   extensive disease of the native vessels:svg-lad patent, svg-pda 40%
   occluded, svg-om occluded, & lima-lad atretic. Right heart cath
   revealed elevated pad & wedge. Post cardiac cath-admitted to ccu &
   artic sun protocol initiated.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Pt remains sedated on Fentanyl/ Versed gtts, unresponsive to pain
   stimuli, no shivering observed. Conts on the Arctic Sun cooling therapy
   x 24hr, Intubated on CMV, IABP on 1:1 setting. 24hr conts EEG
   monitoring. Tele, in AF 40s-50s, ABPs 110-130s/ 40s-50s, maintaining
   MAPs>65. Dopamine infusing at  4mcg/kg/min, Heparin gtt at 600units/hr.
   LS rhonchorus bibasilary, Sats> 97%. Lasix gtt infusing at 5mg/hr, uop
   qs. NGT to lws. Still unable to Doppler his L PT, all other pulses
   dopplerable. Bil fem sites cd+i
   Action:
   Several episodes of mild seizure activity, recorded on EEG video.
   Sedation increased d/t freq episodes of desynchronized breathing w/
   ventilator.Weaned back to100mcg Fentanyl & 4mg Versed d/t persistant
   bradycardia in low 30s. Dopa unchanged.Turned off sedation for Neuro
   team exam. Pt opened eyes & moved all extremities, unclear if he
   followed commands. Remains on 1:1 setting w/ good systolic/diastolic
   unloading. Fi02 reduced to 40%, rate ^16 (see ABGs) only scant
   secretions. Urine op trailing off <10/hr, increased Lasix to 10mg/hr w/
   good response.
   Response:
   Plan:
   Rewarming process to begin at 1800. Wean sedation & change to CPAP to
   evaluate neurological status. ? remove IABP

50yom with h/o chest pain past 4 months with increase last 24hrs.
   Admitted to OSH with STE inferior started IV NTG/[**Hospital **] transferred to
   [**Hospital1 19**] cath lab. Heart cath revealed tight LCX received BMS. Angioseal
   to right groin received 305cc contrast. Transferred to [**Hospital Ward Name **] 3 where he
   was hypotensive and received 2 liters NS. c/o chest pain [**8-8**] and
   became unresponsive after blood draw CPR for 3 minutes,
   epi/succ/propofol and dopamine and came back but vomiting coffee ground
   emesis. Pt was intubated for airway protection. Arrived in the CCU;
   intubated diaphoretic with VSS off dopamine. Admission ECG revealed
   worsening STE inferior with STD V3-5. IVB bivalrudin .75mg/kg/min and
   brought back cath lab. Cath lab revealed LCX BMS open but received 2nd
   BMS proximal to first stent.
   Acute coronary syndrome (ACS, unstable angina, coronary ischemia)
   Assessment:
   Cardiac echo post cath revealed global HK with LVEF 20%.  CPK >1000
   with Troponin 7.6 Dopamine gtt off. Remains difficult to sedate on
   fentanyl/versed gtts. Ventilator 100%
   Action:
   Bivalrudin infusion at .2mcg/kg/hr
   Response:
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor for further hypotension or signs of ischemia.
   Follow serial CPK and monitor PLT count.

Date of service: [**2132-2-8**]
   Initial visit, Cardiology service: CCU
   Presenting complaint: Chest pain
   History of present illness: (from Dr.[**Name (NI) 4908**] initial admission note
   and chart) 50 yo male with h/o HCV presented to [**Location (un) **] with chest
   pain; has been having CP for 4 months with activity; but then 2 nights
   ago was moving wood and that produced some severe CP that lasted
   overnight into today; severe, crushing pain, non-radiating, +SOB and
   nausea. He went to [**Location (un) **] ER where he was found to have TropI 67 and
   EKG with q waves inferiorly and signficant R waves V1-V2. He was
   started on aspirin, heparin gtt, nitro gtt and plavix loaded before
   transferring here.
   .
   Per report BP 110/60 but on arrival SBP 80s and tachycardic
   In cath; found LAD chronically occluded (mid) and LCX mid segment had
   thrombus (assumed culprit lesion); tried balloon angioplasty b/c of low
   platelets (didn't want to give stent) but suboptimal results;
   ultimately placed BMS. Could never fully engage RCA; origin may be
   anomalous. Received heparin during procedure (started at OSH). LVEDP
   was elevated but received a lot of dye trying to find RCA.
   .
   After the catheterization, patient was admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 1682**]. About 30-60
   minutes after arrival on the floor, he complained of recurrent chest
   pain, nausea, back pain. SBP was initially in the 100s on arrival on
   the floor but then dropped to the 80s then 70s. Patient was given IVF
   bolus. He then vomitted, became unconscious, went into PEA arrest. CPR
   was started. Was given epinephrine 1 mg. Pulses returned. Patient
   regained consciousness, again vomited coffee-ground emesis. Was
   intubated. Started on dopamine and wide-open IVF. Transferred to CCU.
   ECG showed new ST depression in precordial leads and ST elevations in
   II, III. R-sided ECG showed ST elevations in lateral leads.
   Past medical history: HCV 2/2 blood transfusion - s/p IFN and
   Ribavarin; neg viral load per report
   Sinusitis
   Depression
   CAD Risk Factors
   CAD Risk Factors Absent

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 50 yo male with h/o HCV presented with NSTEMI,

   evidence of RCA infarct.
   .
   # CORONARIES: Pt presented with chest pain; found with very signicant
   elevation in Trop and CK at OSH, discovered to have chronically
   occluded LAD and thrombus in LCX; now s/p BMS to LCX. RCA unable to be
   engaged. Pt received Plavix load and aspirin prior. Post-cath chest
   pain and new ECG findings of ST elevations in III>II and precordial ST
   depressions suggest RCA infarct.
   - start bivalirudin bolus and gtt given thrombocytopenia
   - re-activate cath lab; will attempt emergent catheterization again

   - serial ECGs
   - trend cardiac enzymes
   - check TTE
