   Cath lab. Hypotension likely due to RCA infarct.
   - IVF and dopamine to maintain BP
   - TTE in a.m.
   .
   # RHYTHM: sinus rhythm, currently tachycardic
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # [**Name (NI) 4909**] Pt with plts 57; baseline unknown. Concern given pt
   started on aspirin/plavix but unable to do balloon angiplasty; thus
   requires clopidogrel.
   - monitor CBC closely
   - call PCP in AM to determine baseline (? if related to HCV)
   .
   # Depression:
   - will restart escitalopram once extubated
   .
   # HCV: Pts LFTs not markedly elevated, T.bili at OSH wnl; pt has
   completed IFN/ribavarin and per report recent viral load undetectable.
   - recheck LFTs
   - monitor for signs of esophageal variceal bleed given coffee ground
   emesis
   - monitor CBC closely; transfuse as needed
   .
   # FEN: NPO while intubated, will consider TF
   .
   # ACCESS: PIV's, L fem line (will need to pull non-sterile femoral line
   once stable)
   .
   # PROPHYLAXIS: Pneumoboots for now (as pt with very low plts) , PPI
   .
   # CODE: Presumed full
   .
   # DISPO: CCU care for now

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with known CAD, diastolic CHF, HTN, DM,
   dyslipidemia, presents to OSH ED complaining of SOB, arrived in
   extremus and respiratory failure requiring intubation, tachycardic with
   likely SVT with aberrancy, new reduced EF, leukocytosis, four quadrant
   air space opacities on CXR, and relative hypotension concerning for
   distributive vs. cardiogenic shock.
   .
   CORONARIES: Pt with known CAD, initial enzymes at OSH negative, though
   now rising with CK 1872
 7559, in setting of a single 150J shock at
   OSH and no clear ischemic EKG changes.  Pt also with new globally
   reduced EF on bedside echo at OSH and here which may be secondary to
   concurrent acidosis/extreme critical illness.  Most likely not ACS.
   - Can d/c heparin drip as ACS appears unlikely (low MB index, troponin
   rise not unexpected in setting of sepsis)
   - start SC heparin
   - Continue Aspirin daily
   - Continue statin
   - start BB once more hemodynamically stable
   - Trend cardiac enzymes to peak CK
   - Repeat 12 lead EKG in AM
   - Consider cardiac cath once more clinically stable for further
   evaluation
   .
   PUMP: Pt with history of diastolic CHF, now with reduced EF on bedside
   TTE as above, mixed picture ACS/sepsis and metabolic acidosis given
   lactate of 7.0 at OSH and rising cardiac enzymes. MAPs in mid 50's on
   arrival, but patient started on low dose levophed overnight for low
   blood pressures and nadir of 74/38 after initation of fentanyl/versed
   for sedation.  CVP on arrival 12.  Central venous O2 sat 87 on
   admission now 99.  Globally reduced EF [**1-20**] acidosis vs. acute aschemia
   (w/ rising troponins).
   - Formal TTE in AM
   - Responded well to fluid bolus, maintain CVP ~15.
   - Hold on further diuresis with Lasix for now given borderline blood
   pressures and CVP of 12 with low urine output on admission; unclear if
   patient responded to IV Lasix dose given at OSH
   - Hold all antihypertensives for now
   .
   RHYTHM: Currently in sinus rhythm, HR 70's. At OSH was found to be
   tachycardic with wide complex tachycardia felt to be SVT with aberrancy
   based on 12 lead EKG. Pt was shocked x 1 at OSH and loaded with
   amiodarone upon transfer.
   - d/c amiodarone drip
   - beta blockers as needed for rate control as BP tolerates.
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: CXR showing diffuse fluffly pulmonary infiltrates
   concerning for ARDS. Continue A/C mechanical ventilation with low tidal
   volume strategy and PEEP to support increased lung resistance.  Doing
   well with wean.
   - Goal pH >7.3
   - If oxygenation continues to improve with FiO2< 60%, wean down PEEP
   .
   ID: Possible sepsis given leukocytosis, with suspected urinary source,
   though pulmonary source could also be present given increased RLL
   infiltrate on CXR.  Urine legionella negative.
   - Fontinue broad spectrum antibiotic coverage with Vanc/Zosyn/Cipro for
   double gram negative coverage.  Recent hospital and rehab stay makes
   hospital acquired organisms possible.
   - Abdominal ultrasound in AM to evaluate for abscess or other potential
   intraabdominal source of infection
   - F/U blood and urine cultures
   - f/u OSH cultures.
   .
   ACUTE on CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: Pt with baseline cr of 1.7, 2.0 at OSH
   earlier today, now 2.5 and oliguric, likely related to pre-renal
   hypoperfusion in setting of severe systemic illness and reduced EF.
   UOP improved somewhat after small IVF bolus increasing to > 20 cc/hr
   overnight
   - Continue to trend creatinine
   - Follow UOP and consider additional small volume IVF bolus
   - Image kidneys with abdominal ultrasound as above
   - f/u Urine lytes
   .
   DIABETES MELLITUS: Pt with significantly elevated blood sugars at OSH
   and on admission.  Patient with history of type II DM and at risk for
   hyperosmolar non-ketotic hyperglycemia, though currently blood glucoses
   not ranging above 600.
   - f/u serum ketones
   - IV insulin drip following [**Last Name (un) 72**] protocol to keep serum glucose <150
   - monitor blood glucose q1 hour
   .
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Pt with large gap metabolic acidosis, initial
   lactate at OSH 7, on arrival here improved to 3.2.  Given elevated
   blood sugars, may also be in DKA, though patient with history of type
   II DM, and DKA less likely.   Serum ketones pending. Pt is s/p 1 amp
   sodium bicarb at OSH.  Gap closed this morning, appears to have largely
   resolved.
   - Continue mechanical ventilation and will slowly decrease
   hyperventilation for respiratory compensation.
   - Continue empiric treatment for sepsis as above with continued
   supportive care
   .
   TRANSAMINITIS: Pt with elevated transaminases on admission, likely
   consistent with global critical illness and possibly related to shock
   liver/hypoperfusion.
   - Continue trending LFTs and coags for now
   - Keep MAP > 65 to maintain end organ perfusion
   .
   FEN: Hyponatremia: falsely low given elevated blood glucose on arrival
   with improvement after correction of hyperglycemia.  NPO for now.
   - F/u nutrition recs for TF
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's/IJ
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with IV Heparin
   -GI ppx with IV protonix
   CODE: Full (confirmed with son)
   DISPO: CCU for now

Chief Complaint:  Respiratory failure/shock
   HPI:
   Please see CCU H&P for full details.  Briefly this is a 74 year old
   female with CAD s/p DES to LAD in [**2189**] and failed PCI to OM1 in [**2187**],
   dCHF, and CKD presented to an OSH via EMS w/ severe SOB.  There, she
   was found to have a wide complex tachycardia concerning for VT though
   has known LBBB at baseline.  She was emergently intubated for
   respiratory failure (81% per report.  In addition she was given one
   150J shock for presumed VT with unclear results (rhythm strips not
   available). She continued to have wide complex rhythm.  Also got 150mg
   of amio and was started on an amiodarone drip. A CXR showed diffuse
   bilateral pulmonary infiltrates so the patient was also given a dose of
   ceftriaxone/azithromycin for CAP as well as IV lasix for possible fluid
   overload (without effect).  Bedside TTE was performed which, per
   report, showed a reduced EF of approximately 30-35% at the OSH w/ gobal
   dysfunction (down from 60%).  Initial cardiac enzymes were negative. An
   ABG shortly after intubation was 7.15/45/66/16/86% and she remained
   difficult to ventilate requiring 100% FiO2 and PEEP 20. Given her
   continued acidosis on the vent, the patient was given 1 Amp of sodium
   bicarb while in the ED. She was transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] CCU for further
   management.
   .
   In the CCU, repeat TTE showed global LV systolic dysfunction w/ EF of
   30%.  Cardiac enzymes were trended and continued to rise, last trop of
   0.52, CK of 7559, MBI 1.6.  She was initially started on a heparin gtt
   due to concern for ACS, though this was later thought to be more
   consistent with a metabolic process/sepsis, and the heparin gtt was
   discontinued.  Also, on review, rhythm was most likely consistent with
   SVT w/ abberancy, not VT.  Amiodarone was discontinued.  The patient
   remained warm, though not febrile which was thought to be consistent
   distributive shock. She was continued on broadened antibiotics (vanc,
   zosyn, cipro).  She was initially hypotensive so was given levophed
   thought this was subsequently weaned off.  Amiodarone was also
   discontinued.  She rec'd a gentle fluid challenge of 500 cc due to
   decreased UOP and increased her output (up from 30 cc/hr to 60 cc/hr).
   .
   Of note, patient had worsening of her chronic kidney disease from a
   baseline creatinine of 1.5 up to 2.7 thought to be secondary to
   hypoperfusion.  She had a borderline UA at the OSH showing protein and
   blood without ketones or glucose.  Repeat UA here unremarkable. An
   abdominal US was performed to look at kidneys, though the read is still
   pending.
   .
   She was initially ventilated on ARDSnet protocol, though she has
   tolerated a rapid wean of ventilation and is currently on AC 24 40% 500
   w/ 12 of PEEP with a most recent ABG of 7.40/29/111.
   .
   She was also initiated on an insulin gtt due to persistently elevated
   BS in the 400s and significant AG acidosis on admission, now well
   controlled with a closed gap. No ketones or glucosuria.
   .
   Unable to obtain review of systems due to intubation, though on
   questioning, able to indicate that she has L knee pain unchanged from
   prior.

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
   74 year old female with known CAD, diastolic CHF, HTN, DM,
   dyslipidemia, presents to OSH ED complaining of SOB, arrived in
   extremus and respiratory failure requiring intubation, tachycardic with
   likely SVT with aberrancy, new reduced EF, leukocytosis, four quadrant
   air space opacities on CXR, and relative hypotension concerning for
   distributive shock.
   .
   # Repiratory failure: CXR initially concerning for ARDS, though no
   clear etiology.  CXR this morning appears to be mildly improved. No
   clear infiltrate, and patient denies any SOB prior.  Per son, patient
   is "prone" to pneumonia, so this is most likely source of possible
   septic/distributive shock. Also, with significant leukocytosis which
   may be from infection vs stress reaction. Requiring PEEPs >10 to
   maintain oxygenation, but has been able to wean significantly since
   admission.  Patient was alert and awake on transfer to MICU, denies
   fever prior to admission, though son states she was "cold" on the days
   leading up to admission. Urine legionella negative.
   - Continue A/C mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume strategy
   and PEEP to support increased lung resistance.
   - Goal pH >7.3
   - Continue to wean ventilation, will consider decreased PEEP now that
   FiO2 is at 40% and oxygenating well
   - Continue to treat for HCAP w/ zosyn, vanc, cipro as had been in house
   in [**Month (only) 8**] and rehab facility up until 3 weeks ago
   - Daily CXR
   - Trend WBC
   - Send sputum culture, follow up blood and urine cultures
   - Follow up cultures from OSH ([**Last Name (un) 2491**])
   - Consider CT torso if no improvement to assess for
   intraabdominal/thoracic source of infection
   # Coronary artery disease: Has history of CAD w/ DES to LAD, now with
   significant troponin leak in the setting of SVT w/ abberancy and shock
   at OSH.  Per cardiology, this is most likely not consistent w/ ACS and
   patient has completed 24H of heparin gtt. MBI not significantly
   elevated.  Likely myocardial stunning/ischemia in the setting of
   sepsis, critical illness and profound acidemia (lactate 7.0 at OSH).
   No clear new ischemic ECG changes.
   - Continue to trend CE until downtrending
   - Continue ASA daily
   - Continue statin
   - BB when HD stable
   - Cards consult prn
   - Repeat ECG in am
   - Consider pRBCs if decreased Hct (goal >25 given CAD and recent
   ischemia), will also improve intravascular volume
   # Global LV systolic HF: Patient now w/ globally reduced EF on TTE with
   elevated CE as above.  Has history of dCHF.  Has been weaned off of
   levophed while in the CCU and has not required fluids to maintain CVP.
   BPs now stable.  Likely [**1-20**] acidemia/critical illness as above. ScVO2
   in CCU was 99 on evening of admission up from 87.
   - Repeat TTE once patient stabilized and is improved from current
   illness to access for any residual deficit
   - Hold antihypertensives for now, restart prn
   .
   # SVT w/ abberancy: Currently in sinus rhythm, HR 70's. At OSH was
   found to be tachycardic with wide complex tachycardia felt to be SVT
   with aberrancy based on 12 lead EKG. Pt was shocked x 1 at OSH and
   loaded with amiodarone upon transfer, since dc'd.
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   - Beta blockers as needed for rate control as BP tolerates; if no blood
   pressure room, consider restarting amiodarone
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Baseline creatinine of around 1.4,
   now up to 2.7.  Patient had been oliguric, but now improved.  Likely in
   the setting of hypoperfusion given globally reduced EF and critical
   illness.
   - Continue to follow urine output, goal >20 cc/hr
   - Urine lytes/eos
   - Continue to trend creatinine
   - IVF prn to maintain UOP
   - Consider renal ultrasound if no improvement in creatinine in the
   morning
   .
   # DM type 2:  BS significantly elevated at OSH and in CCU.  Has been on
   insulin gtt since admission with blood sugars now well controlled.
   Initially, was concern for HHS given gap acidosis and elevated FS,
   though no glucosuria.
   - Will transition to home insulin regimen if possible overnight; per
   patient, she takes 35/40 NPH and humalog SS.
   .
   # AG acidosis: GAP now resolved.  Initial lactate at OSH was 7, now
   wnl.  Concern for HHS, though no glucosuria or other metabolic
   derangements.  Serum B hydroxybuterate pending. Pt is s/p 1 amp sodium
   bicarb at OSH.
   - Continue empiric treatment for sepsis as above with continued
   supportive care
   - Continue to follow chem panel, gap/bicarb.  Will recheck now.
   .
   # Transaminitis: Pt with elevated transaminases on admission, likely
   consistent with global critical illness and possibly related to shock
   liver/hypoperfusion.
   - Continue trending LFTs and coags for now
   - Keep MAP > 65 to maintain end organ perfusion
   - Follow up final read of abd ultrasound done in CCU
   .
   # Leg pain: Patient had recent illness with negative work up. Per her
   son, has had significant pain not improved post rehab.  This had been a
   major concern of hers for the few days prior to this admission.  L knee
   was tapped during prior admission, consistent with arthritis.
   - Continue fentanyl while intubated for pain control
   - Consider repeat plain films, ?repeat tap given septic joint could be
   source of current infection
   - Will likely require additional PT, pain control once sedation
   wean/extubated
   .
   # FEN: Will initiate TF once available, nutrition recommendations
   appreciated. IVF boluses as needed as above.  Replete lytes prn

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with known CAD, diastolic CHF, HTN, DM,
   dyslipidemia, presents to OSH ED complaining of SOB, arrived in
   extremus and respiratory failure requiring intubation, tachycardic with
   likely SVT with aberrancy, new reduced EF, leukocytosis, four quadrant
   air space opacities on CXR, and relative hypotension concerning for
   distributive vs. cardiogenic shock.
   .
   CORONARIES: Pt with known CAD, initial enzymes at OSH negative, though
   now rising, in setting of 150J shock at OSH and no clear ischemic EKG
   changes.  Pt also with globally reduced EF on bedside echo at OSH and
   here which may be secondary to acidosis/extreme critical illness.
   - Continue IV Heparin gtt for possible ACS for now
   - Continue Aspirin daily
   - Trend cardiac enzymes
   - Repeat 12 lead EKG in AM
   - Continue home dose statin
   - Consider cardiac cath once more clinically stable for further
   evaluation
   .
   PUMP: Pt with history of diastolic CHF, now with reduced EF on bedside
   TTE as above, ACS vs. sepsis/acidosis. MAPs in mid 50's, not currently
   on pressors. CVP 12 with borderline BPs while on sedation.
   - Formal TTE in AM
   - Small 500 IVF bolus given for relative hypotension in setting of CVP
   12; continue small IVF boluses if blood pressures worsens or consider
   presesors as needed
   - Hold on further diuresis with Lasix for now given borderline blood
   pressures and CVP of 12 with low urine output
   - Hold all antihypertensives for now
   - f/u SVo2 from IJ
   .
   RHYTHM: Currently in sinus rhythm, HR 70's. At OSH was found to be
   tachycardic with wide complex tachycardia felt to be SVT with aberrancy
   based on 12 lead EKG. Pt was shocked x 1 at OSH and loaded with
   amiodarone upon transfer.
   - d/c amiodarone drip
   - beta blockers as needed for rate control as BP tolerates; if no blood
   pressure room, consider additional amiodarone boluses at that time
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: CXR showing diffuse fluffly pulmonary infiltrates
   concerning for ARDS. Continue A/C mechanical ventilation with low tidal
   volume strategy and high PEEP given increased lung resistance.
   - Goal pH >7.3
   - Wean Fio2 as tolerated
   - If oxygenation continues to improved, wean down PEEP
   .
   ID: Possible sepsis given leukocytosis, with suspected urinary source,
   though pulmonary source could also be present.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotic coverage with Vanc/Zosyn/Cipro for
   double gram negative coverage
   - Abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for abscess or other potential
   intraabdominal source of infection
   - F/U blood and urine cultures
   - F/U urine legionella
   .
   ACUTE on CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: Pt with baseline cr of 1.7, 2.0 at OSH
   earlier today, now 2.5 and oliguric, likely related to pre-renal
   hypoperfusion in setting of severe systemic illness and reduced EF
   - Continue to trend creatinine
   - Follow UOP following small volume IVF bolus
   - Image kidneys with abdominal ultrasound as above
   - f/u Urine lytes
   .
   DIABETES MELLITUS: Pt with significantly elevated blood pressures at
   OSH and on admission, which may be contributing to metabolic gap
   acidosis
   - f/u serum ketones
   - IV insulin drip following [**Last Name (un) 72**] protocol to keep serum glucose <150
   - monitor blood glucose q1 hour
   .
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Pt with large gap metabolic acidosis, initial
   lactate at OSH 7, on arrival here improved to 3.2.  Given elevated
   blood sugars, may also be in DKA, though serum ketones pending. Pt is
   s/p 1 amp sodium bicarb at OSH.
   - Continue mechanical ventilation and increase respiratory rate to
   induce slight hyperventilation to compensate for met. acidosis
   - Continue empiric treatment for sepsis as above with continued
   supportive care
   .
   TRANSAMINITIS: Pt with elevated transaminases on admission, likely
   consistent with global critical illness and possibly related to shock
   liver/hypoperfusion.
   - Continue trending LFTs and coags for now
   .
   FEN: NPO for now.
   - F/u nutrition recs for TF

74 yo female w/ PMH: CAD, NSTEMI/Stent RCA, diastolic CHF EF 55% @
   baseline, CRI (Cr 1.7 baseline), anemia, breast CA s/t XRT,
   osteoarthritis bilat knees s/p recent rehab stay, s/p ccy. Pt at home
   when she became acutely SOB and called EMS. Pt found hypoxic, barely
   conscious.
    Taken to OSH ED where she was emergently intubated for resp failure.
   First ABG after intubation 7.13/ 46/64/16, lactate 7.  Still hypoxic
   after intubation w/ mult vent changes made. EKG concerning for wide
   complex tachy superimposed on LBBB. V-tach vs SVT w/ aberrancy.
   Cardioverted @150J x one with little change in rhythm morphology,
   though rate slower and able to see P waves. 150 mg IV amiodarone bolus
   given and gtt stated. IV heparin gtt initated for possible ACS. Pt also
   w/ leukocytosis, hyperglycemia to 500s, anemia, bilat opacities on CXR,
   and acute on chronic renal failure. Tx
d to [**Hospital1 5**] for further mgt and
   possible cardiac cath once stable.
   CCU course: Arrived [**6-13**] @ 17:00. Dysynchronous on ventilator;
   difficult to ventilate. Sedation changed to fent/versed w/ improvement
   in pt vent synchrony and ABGs. BP down w/ sedation increase. IV
   levophed initiated for BP mgt.  CVP 10-12.
   IV amiodarone shut off as pt in NSR. Pt initially thought to be in
   ARDS- treated w/ 20 PEEP/FiO2 100%, low tV and high RR with steady
   improvement in ABGs. Started on insulin gtt for hyperglycemia w/
   appropriate decrease in blood sugars to 100s. Given 500ml NS fluid
   bolus for low UOP w/ improvement to 20ml/hr. Triple IV anbx for
   possible urosepsis vs pneumosepsis.
   Today [**6-14**]: BP 90s-100s/40s after wean of IV levophed to off at
   12noon.  IV heparin DC
d as unlikely ACS per CCU team.  ?Rhythm change
   in setting of demand ischemia. CVP 15. Able to wean vent settings
   considerably w/ improving ABGs. UOP 20-110ml/hr.  Afebrile. Abd U/S
   done for elevated LFTs and ?pancreatitis- results PND. Skin intact- LLE
   w/ hx of cellulitis, warm and pink to the touch. LLE edema. Still w/
   knee pain r/t OA.
   Code: FULL
   Access: PIV x 2 (OSH), L radial a-line([**Hospital1 5**]), RIJ TLC (OSH- due to be
   changed). All placed on [**6-13**].
   Sepsis without organ dysfunction
   Assessment:
   Tmax 99.5 PO. WBC down to 18.0. HR 79s-80s NSR w/ frequent APCs/PVCs.
   CVP 15-17. Run of SVT @130bpm- broke w/ ETT suctioning before EKG could
   be obtained. UOP 20+ml/hr.
   Action:
   Triple IV anbx- vanco/ cipro/ vanco. ABD U/S to rule out abdominal
   source of infection. Urine and pneumonia also possible sources per
   team. LLE warm w/ recent cellulitis- continue to monitor.
   Response:
   Able to wean IV levophed to off w/ MAPs 70-80 range.  Afebrile.
   Improved urine output.
   Plan:
   PND further ID w/u for source of infection. Continue IV anbx. Trend
   WBC, temps. Hemodynamic monitoring. Goal CVP 12-15.
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 76**])
   Assessment:
   *LS diminished at both bases, otherwise clear. SPO2 98%. Initial vent
   settings AC 40% FIO2, Vt 500x F27, Peep 16.  ETT suctioned q2-4 hours
   for thick, tan secretions. Plateau pressures mid 20s. AM CXR not yet w/
   official read.
   *Pt sedated w/ IV Fentanyl @50mcg/hr and IV versed @ 2mg/hr. Sleeping
   at rest, but when roused able to follow commands, move all extremities,
   and mouth words.
   Action:
   Weaned vent settings per metavision. Serial ABGs.  VAP prevention
   protocol.
   Response:
   ABGs improving w/ most recent 7.4/29/16 on 40%, 500x 24, 12 Peep.
   Plan:
   Continue to closely monitor resp status, ABGs. Wean vent as tolerated.
   Cont VAP prophylaxis.
   Diabetes Mellitus (DM), Type I
   Assessment:
   FS 90-100s on insulin gtt @ 1-4 units/hr.
   Action:
   Titrated [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 77**] [**Last Name (un) 72**] protocol. Hourly FS.
   Response:
   FS within good range.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor and titrate insulin gtt as ordered.
   Renal failure, acute (Acute renal failure, ARF)
   Assessment:
   Creat 2.7 this AM. UOP 20-110ml/hr this shift.
   Action:
   Monitored UOP/ BUN/Creat.
   Response:
   Improving UOP.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor.

Chief Complaint:  Respiratory failure/shock
   HPI:
   Please see CCU H&P for full details.  Briefly this is a 74 year old
   female with CAD s/p DES to LAD in [**2189**] and failed PCI to OM1 in [**2187**],
   dCHF, and CKD presented to an OSH via EMS w/ severe SOB.  There, she
   was found to have a wide complex tachycardia concerning for VT though
   has known LBBB at baseline.  She was emergently intubated for
   respiratory failure (81% per report.  In addition she was given one
   150J shock for presumed VT with unclear results (rhythm strips not
   available). She continued to have wide complex rhythm.  Also got 150mg
   of amio and was started on an amiodarone drip. A CXR showed diffuse
   bilateral pulmonary infiltrates so the patient was also given a dose of
   ceftriaxone/azithromycin for CAP as well as IV lasix for possible fluid
   overload (without effect).  Bedside TTE was performed which, per
   report, showed a reduced EF of approximately 30-35% at the OSH w/ gobal
   dysfunction (down from 60%).  Initial cardiac enzymes were negative. An
   ABG shortly after intubation was 7.15/45/66/16/86% and she remained
   difficult to ventilate requiring 100% FiO2 and PEEP 20. Given her
   continued acidosis on the vent, the patient was given 1 Amp of sodium
   bicarb while in the ED. She was transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] CCU for further
   management.
   .
   In the CCU, repeat TTE showed global LV systolic dysfunction w/ EF of
   30%.  Cardiac enzymes were trended and continued to rise, last trop of
   0.52, CK of 7559, MBI 1.6.  She was initially started on a heparin gtt
   due to concern for ACS, though this was later thought to be more
   consistent with a metabolic process/sepsis, and the heparin gtt was
   discontinued.  Also, on review, rhythm was most likely consistent with
   SVT w/ abberancy, not VT.  Amiodarone was discontinued.  The patient
   remained warm, though not febrile which was thought to be consistent
   distributive shock. She was continued on broadened antibiotics (vanc,
   zosyn, cipro).  She was initially hypotensive so was given levophed
   thought this was subsequently weaned off.  Amiodarone was also
   discontinued.  She rec'd a gentle fluid challenge of 500 cc due to
   decreased UOP and increased her output (up from 30 cc/hr to 60 cc/hr).
   .
   Of note, patient had worsening of her chronic kidney disease from a
   baseline creatinine of 1.5 up to 2.7 thought to be secondary to
   hypoperfusion.  She had a borderline UA at the OSH showing protein and
   blood without ketones or glucose.  Repeat UA here unremarkable. An
   abdominal US was performed to look at kidneys, though the read is still
   pending.
   .
   She was initially ventilated on ARDSnet protocol, though she has
   tolerated a rapid wean of ventilation and is currently on AC 24 40% 500
   w/ 12 of PEEP with a most recent ABG of 7.40/29/111.
   .
   She was also initiated on an insulin gtt due to persistently elevated
   BS in the 400s and significant AG acidosis on admission, now well
   controlled with a closed gap. No ketones or glucosuria.
   .
   Unable to obtain review of systems due to intubation, though on
   questioning, able to indicate that she has L knee pain unchanged from
   prior.

   clear etiology.  CXR this morning appears to be mildly improved. No
   clear infiltrate, and patient denies any SOB prior.  Per son, patient
   is "prone" to pneumonia, so this is most likely source of possible
   septic/distributive shock. Also, with significant leukocytosis which
   may be from infection vs stress reaction. Requiring PEEPs >10 to
   maintain oxygenation, but has been able to wean significantly since
   admission.  Patient was alert and awake on transfer to MICU, denies
   fever prior to admission, though son states she was "cold" on the days
   leading up to admission. Urine legionella negative.

   and PEEP to support increased lung resistance.

Pt is a 67 year old man with PMH DM and HTN, who was found slumped over
   in his car by a police officer.  AED was hooked up and the patient was
   reportedly shocked for VF/VT arrest.   He was intubated in the field,
   started on lidocaine gtt, and taken to [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 608**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 73**] where cooling protocol
   was initiated and he was changed to amiodarone.  His ECG showed sinus
   tachycardia, as well as a possible atrial tachycardia, without evidence
   of ST elevations or ischemia, and initial troponin was 0.03 with flat
   CK.  He was transferred to the [**Hospital1 19**] CCU for further care.  Currently,
   he is intubated and sedated, with his wife being directed to the CCU
   for more information about his history.  Plan to continue amiodarone
   gtt , observe overnight, trend enzymes, and continue cooling protocol.
   In AM, will reassess and consider further work-up for this episode.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Neuro: Pt unresponsive. Pupils unequal 5mm R, 4mm L, reactive to light.
   No corneal/ gag/ cough reflexes. Pt  w/ no reaction to voice/ nail bed
   pressure. Noted jerk-like mvts of head on arrival to CCU, increasing
   over time to full body movements, non-purposeful. GCS 4.
   CV: HR 120s-140s ST w/ frequent PVCs/ Bigem/Trigem. Arrived on IV
   Amiodarone gtt 1mg/min. BP 160s-190s/70s-80s. Palp DP/PT bilat. Normal
   CSM.
   ACCESS: PIV x 2, R tibia intraosseous line- all placed in field at time
   of arrest
   Resp: Orally intubated, FiO2 100% AC, 550 x 16, Peep 12. SPO2 85-92%.
   Tan thick secretions via ETT.
   GI: Abd obese, soft NT. Oral GT- awaiting confirmation of placement. Sm
   amt of stool noted on admission.
   GU: Foley cath 16Fr on arrival D/Cd. Attempted insertion of foley w/
   bladder temp probe- unsuccessful. Incot of urine in bed x one. New 16F
   coude cath placed w/out issue.
   ID: WBC 19. Afebrile. MRSA screen sent. Needs UA/C&S.
   Skin: Intact. Lower R lip w/ some indentation from OSH ETT secure
   device- removed; ETT rotated.
   Action:
   *Cardiac arrest consult team notified. Plan to resume cooling initiated
   at OSH. Artic sun cooling protocol initated here at 1700 w/ goal temp
   set 34 C. Large pads in place w/ additional pad over abdomen. Rectal
   and Esophageal pt temp sources- notably differing by 1 degree Celsius
   at start of protocol (rectal higher).   Attempted bladder temp
   measurement w/out successful placement of foley cath. Sedated w/
   propofol and fentanyl initially, then changed to fentanyl/ midazolam
   r/t associated hypotenstion w/ propofol.
   *Arterial line placed by CCU team. ABG 7.20/62/87/25. Vent settings
   adjusted by resp therapy per metavision.
   *CXR done- awaiting confirmation of OGT placement.
   Response:
   Cooling protocol in progress, not yet at goal temp.  BP and HR stable.
   Resp acidosis via ABG.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor per Artic Sun protocol w/ goal temp 34 degrees.
   Head CT tonight. Awaiting team placement of IJ TLC line. DC IO line (by
   intensivist) and PIVs once other access established. Monitor labs q 6
   hours. Assess for adequate sedation. Follow resp status/  resp
   acidosis/ serial ABGs. Await further team plans/ recommendations.
   Awaiting full H&P/ med list once family arrives.

Pt is a 67 year old man with PMH DM and HTN, hyperlipidemia,  who was
   witness to have a rear end collision by police who then found  him
   slumped over in his car by  police .  AED was hooked up and the patient
   was reportedly shocked for VF/VT arrest rhythm not confirmed.   He was
   intubated in the field, started on lidocaine gtt, and taken to [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 608**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 73**] where cooling protocol was initiated and he was changed to
   amiodarone. They placed an I/O line in right knee.   His ECG showed
   sinus tachycardia, as well as a possible atrial tachycardia, without
   evidence of ST elevations or ischemia, and initial troponin was 0.03
   with flat CK.  He was transferred to the [**Hospital1 19**] CCU for further care.
   He was placed on Artic sun upon arrival and reached Goal cooling of 34
   degrees Celsius at ten PM [**2148-1-16**]. He was paralyzed at 9 pm for
   ventilator dysynchrony and likely shivering. Pt o2 sats were marginal
   however after paralytic was added his sats came up to 100 percent and
   we were able to wean FIO@ from 100 to 50 and PEEP is also being weaned
   was at 15 now 12.  Pt was restless and moving around at start of shift,
   nonpurposeful movements and he was sedated with high dose versed 7 mg
   per hour with several bolus doses and fentanyl 150 MCG per hour so that
   triple lumen  right IJ central line could be inserted.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Neuro: Pt unresponsive. Pupils were pinpoint , pt now paralyzed on
   Cisatracurium. TOF was [**4-29**] twitches pre
   Neuromuscular blockade now 1-2/4 on MA 30.
   CV:  at start of shift pt HR 120s-140s ST w/ frequent PVCs/
   Bigem/Trigem then ? SVT but did convert to SR rate 70-80 after
   paralytics were started and remains in SR/SB all night with non
   sustained runs V tach and blocked PAC
s  pt continues on IV  Amiodarone
   gtt 1mg/min, decreased to 0.5 mg min at 0700 AM
   BP 95/50
110/60 MAPS 65-78 DP/PT bilat by  doppler
   Resp:  At start of shift , FiO2 100% AC, 550 x 16, Peep 15. SPO2
   90-94%.
   CXR showed ? pulm edema and lasix 40 Iv was given-- pt put out 500-600
   ml overnight to that.
   GI: Abd obese, soft distended hypoactive BS, NGT fell out during CT
   scan and we replaced it with pos placement by x-ray putting out 30 cc
   or more of bile liquid when aspirated.
   Skin: Intact. Lower R lip w/ some indentation from OSH ETT secure
   device- removed; ETT rotated every 1-2 hours overnight, VAP protocol
   q2-4 hours.
   Action:
   Pt achieved cooling by 10 PM, went to CT scan for wet read neg bleed,
   trending cardiac enzymes overnight last troponin 0.31 CPK 500,. Pt
   remained in SR/SB- runs of non sustained VT, Blocked PAC
s and PVCs
   K was repleated 30 MEQ then stopped as K was measured as high as 5.6 (
   now 4.1 mag 2 grams iv given.)
   Pt glucose was very high after two doses humalog team ordered Insulin
   drip. Weaned O2 over course of night now weaning PEEP, No secreations.
   Blood cultures x 2 overnight. U/a C+S sent. Last ABG sent at 0700.
   Cardiac enzymes trending up cpk 500 range, continue to follow.
   Response:
   Pt remained at goal overnight, continue to trend cardiac enzymes, Fu
   CXR in am, insulin drip to start.  Urine output dropped to nothing at
   0500 Dr [**Last Name (STitle) **] aware.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor per Artic Sun protocol w/ goal temp 34 degrees.
   Follow cardiac enzymes, insulin drip with q 1 hour glucose checks .

67 yo M with PMH significant for HTN, DM found to be in V-fib arrest
   and transferred from [**Hospital3 **] for further management.  The
   patient was in his car this AM and rolled into the car ahead of him.
   This was witnessed by a police officer who found him slumped over in
   his car.  He received 1 cycle of CPR and an AED was placed that showed
   VF and was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  He was only down
   for a few minutes.  The patient had spontaneous movement at the scene.
   He was intubated by EMS in the field and given 100mg IV lidocaine.  The
   patient was transported to [**Hospital3 **] and given 2g Magnesium,
   150mg IV bolus of amiodarone, followed by  gtt @ 1mg/hr.  His CE at the
   OSH were trop I 0.03, CK 129. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Labs
   were significant WBC 11.9, UA [**6-3**] WBC, 3+ bacteria, mod epis. CXR
   showed well positioned ET tube,  pulm edema and no other acute
   abnormality. He was given 5mg pancuronium x2 and 4mg versed prior to
   transfer and cooling.  He has PIVx2 and right leg IS. He was started on
   Artic Sun protocol and transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] for further management.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   *Intiated on artic sun protocol [**1-16**] w/ goal temp achieved @ 22:00.
   Pt rec
d sedated w/ fentanyl/ versed gtts and paralyzed w/ cistacurium
   for both questionable shivering last night and ventilator dysynchrony.
   Train of four with 4/4 twitches on increased mA of 50.  No changes made
   in paralytic drip rate as pt without shivering/ with stable H20 temp on
   artic sun and no issues w/ ventilation.
   * Neuro assessment limited by paralytic med and sedatives. Pupils 2mm
   bilat, very sluggish. Unresponsive. No spontaneous movements. No
   cough/gag/corneal reflexes. HOB @ 30 degrees or higher to decrease ICP;
   pH within goal range 35-40.
   *CV- HR 50s-60s SB/SR w/ frequent PVCs and occasional runs of AIVR
   70-100BPM (8-12 beats- strips in chart). ABP 90s-100s/50s. CVP 15.
   Rec
d on IV amiodarone 0.5mg/min. Doppler DP/PT bilat. Ext cool, normal
   color.  PLT count this AM 126 (238). CKs climbing.
   *Resp- Orally intubated. Rec
d pt on vent settings FiO2 50%, 550 x 20
   Peep 12. Pt w/out secretions via ETT. SPO2 100%.  AM ABG on these
   settings w/ PO2 60.
   *GI: OGT aspirated this AM for 300ml clear secretions, gastric pH 2.0/
   guiac negative.  Hypoactive BS. PO meds held given large residual
   likely r/t cooling.
   *GU: Foley cath w/ >20ml/hr, clear dark yellow urine.
   *ID: WBC initially 9.7 this AM, up to 15.7 in afternoon (19.0 on
   admission).
   Action/ Response:
   *Artic sun protocol maintained. Labs q 6 hours.
   *Rewarming initiated at 1600 at 0.5C/hr for goal temp 37 C. Closely
   monitoring e-lytes/ glucose/ coags and rhythm while rewarming.
   *Continuous EEG in place; Seen by neurology- no signs of seizure
   activity.
   *IV amiodarone DC
d as pt w/ prolonged QT interval per EP team.  Given
   40mg IV lasix with minimal UOP. ECHO w/ EF 35-40%, inf/lat hypokinesis.
   *Peep increased to 15 from 12 w/ appropriate increase in PO2 from 60 to
   140. FiO2 then decreased to 40% w/ normal ABG following.
   *Holding PO meds until re-warmed and absorption increased.
   *Started IV anbx coverage w/ vanco/cefepime for likely aspiration PNA.
   Plan:
   *Continue artic sun rewarming protocol. Labs q 6 hours.
   *Please give PO meds tonight when rewarmed.
   *Plan for repeat Head CT to evaluate for increasing cerebral edema once
   rewarmed.
   *Readdress need for IV Lasix gtt.
   Acute coronary syndrome (ACS, unstable angina, coronary ischemia)
   Assessment:
   CK/MB/Trop rising.
   Action:
   *Initiated heparin gtt @ 1000 units/hr w/ 4000unit IVP bolus.
   Response:
   Plan:
   *Please give plavix load tonight when rewarmed.
   Diabetes Mellitus (DM), Type II
   Assessment:
   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:

   Assessment and Plan
   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus tach and initiated on arctic sun cooling protocol.
   .
   # RHYTHM: pt found in VF arrest, down time was brief for a few minutes.
   He was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.   He was started on
   amiodarone and initiated on artic sun cooling.  He reached cooling temp
   at 10pm last night.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH,
   structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his
   VF arrest.  However, given cardiac risk factors pt likely with
   underlying cardiac disease.
   -- plan to continue cooling protocol for 24hrs
   -- Cardiac Arrest Team consult and recs
   -- EEG with neuro input
   -- cont sedation with fentanyl/ mid and cont paralysis with cis
   -- cont amiodarone at 5mg/hr for 18 hrs
   -- q8 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol
   -- allow BP to autoregulate with MAPS 60-70
   -- trend CE
   -- TTE
   -- ECG
   -- CXR
   -- monitor on tele
   -- will consider cath emergently if signs of ischemia, but will hold
   off until patient stablizes.
   -- will need to contact PCP to obtain prior records, including cardiac
   history

67 yo M with PMH significant for HTN, DM found to be in V-fib arrest
   and transferred from [**Hospital3 **] for further management.  The
   patient was in his car this AM and rolled into the car ahead of him.
   This was witnessed by a police officer who found him slumped over in
   his car.  He received 1 cycle of CPR and an AED was placed that showed
   VF and was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  He was only down
   for a few minutes.  The patient had spontaneous movement at the scene.
   He was intubated by EMS in the field and given 100mg IV lidocaine.  The
   patient was transported to [**Hospital3 **] and given 2g Magnesium,
   150mg IV bolus of amiodarone, followed by  gtt @ 1mg/hr.  His CE at the
   OSH were trop I 0.03, CK 129. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Labs
   were significant WBC 11.9, UA [**6-3**] WBC, 3+ bacteria, mod epis. CXR
   showed well positioned ET tube,  pulm edema and no other acute
   abnormality. He was given 5mg pancuronium x2 and 4mg versed prior to
   transfer and cooling.  He has PIVx2 and right leg IS. He was started on
   Artic Sun protocol and transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] for further management.
   Cardiac arrest

   in paralytic drip rate as pt without shivering/ stable H20 temp on
   artic sun and no issues w/ ventilator.
   Action:
   *Artic sun protocol maintained. Labs q 6 hours.

   rewarming.

   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I

   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 575**] and [**Doctor Last Name **].
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   67 yr old male with history of DM, HTN, dyslipidemia, Pos FH for CAd
   with MVA yesterday and found by police in VF with prompt CPR and AED
   defibrillation times one with reversion to sinus with some junctional
   tachycardia.   Started on cooling protocol.    Required paralyzing
   agents.  EKG with minor ST-T abnl but no gross STEMI.  CPK peak so far
   695 MB 112 with trop 0.43.  CXR with diffuse infiltrates, possible pulm
   edema.   Head CT neg.
   Physical Examination
   Intubated and sedated.  BP borderline 100/60.
   S1, S2, no murmurs.
   no edema.
   Medical Decision Making
   Complete cooling protocol.  Neuro to see.
   Treat for ACS with asa, plavix, heparin and tentatively for cath
   tomorrow.  Echo this AM.
   EP to see.  On Amio with ST prolongation.
   Antibiotics added for ? aspiration.  Lasix diuresis.

   care proxy.
   Total time spent on patient care: 30 minutes of critical care time.

SOCIAL WORK:  Pt referred to SW as part of cardiac arrest response
   team.  Pt is a 67 year old man with PMH of DM and HTN, who was found
   slumped over in his car by a police officer with apparent cardiac
   arrest.  Pt is currently on CCU with Arctic Sun protocol.  SW met with
   pt
s wife, [**Name (NI) 2057**], and 2 sons in family waiting area.  Pt has 2 other
   children who stayed over night and returned home to bathe and have
   change of clothes, planning to return today.  Wife and sons verbalized
   good understanding of pt
s medical situation, and now awaiting further
   testing, etc.  They express understanding testing and observation takes
   time, and that they are challenged with having to wait to have more
   complete understanding of pt
s situation.  Family reports having very
   good communication with the team, and are very complimentary re; all
   aspects of pt
s care.  Wife states they are holding out hope, and feel
   pt
is in good hands.
      Family members are mutually supportive, and
   welcome visits from larger extended family.  Wife and children planning
   to stay in hospital again overnight.  SW educated re: importance of
   self care, but also normalized their feelings of wanting to be at
   bedside as much as possible.  Role of SW explained.
   SW will continue to follow with team to support family coping.

   67 yo M with DM, HTN presents following VF-arrest s/p shock x1 with
   conversion to sinus tach and initiated on arctic sun cooling protocol.
   .
   # RHYTHM: pt found in VF arrest, down time was brief for a few minutes.
   He was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.   He was started on
   amiodarone and initiated on artic sun cooling.  He reached cooling temp
   at 10pm last night.  No clear h/o ischemia, heart failure, LVH,
   structural heart disease or prior arrhythmia that might have caused his
   VF arrest.  However, given cardiac risk factors pt likely with
   underlying cardiac disease.
   -- plan to continue cooling protocol for 24hrs
   -- Cardiac Arrest Team consult and recs
   -- EEG with neuro input
   -- cont sedation with fentanyl/ mid and cont paralysis with cis
   -- cont amiodarone at 5mg/hr for 18 hrs
   -- q8 hour labs and coags per cooling protocol
   -- allow BP to autoregulate with MAPS 60-70
   -- trend CE
   -- TTE
   -- ECG
   -- CXR
   -- monitor on tele
   -- will consider cath emergently if signs of ischemia, but will hold
   off until patient stablizes.
   -- will need to contact PCP to obtain prior records, including cardiac
   history
   -- [**Hospital1 608**] has AED that shows VF arrest, will try to obtain
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated in the field after being found
   unresponsive and in VF arrest. CXR showed diffuse pulm edema.  Pt
   ventilation improved with sedation and paralysis and have been able to
   wean O2/PEEP overnight. Pt diuresed overnight with 40mg IV lasix.
   -- Repeat CXR this AM
   -- cont sedation and paralysis
   -- goal PCO2 35-40 per arrest protocol
   -- ABG q6
   -- I/O goal: -1-1.5L, consider initiation of lasix gtt
   .
   # CORONARIES: Unclear cardiac history. CE initially negative, but
   slowly trending up with Trop 0.43, CK: 695 MB 112, MBI 16.1.  Unlikely
   acute thrombotic event and likely CE elevation in the setting of VF and
   shock.
   -- ASA 325mg and lipitor 80mg daily
   -- trend CE
   -- Will discuss with team regarding initiation of heparin gtt
   -- consider cath this admission, but will hold off until patient
   stablizes or shows signs of ACS
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with pulm edema and lower ext edema. No prior history of HF.
   -- monitor I/O, daily weights
   -- I/O goal 1-1.5L, consider lasix gtt
   -- TTE
   .
   # DM: Pt with elevated glucose in the setting of cooling. patient with
   history of DM on oral medications at home.  Initiated on insulin gtt
   overnight
   - cont insulin gtt and wean after cooling protocol
   - hold home regimen
   .
   # HTN: Pt with history of HTN. Will plan to let patient autoregulate BP
   with goal MAPS 60-70.
   -- hold BP meds for now
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Plts 126 down from 238 on admission. Cooling can
   cause thrombocytopenia. Pre-test is intermediate for HIT.
   -- cont to trend platelets
   -- hold on heparin products for now
   -- send HIT antibodies
   -- will discuss with cardiac arrest team regarding expected
   thrombocytopenia.
   .

67 yo M with PMH significant for HTN, DM found to be in V-fib arrest
   and transferred from [**Hospital3 **] for further management.  The
   patient was in his car this AM and rolled into the car ahead of him.
   This was witnessed by a police officer who found him slumped over in
   his car.  He received 1 cycle of CPR and an AED was placed that showed
   VF and was shocked x1 with conversion to sinus tach.  He was only down
   for a few minutes.  The patient had spontaneous movement at the scene.
   He was intubated by EMS in the field and given 100mg IV lidocaine.  The
   patient was transported to [**Hospital3 **] and given 2g Magnesium,
   150mg IV bolus of amiodarone, followed by  gtt @ 1mg/hr.  His CE at the
   OSH were trop I 0.03, CK 129. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Labs
   were significant WBC 11.9, UA [**6-3**] WBC, 3+ bacteria, mod epis. CXR
   showed well positioned ET tube,  pulm edema and no other acute
   abnormality. He was given 5mg pancuronium x2 and 4mg versed prior to
   transfer and cooling.  He has PIVx2 and right leg IS. He was started on
   Artic Sun protocol and transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] for further management.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   *Intiated on artic sun protocol [**1-16**] w/ goal temp achieved @ 22:00.
   Pt rec
d sedated w/ fentanyl/ versed gtts and paralyzed w/ cistacurium
   for both questionable shivering last night and ventilator dysynchrony.
   Train of four with 4/4 twitches on increased mA of 50.  No changes made
   in paralytic drip rate as pt without shivering/ with stable H20 temp on
   artic sun and no issues w/ ventilation.
   * Neuro assessment limited by paralytic med and sedatives. Pupils 2mm
   bilat, very sluggish. Unresponsive. No spontaneous movements. No
   cough/gag/corneal reflexes. HOB @ 30 degrees or higher to decrease ICP;
   pH within goal range 35-40.
   *CV- HR 50s-60s SB/SR w/ frequent PVCs and occasional runs of AIVR
   70-100BPM (8-12 beats- strips in chart). ABP 90s-100s/50s. CVP 15.
   Rec
d on IV amiodarone 0.5mg/min. Doppler DP/PT bilat. Ext cool, normal
   color.  PLT count this AM 126 (238). CKs climbing.
   *Resp- Orally intubated. Rec
d pt on vent settings FiO2 50%, 550 x 20
   Peep 12. Pt w/out secretions via ETT. SPO2 100%.  AM ABG on these
   settings w/ PO2 60.
   *GI: OGT aspirated this AM for 300ml clear secretions, gastric pH 2.0/
   guiac negative.  Hypoactive BS. PO meds held given large residual
   likely r/t cooling.
   *GU: Foley cath w/ >20ml/hr, clear dark yellow urine.
   *ID: WBC initially 9.7 this AM, up to 15.7 in afternoon (19.0 on
   admission).
   Action/ Response:
   *Artic sun protocol maintained. Labs q 6 hours.
   *Rewarming initiated at 1600 at 0.5C/hr for goal temp 37 C. Closely
   monitoring e-lytes/ glucose/ coags and rhythm while rewarming.
   *Continuous EEG in place; Seen by neurology- no signs of seizure
   activity.
   *IV amiodarone DC
d as pt w/ prolonged QT interval per EP team.  Given
   40mg IV lasix with minimal UOP. ECHO w/ EF 35-40%, inf/lat hypokinesis.
   *Peep increased to 15 from 12 w/ appropriate increase in PO2 from 60 to
   140. FiO2 then decreased to 40% w/ normal ABG following.
   *Holding PO meds until re-warmed and absorption increased.
   *Started IV anbx coverage w/ vanco/cefepime for likely aspiration PNA.
   Plan:
   *Continue artic sun rewarming protocol. Labs q 6 hours.
   *Please give PO meds tonight when rewarmed.
   Acute coronary syndrome (ACS, unstable angina, coronary ischemia)
   Assessment:
   Action:
   *Initiated heparin gtt @ 1000 units/hr w/ 4000unit IVP bolus.
   Response:
   Plan:
   *Please give plavix load tonight when rewarmed.

   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   Assessment: 67 M s/p VF arrest, intubated and unresponsive.
   Investigation of the etiology of arrest as per primary team.
   Recommendations for Neuroprotection:
   1. Therapeutic Hypothermia: Pt appears to be eligible for cooling with
   Arctic Sun, as he is comatose post-arrest, with stable hemodynamics and
   no evidence of active hemorrhage.
   - Initiate TH with Arctic Sun goal temp 34 degrees C x 18 hours then
   rewarm as per protocol over next 6 hrs
   - While cooled, monitor coags and lytes q8 hours
   - Hypothermia can cause bradycardia so monitor for this
   - If having difficulty reaching goal temp, can utilize sedation, and if
   needed can use paralytic (try bolus dosing first, then gtt if needed)
   - Given slight pupil asymmetry noted on initial exam, would consider
   stat head CT as discussed at time of initial evaluation with residents
   2. Avoid elevated ICP: Keep HOB elevated greater than 30 degrees at all
   times; maintain goal pCO2 35-40.
   3. Monitor for seizure activity via continuous 48h EEG monitoring:
   Order protocol for EEG via POE; contact Neuro Epilepsy ICU fellow for
   EEG interpretation and formal consult.  If sz activity is identified,
   we advocate aggressive seizure control with benzodiazepines and
   antiepileptic medications which will be guided by the Neurology
   consultants.
   4. Avoid hyperglycemia
   5.  Once rewarmed, would aim for normothermia, as some patients may
   spike fevers post-hypothermia, and hyperthermia is clearly associated
   with poorer outcomes in neuro patients; the Arctic Sun pads can be used
   to facilitate normothermia as well if needed
   Will continue to follow along, please call/page 24/7 with any questions
   ([**Numeric Identifier 2131**]).  Consult staffed with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 31**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1526**].
   [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 31**] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 2130**], MD
   Emergency Medicine/Critical Care Medicine fellow

Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 66 Yr. old man with no past medical history who has
   not sought medical care, who was in his usual state of health until
   this evening when he had an unwitnessed arrest.  He was last heard
   walking down the stairs to do some work in the basement and about 5
   minutes later, his wife heard moaning but no fall or crash and found
   him lying on floor unresponsive.  She called 911 and called her son and
   friend who provided CPR until the police arrived and placed an AED on
   the patient (who may have been pulseless at that time).  The AED
   detected a shockable rhythm and fired two shocks.  Estimated time from
   arrest to shock was 10 minutes.  EMS arrived and found that the patient
   had a pulse and stable vital signs but he was breathing shallow breaths
   on his own.  An initial EKG showed ST elevations in the inferior leads,
   most prominent in III and depressions in V1 through V6.  The patient
   was taken to [**Hospital3 1618**] and received 100 mg lidocane in transport.
   At [**Hospital1 **] he was still unresponsive and had posturing.  He was intubated
   for airway protection.  There were no ST elevations seen on EKG at that
   time, but there were depressions in V1 and V2 and evolving Q waves in
   III and AVf.  He had a positive CKMB of 8.  He underwent head and neck
   CT which were negative.  He was given dilantin and ativan.  He was then
   med-flighted to [**Hospital1 5**].
   .
   Upon arrival to the ED he was hemodynamically stable with T 98.4 HR 99
   and BP 117/70 100% O2sat intubated with fio2 100%.   Sedated on
   benzodiazepines without pain medication.  His EKG showed NSR, 88 bpm,
   no ST elevations and Q waves in III and aVF.  He had a bedside echo,
   which showed hypokinesis of the mid and basal inferioseptal and
   inferolateral walls with EF 45%.  Cardiology did not feel that he
   needed an urgent cath given the resolution of ST elevations and he was
   started on a heparin gtt and given aspirin and plavix 300 mg.   Blood
   pressure was found to be elevated at 202/105.  Neurological exam
   revealed cortical posturing and lack of gag and pupilary reflexes
   Hypertension, benign

   66 YOM with no past medical history or recent medical care presents
   after cardiac arrest requiring defibrillation times 2, ST elevations on
   EKG by EMS and OSH, transferred for further management and found to
   have resolution of ST elevations but poor neurological exam.  Initiated
   on cooling protocol.
   .
   * Cardiac Arrest:  Differential diagnosis for sudden arrest includes
   MI, massive PE, cardiac tampenade, arrhythmia, metabolic derrangement,
   toxicosis.  Given ST elevations in inferior distribution on EKGs by EMS
   and elevated CKMB, MI causing V fib arrest seems most likely etiology.
   PE causing PEA arrest and subsequent hypoperfusion leading to V fib
   aslo a possibility, but lack of right heart strain on echo does not
   support this.
   -- Continue aspirin, plavix, high dose atorvastatin, and heparin gtt
   -- obtain am EKG and monitor on telemetry
   -- follow cardiac biomarkers
   -- Formal Echo in am

   -- will consider central venous line if hemodynamically unstable

   .

   intubated for airway protection.  Found to have unclear opacities on
   CXR which may be blood, sputum, or edema.
   -- ventalation weaned to FiO2 50%, will recheck ABG  (goal CO2 < 40)
   -- fentanyl/midazolam for sedation and pain control

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 66 YOM with no past medical history who has not sought
   medical care, who was in his usual state of health until this evening
   when he had an unwitnessed arrest.  He was last heard walking down the
   stairs to do some work in the basement and about 5 minutes later, his
   wife heard moaning but no fall or crash and found him lying on floor
   unresponsive.  She called 911 and called her son and friend who
   provided CPR until the police arrived and placed an AED on the patient
   (who may have been pulseless at that time).  The AED detected a
   shockable rhythm and fired two shocks.  Estimated time from arrest to
   shock was 10 minutes.  EMS arrived and found that the patient had a
   pulse and stable vital signs but he was breathing shallow breaths on
   his own.  An initial EKG showed ST elevations in the inferior leads,
   most prominent in III and depressions in V1 through V6.  The patient
   was taken to [**Hospital3 1618**] and received 100 mg lidocane in transport.
   At [**Hospital1 **] he was still unresponsive and had posturing.  He was intubated
   for airway protection.  There were no ST elevations seen on EKG at that
   time, but there were depressions in V1 and V2 and evolving Q waves in
   III and AVf.  He had a positive CKMB of 8.  He underwent head and neck
   CT which were negative.  He was given dilantin and ativan.  He was then
   med-flighted to [**Hospital1 5**].
   .
   Upon arrival to the ED he was hemodynamically stable with T 98.4 HR 99
   and BP 117/70 100% O2sat intubated with fio2 100%.  He was intubated
   with peak 14, peep 5, on 100% fio2, and sedated on benzodiazepines
   without pain medication.  His EKG showed NSR, 88 bpm, no ST elevations
   and Q waves in III and aVF.  He had a bedside echo, which showed
   hypokinesis of the mid and basal inferioseptal and inferolateral walls
   with EF 45%.  Cardiology did not feel that he needed an urgent cath
   given the resolution of ST elevations and he was started on a heparin
   gtt and given aspirin and plavix 300 mg.   Blood pressure was found to
   be elevated at 202/105.  Neurological exam revealed cortical posturing
   and lack of gag and pupilary reflexes.
   .
   ROS unable to be obtained due to unresponsiveness/ sedation/
   intubation. But by report from his wife he has been feeling fatigued
   today.  Also has had ? left sided chest pain and shortness of breath
   with exertion for a while, but never had it checked out.  Denied
   knowledge of fever, chills, HA.

   There are low inspiratory lung volumes. The heart size appears mildly

   well as in the retrocardiac regions, which are nonspecific and may

   pneumothorax.  Mediastinum is apparently widened, but again this may be
   secondary to supine positioning and low inspiratory volumes.
   IMPRESSION:
   1. Satisfactory placement of endotracheal tube and nasogastric tube.
   2. Patchy ill-defined opacities within the perihilar regions and left
   retrocardiac region, which may be due to pulmonary edema or infection.
   ECG: NSR, 88 bpm, no ST elevations and Q waves in III and aVF.
   Assessment and Plan
   66 YOM with no past medical history or recent medical care presents
   after cardiac arrest requiring defibrillation times 2, ST elevations on
   EKG by EMS and OSH, transferred for further management and found to
   have resolution of ST elevations but poor neurological exam.  Initiated
   on cooling protocol.
   .
   * Cardiac Arrest:  Differential diagnosis for sudden arrest includes
   MI, massive PE, cardiac tampenade, arrhythmia, metabolic derrangement,
   toxicosis.  Given ST elevations in inferior distribution on EKGs by EMS
   and elevated CKMB, MI causing V fib arrest seems most likely etiology.
   PE causing PEA arrest and subsequent hypoperfusion leading to V fib
   aslo a possibility, but lack of right heart strain on echo does not
   support this.
   -- Continue aspirin, plavix, high dose atorvastatin, and heparin gtt
   -- obtain am EKG and monitor on telemetry
   -- follow cardiac biomarkers
   -- Formal Echo in am
   -- Initiate cooling protocol;
      *continuous EEG x 48 hr, cool to 33.5 x 24 hrs ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 77**] [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7916**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1580**])
      *start paralytics with Cisatracurium Besylate for shivering,
   continue fentanyl/midazolam for sedation and pain control
      *HOB elevated > 30 degrees
   -- Chem 7, CBC, INR, tox screen - pending
   -- chest x ray
   -- will hold on obtaining CTA chest to r/o PE, given would not change
   current management
   -- obtain arterial line for BP monitoring - done in ED
   -- will consider central venous line if hemodynamically unstable
   -- Will consider catheterization if neurologically improves
   .
   * Status post intubation for respiratory protection:  Initially
   intubated for airway protection.  Found to have unclear opacities on
   CXR which may be blood, sputum, or edema.
   -- ventalation weaned to FiO2 50%, will recheck ABG  (goal CO2 < 40)
   -- fentanyl/midazolam for sedation and pain control
   -- continue antibiotics with unasyn for aspiration coverage, consider
   stopping vanc
   -- Q 6 mouth care
   .
   * Hypertension: Pt came to the floor with blood pressures above 250.
   Has known hypertension, per wife but not on any antihypertensive
   medications at home.  Unusual to have hypertension in the setting of
   MI, but may have increased catecholamines after resucitation.
   -- continue nitro gtt as needed
   -- 5 mg IV lopressor Q 6 Hr
   -- will eventually convert to PO beta blocker and ACEI once under
   better control and taking POs
   .
   * Neurologic unresponsiveness:  Found to have decorticate posturing at
   OSH.  Did not have pupillary or gag reflexes in ED.
   -- continue cooling protocol with 48 hr EEG
   -- f/u with neurology
   -- continue sedation and paralysis
   .
   * UTI: moderate bacteria seen on UA
   -- f/u culture
   -- continue unasyn as above
   .
   * FEN/GI:  Has OG tube in place but will be NPO while on paralytics
   -- famotidine IV Q 12
   .
   .
   ACCESS: 2 18 G PIV's
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -ppi with famotidine
   -Bowel regimen with docusate, senna when taking PO
   .
   CODE: full
   .

   S: Pt seen and discussed with housestaff. Please see their detailed H&P
   for complete details. In brief, 66 yoM without significant PMHx (no
   medical care in many years), not on any medications at baseline who was

Chief Complaint:  Cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 6050**] is a 62 yo man with h/o CAD s/p early MI, hypertension,
   hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, smoking who [**Last Name (un) **] at 11:45 he was
   walking with his sisters after getting a cup of coffe and he collapsed
   on his face approximately at 11:50 (wife spoke with patient at 11:45 on
   cell phone).  911 was called; per the family approximately 5-10 minutes
   elapsed prior to the arrival of 1st responders and initiation of CPR.
   EMS arrived shortly thereafter and he was found to be in VT.  First EMS
   strip is 11:54 and appears to be sinus bradycardia with very wide QRS
   and PR.  Subsequent strips by EMS show VT at 12:01, 12:04, 12:05,
   12:06.  Multiple VT morphologies and cycle lengths.  He was shocked 4
   times; "post shock" rythm shows resoration of sinus rhythma with very
   prolonged intervals.  There are numerous rhythm strips showing VT at
   variable cycle lengths and morphologies.  He also received 3mg epi, 2mg
   atropine, and lidocaine.
   .
   Upon further history taking, he was in his usual state of health until
   a few days ago when he began complaining of feeling generally unwell.
   As per wife, no specific complaints of chest pain, palpitations,
   dyspnea.  Speaking with his primary care doctor Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6051**] Mr.
   [**Known lastname 6050**] had not seen [**Name8 (MD) **] MD in over 1 year.  He was seen mid-[**Month (only) 1530**]
   where his Hgb A1c was found to be 10, his Cr 2.4, and K 5.9 on
   lisinopril 5mg po daily.  His hyperkalemia was managed by holding his
   ACE inhibitor.  He was seen in clinic on [**4-25**] and he was started on
   lisinopril 10mg po daily + lasix 40mg po daily without repeating a
   potassium measurement.
   .
   At [**Hospital1 5**] ED he was found to be in VT again, received 2 shocks and 300mg
   amiodarone bolus, heparin bolus, 1mg epi x 2, 1mg atropine, aspirin,
   versed, and dopamine drip.  In the cath lab he was found to have what
   appeared to be chronic occlusions of his LAD and RCA.  He had no PCI
   but did have an IABP placed.  In the cath lab he had inumerable
   episodes of VT and was probably shocked 30 times.  He received 2g
   calcium chloride, 4mg atropine, amiodarone 1mg drip, epinephrine 4mg
   bolus and epinephrine 3mcg/min bolus, levophed drip at 1mg/min,
   lidocaine 200mg bolus, 2g magnesium, 150mEq bicarbonate, 2mg versed,
   insulin + bicarbonate.  Peri-code it was discovered that his K was 6.9;
   the VT appeared to respond most favorably to insulin/dextrose &
   bicarbonate.  Upon arriving to the CCU he immediately went into VT
   again and was coded for about 15 minutes with numerous shocks, several
   rounds of epi/atropine, amio bolus.  He returned to NSR.
   .
   Around 5pm he was noted to have rhythmic tongue twitching.  slightly
   decreased with ativan.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Name13 (STitle) 6047**] is a 62 yo man with CAD, CKD, DM who presents with
   cardiac arrest.
   .
   # Cardiac arrest. [**Month (only) 8**] be a primary arrhythmic event versus related to
   ischemia vs post-ischemic cardiomyopathy.  More likely however seems to
   be VT from metabolic derangement/hyperkalemia given the numerous
   morphologies of his VT from the EMS & the wide intervals of his sinus
   rhythm EKG.  Unfortunately he has very poor neurologic prognosis given
   - no cooling given his instability unless becomes febrile
   - neuro consult
   - q 4 hour neuro checks
   .
   # Refractory ventricular tachycardia: may be secondary to either
   hyperkalemia or ischemia.
   - q 4 hours K+ and ABG
   - continue lidocaine drip at 2
   - continue amiodarone drip at 1mg/min
   - echo in AM to eval for WMA/ischemia
   - ACLS & amio if recurrs
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: may be related to VT versus ischemia
   - wean EPI, then levophed, then dopamine
   - IABP.  Re-evaluate need for baloon in AM.
   - Echo in AM
   .
   # Coronary artery disease: LAD and RCA occlusions appeared to be old
   - consider viability study/MIBI and revascularization if survives.
   - aspirin, statin
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: unclear if this is primary from ARF & ACE versus
   secondary to acidosis
   - monitor K q 4 hours.
   - insulin drip
   - s/p kayexalate
   .
   # Mental status: has signs of severe CNS injury with bleak prognosis
   (decerebrate posturing; babinski, dilated pupils, oculocephalics not
   intact); likely anoxic brain injury.  Given h/o fall on head and
   anticoagulation (heparin & aspirin) in the lab, CNS bleed should be
   ruled out.
   - CT head if stabilized in AM
   - EEG in AM
   - propofol for sedation, will try to avoid sedation to monitor neuro
   status.
   .
   # Tongue twitching: neurology c/s feels this is likely myoclonus.
   Seizure also on ddx
   - EEG in AM
   .
   # Acute renal failure: likely due to ACE & lasix.  [**Month (only) 8**] develop ATN
   post-code.  Still urinating
   - monitor I/O
   - appreciate renal recs
   - hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: statin
   .
   # Diabetes: insulin gtt
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ, PPI
   .
   # Code: full.  Family meeting planned in AM

TITLE:  CCU Staff
   62 yo man suffered cardiac arrest today.  Apparently with prior history
   of CAD and family history of premature CAD.  Uncertain time from
   collapse to CPR
 arrived in [**Hospital1 5**] ED apparently receiving CPR.  One
   reported downtime ~ 20 minutes
 but was receiving CPR for at least
   some of that time.  Urgently cathed with showed apparently chronically
   occluded RCA and LAD.  I have personally reviewed the cath films and
   discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4235**].  There is no indication for acute
   intervention in cath lab or surgically at this time.
   The patient has suffered from recurrent ventricular arrhythmias
   requiring multiple shocks.  He is being maintained on an IABP and
   multiple pressors.  Currently his oxygen saturation on 100% FiO2 is
   94-95%, BP is 128/80 on IABP, lungs are ronchorous with decreased air
   movement, cardiac exam is RRR (tachy) with s1s2 II/VI SEM, abd is soft
   with masses or apparent tenderness, ext no C/C/E.  The pt is intubated
   and was moving prior to sedation.
   ECG shows ST with LBBB (earlier) now LBBB appears resolved (on
   telelmetry).
   Impression: Infarct related cardiomyopathy s/p cardiac arrest.  Given
   hemodynamic and arrhythmia instability, he is not a good candidate for
   cooling at this time.  He is receiving Amiodarone and lidocaine
   intravenously as well as pressor support.  We will attempt to correct
   metabolic derangements.  We have consulted the renal service for
   assistance.
   I have reviewed his status in detail with the patient
s family
   including his wife and son.  They are aware that he is critically ill

This is a 62 yr old pt with Hx MI, DM, CAD who collapsed/had CV arrest
   while out walking with sister (witnessed). By report, CPR was initiated
   by EMS after AED advised shock and he was tx with atropine ,
   epinephrine. There is a question as to how long pt was down without
   CPR  or with
 inadequate circulation
  PTA to ER- ? 20-25 minutes by
   one report. On arrival to ER, pt had pulse then arrested( PEA /VF
   arrest) for which he received another defib/shock, more CPR and
   Epi/Atropine as well as Heparin bolus to r/o ACS, ASA and Amiodorone
   bolus 300 mg as well as Dopa gtt.
   In cath lab, no new occlusions were found- only chronic occlusion of
   RCA/LAD so no intervention was done at that time. Pt had
multiple VF
   arrests
 in lab again with hyperkalemia and increased creatinine noted.
   Pt was treated for hyperkalemia with insulin/D50/kexilate and
   ventilator was adjusted to accommodate for acidosis. Pt was also
   started on Amiodorone gtt 1 mg, levo gtt, epi gtt- as well as bolused
   with atropine, CaCl, HCO3. Travenous wire and IABP were
   inserted/placed.
   Upon arrival to CCU pt coded again- defib/shocked several times,
   rebolused with Amiodorone and Lido and HCO3 and started on 2mg  Lido
   gtt as well as insulin gtt for hyperglycemia.
   By early evenings, able to wean off EPI gtt, wean down Levo gtt as MAPS
   stayed -68-74.(remaining on same 15 mcg/kg Dopa gtt). The  Amiodorone
   was kept at 1mg, Lido kept at 2mg with stable heart rhythym. His
   Heparin gtt was d/c as were his sedations meds for better monitoring of
   neuro status. Pupils remains nonreactive, MAE very minimally, posturing
   and reflexive movements only.
   Neuro and Renal both consulted on the pt- [**Name (NI) 6043**] [**Name (NI) **] was deferred d/t
   unstable  hemodynamic situation with the pt. He remains attached to TV
   wire on standby and to Defib/Lifepack.
   Plan is for pt to stabilize overnite and go for head CT/start EEG
   monitoring in AM.
   Family has met with/spoken with  Social work, CCU team-RN and MD, Neuro
   Team re: overall prognosis, situation and have stayed overnite ( wife,
   daughter, son, 2 sisters).
   Hyperkalemia (high Potassium, Hyperpotassemia)
   Assessment:
   Pt admitted s/p CV arrest in setting of hyperkalemia currently
   correcting to 5.2-4.3
   Action:
   Given one dose Kexilate 30gm. Remains on insulin gtt 10u-6u per BS.
   Checking K q 2 hours until overnite- dropping lab check to q 4 hour d/t
   stabilization of lab.
   Response:
   Pt correcting K level to 4.3-4.7.
   Plan:
   Continue to check k level q 4 hour and watch trend.
   Altered mental status (not Delirium)
   Assessment:
   Pt s/p CV arrest perhaps anoxic injury arrived and remains
   nonresponsive to verbal command.
   Action:
   Neuro checks q 1 hour. Neuro consult this shift. D/C heparin gtt- to
   check re: d/c ASA in case of bleed s/p witnessed fall in field. D/C
   sedation at 7:30 pm to better assess neuro status. Initiated [**Location (un) 408**] J
   collar s/p fall as well for neck protection. Using log roll with
   moving, providing collar care. Keeping temperature normal
 Tylenol q 6
   hours prn initiated.
   Response:
    Within 2 hours of d/c sedation, pt moving slightly more but reflex
   movements only- moving tongue, jaw; moving right and left arm and very
   slightly the rt and left legs- appearing to be more posturing  in
   nature. Please refer to extensive neurological flow sheet for details.
   No seizure felt to be occurring per neuro consult.
   Plan:
   Hold kepra per neuro as movements of tongue/mouth not thought to be
   seizure in nature but myoclonic. Once pt
s hemodynamics more
   stabilized, off Levo gtt and overall less unstable- plan to send for
   head CT and start EEG monitoring. Discuss with neuro ? need to d/c ASA
   as well as heparin pending CT scan to r/o bleed/other processes. Keep
   temp normal to decrease metabolic requirements of brain/heart. Tylenol
   for low grade temp and cooling blkt as needed. Add back Propofol gtt
   for sedation if pt requires it instead of versed/Fentanyl to provide
   for easier neuro exams.
   Ventricular fibrillation (VF)
   Assessment:
   Pt admitted to CCU s/p VF arrest possibly d/t hyperkalemia.
   Action:
   Pt remains on amiodorone 1 mg and lido 2mg gtt. Pacer on standby (
   transvenous)-not currently being used. Defib in place and on standby as
   well.
   Response:
   Pt remains free of arrythmias this shift. No pacing as well. (+)
   sensing and pacing( tested) . VVI pacer set at 60 for rate and 10 mA.
   Plan:
   Continue amio/lido gtt. Keep lytes WNL. Continue to have defib in
   place, on standby.

   Mr. [**Name13 (STitle) 6047**] is a 62 yo man with CAD, CKD, DM who presents with
   cardiac arrest.
   .
   # Cardiac arrest. [**Month (only) 8**] be a primary arrhythmic event versus related to
   ischemia vs post-ischemic cardiomyopathy.  More likely however seems to
   be VT from metabolic derangement/hyperkalemia given the numerous
   morphologies of his VT from the EMS & the wide intervals of his sinus
   rhythm EKG.  Unfortunately he has very poor neurologic prognosis given
   - no cooling given his instability unless becomes febrile
   - neuro consult
   - q 4 hour neuro checks
   .
   # Refractory ventricular tachycardia: may be secondary to either
   hyperkalemia or ischemia.
   - q 4 hours K+ and ABG
   - continue lidocaine drip at 2
   - continue amiodarone drip at 1mg/min
   - echo in AM to eval for WMA/ischemia
   - ACLS & amio if recurrs
   .
   # Cardiogenic shock: may be related to VT versus ischemia
   - wean EPI, then levophed, then dopamine
   - IABP.  Re-evaluate need for baloon in AM.
   - Echo in AM
   .
   # Coronary artery disease: LAD and RCA occlusions appeared to be old
   - consider viability study/MIBI and revascularization if survives.
   - aspirin, statin
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: unclear if this is primary from ARF & ACE versus
   secondary to acidosis
   - monitor K q 4 hours.
   - insulin drip
   - s/p kayexalate
   .
   # Mental status: has signs of severe CNS injury with bleak prognosis
   (decerebrate posturing; babinski, dilated pupils, oculocephalics not
   intact); likely anoxic brain injury.  Given h/o fall on head and
   anticoagulation (heparin & aspirin) in the lab, CNS bleed should be
   ruled out.
   - CT head if stabilized in AM
   - EEG in AM
   - propofol for sedation, will try to avoid sedation to monitor neuro
   status.
   .
   # Tongue twitching: neurology c/s feels this is likely myoclonus.
   Seizure also on ddx
   - EEG in AM
   .
   # Acute renal failure: likely due to ACE & lasix.  [**Month (only) 8**] develop ATN
   post-code.  Still urinating
   - monitor I/O
   - appreciate renal recs
   - hold nephrotoxins
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia: statin
   .
   # Diabetes: insulin gtt
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ, PPI
   .
   # Code: full.  Family meeting planned in AM

   inserted/placed. On arrival to CCU cont to have VT without a pulse

SOCIAL WORK:  Pt referred to SW by nursing staff as he was admitted s/p

s wife and son in family
   waiting area, [**Last Name (un) **] en-route from NY.  Family has been updated by team,
   and aware of the gravity of pt
s illness.  Wife and son expressed their
   worry/ fear, while holding out hope.  SW supported them in processing
   their feelings.  Wife and son offered some hx about the patient and

   He had an MI many years ago, but no subsequent hospitalizations.

   plan to stay at hospital tonight.  SW provided some orientation to the
   unit and suggestions re: managing flow of information to extended
   family and friends.  Reinforced the benefits of self care.  SW will
   continue to meet with family to support coping.
