PMH 4 V CABG [**69**]. SEVERE MR/SEVERE TR. PULMONARY HTN. HTN. COUMADIN FOR
   PAF. TIAs. L CAROTID ENDARTERECTOMY. PARTIAL COLECTOMY FOR CRONES.
   COLONOSCOPY 06 SHOWED NO CRONES COLITIS, BUT DIVERTICULI. EMPHASEMA AND
   BRONCHIECTASIS. HYPOTHYROID. BILATERAL CATARACTS. MACULAR DEGENERATION.
   Pt came to EW [**9-29**] with palpitations and weakness and was found to be
   in rapid a-fib with RVR. She was cardioverted into NSR, but became
   bradycardic to the 30s and cyanotic and was intubated and started on
   dopamine. She was also started on IV amiodarone after bolus.[**9-30**] she
   went into juctional rhythm and amiodarone was d/c. [**10-4**] she was loaded
   with digoxin. [**10-5**] she went back into AF with rate in 70-90s and was
   tolerating it. She is presumed to have a community aquired PNA and is
   on levoquin. She was extubated at -09:30 [**10-6**] and was sating in low
   90s on 35% ventimask. She was still somnulent, but rouseable and will
   follow commands. She is on heparin at 2500 units/hr, heparin at 5
   mic/kilo and TPN at 42cc/hr. It is unclear why she is receiving TPN and
   not tube feedings. She is being transfered to be evaluated for valve
   replacement. She is full code.
   She arrived in CCU at 1745 with bp in 80s, minimally responsive,
   intermittently gurgling. She was in A-fib with HR in 1-teens to 130s
   with occasional PVCs. She was on heparin at 250 units/hr and 5mic/kilo
   dopamine. Dopamine was increased and then changed to levophed. It was
   decided to intubate her and then cardiovert her. She was fully
   cultured.
   Airway, Inability to Protect (Risk for Aspiration, Altered Gag, Airway
   Clearance, Cough)
   Assessment:
   Pt arrived solmnulent. She would rouse to stimulation by barely opening
   her eyes, but did not talk or follow any commands. Although sating 100%
   she seemed unable to protect her airway, particularly in setting of
   planned cardioversion.  Her gas on NRB was 7.46/40/306/5/29.
   Action:
   Anesthesia gave her 12mg etomidate and 110mg succinylcholine and easily
   intubated her.
   Response:
   She was put on ventilator at AC 400 X 16 with no overbreathing 5 PEEP
   and 100%. She was suctioned for thin froathy white sputum. VAP care
   done.
   Plan:
   CXR after OG tube placement. Continue with VAP care. Decrease FIO2 with
   gas.
   Atrial fibrillation (Afib)
   Assessment:
   Pt arrived in a-fib and hypotensive on dopamine and heparin.
   Action:
   Anesthesia was called and she was intubated and then cardioverted with
   200J. It was decided not to use amiodarone due to hx of junctional
   rhythm after this drug.
   Response:
   She went into NSR with rate initially in low 100s then down to mid 80s
   with both frequent PVCs and PACs.
   Plan:
   Monitor Rhythm and notify team with change.
   Hypotension (not Shock)
   Assessment:
   Pt arrived with bp in the 80s down to the 50s. BP was being taken on
   the left arm. She was on dopamine at 5mic/kilo in afib in 1-teens. BP
   was being taken on L side. After intubation bp dropped further to 60s
   and dopamine was changed to levophed at .09 mic/kilo. Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 5279**] spoke to
   OSH attending who said she had L subclavian stenosis and blood pressure
   could only be auscultated on the R.
   Action:
   BP auscultated on R and it ranged 130-140s/palp. Dinamap did not
   register bp. Levofed decreased to .02mic/kilo and Aline inserted in R
   radial aline.
   Response:
   Plan:

TITLE:  CCU Fellow Addendum
   Patient seen and plan discussed with CCU housestaff.  For details, see
   CCU resident H&P.  Briefly, the patient is a 73 year old woman with PMH
   of COPD and recently diagnosed hyperthyroidism in the setting of new
   [**Hospital 13715**] transferred from [**Hospital3 364**] Hospital after arresting at home.
   The patient had recently been discharged from [**Hospital1 19**], and was seen
   earlier in the [**Hospital3 **] ED for a COPD exacerbation, which was treated
   and the patient was discharged home from the ED.  While at home, per
   reports, she became unconscious in front of her family, and had been
   down for several minutes before EMS arrived (unclear if CPR
   performed).  Per EMS reports, she was found to have a ventricular
   escape rhythm, and upon pacing had recovery of radial pulses, although
   soon after she lost her pressures, was intubated and taken to the [**Hospital **] ED.  She was found to have inferior ST elevations, and was taken
   emergently to the cath lab where she was found to have no obstructive
   CAD with a wedge of 36 mmHg and cardiac output of over 8 on neo and
   dopamine.  An IABP had been placed prior to the left heart cath, and
   was left in place for transfer.  Upon arrival, she was hypertensive
   with systolics in the 200s on pressors.  Neo and dopamine were
   discontinued.  She was noted to have purple toes in her right foot,
   with non-dopplerable pulses, and after d/c of heparin, the IABP was
   pulled with 50 minutes of pressure.  She had a triphasic popliteal
   pulse in the right leg, and a uniphasic PT pulse in her foot.  The
   color was beginning to improve in the foot after venostasis had been
   achieved, and so a pressure dressing was placed with plan to restart
   heparin and monitor clinically as well as CKs.  As far as her arrest,
   she will be instituted on the cooling protocol, and monitored for signs
   of neurological recovery.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:  s/p cardiac arrest requiring balloon pump for
   pressure support
   HPI:
   Ms [**Known lastname 13709**] is a 73 year-old female with pmh of dementia, newly
   diagnosed hyperthyroidism on methimizole, and atrial fibrillation s/p
   cardiac arrest being transferred from [**Hospital3 364**] Hospital due to
   hypotension requiring a balloon pump.
   She had presented to the [**Hospital3 **] ED the night prior to admission with
   shortness of breath and was treated with combivent and discharged
   home.  The night of admissison she collapsed in the presence of her
   family with a reported down time of about 5-10 minutes.  Her family
   called 911 (at 22:23) and CPR was initiated by the fire department
   while awaiting EMS.  An AED advised no shock as her initial rhythm
   showed a ventricular escape which was paced externally.  Reportedly she
   had pulses for about 10 minutes, then went asystolic while still in the
   field.  Chest compressions were started and she was intubated by EMS.
   She underwent 2 rounds of epi, atropine, and bicarb.  CPR continued
   into her arrival in the ED for another 15 minutes with more rounds of
   epi, atropine, and bicarb.  She eventually developed a sinus
   tachycardia with SBPs in the 80s on neo.
   EKG showed new ST elevations in her inferior leads.  She was loaded
   with 600 mg of plavix, given 325 mg of ASA.  She was also given 125 mg
   of solumedrol in the ED.  She was sent to the cath lab emergently.  She
   again lost a pulse with bradycardia to the 40s while being prepped on
   the cath lab table and underwent an additional round of CPR with epi,
   bicarb, and atropine.  Her HR increased with this treatment to the 90's
   and her pulse returned.
   Of note she was recently admitted to [**Hospital1 19**] from [**2-20**] to [**2-24**] when she
   presented with chest discomfort and was found to have new atrial
   fibrillation and hyperthyroidism.  At that hospitalization she was
   started on methimazole and propanolol for her hyperthyroidism and
   propanolol and aspirin for atrial fibrillation.  Her course was
   complicated by delirium on chronic dementia and psychiatry was
   consulted and made medication changes to her psych meds.
   On arrival to the CCU her SBP were in the 180's to 200's.  Her dopa and
   neo were turned off and she was given 10 mg IV labetalol for
   persistently elevated blood pressures.

   Assessment and Plan Ms [**Known lastname 13709**] is a 73 year-old female with dementia,
   newly diagnosed hyperthyroidism on methimizole, and atrial fibrillation
   s/p cardiac arrest being transferred from [**Hospital3 364**] Hospital due
   to hypotension requiring a balloon pump.
   # Hypotension:  The patient developed hypotension in the post arrest
   setting.  However she was hypertensive on arrival to the CCU.  Pressors
   were weaned and she was given 10 mg IV labetalol for persistently
   elevated SBPs in the 180's to 200;'s.  The IABP was removed.
   - Monitor pressures and add dopamine back if needed for MAP > 65.
   # S/p cardiac arrest:  The differential for cardiac arrest includes
   ischemic heart disease (unlikely given clean coronaries on cath),
   arrhythmia (bradycardias vs long QT syndrome vs idiopathic V.fib),
   valvular heart disease (she did have mitral regurgitation noted on her
   previous TTE), electrolyte abnormality, myocarditis, drug-induced,
   pulmonary embolism.  She is on quetiapine prn which can prolong the QT
   segment and trazadone which can be proarrhythmic.  Thyroid storm has
   been associated with cardiac arrest, however she had been on the
   methimazole so this is less likely.
   - Cooling with artic sun protocol as she was within the 6 hour time
   limit.
   - TTE to evaluate for change in valvular disease.
   - Neuro consult in the am
   - Continuous EEG per artic sun protocol
   - Pending clinical improvement, will need an ICD placed prior to
   discharge.
   - Will check TSH and free T4 as thyroid toxicosis is on the
   differential.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Head CT when stable
   # Pulseless right foot in the setting of IABP:  A known complication of
   IABP is distal limb ischemia.  Per report she had no had pulses in her
   right foot since IABP placement.  This is concerning for limb ischemia
   vs cholesterol emboli.
   - IABP was removed on arrival to the CCU.
   - Will trend CK's and clinically monitor with serial limb exams.
   - Heparin gtt
   - Consider angiography if her exam changes or CKs continue to rise.
   # CORONARIES:  The patient was found to have no occlusive coronary
   artery disease on cardiac catheterization.  Cholesterol had been
   checked in [**2-11**]: total cholesterol 134, LDL 55, HDL 61, and TG 88.
   # PUMP:  The patient had a recent TTE during her last admission which
   showed a normal EF of > 55%.  She currently appears euvolemic.
   - As above, TTE tomorrow to evaluate for change in valvular disease or
   heart function.
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation.    She
   had been started on propanolol for rate control during her last
   hospitalization.
   -  Holding propanolol due to hypotension.
   -  Continue ASA 325 mg daily.
   -  Monitor on telemetry
   # s/p intubation/History of asthma/COPD:  The patient was intubated in
   the setting of cardiac arrest and remains hypotensive, dependent on
   pressors and a balloon pump.
   - Continue ventilator support while being cooled.
   - Hold sedation to assess neurologic status.  Can restart fentanyl and
   versed if she appears uncomfortable.
   - Portable chest X-ray to confirm ETT placement.
   - Continue atrovent MDI qid.  As patient is intubated, will change
   advair to flovent 200 [**Hospital1 **].
   # Transaminitis:  Likely secondary to shock liver from hypotension.
   - Trend LFTs.
   # Lactic acidosis:  Likely secondary to hypoperfusion due to recent
   hypotension.  BP support for MAPs > 65 as needed.
   - Trend lactate.
   #  Hyperthyroidism:
   -  Continue methimazole.
   -  Holding proranolol due to hypotension.
   -  Will check TSH and free T4.
   #  Anxiety/Dementia:  She is on mirtazapine, trazodone, and quetiapine
   -  Hold home medications while intubated.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now, replete lytes prn
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale

TITLE: CARDIOLOGY FELLOW CCU ADMISSION NOTE
Please see housestaff note for full details of H&P.
Briefly, 80F with idiopathic dilated CMP (last EF 30%) , HTN, CKD
found down by her family accompanied by a suicide note and an
empty bottle of carvedilol. EMS reportedly found the patient in
complete heart block and external pacing was begun.  Shortly
after her pulse was lost and she received CPR and 3 rounds of
epinephrine and atropine. She was intubated for airway
protection, received glucagon and started on dopamine in the
field. On arrival to the ED, she was not in CHB and was not
requiring pressors.
PE: T33C   P67SR    123/65    RR12   100%
Intubated, sedated
PERRL, does not withdraw to pain, + posturing both arms
RRR, no murmurs
Bibasilar crackles
Abdomen mildly distended
Extr cool, no edema, s/p R TMA; s/p multiple R finger amputations
EKG [**2181-12-3**] 23:29: SR 85, LAFB, QRS 140ms. Compared to EKG at
23:02, anterolateral twi and STD V4 have resolved.
80F with dCMP s/p reported betablocker overdose and cardiac
arrest, hemodynamically stable off pressors.  Duration of cardiac
arrest unclear at this time.

-       serial neurologic checks

Chief Complaint:  s/p PEA arrest, Beta Blocker overdose
   HPI:
   79 yo F w/ PMHx DM, CHF [**3-5**] idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy with EF
   35% 9/08, HTN, and CKD  found down at home on ground by family, EMS
   called, noted her to be in complete heart block moving all extremities
   and transcutaneous pacing was inititated. She arrested and received 3
   rounds of epi/atropine and chest compression for unclear amount of
   time, she received 4mg IV glucagon and dopamine, intubated in the
   field. EMS reported they found a suicide note and an empty bottle of
   carvedilol 25mg PO BID filled on [**11-7**] for 60 tabs. Also empty bottle of
   Lasix, Lipitor, and a bottle of carvedilol 12.5mg PO BID with some
   pills remaining was found by her bedside. Family did not confirm this
   story.
   On arrival to the ED, HR 135 BP 163/84 RR 14 POX 99% intubated. Her
   exam was intubated and sedated, 3mm not reactive pupils b/l, stable
   pelvis, no evidence of trauma. Initial EKG wide complex tachycardia at
   rate of 135, bicarb drip initiated, EKG improved to narrow complex
   sinus rhythm in 80s. CXR showed right mainstem intubated, tube pulled
   back. RIJ placed without complication. CT head negative. She was
   sedated on fentyl and versed. She received 50 g charcol via OG. Artic
   sun protocol was initiated. VS prior to transfer BP 109/65 off any
   pressors HR 68 intubated PC 60% FIO2 TV 480 Peak Pressure of 44 PEEP 0.
   .
   Unable to obtain review of systems [**3-5**] intubation.
   .
   On arrival to the floor, the patient was continued on the Artic Sun
   cooling blanket, and fentanyl and versed were increased to keep patient
   from biting the ET tube. Approximately 20 mins after arrival, the
   patient became bradycardic and was found to be pulseless, a PEA code
   blue protocol was initiated. Chest compressions were started, cooling
   protocol was discontinued, and she received epinephrine x3, atropine
   x4, 2 amps bicarb, 1 amp calcium chloride, 1 amp glucagon, and an
   epinephrine gtt. She also received 1 amp D50 and 10 units regular
   insulin for hyperkalemia. After 15 mins of CPR, a pulse returned at 125
   and BP of 200/100. An EKG and CXR showing no pneumothorax were obtained
   and 10 mins later PEA returned. Again the epinephrine drip and CPR were
   resumed. She received atropine x1, calcium chloride x2. A dopamine gtt
   was started at 10mcg/kg/hr and an epinephrine gtt changed to rate of
   0.05 and a bicarb drip was started. At this time, her family was
   present and updated on the events of the night. The poor prognosis
   given the length of the code blue, and now significant hypoxia of 80%
   on 100% FiO2 after CPR were communicated. The family (pt's son and
   daughter) did not want ventilatory support withdrawn but agreed
   escalating care would not change the poor prognosis. Approximately 1
   hour later with the family at the bedside, the patient became
   bradycardic and hypotensive and died at 6:38 am.

   79 yo F with h/o idiopathic dialated cardiomyopathy, EF 35%, DM, HTN
   presents after being found down at home by family s/p PEA arrest in the
   field and concern for carvedilol overdose and now repeated PEA arrests.
   .
   # RHYTHM:  Per EMS reports (strip not available) was found in complete
   heart block and transcutaneously paced in the field. She did received
   4mg IB glucagon. Wide complex tachycardia was noted on presentation to
   ED which resolved with bicarb drip. On arrival to the CCU, she quickly
   developed PEA arrest. CODE BLUE PROTOCL per PEA algorithm carried out
   with successful resumption of spontaneous circulation twice. After
   discussion with family goals of care given poor prognosis plan was for
   no further escalation of care. Patient expired at 6:38 am after
   becoming bradycardic/hypotensive with family at bedside. Awaiting
   family decision on autopsy, medical examiner declined case. PCP
   [**Name Initial (PRE) 397**].

   79yo female admitted s/p ?CHB then ?PEA/cardiac arrest in field after
   an apparent suicide with empty carvedilol bottle at bedside. CPR,
   intubation, ACLS meds in field, transcutaneous pacing
 transported to
   [**Hospital1 19**] ED in ST/SR, BP 120s. no pressors. Given charcoal. Bicarb gtt.

   33.3 via artic sun
 goal temp reached at 0024hrs. Fentanyl + Versed
   for sedation. RIJ TLC placed. Sent to CCU at 0415hrs
 at 0445hrs pt
   noted to go into SB 45-50 w/ more of a 1^st AVB
 BP cycled at this
   time, but unable to get BP, then attempted to palpate pulses while
   calling for CODE and doppler. Pt subsequently went thru 2 PEA arrests
   then partially stabilized close to 6am. Aline placed,  Dopamine gtt,
   Bicarb gtt, back on Fentanyl/Versed gtts (pt biting on ETT and fighting

 sats poor since arrest 80s). Family arrived at bedside
   after 6am, updated on events and codes
 discussed that pt will
   probably go back into PEA arrest. Family decided to maintain current
   treatments but not withdraw support. Family aware that patient may
   arrests again but no further treatment will be given poor medical
   outcome. 0635 BP dropping with HR
 0638 pt expired with family at
   bedside. Emotional support given.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:  STEMI/Vfib arrest
   HPI:
   51 yo M with 3V CAD, previously stented to LAD at OSH in setting of MI,
   presents from [**Location (un) 196**] with CP, nausea and SOB similar (but worse) to
   prior MI. Initially EKG within normal limits, but was having ectopy,
   eventually EKG showed anterior ST elevations and he was given aspirin,
   heparin, plavix and IIb/IIIA, his BP dropped to the 100s he was given
   neosynpephrine.
   .
   Pt was then transfered to [**Hospital1 **] for catheterization. He was taken
   immediately to the cath lab, already in cardiogenic shock with BP
   dropping to 80s. Pt vomited but no clear aspiration noted. An IABP pump
   was placed. He was found to have an acute in-stent thrombosis of LAD,
   successfully cleared, chronically occluded RCA and 80% LCX. Pt
   developed VF arrest, CPR was initiated, he was shocked to brady rhythm
   for which he was given 3mg of atropine. Nadir ABG revealed 6.96/52/236,
   HCO3 13, Lactate 10. He was intubated and
   initially there was some small amounts of red frothy return from
   the ETT. IABP was replaced by Impella and required high doses of
   levophed and dopamine. Oxygenation worsened down to 70s and PEEP
   increased to 18 with improvement of O2 to 80s. Did not respond to
   increased tidal volumes to 750 and RR to 28, so pt paralyzed. After
   total of 400mg IV lasix and began improving oxygenation with urine
   output.  Pt started on amio with reduction of ectopy.
   .
   ROS unable to be obtained due to intubation/sedation.

   Studies:
   CXR:
   Catheter projecting over the thoracic aorta, left ventricular outflow
   tract and cavity is probably a ventricular assist device. Ascending
   Swan-Ganz catheter ends in the right pulmonary artery. ET tube is
   approximately 3 cm above the carina and could not be advanced.
   Interstitial pulmonary edema is generally mild throughout the lungs,
   but there is greater opacification in the right upper lobe, which could
   be asymmetric edema (a finding seen with acute mitral regurgitation)
   or, alternatively concurrent pneumonia or aspiration or pulmonary
   hemorrhage. At the apex, small lucencies are probably due to emphysema,
   but should be considered in clinical context to exclude tuberculosis.
   Mediastinal widening is symmetric, from the carina to the thoracic
   inlet, probably due to combination of fat and mediastinal vascular
   engorgement but adenopathy is not excluded by this examination and if
   there is clinical concern for aortic dissection, I could explain the
   widening in the region of the aortic knob
   .
   EKG:
   ST elevations in Anterolateral leads I, AVL, V2-V5. . Inferior ST
   depressions. Lots of ventricular ectopy .
   .
   Emergency TTE:
   No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. LV systolic
   function appears depressed, but not severely so. A catheter is present
   in the left ventriculoar cavity. There is no ventricular septal defect.
   The right ventricular cavity is dilated with severe global free wall
   hypokinesis. There is no pericardial effusion.
   .
   TEE:
   No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is moderately depressed (LVEF= 30 % with
   relative preservation of the lateral, inferolateral and inferior
   walls). The distal tip of the Impella device appears to be in good
   position at approximately 5 centimeters from the aortic root. There is
   no ventricular septal defect. with moderate global free wall
   hypokinesis. There are simple atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta
   to 40 centimeters from the incisors. No thoracic aortic dissection is
   seen. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) appear structurally normal with
   good leaflet excursion. The extent (if any) of aortic regurgitation
   cannot be characterized in the presence of an Impella device which
   crosses the aortic valve. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally
   normal. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. There is no pericardial
   effusion.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Moderately depressed left ventricular systolic function
   with relative preservation of the lateral, inferolateral, and inferior
   walls. Severe right ventricular hypokinesis. Appropriate positioning of
   an Impella device in the left ventricle.
   .
   CARDIAC CATH:
   Found to have occluded RCA and 80% LCX and Occluded LAD stent with
   thrombus, underwent PTCA and thrombectomy, restored slow flow with
   residual mild thrombus and no reflow despite adenosine.
   Assessment and Plan
   51 yo M with 3V CAD, s/p instent thrombosis of LAD, VF arrest.
   # CORONARIES: 3VD, s/p LAD in stent thrombosis. CEs prior to cath:
   CK258 MB17 MBI6.6 TropT0.07.
   - ASA, Plavix, statin
   - if except recovery, can discuss CABG given age and diffuse disease.
   - continue aggrastat for 6 hrs
   - consider heparin drip
   # PUMP:  EF ~30%. Impella, swan, aline in place.
   - Pressor support (Levophed and dopamine), avoiding dobutamine due to
   tachycardia/arrhythmia
   - Continue to uptitrate if necessary, with addition of vasopressin as
   next [**Doctor Last Name **].
   - monitor for volume given large volume diuresis, concern for
   hypotension, poor kidney perfusion.
   - IVF prn hypotension once forward flow improved.
   - ECHO Monday to assess effect of ischemia on function
   - consider Tandem heart if RV worsens
   - MV02 70%, CI 5 (3.5 of his own)
   - watching BP, tachycardia, UOP
   # RHYTHM: s/p V fib arrest, now loaded with Amio and Mg. Now sinus
   tachy, likely due to poor EF and acidosis.
   - Lidocaine gtt if break thought arrhythmias
   - consider BB for improved HR control and ectopy.
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   # HYPOXIA: Improved, initially thought to be severe pulm edema due to
   cardiogenic shock. Differential also included superimposed [**Doctor Last Name 76**] from
   aspiration, possible pulmonary hemorrhage or contusion in the setting
   very elevated wedge and multiple anticoagulants. Complicated by morbid
   obesity.
   - Hold aggressive diuresis with lasix drip. Given initial euvolemia
   expect pt to become hypovolemic quickly and may require returned IVF
   given impella and pressors improving forward flow.
   - For continued desaturation, can consider recruitment with short
   course of increased PEEP.
   - Vent settings with tidal volumes 8cc/kg
   - frequent ABGs
   - f/u pulm recs, appreciate input
   #  ACIDOSIS: Predominantly due to lactate accumulation and poor
   ventilation. Improving with Impella and pressors.
   - continue frequent ABGs
   - paralysis to improve ventilation
   - bicarb prn
   # MYDRIASIS: Likely secondary to atropine/paralysis.
   -Once respiratory and hemodyanamic status stabilized would obtain head

   #  LEUKOCYTOSIS: Likely stress reaction. No evidence of infection
   although high risk for aspiration.
   #  ACUTE RENAL INSUFFICIENCY: To be expected with arrest and poor
   forward flow. Also possible component of dye load (240ml omnipaque).
   - Monitor I/Os, IVF prn

   complicated by heart block requiring a pacemaker and PNA, ischemic
   cardiomyopathy (EF 35-40%) who presents after vfib arrest.  Per her
   nurse [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 714**] rehab, where she had been since her recent discharge,
   she was found slumped on the toilet at 9:30 p.m.  She did respond to
   caregivers and had a pulse at that time but lost it shortly
   thereafter.  The initial rhythm was noted to be vfib and she was
   shocked twice with return of spontaneous circulation.  By report,
   though not noted in the EMS paperwork, she again lost her pulse and was
   shocked an additional time and received a lidocaine bolus.  She was
   taken to an OSH where she was intubated and started on dopamine and
   transferred to the [**Hospital1 5**] ED.  A head CT in the ED showed no evidence of
   bleed.

   patient ingested anything.  She did not notice any confusion, but
   stated that she has been very weak and fatigued.
   .
   The patient was estimated to be down for approx 15 min prior to EMS
   arrival. There are some reports of bystander CPR but that is not
   confirmed. When EMS arrived the patient was pulseless and apneic and
   found to be in V Fib. She was shocked then asystolic and then developed
   PEA arrest. She was given Epi x4 and atropinex3 per ACLS and eventually
   regained pulse shortly after arrival to OSH ED. She was intubated in
   the field. At OSH ED, the patient had SBP to 70/palp. Patient had a Fem
   line placed. Preliminary report of Head CT & CT A/P from OSH were
   negative. She was started on 3 pressors and medflighted to [**Hospital1 5**].
   During transfer she received 2 unit of PRBCs.
   .
   In the ED, initial vs were: 102, 82/19, RR 34, 100% on vent. Pressors
   were increased to max dose. She was given Calcium gluconate 1 amp,
   NaHCO3 2 amps, and started on 1 L NaHCO3, thiamine 100mg IV, The ED was
   unable to place either a radial or a femoral arterial line for BP
   monitoring. Pressors were increased to Dopamine 20, levo 0.5 &
   vasopressin 1.2 drip. Pt was bronched in the ED for concern re:
   misplaced ET tube due to air leak. ET was found to be in right main
   stem and was properly positioned. Bloody secretions were noted in
   bronchi and trachea. In our ED, she was given 1 unit of PRBCs, 1 unit
   FFP & 1 unit Platelets. Her vitals prior to transfer to the floor were:
   102/69, 110, RR 21 at 100% on vent.
   .
   On the floor, patient is intubated, not sedated and not responsive to
   painful stimuli.

 .H/O ALCOHOL ABUSE
 ACIDOSIS, METABOLIC
   Assessment and Plan:  33 yo female presents after cardiac arrest of
   uncertain eitology.  The patient is  with hypotension, acute
   respiratory failure and multisystem organ failure.  The patient is
   critically ill and her prognosis is extremely poor.
   .
   #  Shock - hypovolemic s/p cardiac arrest. Initial rhythm noted by EMS
   was VFIB. Unclear cause of arrest.  CE, EKG & ECHO not consistent with
   MI.  I feel most likely cause of arrhythmia possibly secondary to
   electrolyte abnormalities or acidosis from toxic ingestion
   - levofed, dopa and vasopressin to keep MAP >65
   - stat ECHO
   - empiric vanco/zosyn for possible sepsis.
   - monitor labs for DIC, hemolysis.
   - arctic sun goal temp 34.
   .
   #  Respiratory failure - continue mechanical ventilation. With maximal
   support patient continues to be hypoxic at this time with high peak
   plateu pressures.  unable to place A line.
   - serial VBGs
   - sedation with fentanyl & midaz
   - t/c paralysis if pressures continue to be high.
   .
   #  Acute Renal Failure - Pt without any urine output since arrival to
   ICU.  Likely dense ATN due to prolonged hypoperfusions of kidneys.
   - renal consult appreciated
   - will place fem HD line & start urgent CVVH
   .
   #  Liver failure - Patient with large increase in LFTs since they were
   done at OSH.  Most likely acute on chronic.  Likely with some
   cirrohosis given EtOH abuse history.
   - trend LFTs coags.
   .
   #  Altered mental status - Patient's neurologic exam is concerning for
   anoxic brain injury.  Pt currently sedated on versed and fentanyl.
   - t/c neuro consult in am.
   .
   #  Lactic Acidosis - Patient with severe lactic acidosis which has not
   improved despite adequate resusciation and improved BP.  Seems out of
   proprotion to that expected from resusictation alone. Concern regarding
   occult ingestion. osmolar gap 16.
   - appreciate toxicology consult
   - VBG, lactate, ionized Ca Q2hrs
   .
   FEN: NPO
   .
   Prophylaxis: Hep SQ
   .
   Access: femoral line
   .
   Code: Full (discussed with family), chaplain consulted.
   .
   Communication: sister, brother and [**Name2 (NI) 10318**].
   .
   Disposition: ICU for now.

TITLE:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   resident for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with
   the note above, including the assessment and plan.  To that I would add
   the following:
   This is a 33 yo woman who was found down at home.  Bystander CPR
   performed, in v-tach on EMS arrival.  Shock x1 converted to PEA with
   eventual establishment of pulse.  Has required 3 pressors
 dopamine,
   levophed, vaspressin
 since event.  pH 6.8 and lactate > 20 at OSH
   ED.  LifeFlight transport to [**Hospital1 5**] ED.  Continued to require 3
   pressors.  HCO3 drip started.  Cooling initiated.  pH increased
   slightly to 7.0.  Transferred to ICU for further management.
   A/P:  Prognosis poor given prolonged shock.  Her degree of neurologic
   insult from this is not entirely clear but has the potential to be
   severe.  For now we will only plan to cool with target temp of 34-35
   given hemodynamic instability.  Continue current pressor management and
   bicarb gtt. Attempt to place a-line
 multiple attempt at fem a-line
   unsuccessful in ED.  Thiamine given in ED.  Will follow pH and lactate
   closely.  Will obtain echo.
   Pt is critically ill.  Time spent 60 min.

Chief Complaint:  Cardiorespiratory arrest.
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12604**] is a 70-year-old man with dyslipidemia, hypertension,
   diabetes, overweight, coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation,
   COPD, presenting after cardiorespiratory arrest at home.
   .
   Mr [**Known lastname 12604**] felt unwell yesterday, short of breath and out of sorts.
   This resolved somewhat, but today he again became even more short of
   breath before collapsing at home. His daughter was at home with him and
   began chest compressions after calling 911. AED pads were placed on him
   en route and it his rhythm was shocked, purportedly while in VF,
   although we cannot confirm. He then became asystolic, given
   epinephrine, atropine, defibrillated again twice, given amiodarone and
   intubated in the field. Went to [**Hospital3 519**], by which time he was
   in sinus rhythm with normal blood pressure. Significant labs from that
   admission include D-dimer in 2400s. Cooling commenced and he was
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for further management.
   .
   Upon arrival in the ED his HR was noted to be in the 80s, blood
   pressure in 140s/80s. Oxygen saturation was 98%. He was having
   irregular myoclonic jerks in the ED. Cooling was continued and he was
   sent to the cath. lab. In the cath. lab. his right dominant system
   revealed some diffuse, non-flow-limiting disease, that did not warrant
   intervention (see summary of cath findings below).
   .
   He was transferred to the CCU, already intubated and sedated. Vital
   signs on arrival were 94.8 F, 117 BPM, 142/85 mmHg, RR 21 and 100% O2

   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM ([**2119-4-4**]):
   The left atrium is dilated. The right atrium is moderately dilated. The
   left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is mild regional left
   ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior/inferolateral
   hypokinesis/akinesis. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with
   depressed free wall contractility with preservation of apical wall
   motion (consistent with [**Last Name (un) 3596**] sign; raises question of possible
   pulmonary embolus (or other cause of pulmonary hypertension or right
   ventricular dysfunction). The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly
   thickened. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation
   is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. No mitral
   regurgitation is seen. There is a small pericardial effusion.
   .
   ETT:
   None.
   .
   CARDIAC CATH ([**2119-4-4**]):
   1. Coronary angiography in this right-dominant system demonstrated
   two-vessel disease. The LMCA was short and had no angiographically
   apparent stenosis. The LAD had minimal disease. The LCx had serial
   stenoses, with the distal lesion appearing ulcerated. Neither were
   hemodynamically significant. The ramus intermedius had mild disease.
   The RCA was chronically occluded proximally and filled via left-to
   right collaterals.
   2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal systemic arterial blood
   pressure.
   ASSESSMENT
   .
   This 70-year-old man has had a witnessed cardiac arrest at home with
   CRP by his daughter at the scene. VF was noted in EMS. He was rapidly
   cooled, but his neurologic unresponsiveness and myoclonus is concerning
   for severe hypoxic injury. The etiology of this presentation is
   unclear.

   .
   Cardiorespiratory (VF?) Arrest
     Differential diagnosis includes arhythmia, pulmonary embolism,
   myocardial ischemia, perhaps resulting in arhythmia, toxic. CTA was
   negative on wet read, ischemia appears not to be profound, given
   enzymes and EKG, toxicity is possible. Arhythmia is possible,
   particularly if digoxin was being taken incorrectly, if too much
   methylphenidate was being taken (he was recorded as taking 20 mg).
   Given low level of digoxin (0.7) and history of non-compliance with
   glipizide dosing (per PCP), medication non-compliance or error is also
   possible. He takes three anti-arhythmic medications (atenolol,
   diltiazem and digoxin). Was likely VF arrest based on EMS report.

     Likely hypoxic injury given non-responsiveness and myoclonus.
   Difficult to determine outcome at present, particularly given sedation,

   examination shows no reflex activity whatever. Myoclonus can sometimes

Chief Complaint:  unresponsive s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI:
   73M with h/o severe cardiomyopathy (EF [**9-19**]) s/p biV/ICD ([**2115**]),  afib
   on coumadin and dig, rheumatic heart disease s/p mitral valve repair in
   [**2109**] with residual 3+ MR, CRI, h/o CVA, who was found unresponsive on
   park bench s/p cardiac arrest and loss of pulse during EMS transport on
   way to [**Hospital1 5**] ED.
   .
   Complex story pieced together with family report, ED records, OMR, and
   info from ICD interrogation. Per OMR note, patient had increasing LE
   edema since 6 days PTA, called Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] and was told to restart lasix
   20mg [**Hospital1 **]. Per family report, patient had not been feeling well for 2
   days PTA with fatigue, vague symptoms. On AM of admission, pt had ICD
   firing for sensed VT at 11am with LOC prior to shock, with  episode of
   incontinence. Pt called Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] at 2pm who thought that patient may
   be hypokalemic, told to take 40meq KCL with planned f/u in [**Hospital 2509**]
   clinic. Patient then went to park to meet friends with possible
   marijuana use (?laced with cocaine) and was found unresponsive on park
   bench for unknown amt of time and EMS called.
   .
   No EMS records, but per ED report, pt had loss of pulse in transport,
   was given seconds of chest compressions, and on arrival in ED at
   5:20pm, was in pulseless wide complex tachycardia concerning for
   polymorphic VT. CPR commenced and pt given epi 1mg x 1, atropine 1mg x
   1, and intubated (initial gas 7/16/32/189), femoral line placed. During
   course in ED, patient went in and out of pulseless VT/WCT (loss of
   pulse for minutes at a time) requiring intermittent shocks by ICD (x 5
   shocks per ICD interrogation between 4:46pm and 5:39pm), external
   defibrillation, and medications (amiodarone, epi, vasopressin,
   atropine). When regained pulse, pt hypotensive (SBP 36-67/26-29) so pt
   started on Neosynephrine and Levophed. Labs significant for INR 4.4,
   Hct 28.2, Cr 1.2, K 2.8. Given 30mg IV KCL, 2mg Mag sulfate, and given
   Hct drop from b/l of 32-35, sent for CT head for concern of bleed in
   setting of elevated INR. Wet read of CT head with no bleed, mass
   effect, or shift. Also given 4amps of Digibind after labs drawn.
   Patient lost pulse while down at CT scan, required one round of
   epi/atropine/CPR and regained pulse after 3 min, and was sent up to CCU
   directly on Neosynephrine at 4.8 and Levophed at 2.6.
   .
   On arrival to CCU, patient was intubated, sedated with fentanyl and
   versed. Met with family for update, identification, and confirmed full
   code. Overnight, Arctic sun cooling protocol initiated, reached goal
   temperature at 8:30pm. Started on dopamine, levophed and neosynephrine
   weaned off. ICD interrogated showing 6 episodes of ATP/shock for sensed
   VT/VF. Bedside ECHO done showing no large change from prior. ECG showed
   v-pacing and resolution of global WCT in limb leads, continued to have
   ACT in precordial leads with changed morphology from old ECG. Repeat
   ABG was 7/22/45/70, PEEP increased to 10. Cr increased from 1.2-> 1.9,
   INR decreased to 3.3, K was 5, lactate was 5.6. Given 20mg IV lasix
   with no response, then 40mg IV x 1 for volume overload by exam, CXR and
   no urine output. Cardiac arrest team notified, patient enrolled in IV
   steroid clinical trial with family consent.
   .
   Unable to obtain review of systems as patient unresponsive. Per OMR,
   patient with recent increase in LE edema.

   Assessment and Plan
   73M with h/o severe cardiomyopathy (EF [**9-19**]) s/p biV/ICD ([**2115**]),  afib
   on coumadin and dig, rheumatic heart disease s/p mitral valve repair in
   [**2109**] with residual 3+ MR, CRI, h/o CVA who was found unreponsive and
   s/p cardiac arrest from unknown etiology with multiple rounds of ICD
   firing and ACLS/CPR now on cooling protocol and pressor support.
   .
   # s/p CARDIAC ARREST: Unclear precipitant, but etiologies of arrhythmia
   include electrolyte abnomalities such as hypokalemia, BiV/ICD
   anti-tachycardia pacing (ATP) inducing wide complex tachycardia for
   sensed atrial tachycardia, or arrythmia in setting of dig toxicity or
   possible cocaine use. Likely multifactorial as hypokalemia lowers
   threshold for arrythmias, predisposes to dig toxicity. By overnight ICD
   interrogation, patient had 6 episodes of ineffective ATP leading to
   shock with one episode at 11am, and one at 4:46pm which may correlate
   with patient's episodes of unresponsiveness. Initial lytes showed
   hypokalemia, acidemia. Utox for cocaine and dig level pending. No
   evidence of ACS as etiology. Patient s/p multiple episodes of loss of
   pulse with wide complex tachycardia, so started on cooling protocol
   overnight. Family aware of critical status.
   - Cardiac arrest team and Neuro EEG ICU team aware and will be
   following patient, appreciate recs
   - formal EP consult in AM
   - bedside ECHO overnight showed same as prior (mod to severe MR, global
   HK, EF 15%, mod TR, pleural effusion, no pericardial effusion), f/u
   final read
   - Continue cooling protocol with time of goal temperature reached at
   8:30pm. Cool for 18-24hrs, then rewarm slowly), then after patient
   warmed do thorough neuro exam to assess residual functional status
   - Q4hr lytes on cooling protocol, including coags (next at 2am, 6am)
   and closely follow K
   - order for continuous EEG monitor, neuro will be following
   - f/u Utox screen, dig level - hold digoxin in meantime
   - f/u CT head final read
   - continue pressors to keep MAP>55, wean down as tolerated (Wean down
   Neo first, then Dopamine)
   - defibrillator pads in place
   - patient on IV steroid clinical trial per protocol
   .
   # RHYTHM/WIDE COMPLEX TACHYCARDIA: Patient's ECGs showing irregular
   wide complex tachycardia concerning for polymorphic VT with possible
   positive concordance, which went in/out of pulseless VT/VF requiring
   shocks/ACLS/CPR for regaining of pulse. Unclear what rhythm patient in
   when pacer initiated ATP/shock and whether was appropriate. Currently
   patient with pulse, on pressor support. Patient's baseline rhythm was
   afib with ventricular pacing, BiV/ICD in place. On coumadin and digoxin
   at baseline. Recent INR was therapeutic, unclear compliance with
   medications.
   - monitor on telemetry
   - EP consult in AM
   - IV amio bolus prn return to fast VT
   - follow lytes closely, aggressively replete K, Mg
   - follow INR, hold coumadin as supratherapeutic and pts become
   coagulopathic on cooling protocol
   - hold digoxin pending dig level, hold carvedilol while patient on
   pressor support
   .
   # PUMP/DECOMPENSATED SYSTOLIC CHF: Patient with known severe
   cardiomyopathy from valvular dz/NYHA IV sCHF with EF 10-15%. Followed
   by Dr [**First Name (STitle) **] in heart failure clinic. Recent OMR notes indicate increase
   in LE edema suggesting decompensated heart failure with plan for
   increase in lasix, but unclear if patient had been taking this. By
   exam, patient appears hypervolemic with elevated JVD, effusion on CXR,
   and LE edema. BNP pending. Given 20mg IV lasix overnight.
   - f/u ECHO report
   - f/u BNP
   - IV lasix diuresis as above with goal to achieve UOP with careful
   repletion of lytes
   - holding digoxin and carvedilol for now
   .
   # CORONARIES: No known CAD or risk factors. Clean coronaries on last
   cath [**2114**]. No h/o chest pain, no indication of ACS as cause of cardiac
   arrest at this time.
   - cycle enyzmes
   - follow ECGs
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Patient intubated in setting of unresponsiveness
   and cardiac arrest. No known pulmonary history, but may be component of
   fluid overload from decompensated heart failure.
   - continue intubated for now, adjust vent settings to improve
   oxygenation
   - follow ABGs, and if INR continues to normalize, consider a-line
   placement in AM
   - diuresis with IV lasix as above
   .
   # METABOLIC ACIDOSIS: Patient initial ABG of 7.16/32/189 showed triple
   acid base disorder of primary AG metabolic acidosis likely [**1-8**] lactic
   acidosis and acute renal failure, with concomitant non gap metabolic
   acidosis and respiratory acidosis (from
   hypoventilation/unresponsiveness). Slightly improved after intubation,
   possible fluids in ED. Initial lactate 5.6, Cr up from 1.2-> 1.9
   overnight.
   - follow ABGs, adjust ventilator settings, follow lactate/renal
   function. Hold on additional fluids for now given low EF, but replete
   lytes
   .
   # ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: Cr increased to 1.9 from baseline of
   1.2-1.6. Likely in setting of poor forward flow during cardiac arrest
   in patient with low EF
   - follow Cr
   - renally dose meds
   - monitor UOP
   - send Ulytes if does not continue to improve.
   .

   # s/p CARDIAC ARREST: Unclear precipitant, but etiologies of arrhythmia
   include electrolyte abnomalities such as hypokalemia, BiV/ICD
   anti-tachycardia pacing (ATP) inducing wide complex tachycardia for

   possible cocaine use. Likely multifactorial as hypokalemia lowers
   threshold for arrythmias, predisposes to dig toxicity. By overnight ICD
   interrogation, patient had 6 episodes of ineffective ATP leading to
   shock with one episode at 11am, and one at 4:46pm which may correlate
   with patient's episodes of unresponsiveness. Initial lytes showed
   hypokalemia, acidemia. Utox for cocaine and dig level pending. No
   evidence of ACS as etiology. Patient s/p multiple episodes of loss of
   pulse with wide complex tachycardia, so started on cooling protocol
   overnight. Family aware of critical status.  He did not have goot urine
   output overnight, and therefore he likely needs inotropes in order to
   increase contractility and cardiac output in order to accurately
   diurese with Lasix.
   - will keep K>5.0 in order to prevent arrhythmias (about 80mEq of K
   today as long as creatinine stable or less, will check 10am)
   - start Milrinone gtt to act as inotrope (and stop dopamine when start
   milrinone)
   - add neosynephrine as needed to support blood pressure
   - when milrinone/neo have taken effect, start Lasix gtt in order to
   diurese

TITLE:
   Cardiac Arrest Consult service Note:
   73 year old male with baseline severe cardiomyopathy (EF 10-15%) who
   suffered cardiac arrest with underlying etiology possibly related to
   hypokalemia with underlying poor substrate.  He was initially very
   hemodynamically unstable in the ED with multiple re-arrests which had
   improved somewhat on admission to CCU though still very
   vasopressor-dependent.  We had initially advised holding off aggressive
   cooling in ED because of recurrent arrests and to begin when patient
   reaches a stable steady state (ie., no re-arrests for 30 minute
   interval or so)
 thus, cooling began with Artic sun in the CCU though
   patient baseline post-arrest temperature was cool so effectively has
   been hypothermic since admission.  At this point, he is on the induced
   hypothermia and continuous EEG pathway.  His vasopressor dependence is
   improving and he is on inotropic support.  He has been entered into the
   post-arrest shock steroids vs. placebo research protocol.
   A: Post-cardiac arrest likely secondary hypokalemia with baseline
   cardiomyopathy
   Plan:
   1)       Neuroprotective Strategies
   a.       Continue cooling for 24 hours and then begin re-warming
   monitor for electrolyte shifts particularly in re-warming phase.  Given
   that the initial suspected reason for arrest in this case was related
   to K+, particular attention should be given to close monitoring during
   re-warming.
   b.       If patient bleeds significantly during cooling protocol would
   re-warm to low-normal temperature (36 degrees)
 should be ok to cool
   with coagulopathy but just monitor coags as you are doing
   c.        Continuous EEG pathway
 neuron/EEG team following
 will
   treat seizure aggressively if present
   d.       Minimize intra-cranial hypertension through simple means
   including elevation of the head of bead and maintenance of normocarbia
   (pCO2 35-40 mmHg) if possible
   e.       Avoid hyperglycemia
   2)       Hemodynamic Support
   a.       Patient receiving pressors and inotropes
   b.       Note that patient is in the post-arrest shock steroid study
   with the endpoint being resolution of vasopressor-dependence.  He will
   receive study drug (hydrocortisone 100 mg) or placebo every 8 hours
   until 24 hours post resolution of vasopressor-dependence.  Note that
   inotropic support (ie., milrinone) is not considered a vasopressor and
   does not effect study protocol.
   3)       Underlying Etiology
   a.       Primary service and EP addressing underlying etiology of
   arrest
   Thank you for this consult and please contact me anytime by pager
   ([**Numeric Identifier 7786**]) if there are any questions regarding post-arrest pathway or
   study protocol.
   Time: 30 minutes

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD, anoxic brain injury after
   asystolic cardiac arrest, currently ventilator dependent, presents from
   [**Hospital3 **] with bradycardia, hypotension and hyperkalemia.
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt was initially hypotensive in the ED with BP of
   70/30's.  Pt with known systolic CHF, with EF ~ 30%.  However, BP
   improved after receiving atropine and treatment for his hyperkalemia
   while in the ED up to 120's. BP on arrival to CCU 92/43, HR 53.  Pt is
   s/p ~3L IVF in ED.  Possible that hypotension is related to
   distributive shock physiology given fever in ED, or related to on-going
   bradycardia/junctional rhythm.
   - Hold Carvedilol
   - Hold Lasix
   - Goal MAP >55
   .
   # Bradycardia:  The patient was noted to be bradycardic in the ED tp
   the 40's on arrival.  12-lead EKG showed slow atrial fib vs. a
   junctional rhythm, however his bradycardia improved after treatment of
   his hyperkalemia.  The etiology of this patient's bradycardia is likely
   related to his metabolic derangements in the setting of conduction
   system disease, or an active infection as the patient did spike a fever
   to 102 on arrival.  A temporary pacer was considered but felt to be not
   ideal for this patient at this time given his fevers and likely
   infection.
   - Hold Carvedilol for now
   - EP consult in AM to evaluate for possible PPM placement
   - Pacer pads in place as needed
   - Atropine prn
   .
   # Fevers: Up to 102 in ED. Lactate of 2.3.  UA with mod leuks, several
   WBCs, and many bacteria, with possible source of infection being
   urine.  CXR on [**4-30**] at [**Hospital3 **] suspicious for LLL infiltrate
   and patient was started on Vanc 1gm IV daily on [**5-1**] for MRSA positive
   sputum.
   - Continue empiric ABx coverage for now with Vanc/Zosyn until better
   idea of source given hypotension in ED
   - f/u CXR
   - f/u Blood, Urine cultures
   - pt with no indwelling lines on admission; dirty fem line placed in ED
   to be pulled
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: s/p Kayexalate, IVF and calcium gluconate in ED. Repeat
   K still 5.5, treat as needed w/Kayexalate and insulin, d50, and calcium
   gluconate. Elevated K+ may be related to rising creatnine and worsening
   renal function.
   - f/u K+
   - Kayexalate PRN
   .
   # Type II Resp Failure: Patient is ventilatory dependent, likely due to
   his poor neurologic status. Tracheostomy in place, and patient
   comfortable on CIMV.
   - Continue vent
   - Wean O2 to 40% if possible today
   .
   # CKD: Cr 2.3 on admission within range of prior renal function.
   However, pt with rising Cr (was 1.0 at [**Hospital3 **] several days
   ago), and although Cr within range of previous Creatinines here, pt may
   be in ARF.  BUN noted to be elevated to 160 on admission labs, elevated
   out of proportion to Creatinine.
   - monitor Cr after IVF
   - renally dose meds

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD, anoxic brain injury after
   asystolic cardiac arrest, currently ventilator dependent, presents from
   [**Hospital3 **] with bradycardia, hypotension and hyperkalemia.
   .
   # Bacteremia: Possible etiologies include lungs vs GI vs GU. [**Month (only) 51**] have
   transient cholangitis given elevated Alk phos and bili. No e/o acute
   cholecystitis on liver u/s though could be acaclulous chole.
   - cont Zosyn
   - DC vanc (initially started at rehab for PNA)
   - follow cx data
   - follow fever curves
   .
   # Hypotension: Required fluid bolus overnight. Likely hypotension
   related to infection.
   - Hold Carvedilol
   - Hold Lasix given infected
   - Goal MAP >55
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Possible this is related to transient cholangitis vs
   hepatic congestion vs shock liver. ABX as per above.
   -cont ABX as per above
   - f/u final liver u/s results
   - cont to trend LFTs
   .
   # Bradycardia:  Sinus bradycardia. HR stable in 50
   - Hold Carvedilol for now
   - Pacer pads in place as needed
   - Atropine prn
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Likely [**1-2**] renal dysfunction. K currently stable.
   - f/u K+
   - Kayexalate PRN
   .
   # Type II Resp Failure: Patient is ventilatory dependent, likely due to
   his poor neurologic status. Tracheostomy in place, and patient
   comfortable on CIMV.
   - Continue vent
   - Wean O2 to 40% if possible
   .
   # CKD: No e/o obstruction on renal u/s.  Most likely ATN [**1-2**]
   hypotension and subsequent ischemia.
   - f/u urine lytes and eos
   - monitor Cr after IVF
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Supratherapeutic INR:  INR trending down, now 3.6.
   - Hold coumadin and plan to restart tomorrow
   - FFP if more signs of active bleeding, though not ideal given
   patient's history of CHF and AVR
   - Follow INR closely with goal 2.5-3.5
   .
   # Hematuria: Likely traumatic foley placement in setting of elev INR
   given history of difficult foley placement in the past. Cont to pass
   clots.
   - [**Month/Day (2) 227**] if hematuria continues
   - Reversal of supratherapeutic INR as above
   .
   # CAD: Troponin 0.15 in ED, CK-MB 3. EKG with no ischemic changes.
   - Trend cardiac enzymes
   .
   # Seizure Disorder: Patient previously on Keppra but no longer on
   anti-epileptic medication while at [**Hospital1 997**].
   - Monitor off anti-epileptics
   .

TITLE: Cardiology fellow addendum to house officer admission note
   Mr. [**Known lastname 2262**] is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, h/o aortic valve replacement (St.
   [**Male First Name (un) **]), PAD s/p bypass surgery and recurrent LE ulcers who was admitted
   to the [**Hospital1 **] following a cardiac arrest at home in [**2108-2-29**].  He was
   discharged to a nursing home with trach/peg and with minimal
   repsonsiveness at baseline.  He was sent to the ER today for
   hypotension and bradycardia.  In the ED, EKGs showed slow atrial
   fibrillation and junctional bradycardia.  He was initially hypotensive
   with BP down to 70 systolic.  He received treated for hyperkalemia
   (Calcium, insulin/d50) and his blood pressure improved, as did his
   heart rate.  In the ED, he was also found to have a fever to 101/102.
   PE: BP 126/71, HR 64, on ventilator, og tube draining tube feed like
   material
   unresponsive, eyes roving from left to right
   RRR, S1, S2, no mrg appreciated (difficult to hear over vent sound)
   abdomen soft, nt, nd
   ext: 1+ edema, warm
   labs: notable for K 5.9, lactate 2.3, bun 160, cr 2.3, trop 0.15, ck
   33, mb 3, inr 5.6, +u/a
   most recent ekg: appears to be sinus rhythm, rate 64 (very low
   amplitude p waves, so cannot be sure this is sinus vs a junctional
   rhythm)
   A/P: 91M with recent cardiac arrest, trach/peg dependent at baseline,
   unresponsive at baseline who presents with slow af/junctional rhythm,
   hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities and fever.
   1. slow afib/junctional rhythm: Likely secondary to electrolyte
   abnormalities in patient with likely underlying conduction system
   disease.  Unclear reason for hyperkalemia- cr 2.3, but at baseline.
   Will discontinue any hyperk inducing medications (?ace inhibitor,
   spironolactone).  Temporary pacer wire not indicated at this time.  EP
   evaluation for possible pacemaker once infectious issues are resolved.
   IF becomes bradycardic and hypotensive, would first start dopamine for
   chronotropy/inotropy.
   2. Fever:  Patient with positive urinalysis.  Would treat empirically
   for UTI/sepsis and send blood and urine cultures, follow up chest xray.
   Check lipase, lfts. Repeat CXR.
   3. Family unable to be reached from ED. Will continue to try and
   contact them to update.

   ECHO
   The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
   are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-30 %)
   secondary to extensive akinesis involving the apex and anterior septum;
   there is severe hypkinesis of the anterior free wall, inferior septum,
   and inferior free wall. The basal half of the posterior and lateral
   walls contracts normally. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased
   left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular
   chamber size is normal. with depressed free wall contractility. The
   aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. A bileaflet aortic
   valve prosthesis is present. The aortic valve prosthesis appears well
   seated, with normal leaflet/disc motion and transvalvular gradients.
   Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to
   acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is no pericardial effusion.
   Impression: extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct of unknown
   acuity; inferior hypokinesis; findings consistent with multivessel
   obstructive coronary [**Last Name (un) **] disease
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   - cte ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - try to ween propofol to better assess brain/seizure activity and f/u
   neuro recs today
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support was briefly necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   # Possible Cardiogenic shock: Has edema and uop now down to almost zero
   - BPs stable and appearts fluid overloaded on exam so will try lasix
   today to increase uop (bolus X 1) follow UOP today
   #
twitching
 movements noted with weaning sedation: concern for

   The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
   are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-30 %)
   secondary to extensive akinesis involving the apex and anterior septum;
   there is severe hypkinesis of the anterior free wall, inferior septum,
   and inferior free wall. The basal half of the posterior and lateral
   walls contracts normally. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased

   chamber size is normal. with depressed free wall contractility. The
   aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. A bileaflet aortic
   valve prosthesis is present. The aortic valve prosthesis appears well
   seated, with normal leaflet/disc motion and transvalvular gradients.
   Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to
   acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   - cte ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - try to ween propofol to better assess brain/seizure activity and f/u
   neuro recs today
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support was briefly necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   # Possible Cardiogenic shock: Has edema and uop now down to almost zero
   - BPs stable and appearts fluid overloaded on exam so will try lasix
   today to increase uop (bolus X 1) follow UOP today
   #

   while in the ED up to 120's. BP on arrival to CCU 92/43, HR 53.  Pt is

TITLE: Cardiology fellow addendum to house officer admission note
   Mr. [**Known lastname 2262**] is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, h/o aortic valve replacement (St.
   [**Male First Name (un) **]), PAD s/p bypass surgery and recurrent LE ulcers who was admitted
   to the [**Hospital1 **] following a cardiac arrest at home in [**2108-2-29**].  He was
   discharged to a nursing home with trach/peg and with minimal
   repsonsiveness at baseline.  He was sent to the ER today for
   hypotension and bradycardia.  In the ED, EKGs showed slow atrial
   fibrillation and junctional bradycardia.  He was initially hypotensive
   with BP down to 70 systolic.  He received treated for hyperkalemia
   (Calcium, insulin/d50) and his blood pressure improved, as did his
   heart rate.  In the ED, he was also found to have a fever to 101/102.
   PE: BP 126/71, HR 64, on ventilator, og tube draining tube feed like
   material
   unresponsive, eyes roving from left to right
   RRR, S1, S2, no mrg appreciated (difficult to hear over vent sound)
   abdomen soft, nt, nd
   ext: 1+ edema, warm
   labs: notable for K 5.9, lactate 2.3, bun 160, cr 2.3, trop 0.15, ck
   33, mb 3, inr 5.6, +u/a
   most recent ekg: appears to be sinus rhythm, rate 64 (very low
   amplitude p waves, so cannot be sure this is sinus vs a junctional
   rhythm)
   A/P: 91M with recent cardiac arrest, trach/peg dependent at baseline,
   unresponsive at baseline who presents with slow af/junctional rhythm,
   hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities and fever.
   1. slow afib/junctional rhythm: Likely secondary to electrolyte
   abnormalities in patient with likely underlying conduction system
   disease.  Unclear reason for hyperkalemia- cr 2.3, but at baseline.
   Will discontinue any hyperk inducing medications (?ace inhibitor,
   spironolactone).  Temporary pacer wire not indicated at this time.  EP
   evaluation for possible pacemaker once infectious issues are resolved.
   IF becomes bradycardic and hypotensive, would first start dopamine for
   chronotropy/inotropy.
   2. Fever:  Patient with positive urinalysis.  Would treat empirically
   for UTI/sepsis and send blood and urine cultures, follow up chest xray.
   Check lipase, lfts. Repeat CXR.
   3. Family unable to be reached from ED. Will continue to try and
   contact them to update.

   Assessment and Plan
 63-year-old woman with history of atrial fibrillation/flutter
   presented after v-fib arrest.
   .
   # Cardiac arrest: unclear precipitant for initial v-fib. Might have
   been atrial arrhythmias degenerating into v-fib, or a pulmonary process
   (aspiration; no evidence of PE) leading to cardiac arrest. No evidence
   of ischemia. Now intubated. Rhythm now in sinus.  CT head negative for
   acute process.  EEG showed seizure activity/burst suppression pattern
   requiring propofol to suppress.
   - Artic Sun protocol, then re-warm today
   - Continue ventilatory support; ABG this morning
   - 48h continous EEG
   - HOB > 30
   - f/u chest CTA final read
   .
   # ?Aspiration PNA vs. Pneumonitis:  CT chest showed LUL and LLL
   findings consistent with atelectasis vs. PNA, also with leukocytosis
   and unable to be maintained at 34C yesterday without continual decrease
   of water temp for arctic sun.  Received one dose of Vanc/Zosyn, then
   switched to Levo/Flagyl to cover for aspiration PNA.
   - Continue Levo/Flagyl
   - f/u Sputum cx, Bcx
   - f/u final read Chest CT
   .
   # CORONARIES: no evidence of ischemia on ECG. Elevated trop and CK most
   likely from cardiac arrest and CPR. S/p RCA DES in [**2161-7-22**].
   - telemetry
   - continue ASA, clopidogrel
   .
   # PUMP: BP stable with SBP in 120s-150s. EF >55% in [**2161-7-22**].  Consider
   possible TTE in the future.
   - monitor BP
   .
   # RHYTHM: h/o afib, now in sinus. Was initially in vfib then asystole.
   Unclear precipitant.
   - continue warfarin
   - telemetry
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:   Continue levothyroxine
   .

s note.  She remains

   Addendum to Physical Examination:  Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **]
s Note.
   Medical Decision Making.  Mrs. [**Known lastname 8754**] is 53 year old woman with a
   prior AFib with RVR (simulating ventricular tachycardia) in [**2161-7-22**]
   which was treated with a CYPHER DES.   She also had a large ASD with
   significant left to right shunt.   She underwent as is an atrial
   flutter ablation but was pending for a atrial fibrillation ablation
   after 3-6 months of dual antiplatelet therapy for her DES.    She had a
   witnessed cardiac arrest yesterday with ultimately responded to CPR
   although there was question of cerebral anoxia.   Her EKG showed stable
   changes without evidence of stent thrombosis.
   She was cooled for > 18 hours and has not been rewarmed without return
   of cerebral function to date.  She is off pressors and hemodynamically
   stable. We will continue supportive care for her cerebral injury.
   The total time for this visit was 40 minutes and over 50% of the time
   was spent coordinating care.

Date of service: [**2161-11-5**]
   Initial visit, Cardiology service: CCU
   Presenting complaint: Arrhythmia
   History of present illness: 53-year-old woman with history of atrial
   fibrillation presented after having v-fib arrest. At her nursing home
   this morning she was found down. EMS was called, finding her to be in
   v-fib. She received shocks x 3, 6 mg total of epinephrine, 300 mg
   loading dose of amiodarone then drip. Intubated in the field. She was
   transported to [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], where she was given 1 unit of pRBCs. Guaiac
   reportedly negative. Got a total of 2.5 L of NS. Started on Artic Sun
   before med flight to [**Hospital1 1**].
   .
   On arrival to the [**Hospital1 1**] ED, she was found cold with 8mm fixed pupils
   bilaterally and no response to stimuli. SBP was in the 140s-160s
   without pressor, HR 50s-60s. ECG showed... She got a head CT and chest
   CTA. Transferred to CCU for further management.
   .
   Of note, patient was admitted to [**Hospital1 1**] from [**2161-8-12**] to [**2161-8-17**] for
   syncope and runs of VT. Prior to this admission, OSH ETT had shown
   possible mild basal inferior ischemia vs. attenuation artifact with
   overall normal systolic function. She underwent cardiac
   catheterization, which showed a 90% distal RCA stenosis, and a DES was
   placed in the RCA. TTE and TEE showed a large (21 mm) secundum atrial
   septal defect with LVEF>55%. Review of her strip rhythm suggested that
   her arrhythmia may be atrial in origin rather than ventricular
   tachycardia. For that reason, she underwent an EP study on [**2161-8-14**],
   which included ventricular stimulation as well as assessment for atrial
   arrhythmias.  She was found to have inducible atrial flutter, that was
   typical counter clockwise flutter and she had a successful isthmus
   ablation. She had no sustained ventricular tachycardia with ventricular
   stimulation protocol. She was evaluated by the cardiac surgeons as well
   as the interventional cardiologists for percutaneous surgical closure
   of her large secundum ASD, and it was deemed that this should be done
   as an outpatient. In addition, with her history of significant atrial
   arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation, it was thought that a pulmonary

 course and caliber, with scattered atherosclerotic calcifications.

 pulmonary arteries, to suggest pulmonary embolism.  No significant
 mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy detected.

 posterior aspects of the right and left upper lobes and the posterior basal
 segment of the left lower lobe, secondary to aspiration. There is
 isoattenuating material noted in the left main bronchus, related to aspirated
 secretions. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

 involving the anterior left second,third,fourth,fifth and sixth ribs, of which
 3,5 and 6 are displaced fractures. Undisplaced rib fractures are noted in the
 anterior right second, third, fourth and fifth ribs.  The nasogastric tube is
 seen terminating in the proximal stomach.  The endotracheal tube is in good
 position.

 Visualized portion of the liver, spleen, in the non-contrast study appears
 unremarkable.

 1.  No acute pulmonary embolism or acute thoracic aortic pathology detected.

   [**2148-11-29**] ECHO:
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is moderately
   dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left
   ventricular cavity size is borderline dilated. There is severe regional
   left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior and inferolateral
   akinesis. There is moderate to severe hypokinesis of the remaining
   segments (LVEF <20%). The estimated cardiac index is depressed
   (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle.
   The right ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with severe global
   free wall hypokinesis. There is abnormal diastolic septal
   motion/position consistent with right ventricular volume overload, as
   well as a conduction abnormality or RV apical pacing. The aortic valve
   leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and
   no aortic stenosis. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation
   is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is at
   least mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, athough this may be
   underestimated given severity of TR. There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Dilated left ventricle with severe regional and global
   systolic dysfunction, c/w prior extensive inferior myocardial
   infarction and a superimposed process (or multivessel CAD). Markedly
   dilated right ventricle with severe global systolic dysfunction. Mild
   aortic regurgitation. Moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.
   Depressed cardiac index and at least mild pulmonary hypertension.
   CXR: ETT balloon hyperinflated. Low lung volumes, with possible mild
   vascular congestion. Moderate cardiomegaly.
   CT head: No acute intracranial abnormality. No intracranial hemorrhage
   or loss of [**Doctor Last Name **]-white matter differentiation.
   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo M with PMH significant for CHF (EF: 20-25%), CAD s/p CABG, CKD,
   a-fib on coumadin, s/p ICD, presents after VF arrest.
   .
   #. VF Arrest: Pt reportly found in VF arrest with ROSC after 2 shocks
   by EMS. On ECG rhythm shows likely sinus tach with LBBB. Unclear as to
   whether patient was actually in VF arrest given no rhythm strips with
   records. The patient reportly has had episodes of VT in the past and is
   on Mexiletine. He also has a AICD that did not fire per report. The
   patient was started on lidocaine gtt and cooling was initiated.  Likely
   arrhythmia in the setting of severe cardiomyopathy (likely ischemic)
   given history. Unlikely ACS given ECG and prior cath 3 months prior.
   CE mildly elevated, but likely combination of demand and and CKD.
   - initiate cooling protocol
   - sedation with fentanyl and versed
   - EEG in AM per protocol
   - cont lidocaine gtt for now, holding home mexiletine
   - EP to interrogate pacer in AM
   - ECG in AM
   - TTE in AM
   - cont to trend enzymes
   - monitor neuro status
   - holding coumadin for a-fib
   - cont home amio
   - f/u head CT
   -
   # CORONARIES: Pt with CABG and recent cath 3 months prior that showed
   occluded grafts, but no intervention per wife. ECG shows LBBB, no old
   to compare. CE elevated with Trop 0.16 and CK 521, MB: 13. Given
   patient's comorbidities including severe CHF, CKD and poor functional
   status and recent cath the patient would likely benefit from medical
   management at this time.
   - trend enzymes
   - ASA 325mg and lipitor 20mg (hold high dose given LFT abnormality)
   - will need to obtain OSH records
   - ECG
   - monitor tele
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   .
   # PUMP: Pt with severe CHF. Patient appears to be overloaded on exam.
   Although JVP difficult to assess. Pt with lower ext edema evidence of
   pulm edema on CXR.
   - consider swan placement and/or milrinone to improve CO
   - TTE in AM
   - holding BB and ACEI given hypotension
   - will hold on diuresis given hypotension, but consider lasix if
   pressures tolerate
   - obtain outside records
   .
   #. Resp Distress: Pt was intubated for airway protection in the setting
   of VF arrest. Patient likely volume overloaded from CHF and pulm edema
   on CXR.
   - ABG after placement of a-line
   - sedation
   - avoid hypercapnia given cooling protocol
   - will adjust vent setting pending ABG
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely cardiogenic shock in the setting of VF arrest and

   arrhythmia in the setting of severe cardiomyopathy (likely ischemic)
   given history. Unlikely ACS given ECG and prior cath 3 months prior.
   CE mildly elevated, but likely combination of demand and and CKD.

 Optiray 350  contrast material.  Multiplanar reformatted images were obtained
 and reviewed.

 CTA CHEST:  No filling defects are identified within the pulmonary arteries to
 suggest acute pulmonary embolism.  No dissection flap is present within the
 thoracic aorta.  The ascending aorta is dilated to 4.5 cm. There are bibasilar
 consolidations, which are moderate consistent with aspiration versus
 pneumonia.  No pulmonary masses are identified.  Endotracheal tube is well
 positioned approximately 4 cm from the carina.  NG tube courses through the
 esophagus with tip and side port terminating within the stomach.

 There is cardiomegaly and evidence of prior coronary artery bypass grafting
 with median sternotomy wires intact.  Three-vessel coronary artery
 calcifications are present.  There is calcification of the aortic valve.
 Incidental note is made of duplicated IVC with the left-sided IVC emptying
 into a dilated coronary sinus.  A right-sided pacemaker is present with leads
 terminating in the expected right atrium and right ventricle.  No pericardial
 effusion is present.

 Incidental note is made of a small amount of fluid surrounding the
 endotracheal tube proximally (series 3:  image 3).

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are identified.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  No pulmonary embolism or thoracic aortic dissection.

 2.  Small-to-moderate bibasilar consolidation with aspiration favored over
 pneumonia.

CCU Death Note:
   Pt has been at home, getting weaker. He passed out at home after c/o of
   a HA. He went to OSH where CT showed intracranial hemorrage. He
   developed R pnuemonthorax when central line was attempted and chest
   tube was inserted. He was intubated through old tracheostomy  site and
   placed on a ventilator. A triple lumen was then inserted in R groin. He
   was transfered to [**Hospital1 19**] EW. Here he remained unresponsive to all
   stimuli. His hematocrit was 17.9, WBCs 50 and platelet 35. He received
   manntal and was satarted on neosynephrine for hypotension. He had blood
   coming out of his CT and brown liquid from his NG tube.  His son and
   daughter arrived and stated he would become CMO once the rest of the
   family arrived. He would not receive CPR or further medication to
   prolong his life.  He was seen by and anointed by the priest in EW.
   CCU COURSE: Pt arrive in CCU ~0830 on neosynephrine  at .6mic/kilo on
   CPAP 10/5. He was accompanied by 3 of his children. HR was in low 100s
   with bp in low 100s to 1-teens. He was unresponsive, but breathing and
   becoming more tachypnic. He was started on morphine drip at 0900 up to
   5mg/hr and looked more comfortable. His wife arrived ~1000. The family
   was waiting for 2 more relatives prior to disconnecting vent and
   pressures. But at ~1030 he started to drop his hr and at 1210 he died
   with his family at his side. The priest arrived shortly after.
