   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:  The patient is a 61 yo man with h/o CAD s/p DES
   to the LAD and D1, and hyperlipidemia, who presented from [**Hospital1 **] with STEMI and is now s/p BMS to the RCA.
   .
   # STEMI:  The patient presented with chest pain and subsequently lost
   consciousness at [**Hospital3 519**].  He was found to have STe in II, III,
   AVF, and after one hour of resuscitiation, subsequent cardiac
   catheterization demonstrated a fresh thrombus in the mid-RCA.  Heparin
   and integrilin gtts were held, and he was started on cooling protocol.
   He was on Dopamine briefly prior to cardiac catheterization. Rewarming
   starts at 1130
    - Continue cooling protocol with Fentanyl/Verset for sedation and
   Vecuronium for paralytics for 18 hours
    - Continue to monitor CK, troponins x3
   - Continue to hold heparin and integrilin, given significant bleeding
   from nose
    - Hold on Lasix for now, as patient is pre-load dependent
    - Give IVFs as needed to maintain MAPs > 60
    - Continue Dopamine to maintain MAP > 60.
    - Monitor for bradycardia, hypotension, and electrolyte shifts with
   cooling protocol
   -  Atropine if patient becomes increasingly bradycardic.
    - Continue ASA 325 mg daily, Plavix 75 mg daily
    - Increase Lipitor to 80 mg daily
    - Start low dose BB as BP tolerates
    - Repeat ECG  tomorrow AM.
    - Replete lytes
   - TTE tomorrow
   - If pt develops pulmonary edema, consider acute MR, contact cards
   fellow.
   .
   #. Respiratory Distress:  The patient was intubated at [**Hospital3 519**]
   in the setting of cardiac arrest.  He was fighting the ventilator on
   arrival and his initial ABG was 7.23/40/273.  After cardiac
   catheterization, he became more stable on the ventilator and his
   current ABG returned 7.47/24/206; Improving, but now with low pCO@
    - Continue on CMV during cooling protocol
    - Aim for pO2 in the low 100s (decrease free radicals) and CO2 between
   35 and 40.
    - Continue VAP precautions with raising the HOB to 30%
   # RHYTHM:  The patient presented in VFib arrest and then had a
   junctional rhythm.  He is currently in sinus rhythm.
    - Continue to monitor on telemetry.
    - Continue to replete K > 4.0 and Mg > 2.0
   # Acute Systolic Congestive Heart Failure:  The patient had an acute RV
   infarct this afternoon, and his hemodynamics in the cath lab
   demonstrated increased biventricular filling pressures.  He does not
   have a known history of CHF, per our records, and these elevated
   filling pressures are most likely [**3-14**] his acute RV infarct.
    - TTE tomorrow.
    - Hold on diuresis for now, as patient is pre-load dependent.
    - Dopamine gtt for now to increase contracility and CO
   .
   # Nose bleed:  The patient had a persistent nose bleed this afternoon
   in the setting of traumatic NGT placement and integrilin/heparin gtts.
   The bleeding appears to have stopped with Afrin nasal spray, and the
   patient's Hct has remained stable.
    - Recheck Hct q6h
    - Continue Afrin NS
    - Consider ENT C/S if bleeding starts again.
   .
   #Lactic Acidosis: Lactate 10 in cath to 4.1 today; improving
      - 2 amps of bicarb given
      - Consult with RT to balance RR with acidosis
      - continue to monitor with q 12 lactates
   #Shock Liver: Elevated Enzymes s/p resuscitation AST 415 ALT 288 and
   trended down this AM.
   - Continue to monitor daily LFTs
   .
   # Diabetes: Unsure of home medications as cannot obtain records or an
   emergency contact
         -Elevated BS on Chemistries
        - Start sliding scale today and continue to monitor FSBS
   #  Identity:  The patient presented from [**Hospital3 519**] with minimal
   paperwork, after driving there himself.  Records from [**Hospital1 12**] gave his
   mother, [**Name (NI) 7816**] [**Name (NI) 7817**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7818**]) as his next of [**Doctor First Name 23**].  He is single
   and not married.  The patient has a cell phone, but no saved numbers.
    - Consider Ethics C/S in the am re: calling numbers from phone in
   order to alert family
    - Re-attempt calling patient's mother in am.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO for now; consider starting tube feeds after warming
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   PA Catheter - [**2118-8-27**] 06:30 PM
   Cordis/Introducer - [**2118-8-27**] 06:30 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2118-8-27**] 06:30 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2118-8-27**] 06:30 PM

   family/find more information regarding the patient.  Ethics C/S may be
   needed tomorrow.

[**Doctor Last Name 1046**] in the
   chest
 while moving furniture, patient drove to the ED and shortly
   after arrival had a witnessed cardiac arrest requiring prolonged
   resuscitation with anti-arrhythmics and vasopressors & was transferred
   to [**Hospital1 5**] for treatment of STEMI in the cath lab: now s/p BMS to the
   RCA.
   [**8-27**]: DES placed to patient
s RCA (thrombus). Arctic Sun cooling
   protocol initiated on arrival to the CCU and goal temperature (34
   celcius) was reached at 2300.
   [**8-28**]: Patient continues to be cool to goal temp 34 celcius with some
   mild variation (within 1 degree celcius) throughout the day. Re-warm to
   37 celcius began 1730. Hemodynamically stable, although bradycardic
   (1^st AVB with prolonged QT) to the 40
s on dopamine gtt, sedation and
   NMB. EEG leads applied. Sister [**Name (NI) 161**] by phone # obtained on
   patient
s cell phone in the afternoon (ok
d with ethics) which is first
   family contact since patient
s hospitalization began.
   NE Organ Bank notified of patient and they plan to follow his care this
   admission.
   Cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   s/p cardiac arrest at OSH on [**8-27**]. DES placed to RCA on [**8-27**].
   -HR 38-54, SB with 1^st AVB & prolonged QT (by EKG). NBP 95-115/ 60
   MAPs 60-70
s on dopamine gtt.
   -CVP 11-15 and PA pressures: 35-45/15-25.
   -MV O2 sat 80; CO/CI/SVR: 8.1/3.8/661
   -Arctic Sun cooling at goal 34 celcius (range 33.8-35) by rectal &
   esophageal monitoring.
   -Patient with cold extremities, dopplerable pulses & impaired neuro
   exam given NMB and dopamine gtt in place. TOF 0-2 on NMB ([**5-14**] prior to
   NMB).
   Action:
   -Hemodynamic monitoring including CVP and PA pressures- no ALine.
   Dopamine gtt at 6 mcg/kg/min.
   -Electrolyte/lab monitoring given fluid/electrolyte shifts during
   cool/re-warm process- elecytrolyte repletions including 2 gm Mg and15
   mmol sodium phosphate.
   -Maintained high levels of sedation to prevent pain from cooling and
   NMB; followed with TOF monitoring. Fentanyl at 150 mcg/hr and Versed at
   3 mg/hr.
   -Vecuronium was bolused and gtt re-started at 0.05 mcg/kg/min at 10:30
   am (had been off since 6 am) as patient began to shiver with associated
   increase in HR to the 60
s and core temps warming towards 35 celcius.
   *Re-warm began at 1730 (to goal of 37 celcius over 6-8 hours)*- total
   cooling time 18 hours.
   - Frequent turning, repositioning and skin care while immobile from
   NMB.
   -EEG placed by Neuro
   -Heparin and integrilin continue to be held [**3-14**] epistaxis (resolved
   overnight with Afrin spray). Pneumo boots placed for DVT prophylaxis.
   Response:
   -Hemodynamics & lab results as above.
   -Bradycardia likely [**3-14**] cooling process as e/b increase in heart rate
   when patient shivering.
   -Pupils 2-3 mm and non-reactive to light (on dopamine gtt). No
   spontaneous movement or withdrawal as patient on NMB.
   -Pedal pulses remain dopplerable and extremities cool to touch.
   -No EEG results at this time
   Plan:
   Continue hemodynamic monitoring. Labs scheduled for 10 pm, monitor
   electrolyte shifts. Continue re-warm at rate of 0.5 degrees celcius per
   hour until goal temp 37 (total warm time 6-8 hours). Pain medication
   and supportive therapies. Wean off NMB with TOF. TTE on Monday (sooner
   if patient deteriorates hemodynamically). EEG monitoring per Neuro
   team- likely head CT when stable.

   The patient is a 61 yo man with h/o DM, CAD s/p stents to D1 and LCx,
   who presented from [**Hospital3 **] as a Code STEMI.  The patient was
   reportedly in his normal state of health until noon on [**8-27**], when he
   was lifting furniture and developed chest pain.  He reportedly had
   associated diaphoresis and lightheadedness.  An hour and a half later,
   the patient drove himself to [**Hospital3 519**], where he continued to
   have substernal chest pain.
   .
   On arrival to the ED, the patient was noted to be ashen but conversant
   and AAO x3.  His initial VS were BP 130/77, P 51, R 14, O2 97% on RA,
   Wt 233 lbs.  On transfer to the ED stretcher, the patient went into
   VFib arrest.  He was coded for 54 minutes, during which time he was
   intubated and received 12 mg Epinepherine, 5 mg of Atropine, and was
   started on Lidocaine and Dopamine gtts.  Cooling protocol was
   initiated, and he was then transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] as code STEMI for
   cardiac catheterization.
   .
   In the cath lab, the patient was found to have a total occlusion of the
   mid-RCA.  He underwent successful primary PCI and had a BMS placed in
   his RCA.  He was weaned off the pressors, and heparin and integrilin
   were discontinued as the patient continued to have substantial bleeding
   from his nares.
   .
   The patient was intubated and sedated upon arrival to the CCU and was
   thus unable to answer ROS.

Chief Complaint:  s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI: 36yo male with medical history notable for morbid obesity was
   admitted from the ED s/p cardiac arrest.
   Patient was found by his family having tonic-clonic movements and
   unresponsive. EMS was called and patient was found to be in Vfib
   arrest. He was initially cardioverted at 200J, and rhythm converted to
   asystole. He received epi, atropine, narcan, and 100mg lidocaine for
   recurrent VF. He was defibrillated again with conversion to sinus
   tachycardia. He was intubated and started on a lidocaine drip.
   Hypothermia cooling protocol was initiated at that time, and he was
   taken to an OSH. At the OSH, vital signs on arrival were BP 111/66, HR
   98, RR 23, temp 98.5, and O2 sat 96% on vent (unclear settings at the
   time). He was administered midazolam 8mg total, ativan 2mg IV x 2,
   lopressor 5mg IV x 1, and 1L normal saline bolus. The patient was then
   transferred to [**Hospital1 19**]. Upon arrival at [**Hospital1 19**], vital signs were temp
   37.9, HR 142 / BP 139/50, RR 48, and O2 sat 97% on vent (unclear what
   the settings were). He was switched to propofol boluses for sedation.
   He was started on the arctic sun protocol and transferred to the floor.
   He required vecuronium x 1 for paralysis.
   Patient is intubated and sedated and full review of systems could not
   be obtained.  In discussion with his wife, patient was dizzy one day
   ago when he bent over to pick up something. On this day of admission,
   patient was in his usual state of health. He and his wife went [**Name2 (NI) 6625**]
   without any complications. On the evening of admission, she heard a

   Assessment and Plan
   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   1. s/p Arrest
   Etiology of his arrest is unclear and will be very difficult to assess
   given that he was unmonitored at the time of the event. Given patient's
   multiple medical problems including sleep apnea, asthma, and morbid
   obesity, a likely etiology of his arrest is arrest in the setting of
   hypoxia related to his obesity-hypoventilation, sleep apnea, and
   asthma. Additional differential diagnosis includes ischemia, structural
   heart disease, and arrhythmia, although patient has no prior history of
   any of these abnormalities. An additional possibility includes a
   non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic instability resulting in a PEA arrest,
   although patient has no specific localizing symptoms or signs.
   - ECG upon arrival to the floor
   - rule-out MI
   - check fasting lipids in the AM
   - consider cardiac catheterization once more hemodynamically stable
   - echo in the AM
   - consider EP consult in the AM and possible EPS once hemodynamically
   stable and has completed the arctic sun protocol
   - continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun
   - replete electrolytes aggressively
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. Leukocytosis
   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related to his Vfib arrest,
   although infection is also possible. Only localizing symptom at this
   time includes his UA that is suggestive of UTI, although no leuks or
   nitrates despite > 50 WBCs and bacteria.
   - resend UA and culture, treat with cipro if positive
   - follow-up blood cultures
   - follow-up CXR read
   3. Morbid Obesity
   Patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient
   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure
   4. Respiratory Failure
   Patient was intubated in the setting of cardiac arrest. Patient is on
   room air at baseline but does have a history of asthma and obstructive
   sleep apnea. No additional evidence of pneumonia or additional
   respiratory incident. ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling

   maintain MAP > 65

Chief Complaint:  s/p cardiac arrest
   HPI: 36yo male with medical history notable for morbid obesity was
   admmitted from the ED s/p cardiac arrest.
   .
   Patient was found by his family having tonic clonic movements and
   unresponsive. EMS was called and patient was found to be in Vfib
   arrest. He was initially cardioverted at 200J and rhythm converted to
   asystole. He received epi, atropine, narcan, and 100mg lidocaine for
   recurrent VF. He was defibrillated again with conversion to sinus
   tachycardia. He was intubated and started on a lidocaine drip.
   Hypothermia cooling protocol was initiated at that time and taken to an
   OSH. At the OSH, vital signs on arrival were BP 111/66, HR 98, RR 23,
   temp 98.5, and O2 sat 96% on vent. He was administered midazolam 8mg
   total, ativan 2mg IV x 2, lopressor 5mg IV x 1, and 1L normal saline
   bolus. The patient was then transferred to [**Hospital1 19**]. Upon arrival at
   [**Hospital1 19**], vital signs were temp 37.9, HR 142 / BP 139/50, RR 48, and O2
   sat 97% on vent (unclear what the settings were). He was switched to
   propofol boluses for sedation. He was started on the arctic sun
   protocol and transferred to the floor. He required vecuronium x 1.
   .
   Patient is intubated and sedated and full review of systems could not
   be obtained.  In discussion with his wife, patient was dizzy one day
   ago when he bent over to pick up something. On this day of admission,
   patient was in his usual state of health. He and his wife went [**Name2 (NI) 6625**]
   without any complications. She heard a noise in their bedroom and found
   that he had whole body shaking, eyes rolling back into his head. She
   called 911 and then went with him. She thinks he was breathing but
   unsure if he had a pulse.

   Assessment and Plan
   36yo male with morbid obesity was admitted s/p cardiac arrest at home.
   1. s/p Arrest
   Etiology of his arrest is unclear and will be very difficult to assess
   given that he was unmonitored at the time of the event. Differential
   diagnosis includes pulmonary embolus given intraventricular conduction
   delay in lead V1, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Preliminary evaluation of
   echo appears to demonstrate RV dysfunction which would also be
   consistent for pulmonary embolus. Additional differential diagnosis
   includes ischemia, structural heart disease, and arrhythmia, although
   patient has no prior history of any of these abnormalities. An
   additional possibility includes a non-cardiac cause of hemodynamic
   instability resulting in a PEA arrest, although patient has no specific
   localizing symptoms or signs.
   - for evaluation of PE, will check CTA chest for evaluation of PE and
   coordinate CT head to evaluate for any intracranial bleed that would
   act as a contraindication to anticoagulation
   - follow-up fasting lipids in the AM
   - consider cardiac catheterization once more hemodynamically stable,
   although this seems less likely given that patient has minimmal other
   risk factors
   - follow-up echo read
   - consider EP consult in the AM and possible EPS once hemodynamically
   stable if no additional cause of VF arrest is found
   - continue cooling protocol via Arctic Sun
   - follow-up EEG and neuro recs per cardiac arrest protocol
   - replete electrolytes aggressively
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. Leukocytosis
   Etiology of his leukocytosis is most likely related to his Vfib arrest,
   although infection is also possible. Only localizing symptom at this
   time includes his UA that is suggestive of UTI, although no leuks or
   nitrates despite > 50 WBCs and bacteria.
   - resend UA and culture, treat with cipro if positive
   - follow-up blood cultures
   - follow-up CXR read
   3. Morbid Obesity
   Patient has morbid obesity and is currently undergoing outpatient
   evaluation for gastric bypass.
   - continue outpatient evaluation for gastric bypass procedure pending
   resolution of acute medical concerns
   4. Respiratory Failure
   Patient was intubated in the setting of cardiac arrest. Patient is on
   room air at baseline but does have a history of asthma and obstructive
   sleep apnea. No additional evidence of pneumonia or additional
   respiratory incident. ABG on current settings demonstrates adequate
   oxygenation but likely respiratory acidosis given slightly elevated
   PCO2.
   - continue to maintain intubation and sedation for adequate cooling

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 12424**] is a [**Age over 90 **] year-old man with a history of moderate aortic
   stenosis (1-1.2 cm2), aortic regurg, first-degree AV block, recent
   DVT/PE on coumadin (diagnosed ~[**2181-4-24**]), HTN, CKD, and left BKA who is
   transferred from [**Hospital1 5**]-[**Location (un) 3**] for management of third degree av block.
   .
   # Complete heart block:  Unclear etiology, may be related to coronary
   ischemia though does not carry diagnosis of CAD, not on beta blockers
   or calcium channel blockers at baseline, no evidence of myocarditis.
   Electrolytes not significantly abnormal to suggest cause.
   - continue transvenous pacing
   - EP consult for PPM
   - check cardiac enzymes
   - EKG on arrival
   - check tsh, spep/upep
   - ECHO to eval for cardiomyopathy
   .
   # Hypotension:  Was hypertensive on arrival to OSH and levophed
   initiated in setting of intubation and propofol.  DDx includes propofol
   effect, bradycardia, hypovolemia; would also consider pericardial
   tamponade given pacer wire placement. Sepsis and PE less likely.  Has
   stable aortic stenosis.
   - IVF bolus on arrival
   - weane pressors as tolerated
   - consider changing sedation to fent/midazolam
   - check ECHO
   - blood, urine, sputum cultures
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Intubated for airway protection in setting of
   bradycardia and asytole.  Likely aspirated given gastric contents from
   ETT so may have also developed pneumonitis/pneumonia.
   - ABG and CXR on arrival
   - continue current vent settings
   - sputum cultures
   - hold on antibiotics for now
   .
   # Recent DVT/likely PE:  Diagnosed ~[**2181-4-24**] with DVT in left lower
   extremity, also with probable PE on v/q scan.
   - hold coumadin for now given likely EP procedure
   - low dose vitamin k
   - monitor respiratory status
   .
   #  Chronic kidney disease:  Baseline creatinine 1.8.
   - mucomyst and bicarb IVFs prior to procedure
   .
   # Tophaceous gout: On chronic steroids, allopurinol, colchicine
   - continue prednisone at current dose
   - continue allopurinol
   - will hold colchicine pending creatinine check
   .
   FEN:  NPO, IVFs
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with warfarin
   -Bowel regimen with colace
   .

81yof with PMH: severe 3VD including 70% ostial LM, unsuccessful PCI in
   the past, CHF, CRI, PVD, IDDM had a recent admit to OSH 2weeks ago for
   CHF exacerbation, abdominal and right leg pains discharged home after 4
   days with increased lasix dose. .  Presents to OSH [**2-10**] 1500 for
   SSCP/epigastric pressure with ST depressions and peaked TW +trop 3.0,
   started heparin gtt and dopamine gtt for hypotension SBP 70, received
   dilaudid IVB before transfer to [**Hospital1 5**]/EW. Arrived with SBP 90 with
   dopamine gtt at 10mcg/kg/min. EKG with STD laterally +trop 1.5. Pt was
   admitted to CCU at 0500 on Heparin at 1000u/hr, dopamine at
   10mcg/kg/min with SBP 96 HR 135. She received 1 liter NS and dopamine
   was shut off with decrease in HR from 130s to 90s NSR. PT reported
   chest discomfort as minimal.She was bloused with and started on
   integrellin shortly after admission.  BUN/Creat elevated at 91/1.8 with
   K+ 5.5. She reports loss of apatite and that she has not eaten or drunk
   liquids for the past 2 days. She finally ate some oatmeal and has been
   drinking water in the afternoon. . After talking with patient and her
   daughter, who is the proxy she is DNI, but is to received shocks, CPR
   and meds. She is oriented X 3 and although she appears to understand
   most of what is said to her, her accent is strong and she is difficult
   to understand. Her daughter spoke to her on the phone. Her skin is
   without lesions.
   Hypotension (not Shock)
   Assessment:
   Pt received 1 liter NS after arriving in CCU as dopamine was stopped.
   She had more stable bp until ~0730 when she became hypotensive to the
   70s with maps in the mid 40s. She reported unchanged minor chest
   pressure and was not sure about that. HR was in mid 90s to low 100s.
   Lungs are clear and she was sating 100% on 2L NP. She felt thirsty and
   mucous membranes appeared dry. She had been on increased dose of lasix
   after recent admission for CHF.
   Action:
   She received 3 more 500 NS bolues for at total of 2500cc and NS
   started at 200cc/hr. Phenylephrine was started at 0800 at .5mic/kilo as
   first 1st bolus was running. Neo was shut off at 0920 as more fluid was
   given, however it had to be restarted at 1030 for maps in the 40s. NS
   continues at 200cc/hr. She was cultured. ECHO done to ascertain if she
   has had change in cardiac function with troponin bump.
   Response:
   BP has been stable on neo with U/O 10-50cc/hr. She was started on ABX.
   Echo showed EF of ~20% (45%), with moderate MR. She also had pulmonary
   hypertension with PA pressure ~50. Maps have been above 65 since back
   on neo. Fluid continues at 200cc/hr. She will have had 4 liters in
   since 5am once this liter finishes. She should be watched closely as
   she has low EF and hx of heart failure. Of note neo is running through
   a peripheral line. She is being evaluated for a picc. Neo being weaned
   as PTT too high now for PICC and baseline bp 70-100s.  Thus far
   tolerating wean.
   Plan:
   Try to get neo off. Continue to assess for signs of fluid overload.
   Central sleep apnea (CSA)
   Assessment:
   Pt noted to have long apnic periods followed by hyperventilation which
   awakens her. Sats do not drop, even on RA. She frequently moans as she
   awakens with hyperventilatory respirations and appears very short of
   breath and uncomfortable.  Pt feeling very weak and exhausted as she is
   unable to sleep. She reports she felt like this at home.
   Action:
   Blood gas drawn to ensure she was not retaining CO2. Gas was
   7.39/33/100/ -3/ 21. Although pt does not de-sat she doesn
t sleep and
   c-pap will be tried to see if it helps her.
   Response:
   Will have resp attempt c-pap tonight,
   Plan:
   Support and monitor pt. Try c-pap later.
   Myocardial infarction, acute (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   Assessment:
   Pt CKs continue to climb. In EW they were 368/45/12.2 and at 11am they
   were 792/98/12.4. She states she has minor epigastric discomfort, but
   it has been persistent and has not changed since admission here. Blood
   pressure too low to given beta-blockers or nitrates. She is on heparin
   and was started on integrellin after arrving in CCU.
   Action:
   Team notified. Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 876**] feels cath not valuable as pt has such
   significant known multivessel disease not treatable with intervention,
   and she is not a surgical candidate.  Integrellin was stopped at 0830
   and heparin continues at 1000 units/hr. PTT >150 and heparin off from
   1800 to 1900. Will be started at 700u/hr.
   Response:
   No further CKs ordered as it will not change treatment.  Restart
   heparin per ss.
   Plan:
   Check PTT in 6hr. Monitor for further pain.

   As mentioned in Dr [**Last Name (STitle) **]
s note and the housestaff note Ms [**Known lastname 4160**] is
   an 81F with h/o CAD with inoperable and non-interveneable coronary
   artery disease who presents with epigastric pain and hypotension
   non-responsive to fluids.  She in addition has a troponin T elevation
   to 1.5 initially and later to 3.5.  During the day she continues to be
   hypotensive despite further fluid resuscitation and low dose
   neosynephrine.  On exam she does not seem to be volume overloaded nor
   has features of cardiogenic shock (warm clammy skin, warm shins and
   extremities).  The hypotension most likely is secondary to a
   distributive shock with UTI as a source.  The cardiac enzyme elevation
   despite its extent is due to hypotension in the setting of urosepsis
   and represents a type II myocardial infarction, which we are treating
   conservatively and if there is any platelet activation with ASA,
   clopidogrel and heparin.
   Access has been a problem in her and we wanted to place a central line
   in her to monitor her CVP for goal directed therapy.  However, she has
   recently had a bad experience of line placement and is mortified to
   have a central line placed.  We are currently trying to get the PICC
   team to place a line in order to avoid IJ or subclavian canulation.  In
   case this is not successful I spoke to the family in regards of further
   plans.  Ms [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 359**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4166**] is her daughter and HCP.  We agreed to try
   placing a PICC line and if this does not work to continue the therapy
   as is suboptimally with peripheral iv therapy and pressor infusion but
   avoidance of a central line.  If she happens to worsen her clinical
   status we would not augment clinical efforts and change our focus on
   comfort only.
   Her code status at present is DNI with resuscitation efforts in case of
   a cardiac arrest in the realm of the limitation to not being able to be
   intubated.

   rhythm was asystole then VF during resuscitation with epi and atropine,
   given 2 shocks with restoration of sinus rhythm. Intubated. Amiodarone
   started. ECG initially with STE inferior, then anterior. CODE STEMI
   initiated. At cath, single vessel disease with mid-distal LAD occlusion
   which was a small vessel. LV gram with apical dyskinesis but otherwise
   preserved LV function. No intervention performed given proximal and mid
   LAD tortuosity, small vessel, as well as relative preservation of
   ventricular function. GCS = 5 off sedation with flexor posturing.
   Unable to obtain ROS due to intubated and sedated.
   Past medical, social, family, medications, and allergies per CCU
   housestaff note.
   Exam notable for intubated, sedated, no response to pain or voice,
   flexor posturing, reactive pupils bilateral, mechanical breath sounds,
   RRR, no peripheral edema, warm extremities.
   Labs with Hct 30, Plt 219, Cre 0.6; most recent ABG 7.30/44/533.
   CXR demonstrates expanded lung fields, intubated, no acute process.
   Impression and plan: 59F s/p out of hospital VF arrest secondary to
   anterior STEMI. Cooling. Echo. ASA, plavix, integrillin. Rest of plan
   per CCU housestaff note.

   .
   Mr. [**Known lastname 659**] stopped smoking in [**2072**], as [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 3690**] resolution, and started
   running shortly thereafter. He ate poorly, but became good at running.
   He started running with his son in [**2102**]. In [**2104**] he had some exertional
   chest pain which led to nuclear stress test and catheterization, with
   placement of a bare metal stent in left circumflex. Since that time he
   had been free of symptoms, with his most recent stress test in [**Month (only) 2877**]
   this year not revealing any concerning ischemia, per the patient. He
   had received this care in [**Location (un) 12729**], where he lives with his wife. [**Name (NI) **]
   most recently completed a marathon two months ago without chest pain.
   .
   Mr. [**Known lastname 659**] was running the [**Location (un) **] Marathon today, with his son, without
   having taken his ASA and Plavix for the last two days. His doctor had
   previously told him to hold these for two days prior to racing to
   reduce bruising. He got to mile 25 before witnessed callapse, earlier
   increasing shortness of breath and fatigue, followed by loss of
   consciousness. Bystander provided CPR until AED arrived. No strips, but
   AED determined shockable rhythm, likely VF. Sinus rhythm was
   re-established after two shocks and he was brought to [**Hospital1 5**] and
   directly into the cath lab. En route he received 100 mg lidocaine. In
   the ED he was noted to have ST elevation in V3 with biphasic t-waves.
   ST depression was also commented upon there. Code STEMI was called. He
   received Integrillin, IVFs (~ 2L), ASA 325 mg, Plavix (loaded with 600
   mg), vitals were 151/87, HR 86, RR 23, 97% NC. Cardiology was consulted
   and recommended direct transfer to the cath. lab. On coronary
   agiography, LCx stent was appreciated and open, LAD disease was noted ~
   90%. Unlikely STEMI, infact unlikely ACS, but Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4235**] describes as
   likely angina/ischemia with consequent VF and arrest. Possible that
   ischemic changes on EKG are secondary to demand and shocks. A long
   stent drug-eluting stent was placed in the LAD. He received 20 mg IV
   Lasix. EKG had partly normalized after cath.
   .
   On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools.
   He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock
   pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.

TITLE: Cardiology Fellow Admission Note
   Agree with H&P by CCU housestaff (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]. Please see their note for
   complete details.
   Briefly, 55M h/o HTN, hyperlipidemia, MVP presents after sudden cardiac
   arrest.  Patient was working construction, on break, witnessed to
   collapse. CPR started by bystander. Multiple AED shocks, epi, atropine.
   Started on lido drip. Rhythm was VF and PEA intermittently. 40 min
   until spontaneous perfusion restored. Intubated in the field. [**Location (un) **]
   to [**Hospital1 1**] where became hypotensive requiring max dopa and levophed.
   Taken to cath lab which demonstrated minimal coronary disease, normal
   wall motion, CI 8.18, LVEDP 15, and Ao 112/64. Lidocaine stopped and
   cooling protocol begun. Transfer to CCU for further care.
   Past medical, social, family, medications, allergies per CCU housestaff
   note.
   Exam with BP 103/60, HR 111 reg, RR 29, T 94.5, SaO2 94%, AC
   500/26/0.6, intubated and sedated, coarse breath sounds, tachycardic
   without murmurs, no peripheral edema, warm extremities, no withdrawal
   to pain, pupils nonreactive.
   Labs notable for WBC 28.2, Hct 49.2, Plt 319, BUN25, Cre 1.2, lactate
   3.9, ABG 7.24/72/38, tox screens neg.
   ECG: sinus tach, probable LAA, low limb volts, Q in III, delayed R-wave
   transition
   CXR: low lung volumes, atelectasis, mild edema.
   CT head: diffuse grey-white matter loss consistent with anoxic brain
   injury
   CTA chest: no dissection, aneurysm, or PE
   Prior studies: normal echo and cath [**2154**], stress test [**2154**] with
   multifocal NSVT
   Impression: Sudden cardiac arrest without significant coronary disease,
   consider primary arrhythmic event. Prolonged resuscitation effort.
   Continue cooling. Shock likely distributive due to arrest, would wean
   dopa/levophed as tolerated for MAP>60, transition to neosynephrine if
   needed. Echo. Neuro consult. Consider EP consult pending neurological
   prognosis.
   Plan discussed with CCU housestaff and attending Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].

   - CT Chest:  No aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm, or pulmonary

   Assessment and Plan
   55 year old man who presents with cardiac arrest.
   # Cardiac arrest: VFib arrest with episodes of PEA and asystole. Most
   likely etiology is primary arrythmogenic arrest. DDx include ischemic
   cardiomyopathy, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, myocarditis,
   long QT syndrome in decreasing order of likelihood.  Per cardiology
   records, he had a h/o ventricular arrythmia.  Unclear etiology ? if
   metabolic related (ie. Hyperthyroidism) vs infection
   (pulmonary/intra-abdominal)
   - obtain PCP records
   [**Name Initial (PRE) **] trend CE (expect elevation because of CPR)
   - TTE to eval EF on [**11-1**]
   - monitor CBC, CMP
   - hold lidocaine ggt; if goes back in VF then amiodarone, since no
   ischemic disease.
   # Neurologic compromise: Concern for anoxic injury in setting of
   cardiac arrest. Currently on cooling protocol.
   - EEG and neurology consultation
   - monitor coags and lytes while cooled
   - arctic sun treatment protocol
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   # Hypotension: Initially in setting of VF, suggesting a cardiogenic
   shock proccess. Worsening of hypotension may have been artifactual,
   related to a line. CI during cath and a line tracing from femoral
   sheath support this.
   - Monitor BP
   - wean down pressor (dopa/levo) as tolerated, currently only on
   levophed
   - Consider changing to Neo since this has less B1 ionotropic effect.
   # Metabolic Acidosis: likely from tissue ischemia. Lactate was
   elevated. AG of 18 with delta-delta of [**6-9**] (0.5) is indictive of a
   combined metabolic acidosis (AG and non-AG).  AG is due to lactate [**1-30**]
   hypoperfusion that is complicated by the hyperglycemic episodes
   thoughout the night [**1-30**] HCO3 gtt. Non-AG is of unclear etiology, could
   be [**1-30**] dilutional effect and respiratory alkalosis though can not rule
   out RTA etiology.  He was given experimental dose of medication, likely
   contributed to the hyperglycemia.  And he was receiving HCO3 in D5W.
   Clinically resemble DKA, though, he does not have a documented
   diagnosis of DM.
   - treating with HCO3 bolus to prevent acidosis induced VF.
   - continue IVF support, insulin drip, lyte replete.
   - q1h glucose check, with ABG's to see if he is responding to
   treatment.
   - serial ABG check.
   # Respiratory arrest: Likely a consequence of VF arrest. Currently
   intubated and sedated. Note fild intubation most likely required
   paralysis. CXR with mild hilar fullness, but the rest of the exam in
   inconsistent with pulmonary edema or decompensated systolic
   dysfunction. Leukocytosis is most likely attributed  to arrest, and is
   less indicative of PNA. Although of low pretest probability PE CT was
   obtained in ED and was negative. Most recent ABG suggestive of
   respiratory alkalosis.
   - monior O2 sats and ABG prn
   - modify TV and RR to correct respiratory alkalosis
   - wean sedation in am as tolerated
   - emperically coverage with zosyn.
   FEN: lytes q6, prn IVF
   ACCESS: 18gx2, CVL R groin, femoral sheath
   PROPHYLAXIS: SQH, PPI

                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Cardiac arrest with question of pulmonary embolus.

 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from same day.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial CT images were acquired through the chest prior to and
 following the administration of intravenous contrast.  Coronal, sagittal and
 oblique reformatted images were also reviewed.

 FINDINGS:  There is no aortic aneurysm or dissection.  The pulmonary arterial
 system is well opacified and there is no evidence of embolic filling defect.
 The lungs are notable for bilateral dependent opacities in the upper and lower
 lobes, likely related to atelectasis or aspiration.  The patient is intubated
 with an endotracheal tube terminating at the origin of the right main stem
 bronchus.  This tube should be retracted.  A nasogastric tube terminates in
 the stomach.  The heart and great vessels are notable for a small amount of
 atherosclerotic coronary arterial calcification.  There is no mediastinal or
 axillary lymphadenopathy.

 Study is not tailored for assessment of subdiaphragmatic contents.
 Nevertheless, those included are notable for a trace amount of perihepatic
 free fluid, a small hiatal hernia as well as fluid and fat stranding adjacent
 to the duodenum, with a possibly thickening wall.

 Included osseous structures reveal no suspicious sclerotic or lytic lesion.
 Incidental note is made of a non-displaced right fourth rib fracture
 anteriorly (3:11).

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm, or pulmonary embolus.
 2.  Bilateral dependent consolidations, either atelectasis or aspiration.
 3.  Endotracheal tube in the right mainstem bronchus, which should be
 retracted.
 4.  Coronary arterial calcification.
 5.  Axial hiatal hernia.
 6.  Trace ascites.
 7.  Stranding and fluid about the second portion of the duodenum, and
 duodenitis is not excluded.

   PND report
   Assessment and Plan
   In brief this is a 55 year old man who presents with cardiac arrest.
   # Cardiac arrest: VFib arrest with episodes of PEA and asystole. Most
   likely etiology is primary arrythmogenic arrest. Ischemic
   cardiomyopathy was strogly suspected given patient's reported history.
   However, there was no evidence of CAD on cath and there were no ECG
   changes to suggest MI. Alternatively, left ventricular systolic
   dysfunction may have lead into ventricular arrythmia that evolved into
   VF. A less likely possibility may be myocarditis leading to
   non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (given symptoms of URI over last several
   months).  Long QT syndrome is not supported by ECG findings. Hereditary
   arrythmogenic conditions would be unlikely to manifest for the first
   time this late in life.
   - obtain PCP/Cardiology records
   - trend CE (expect elevation because of CPR)
   - TTE to eval EF
   - monitor CBC, CMP
   - hold lidocaine ggt; if goes back in VF then amiodarone, since no
   ischemic disease.
   # Neurologic compromise: Concern for anoxic injury in setting of
   cardiac arrest. Currently on cooling protocol.
   - EEG and neurology consultation
   - monitor coags and lytes while cooled
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   # Hypotension: Initially in setting of VF, suggesting a cardiogenic
   shock proccess. Worsening of hypotension may have been artifactual,
   related to a line. CI during cath and a line tracing from femoral
   sheath support this.
   - Monitor
   - wean down pressor (dopa/levo) as tolerated.
   - Consider changing to Neo since this has less B1 ionotropic effect.
   # Respiratory arrest: Likely a consequence of VF arrest. Currently
   intubated and sedated. Note fild intubation most likely required
   paralysis. CXR with mild hilar fullness, but the rest of the exam in
   inconsistent with pulmonary edema or decompensated systolic
   dysfunction. Leukocytosis is most likely attributed  to arrest, and is
   less indicative of PNA. Although of low pretest probability PE CT was
   obtained in ED and was negative. Most recent ABG suggestive of
   respiratory alkalosis.
   - monior O2 sats and ABG prn
   - modify TV and RR to correct respiratory alkalosis
   - wean sedation in am as tolerated
   # AGMA: likely from tissue ischemia. Lactate elevated but improving.
   - will treat with HCO3 ggt to prevent acidosis induced VF.
   FEN: lytes q6, prn IVF

   CXR
   Markedly low lung volumes with resultant bronchovascular crowding
   and atelectasis at the lung bases. There is likely mild edema as well.
   Endotracheal tube is slightly low. Consider retracting approximately
   1-2 cm for optimal placement.
   CTA chest
   No pe, dissection or aneurysm. ETT tube is in the right mainstem

   Diffuse cerebral edema with loss of grey-white matter differentiation
   and sulcal effacement overall consistent with anoxic brain injury.
   C CATH:
   PND report
   Assessment and Plan
   In brief this is a 55 year old man who presents with cardiac arrest.
   # Cardiac arrest: VFib arrest with episodes of PEA and asystole. Most
   likely etiology is primary arrythmogenic arrest. Ischemic
   cardiomyopathy was strogly suspected given patient's reported history.
   However, there was no evidence of CAD on cath and there were no ECG
   changes to suggest MI. Alternatively, left ventricular systolic
   dysfunction may have lead into ventricular arrythmia that evolved into
   VF. A less likely possibility may be myocarditis leading to
   non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (given symptoms of URI over last several
   months).  Long QT syndrome is not supported by ECG findings. Hereditary
   arrythmogenic conditions would be unlikely to manifest for the first
   time this late in life.
   - obtain PCP/Cardiology records
   - trend CE (expect elevation because of CPR)
   - TTE to eval EF
   - monitor CBC, CMP
   - hold lidocaine ggt; if goes back in VF then amiodarone, since no
   ischemic disease.
   # Neurologic compromise: Concern for anoxic injury in setting of
   cardiac arrest. Currently on cooling protocol.
   - EEG and neurology consultation
   - monitor coags and lytes while cooled
   - wean sedation as tolerated
   # Hypotension: Initially in setting of VF, suggesting a cardiogenic
   shock proccess. Worsening of hypotension may have been artifactual,
   related to a line. CI during cath and a line tracing from femoral
   sheath support this.
   - Monitor
   - wean down pressor (dopa/levo) as tolerated.
   - Consider changing to Neo since this has less B1 ionotropic effect.
   # Respiratory arrest: Likely a consequence of VF arrest. Currently
   intubated and sedated. Note fild intubation most likely required
   paralysis. CXR with mild hilar fullness, but the rest of the exam in
   inconsistent with pulmonary edema or decompensated systolic
   dysfunction. Leukocytosis is most likely attributed  to arrest, and is
   less indicative of PNA. Although of low pretest probability PE CT was
   obtained in ED and was negative. Most recent ABG suggestive of
   respiratory alkalosis.
   - monior O2 sats and ABG prn
   - modify TV and RR to correct respiratory alkalosis
   - wean sedation in am as tolerated
   # AGMA: likely from tissue ischemia. Lactate elevated but improving.
   - will treat with HCO3 ggt to prevent acidosis induced VF.
   FEN: lytes q6, prn IVF
   ACCESS: 18gx2, CVL R groin, femoral sheath
   PROPHYLAXIS: SQH, PPI
   CODE: Presumed full

 infarct, shift of midline structure or acute large hemorrhage is present.  The
 paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells show bilateral maxillary mucosal
 thickening.

 Global cerebral edema.

 above, there appears to be high density in the sulci and cisterns. Although
 the severity  of swelling can create an artifactual appearance of hyperdensity
 in the sulci, the cisternal involvement is convincing. This most likely
 represents subarachnoid hemorrhage, but a severe meningitis could produce
 similar findings.

 The paranasal sinuses demonstrate free fluid in the maxillary and sphenoid
 sinuses and possibly in the ethmoids.

   Assessment and Plan
   79yo M w/hx of CAD s/p MI X 2, CHF, DM, Stage IV CKD who presents s/p
   cardiac arrest.
   .
   1. CARDIAC ARREST: Etiology includes VT/Vfib secondary to scar tissue
   from prior infarction vs. new ischemic event.  Neurologic etiologies
   such as seizure or stroke are also possible.  His pupils are fixed and
   dilated indicating either medication effect (paralytic) or neurological
   catastrophe. He is bradycardic; may be secondary to infarction vs.
   [**Location (un) **] reflex vs  medication effect given that he was on a b-blocker,
   although this is less likely.
   - cooling protocol with Arctic Sun aborted [**2-9**] bradycardia
   - trend enzymes and labs
   - neurology consult, 48 hour EEG per protocol
 likely to weigh in on
   brain death
   - sedation with Fentanyl/Versed and paralytics PRN for shivering
   - aspirin, lipitor for possible NSTEMI
   - hold off on heparin for now given INR is 3.0
 3.7
   - hold on b-blocker while hypotensive on dopamine
   - continue amiodarone for arrhythmia
   .
   2. RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt currently on ventilator, s/p cardiac
   arrest.  Lungs sound clear but diminished, chest CT with mild pulmonary
   edema.
   - wean vent settings as tolerated
   - Fentanyl/Versed for sedation with PRN paralytic
   .
   3. ANURIC RENAL FAILURE: Current electrolytes and acid/base status is
   increasingly acidotic and hyperkalemic.  Etiology for renal failure is
   likely ATN s/p shock and poor perfusion.  Per report, pt received ~2L
   NS at the OSH and 1L NS in the ED with no output since. No response to
   Lasix. Renal failure likely to worse with epinephrine and severe
   bradycardia.
   - monitor volume status
   - urine electrolyes, UA
   - hold ACE, renally dose meds
   .
   4. CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE: EF of 35-40%.  Pt is already intubated,
   has mild pulmonary edema on chest CT.
   - fluids to try to preserve kidney function
   - monitor respiratory status
   - holding ACE
   .
   5. ELEVATED WBC: Likely in the setting of stress response to cardiac
   arrest, also possibly due to NSTEMI.
   - blood cultures, urine culture
   - continue to monitor
   - hold on antibiotics for now
   .
   6. DM:
   - continue home insulin regimen of Lantus
   - regular insulin sliding scale while NPO
   .
   7. FEN: NPO for now; IV fluids
   .
   8. ACCESS: R femoral triple lumen; L arterial line; L intraosseous
   access placed in the field
   .
   9. PPX: INR therapeutic on Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis; Famotidine for
   stress ulcer prophylaxis; colace and senna PRN
   .

   stage IV diabetic nephropathy (Cr 3.0) who presented to the ED after a
   witness unresponsive episode.  Per the family, he was walking down the
   street and had a wittness loss of consciousness.  EMS was called and he
   was taken to [**Hospital 2369**] hospital.  On arrival (11:20am) he was in
   asystole.  He was given Epi X 3 and Atropine X 1.  He then went into
   Vfib and shocked (200 joules).  He then went into Afib and became
   bradycardic.  Dopamine was started.  He regained a perfusing rhythm at
   11:35am.  He was given Calcium chloride, Magnesium, Amiodarone 300mg IV
   X 1 and bicarb during the resuscitation at [**Last Name (un) 2369**].  He later had
   another episode of VT at 12:40 and an amiodarone gtt was started.  He
   was transferred to the [**Hospital1 1**] ED.
   .
   Per [**Hospital1 1**] ED report, he had presented to [**Hospital 2369**] hospital in Vfib, then
   became asystolic.  After the initial resuscitation he had 2 additional
   asystolic arrests in the [**Last Name (un) 2369**] ER.
   .
   In the [**Hospital1 1**] ED, initial vitals were T98.2 HR75, BP149/106, RR32 100%
   on the vent.  The post-arrest consult team was called and recommended
   cooling him to 33-34 degrees and weaning his propofol to
   fentanyl/versed.  A R femoral line was placed, he was given 1L IVF and
   had a head, chest, abdomen CT done without contrast.  He was kept on
   dopamine, propofol and amiodarone.  He was given 1mg Atropine for
   bradycardia to 35During transfer to the floor, he became bradycardic.
   External pacer pad were placed and his dopamine was increased from
   15mcg/kg to 20mcg/kg.  He was briefly externally paced and given
   additional an additional 1mg of Atropine.  On arrival to the CCU he was
   not being paced and his dopamine was back down to 15mcg/min.  CT scan
   showed a sternal fracture and mediastinal hematoma.
   .

   79yo M w/hx of CAD s/p MI X 2, CHF, DM, Stage IV CKD who presents s/p
   cardiac arrest.
   .
   1. CARDIAC ARREST: Etiology includes VT/Vfib secondary to scar tissue
   from prior infarction vs. new ischemic event.  Neurologic etiologies
   such as seizure or stroke are also possible.  Given troponin elevation,
   most likely a cardiac event.  Bradycardia may be secondary to
   infarction vs. medication effect given that he was on a b-blocker,
   although this is less likely.

   - hold on b-blocker while hypotensive on dopamine
   - continue amiodarone for arrhythmia

   arrest.  Lungs sound clear, chest CT with mild pulmonary edema.
   - wean vent settings as tolerated
   - Fentanyl/Versed for sedation
   .
   3. ANURIC RENAL FAILURE: Current electrolytes and acid/base status is
   stable.  Etiology for renal failure is likely ATN s/p shock and poor
   perfusion.  Per report, pt received ~2L NS at the OSH and 1L NS in the

Clinician:  Resident
   ICU Event Note/Cardiac Arrest and Death
   .
   Called to see patient for code blue cardiac arrest at approximately
   4:50am.  At that time, patient was pulseless and receiving CPR, and
   being ventilated.  PEA algorithim was followed -- see code report for
   details -- and initial impression was for metabolic arrest [**2-9**] to
   hyperkalemia/hypoglycemia or acidemia.  She was given bicarbonate,
   glucose, insulin and calcium in addition to
   epinephrine/atropine/vasopressin.  Pulse was intermittently recovered
   and patient was given IVF's, dopamine and neosynephrine.  Femoral line
   was placed for IV access.  Intubation was complicated by significant
   amount of aspiration of stomach contents during the code.  Patient was
   difficult to oxygenate during the code, but after successful intubation
   there were no further apparent complications with her airway.  Bedside
   echo demonstrated no pericardial effusion/tamponade, and showed a
   hypocontractile left ventricle.  She had symmetric breath sounds, and
   no apparent evidence of tension pneumothorax.  She was shocked for VT
   x2 by external pacer pads during the code with successful return of
   underlying rhythm, but without sustained return of her pulse.
   Ultimately, pulse could not be maintained  in the face of substantial
   acidemia, and hypoxemia.  Lab work demonstrated profound respiratory
   acidemia with pH < 7.0.  She was given bicarbonate acutely and bag
   ventilation was increased.  After 45 minutes of the above the decision
   was made to terminate the code given prolonged hypoxemia and
   pulselessness.  Time of death: 5:37AM.  [**Hospital **] healthcare proxy,
   PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] care team notified.
   Total time spent:  45 minutes
   Patient is critically ill.

Chief Complaint:  Chest pain
   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10408**] is an 89 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for CAD
   s/p CABG and multiple PCIs most recently in [**4-21**], ischemic
   cardiomyopathy with an LVEF 25-30%, PAF, and [**Hospital **] transferred from an
   OSH for cardiac catheterization after VF arrest. The patient initially
   presented to OSH on [**2104-11-8**] with chest pain. Per review of records, the
   chest pain woke him from sleep at 2 am described as [**8-22**] epigastric
   pain and did not improve with SL NTG. He then was taken to an OSH ED,
   where he was found to be in atrial fibrillation with RVR with lateral
   STD. While in the OSH ED, he developed [**11-22**] left-sided chest pain
   different from intial chest pain that resolved with NTG and morphine.
   His labs at that time were notable for elevated cardiac biomarkers to
   CK 42, MB 3.1, TnT 0.22.  Cardiology was consulted with recommendation
   for cardiac catheterization.  Prior to catheterization, however, the
   patient had VF arrest on [**11-10**] with ROSC after defibrillation x2, CPR,
   calcium, and amiodarone.  At that point, the patient was started on
   heparin gtt, integrillin gtt, and taken to cardiac catheterization.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated 60% proximal and mid-LAD, 80-90%
   LCx, 100% proximal RCA, some in-stent resteonsis of OM with IABP
   placed. CT surgery was consulted for possible CABG, which the family
   deferred pending transfer to [**Hospital1 19**] for further evaluation and repeat
   cardiac catheterization.  Of note, the patient received 4 units PRBCs
   at OSH for a hct of 28.7.  In addition, the patient was also admitted
   to [**Hospital1 19**] on [**9-20**] for chest pain that resolved without
   intervention.
   .
   Currently, the patient is resting comfortably without complaints.

   2. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated normal systemic blood

   3.  Successful angioplasty of the obtuse marginal branch with a 2.0mm

   excellent flow throughout the vessel (See PTCA comments).
   4.  Successful PTCA and stenting of the LCX with a Xience (2.5x15mm)
   drug eluting stent postdilated with a 2.75mm balloon.  Final
   angiography demonstrated no angiographically apparent dissection, no
   residual stenosis and TIMI III flow throughout the vessel (See PTCA
   comments).

 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
   Mr. [**Known lastname 10408**] is an 89 year old gentleman with a PMH significant for CAD
   s/p CABG and multiple PCIs most recently in [**4-21**], ischemic
   cardiomyopathy with an LVEF 25%, PAF, and [**Hospital **] transferred from an OSH
   for cardiac catheterization after VF arrest.
   .
   # Coronaries: Patient with severe CAD s/p CABG now with OSH diagnostic
   cardiac catheterization demonstrating possible in-stent restenosis of
   OM 1 after recent PCI with in-hospital VF arrest at OSH concerning for
   ischemic event.
   - Continue ASA, heparin gtt, metoprolol, atorvastatin.
   - Plan for cardiac catheterization today.
   - Hold plavix for now until after cardiac catheterization, will clarify
   post-cath.
   - Continue IABP for now at 1:1 with heparin gtt.
   - Hold on trending cardiac biomarkers, as MB has already started
   trending down at OSH.
   .
   # Pump: Patient with known systolic CHF with LVEF 25-30%.  Currently
   appears euvolemic with minimal pulmonary vascular congestion on CXR and
   minimal signs of volume overload on exam.
   - Goal TBB -500-even with lasix prn.
   - Continue metoprolol, patient currently not on ACE-I. Will consider
   starting after cardiac catheterization.
   - Monitor I/Os, volume status, daily weights.
   .
   # Rhythmn: Patient with a history of PAF with report of AF with RVR on
   initial presentation although available ECGs demonstrate sinus
   rhythmn.  Patient also with VF cardiac arrest at OSH, with longest QTc
   recorded as 511 msecs prior to VF.  Possible etiologies to VF arrest
   include ACS versus R on T with prolonged QTc.
   - Continue metoprolol 12.5 mg po bid
   - Continue amio IV load for now, although will need to consider
   switching to alternative anti-arrythmic given history of pulmonary
   toxicity.
   - Hold citalopram given concern of prolonged QTc.
   - Serial ECGs to monitor QTc.
   .
   # CVA: Continue ASA
   .
   # Hypothyroid: Continue levothyroxine
   .
   # Depression: Hold citalopram as above.
   .
   # GERD: Zantac prn
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Baseline serum sodium of mid-130s, likely secondary to
   relative intravascular volume depletion in setting of CHF.
   - Trend lytes, check urine electrolytes.
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline hct in 30s and at baseline.
   - Trend hct, active T+S.
   .
   FEN: NPO for cath, replete as necessary.
   ACCESS: CVL left groin, IABP right groin.
   PPx: Heparin gtt, Zantac

 territorial infarction.  The sulci and ventricles appear prominent, likely

 There is no cerebral edema.  The orbits are unremarkable.  Mucosal thickening

 cells appear well aerated.  Nasogastric tube is partially imaged.  Small
 amounts of secretions within the nasopharynx are noted.  No acute fracture is

 1.  No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage.

 IMPRESSION:

 No evidence of acute fracture or malalignment.  Extensive degenerative disc
 disease of the cervical spine, most pronounced at C5-C6 and C6-C7.  In the
 setting of high clinical suspicion for ligamentous or cord injury, MR may be
 considered for further assessment.
